snippet: He was just an honest farmer,'' said the widow of Zhang Huangli, speaking bitterly in her dirt-floor farmhouse about the death of her husband on Jan. 8.     On that day, here among the rice paddies and scraggly pine groves of Hunan Province,...
lead_paragraph: He was just an honest farmer,'' said the widow of Zhang Huangli, speaking bitterly in her dirt-floor farmhouse about the death of her husband on Jan. 8. On that day, here among the rice paddies and scraggly pine groves of Hunan Province, thousands of farmers -- more than 10,000, participants say -- streamed from the surrounding hills to the Government office in Daolin, a town of a few thousand. They came to demand an end to what they consider excessive taxes and corruption by the local Communist Party officials who rule over them.

keywords: MARQUEZ, ISABEL CRISTINA; ARMENIA (COLOMBIA); COLOMBIA; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; EARTHQUAKES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; COLOMBIAN-AMERICANS
headline: After Quake, a Sorrowful Journey to Colombia
section: Front Page; New York and Region
snippet: Standing on the threshold of the tiny blue house she calls home, Isabel Cristina Marquez, open-mouthed and wide-eyed, looks around, surveying the damage. ''We've lost our home,'' she quickly concludes and, softly, begins to cry.    Ms. Marquez, a...
lead_paragraph: Standing on the threshold of the tiny blue house she calls home, Isabel Cristina Marquez, open-mouthed and wide-eyed, looks around, surveying the damage. ''We've lost our home,'' she quickly concludes and, softly, begins to cry. Ms. Marquez, a 28-year-old waitress from Elmhurst, Queens, has been crying every day since Monday afternoon, when a powerful earthquake rocked this city. She was born here and lived here all her life before migrating to New York with her daughter two and a half years ago. Her parents and a brother had left earlier and live with her.

keywords: DENVER (COLO); DENVER BRONCOS; ATLANTA FALCONS; PARADES; SUPER BOWL; FOOTBALL
headline: The Broncos Get a Champion's Welcome
snippet: In a celebration of two straight Super Bowl victories, orange and blue plastic horse heads bobbed in a huge parade here, confirming that the Broncos, the sporty stallions of the National Football League, have trampled Denver's fusty image as a cow...
lead_paragraph: In a celebration of two straight Super Bowl victories, orange and blue plastic horse heads bobbed in a huge parade here, confirming that the Broncos, the sporty stallions of the National Football League, have trampled Denver's fusty image as a cow town. ''We are the champions, we are the champions,'' sang a joyous crowd, estimated at 375,000 people, that overflowed Civic Center Park. Hoping to persuade the team's quarterback, John Elway, to postpone retirement, some held up signs calling for a ''Three-peat'' and chanted, ''One more year, one more year.''

headline: World Briefing
snippet: AFRICA    GUINEA-BISSAU: THOUSANDS FLEE FIGHTING  Thousands of people scrambled to flee Bissau, the capital, as fighting intensified between loyalist and rebel forces, and the rebels announced ''a final assault'' on the city. At least 15 people were...
lead_paragraph: AFRICA GUINEA-BISSAU: THOUSANDS FLEE FIGHTING Thousands of people scrambled to flee Bissau, the capital, as fighting intensified between loyalist and rebel forces, and the rebels announced ''a final assault'' on the city. At least 15 people were reported killed. The fighting appeared to signal the end of an accord in November that halted a five-month civil war in the former Portuguese colony. (AP)

headline: World Briefing
snippet: EUROPE    ITALY: IMMIGRATION LAWS EASED -- The Government says it will modify its immigration laws to allow as many as 200,000 illegal aliens to obtain residency permits, leading to concern in other European countries that some of them might move in...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE ITALY: IMMIGRATION LAWS EASED -- The Government says it will modify its immigration laws to allow as many as 200,000 illegal aliens to obtain residency permits, leading to concern in other European countries that some of them might move in search of better jobs. Every year tens of thousands of Albanian, Kurdish and North African refugees come ashore on the Adriatic coast. Alessandra Stanley (NYT) GERMANY: A RIFT IN COALITION -- A major rift appeared in Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's coalition as Greens politicians refused to compromise on a plan to relax Germany's citizenship laws, an issue that contributed to an election defeat for the Social Democrats and Greens in Hesse state. Mr. Schroder, in turn, accused the Greens of pursuing too radical an agenda. The Greens insist that the new law retain provisions allowing dual citizenship. (Reuters)

keywords: COZMA, MIRON; ROMANIA; BUCHAREST (ROMANIA); MINES AND MINING; SENTENCES (CRIMINAL); COAL; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Romania Seizes Miners' Chief in Fierce Clash
snippet: The militant leader of Romania's coal miners was arrested today after clashes between riot policemen and miners that left one miner dead, dozens injured and more than 500 arrested.    The arrest of the leader, Miron Cozma, came as he and about 2,000...
lead_paragraph: The militant leader of Romania's coal miners was arrested today after clashes between riot policemen and miners that left one miner dead, dozens injured and more than 500 arrested. The arrest of the leader, Miron Cozma, came as he and about 2,000 miners headed toward the capital, Bucharest, to protest an 18-year prison sentence handed down against him in absentia for his role in a violent 1991 miners' protest.

keywords: GREENSPAN, ALAN; RUSSIA; LATIN AMERICA; FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS; CHINA; BRAZIL; SURVEYS AND SERIES; UNITED STATES ECONOMY; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: World Ills Are Obvious, the Cures Much Less So
snippet: Pigs to the left, pigs to the right, pigs all around him, Charles E. Burrus stood in the cacophonous center of his barn, gesturing at the indignant squealers. He felt like squealing, too.    ''I don't know what we're going to do in the next three...
lead_paragraph: Pigs to the left, pigs to the right, pigs all around him, Charles E. Burrus stood in the cacophonous center of his barn, gesturing at the indignant squealers. He felt like squealing, too. ''I don't know what we're going to do in the next three months,'' said Mr. Burrus, oblivious to the stench of the 7,000 animals around him. ''We're losing $10,000 to $15,000 a semi load.''

keywords: SHARIF, NAWAZ; VAJPAYEE, ATAL BEHARI; INDIA; PAKISTAN; KASHMIR AND JAMMU; ATOMIC WEAPONS; NUCLEAR TESTS; INDIA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-PAKISTAN; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: India Promises, With Pakistan, To Seek Peace
snippet: The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan pledged today to take immediate steps to reduce the risk of nuclear war and seek solutions to a half century of raging disputes, including their most volatile discord, the conflict in Kashmir.    Agreements...
lead_paragraph: The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan pledged today to take immediate steps to reduce the risk of nuclear war and seek solutions to a half century of raging disputes, including their most volatile discord, the conflict in Kashmir. Agreements between the world's newest nuclear powers were announced in two signed documents and a joint statement, all issued at the end of a historic weekend bus trip to Pakistan by Atal Behari Vajpayee, the first Indian Prime Minister to visit the country in 10 years.

keywords: ITALY; VIOLENCE; SOCCER; TEAR GAS
headline: Violence Erupts
snippet: A wave of violence swept Italy's minor league soccer stadiums yesterday, with spectators tossing rocks and police using tear gas to subdue fans.     One player is under investigation for attacking a police officer after a game, the ANSA news agency...
lead_paragraph: A wave of violence swept Italy's minor league soccer stadiums yesterday, with spectators tossing rocks and police using tear gas to subdue fans. One player is under investigation for attacking a police officer after a game, the ANSA news agency reported.

keywords: QUITO (ECUADOR); ECUADOR; LABOR; FINANCES; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES); STRIKES; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Ecuador Roads Blocked on Strike's First Day
snippet: Protesters blocked highways outside this capital today. In the city, the police repelled demonstrators with tear gas on the first day of a nationwide strike to protest higher prices and Government plans to cut spending.     Thousands of Indians...
lead_paragraph: Protesters blocked highways outside this capital today. In the city, the police repelled demonstrators with tear gas on the first day of a nationwide strike to protest higher prices and Government plans to cut spending. Thousands of Indians barricaded highways in 15 of the 22 provinces. Demonstrators hurled stones at the police and burned tires on the streets of Guayaquil, the main port, 170 miles southwest of Quito.

keywords: MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; KOSOVO (SERBIA); SERBIA; MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; MINORITIES (ETHNIC, RACIAL, RELIGIOUS); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Embassies Are Stoned As Tensions Begin to Rise
snippet: Giving vent to their rage over NATO bombings of their neighboring country, thousands of sympathizers with Serbia marched on the American Embassy here today, throwing rocks, setting embassy cars on fire and seeking to burn down the compound with...
lead_paragraph: Giving vent to their rage over NATO bombings of their neighboring country, thousands of sympathizers with Serbia marched on the American Embassy here today, throwing rocks, setting embassy cars on fire and seeking to burn down the compound with firebombs. There were also demonstrations and smashed windows outside the British and German Embassies. The riots were the most glaring sign yet of the mounting tension in the surrounding Balkan states after NATO's military action against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. Macedonia, the only republic to emerge relatively unscathed from the breakup of Yugoslavia, is a poor country with simmering ethnic rivalries of its own.

headline: World Briefing
snippet: EUROPE    RUSSIA: ANTI-SEMITISM INQUIRY PRESSED -- Russia's chief prosecutor, Yuri Skuratov, has ordered an investigation into anti-Semitic statements by Albert Makashov, a Communist lawmaker. Mr. Makashov virtually invited a group of Cossacks to...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE RUSSIA: ANTI-SEMITISM INQUIRY PRESSED -- Russia's chief prosecutor, Yuri Skuratov, has ordered an investigation into anti-Semitic statements by Albert Makashov, a Communist lawmaker. Mr. Makashov virtually invited a group of Cossacks to ransack Jewish homes during a speech in the southern town of Novocherkassk. He also said he was changing the name of his political movement to ''Movement Against the Yids.'' The regional prosecutor had refused to investigate the remarks. Michael R. Gordon (NYT)

keywords: CHINA; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: A Secretive Army Grows to Maintain Order in China
snippet: In late 1997, President Jiang Zemin announced that China would cut the People's Liberation Army, then three million strong, by half a million troops as part of China's drive for a leaner, more advanced military that could both defend the homeland and...
lead_paragraph: In late 1997, President Jiang Zemin announced that China would cut the People's Liberation Army, then three million strong, by half a million troops as part of China's drive for a leaner, more advanced military that could both defend the homeland and reinforce China's image as a power in Asia. What the President did not say was that as the army shrank, another, more secretive branch of the military, dedicated to internal stability, was already expanding. At the very time of Mr. Jiang's speech, it was absorbing 14 army divisions, or more than 100,000 troops.

keywords: CAPE TOWN (SOUTH AFRICA); SOUTH AFRICA; JOHANNESBURG (SOUTH AFRICA); PEOPLE AGAINST GANGSTERISM AND DRUGS; ATTACKS ON POLICE; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; VIGILANTES; ISLAM; POLICE; CRIME AND CRIMINALS; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC

snippet: The police intelligence document that Superintendent Wicus Holtzhausen plucks from his briefcase is a warning that he is on a hit list.     He was, it says, among those branded ''political criminals'' who ''should be eliminated'' whose names were...
lead_paragraph: The police intelligence document that Superintendent Wicus Holtzhausen plucks from his briefcase is a warning that he is on a hit list. He was, it says, among those branded ''political criminals'' who ''should be eliminated'' whose names were read out recently at the mosque where the Muslim group called People Against Gangsterism and Drugs was formed.

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); EUROPE; AUSTRALIA; SERBIA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Demonstrators In Many Cities Demand Halt To Air Strikes
snippet: Thousands of protesters took to the streets today in several cities in Europe, Australia and the United States to demand an end to NATO bombings in Yugoslavia.    One of the biggest demonstrations was in Vienna, where some 9,000 Serbs rallied on St....
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters took to the streets today in several cities in Europe, Australia and the United States to demand an end to NATO bombings in Yugoslavia. One of the biggest demonstrations was in Vienna, where some 9,000 Serbs rallied on St. Stephen's Square, according to the local police. In Paris, clashes broke out as the police fired tear gas at some 300 pro-Serbian demonstrators who threw bottles and rocks at the United States Embassy.

keywords: DIALLO, AMADOU; NEW YORK CITY; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Symbolism in Action
snippet: More than a thousand men and women have been arrested for protesting police misconduct and brutality in the case of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed immigrant who was killed outside his Bronx apartment a few weeks ago. Some critics, including Mayor Rudolph...
lead_paragraph: More than a thousand men and women have been arrested for protesting police misconduct and brutality in the case of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed immigrant who was killed outside his Bronx apartment a few weeks ago. Some critics, including Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, have ridiculed the daily demonstrations at New York's Police Headquarters as a publicity stunt. Hearing this brings to mind the white politicians who stood in our way in the 1960's, when we in the civil rights movement used sit-ins, freedom rides, mass meetings and marches as a form of protest in the South. At the time our tactics were questioned, too. But we knew we had to dramatize our opposition to segregation -- there was no other way to energize the larger community and mobilize wide-scale support for our cause.

keywords: CARTER, DEAN; CARTER, DIANE; SARZETAKIS, STEPHANOS; LOPATCONG (NJ); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; DOMESTIC VIOLENCE; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
headline: Police Officer Kills 2 And Commits Suicide
snippet: A Lopatcong police officer fatally shot his estranged wife at her workplace, then killed the owner of a nearby restaurant before killing himself yesterday, the police said.    Officer Dean Carter, 52, walked into a builder's office in Phillipsburg...
lead_paragraph: A Lopatcong police officer fatally shot his estranged wife at her workplace, then killed the owner of a nearby restaurant before killing himself yesterday, the police said. Officer Dean Carter, 52, walked into a builder's office in Phillipsburg where his estranged wife, Diane, worked, and shot her about 3:30 p.m. He then went to Stephano's Family Restaurant and shot Stephanos Sarzetakis, the restaurant owner, before killing himself.

keywords: HABIBIE, B J; BELO, CARLOS; LIQUICA (INDONESIA); EAST TIMOR; INDONESIA; INDEPENDENCE MOVEMENTS AND SECESSION
headline: Militiamen Backed by Indonesia Kill 25 in East Timor, Cleric Says
snippet: Militiamen who oppose independence for East Timor, backed by the Indonesian Army, killed at least 25 people on Tuesday, the region's Roman Catholic Bishop said today.    Saying he was ''ashamed to be an Indonesian,'' Bishop Carlos Belo condemned the...
lead_paragraph: Militiamen who oppose independence for East Timor, backed by the Indonesian Army, killed at least 25 people on Tuesday, the region's Roman Catholic Bishop said today. Saying he was ''ashamed to be an Indonesian,'' Bishop Carlos Belo condemned the violence in an emotional news conference held after inspecting a bloodied churchyard in Liquica where the killings took place.

headline: World Briefing
snippet: EUROPE    SPAIN: 11 NEW PINOCHET CHARGES -- Judge Baltasar Garzon, whose extradition request has kept Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 83, under arrest in London since October, has added 11 new charges of torture against the former Chilean dictator, bringing...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE SPAIN: 11 NEW PINOCHET CHARGES -- Judge Baltasar Garzon, whose extradition request has kept Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 83, under arrest in London since October, has added 11 new charges of torture against the former Chilean dictator, bringing the total to 51 from the period beginning in 1988. England's Law Lords have ruled that the decision on whether to proceed with the extradition case can be based only on crimes that are alleged to have taken place after 1988. Al Goodman (NYT) SPAIN: FRANCO'S TOMB BOMBED -- A bomb damaged the basilica in the enormous Valley of the Fallen tomb where Generalissimo Francisco Franco is buried, 30 miles northwest of Madrid. The police said a small Marxist guerrilla group called October First Anti-Fascist Resistance Group claimed responsibility for the blast. The tomb opened 40 years ago this month, and was built by political prisoners of Franco's dictatorship. Al Goodman (NYT)

keywords: ANWAR IBRAHIM; KUALA LUMPUR (MALAYSIA); MALAYSIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Guilty Verdict for Ex-Official in Malaysia Sets Off Noisy Protests
snippet: Anti-Government riots erupted in the heart of this orderly city today after Anwar Ibrahim, the ousted Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, was found guilty of corruption and given an unexpectedly harsh sentence of six years in prison.    Declaring that...
lead_paragraph: Anti-Government riots erupted in the heart of this orderly city today after Anwar Ibrahim, the ousted Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, was found guilty of corruption and given an unexpectedly harsh sentence of six years in prison. Declaring that his conduct ''strikes at the very core of the administrative system,'' Judge Augustine Paul found Mr. Anwar guilty of all four charges that he abused his power as Malaysia's No. 2 official. He refused to give Mr. Anwar credit for the time he has served in jail since his arrest last September.

keywords: CLINTON, BILL; KOSOVO (SERBIA); SERBIA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: U.S. Officials Suspect Deadly Chemical Weapons in Yugoslav Army Arsenal
snippet: The United States believes that the Yugoslav army has stocks of lethal and nonlethal chemical weapons and that some of the less deadly forms have probably been given to the Serbian paramilitary forces that have terrorized Albanians in Kosovo,...
lead_paragraph: The United States believes that the Yugoslav army has stocks of lethal and nonlethal chemical weapons and that some of the less deadly forms have probably been given to the Serbian paramilitary forces that have terrorized Albanians in Kosovo, according to Pentagon and other Clinton Administration officials. Pentagon officials said yesterday that the Administration had no evidence that the Yugoslav army or the Serbian forces had used, or were planning to use lethal chemical agents against either the ethnic Albanians they have been driving out of Kosovo or the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army, which has been battling Yugoslav forces in the Serbian province.

keywords: PEOPLE'S PARK (BERKELEY, CALIF); VIETNAM; UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA; VIETNAM WAR; UNITED STATES POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; PARKS AND OTHER RECREATION AREAS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: A Landmark of the 60's Defies Transformation
snippet: On days when the sun looks kindly on it, People's Park can seem like a quaint little town.    The people who live nowhere in particular picnic on the east end, on benches in a grove. A smattering of bodies flop on the uncombed lawn. Community...
lead_paragraph: On days when the sun looks kindly on it, People's Park can seem like a quaint little town. The people who live nowhere in particular picnic on the east end, on benches in a grove. A smattering of bodies flop on the uncombed lawn. Community gardeners tend their patches on the west end, and the few nearby drug addicts are camouflaged by shrubs, easily overlooked.

keywords: JAMAICA (WEST INDIES); KINGSTON (JAMAICA); TAXATION; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Protests Over Rise in Fuel Tax Disrupt Streets in Jamaica
snippet: Jamaicans blocked main roads with barricades of burning tires and furniture today, defying the police, who fired warning shots and tear gas. At least six people were reported killed.    Violent protests have swept the island since the Government...
lead_paragraph: Jamaicans blocked main roads with barricades of burning tires and furniture today, defying the police, who fired warning shots and tear gas. At least six people were reported killed. Violent protests have swept the island since the Government announced $100 million in new taxes on Friday. The unrest prompted several airlines and three cruise ships to cancel trips to Jamaica today.

keywords: DJUKANOVIC, MILO; MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; GELBARD, ROBERT S; KOSOVO (SERBIA); SERBIA; MONTENEGRO; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: Playing Chicken With Milosevic
snippet: Until Milo Djukanovic's new best friends in the United States and Western Europe began to drop bombs on Montenegro in late March, life had been going along swimmingly for the handsome young President of this Yugoslav republic.     Just 37 years old,...
lead_paragraph: Until Milo Djukanovic's new best friends in the United States and Western Europe began to drop bombs on Montenegro in late March, life had been going along swimmingly for the handsome young President of this Yugoslav republic. Just 37 years old, built like an N.F.L. linebacker, packaged in dark Italian suits, married to an attractive blonde and hailed by voters as Milo the Blade, Djukanovic (djew-KAHN-oh-vich) has been playing a deliciously wicked game of chicken with the Serbian dictator Slobodan Milosevic. Before bombs and cruise missiles began to rain on Yugoslavia, the Montenegrin President even seemed to be winning.

keywords: NEW YORK TIMES; NEWSPAPERS; ADVERTISING; SMOKING AND TOBACCO
headline: The New York Times Bans Cigarette Ads
snippet: Joining a small group of newspapers, The New York Times will ban cigarette advertising in its pages, effective Saturday.    The newspaper decided to impose the ban because of concerns about the harmful effects of cigarette smoking, said Nancy...
lead_paragraph: Joining a small group of newspapers, The New York Times will ban cigarette advertising in its pages, effective Saturday. The newspaper decided to impose the ban because of concerns about the harmful effects of cigarette smoking, said Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The New York Times Company.

headline: Critic of Flawed CNN Report Is Named as a Source for It
snippet: A retired military officer who has been a leading critic of CNN's repudiated broadcast on the use of nerve gas against defectors in the Vietnam War was named yesterday as one of the confidential sources for the broadcast.    The officer, Maj. Gen....
lead_paragraph: A retired military officer who has been a leading critic of CNN's repudiated broadcast on the use of nerve gas against defectors in the Vietnam War was named yesterday as one of the confidential sources for the broadcast. The officer, Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, who in the late 1960's commanded a special forces unit in Vietnam, was identified as someone who had confirmed the charges contained in the broadcast in a lawsuit filed against him yesterday by April Oliver, the lead producer of the discredited report on a Vietnam mission known as Operation Tailwind.

keywords: BANZER, HUGO; COLOMBIA; BOLIVIA; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; COCAINE AND CRACK COCAINE; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC
headline: Bolivia, at Risk of Some Unrest, Is Making Big Gains in Eradicating Coca
snippet: Ever since drought drove his family from a rocky cornfield high in the Andes 15 years ago, Espinosa Leon has been chopping down tropical rain forest to grow coca bushes, which  produce cocaine. Now, at 38, Mr. Leon finds himself at another...
lead_paragraph: Ever since drought drove his family from a rocky cornfield high in the Andes 15 years ago, Espinosa Leon has been chopping down tropical rain forest to grow coca bushes, which produce cocaine. Now, at 38, Mr. Leon finds himself at another crossroads. ''The army is coming any day to destroy my last coca,'' said Mr. Leon, who had already slashed three-quarters of his crop in recent months in exchange for aid from United Nations technicians forming a forestry project here. ''I don't have to like it, but coca has no future.''

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); BELGRADE (SERBIA); SERBIA; CHINA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; CHINA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; FOREIGN SERVICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: CHINA PROTESTERS RAGE AT AMERICA
snippet: Large, angry protests erupted around American Government offices in several cities after Chinese learned that NATO bombs had hit their embassy in Belgrade, killing at least three people sleeping inside. By this morning, the demonstration had left a...
lead_paragraph: Large, angry protests erupted around American Government offices in several cities after Chinese learned that NATO bombs had hit their embassy in Belgrade, killing at least three people sleeping inside. By this morning, the demonstration had left a consulate in flames and the embassy here in a state of siege with most of its windows broken by rocks. In Chengdu, in western China, several thousand protesters threw rocks and bottle-rockets, setting a consulate building on fire. The police used tear gas to disperse the crowd, said an embassy spokesman here.

headline: Sports of The Times; Tax Is Funny Money For Wealthy Owners
snippet: BERNIE WILLIAMS thought he was back in the 60's. That's what the Yankee center fielder said in Kansas City on April 30 when 2,000 fans staged a polite little protest at the ball park.    Big deal. Nobody occupied the infield, trying to turn it into a...
lead_paragraph: BERNIE WILLIAMS thought he was back in the 60's. That's what the Yankee center fielder said in Kansas City on April 30 when 2,000 fans staged a polite little protest at the ball park. Big deal. Nobody occupied the infield, trying to turn it into a People's Park. No fans chained themselves to first base. No tear gas. No billy clubs. No arrests. Call that a protest? Call that the 60's?

keywords: VIETNAM; STANFORD UNIVERSITY; VIETNAM WAR; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Editorial Observer; Days of Protest and Remembrance at Stanford
snippet: Stanford University is tranquil this spring, graced by the brilliant sunshine and eucalyptus fragrance that help give the campus its distinctive California accent. Long gone are the sights and sounds of my undergraduate days three decades ago --...
lead_paragraph: Stanford University is tranquil this spring, graced by the brilliant sunshine and eucalyptus fragrance that help give the campus its distinctive California accent. Long gone are the sights and sounds of my undergraduate days three decades ago -- windows shattering in the night, tear-gas canisters exploding, the president's office in flames. So it was with considerable curiosity that I returned to campus last weekend to attend a reunion of the anti-war movement that did so much to transform Stanford into a political battleground in the late 1960's. What, I wondered, had become of the students who spent their college years resisting the war in Vietnam and Stanford's links to it? What, if any, vestiges of the movement could be found on campus today?

keywords: FLORENCE (ITALY); SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Twenty Injured In Riot in Florence
snippet: At least 20 people were injured, and one was reported in serious condition with stab wounds, following clashes between rival fans at the end of yesterday's Fiorentina-Lazio league game in Florence, police reported.     A Florentine man, stabbed in...
lead_paragraph: At least 20 people were injured, and one was reported in serious condition with stab wounds, following clashes between rival fans at the end of yesterday's Fiorentina-Lazio league game in Florence, police reported. A Florentine man, stabbed in the abdomen, was hospitalized to undergo surgery. Others, hit and bruised by bottles or rocks thrown by rival supporters, were treated in local hospitals and released.

keywords: HABIBIE, B J; SUHARTO; JAKARTA (INDONESIA); INDONESIA; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Indonesian Students Agitate for Suharto Trial
snippet: Students threw rocks today and demanded that former President Suharto be tried on charges of corruption as they marched on Parliament on the first anniversary of Mr. Suharto's resignation.    The police fired warning shots and tear gas at 2,000...
lead_paragraph: Students threw rocks today and demanded that former President Suharto be tried on charges of corruption as they marched on Parliament on the first anniversary of Mr. Suharto's resignation. The police fired warning shots and tear gas at 2,000 protesters in a scene reminiscent of the demonstrations and riots that drove Mr. Suharto from office after 30 years.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-7    Clinton Pushes for Troops Along Kosovo Border  The Clinton Administration announced that the United States would press its allies to move quickly to deploy what was described as a peacekeeping force of about 50,000 troops on...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Clinton Pushes for Troops Along Kosovo Border The Clinton Administration announced that the United States would press its allies to move quickly to deploy what was described as a peacekeeping force of about 50,000 troops on the borders of Kosovo. A1 Yugoslavia insisted that it play a central role in negotiations within the United Nations to end the war and provide a political settlement to Kosovo. A7 Rebels fighting for Kosovo's independence claim to have killed a Russian captain in a battle with Serbian troops inside Kosovo, in a development that could complicate Russia's role in the Kosovo crisis. A7 NATO warplanes assigned to attack a military compound in northwestern Kosovo struck what Yugoslavia's official news agency described as a nearby prison, killing at least 19 inmates and guards. A7 Smallpox Elimination Delayed A World Health Organization panel in Geneva effectively decided to postpone eradicating the world's known remaining stocks of the smallpox virus until at least 2002. The recommendation reflected widespread agreement that more time is needed to study smallpox before it is irrevocably destroyed. A3 Indonesian Students Protest Students protested and demanded that former President Suharto be tried on charges of corruption as they marched on Parliament on the first anniversary of Mr. Suharto's resignation. The police fired warning shots and tear gas at 2,000 protesters in a scene reminiscent of the riots that drove Mr. Suharto from office after 30 years. A3 New Bombing Suspect The United States Government has taken another suspect into custody in the continuing investigation of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile charged in the bombings of two United States embassies in Africa last year. The suspect, Ihab M. Ali, was charged with perjury on Wednesday after he came to New York City. A4 Germany's Immigration Law Germany adopted an immigration law that will make it easier for many of the country's seven million residents of foreign origin to become citizens. The legislation will go into effect on Jan. 1. A3 World Briefing A4 NATIONAL A8-11, 14 House Democrats Seek Early Vote on Gun Bill House Democrats called for a gun-control vote within the next week, in a move to build on the momentum of the Senate's juvenile crime bill that includes firearms measures. A1 A handful of provisions in the Senate bill may do as much or more to curb the flow of illegal guns than the much debated measures that require child safety locks and background checks at gun shows. A10 Today's graduation at Columbine High School will be broadcast by CNN. The community finds itself struggling with the massacre and with how to reclaim its privacy. A8 Investigators are planning to labor through the summer to determine if any friends of the gunmen in the Columbine school shootings aided them or knew of the attack beforehand. A8 The youth who shot and wounded six students at a school in Conyers, Ga., sat in a juvenile detention center for a second day as investigators continued to search his family's home for clues to his motivation. A8 Fund-Raiser Pleads Guilty Yah Lin Trie, a Democratic fund-raiser and friend of President Clinton, pleaded guilty to two political fund-raising charges and agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department's campaign finance inquiry. A1 A note the Justice Department has obtained from Mr. Trie's Little Rock office suggests he was aware of a bribery problem. A9 Ruling on Medical Marijuana The Administration announced that it would sell Government-grown marijuana to privately financed scientists for research into whether marijuana can help sick people. A11 Reduced Penalty Sought Lawyers for President Clinton asserted in court that he should pay no more than $33,737 in reimbursements to lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual harassment lawsuit against Mr. Clinton. The Jones lawyers want $500,000. A14 Genome Project on Schedule The publicly financed effort to decode the human genome is on track to meet its goal of finishing a draft of the genome in a year. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Plea Deal Rejected In Police Brutality Case Prosecutors have refused a plea deal sought by the police officer charged with torturing Abner Louima, according to people close to the case. They said that the offer was made and rejected the day after a police sergeant testified that the officer, Justin A. Volpe, had boasted to him that he had committed the torture. A1 Clintons Eye New York Vacation Hillary Rodham Clinton is edging closer to running for the Senate from New York, and the Clintons' choice of summer vacation spot is once again affected by politics. The First Couple are exploring the recreational options across the Empire State. A1 Lucci Wins an Emmy Susan Lucci won the Daytime Emmy award for best actress. The hard-luck soap star, who had been nominated 18 times, was honored for her portrayal of Erica Kane on ''All My Children.'' B4 Religious Rights Violated A Westchester County school district violated its students' First Amendment rights to religious freedom by allowing schools to engage in religious-oriented activities, including the construction of a Hindu god's likeness and New Age prayer recitals at an Earth Day celebration, a Federal judge ruled. B1 Plan to Block Pay Fails A law withholding legislators' pay until a budget is passed is unconstitutional, a Brooklyn judge ruled. The ruling was a blow to an attempt to speed the state's notoriously lethargic budget process. B1 Study on Gambling A commission appointed by President Clinton and Congress is expected to recommend in June that state lotteries curtail advertising in economically distressed communities and contribute to research and treatment for problem gambling. Case, chairman of America Online, as part the company's preparations for the rebuttal phase of the antitrust trial against the software giant. headline: Palestinians' 'Day of Rage' Is Punctuated by Calm
snippet: Hundreds of Palestinians marched down a hilltop here today, trampling though rocks and bramble toward a neighboring, and expanding, Jewish settlement.     Adults waved protest banners and youths swung slingshots loaded with rocks. They hiked...
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Palestinians marched down a hilltop here today, trampling though rocks and bramble toward a neighboring, and expanding, Jewish settlement. Adults waved protest banners and youths swung slingshots loaded with rocks. They hiked determinedly toward a line of Israeli soldiers waiting with guns beside a rough road newly plowed by the settlers through the Palestinians' olive fields.

headline: World Briefing
snippet: ASIA    KOREAS: CONFRONTATION AT SEA -- South Korea said today its patrol ships tried to push North Korean ships out of the South's territorial waters as a standoff in the Yellow Sea entered its fifth day. YTN television reported that South Korean...
lead_paragraph: ASIA KOREAS: CONFRONTATION AT SEA -- South Korea said today its patrol ships tried to push North Korean ships out of the South's territorial waters as a standoff in the Yellow Sea entered its fifth day. YTN television reported that South Korean ships had pushed several ships back into North Korean waters. North Korean warships have been sailing into a disputed South Korean buffer zone apparently to protect fishing boats, ministry officials said. North Korea maintains that South Korea is intruding in its waters. (Reuters) KASHMIR: INDIA CONTINUES ATTACKS -- Indian troops continued to shell Islamic militants in Kashmir as India and Pakistan prepared for talks on the issue in New Delhi on Saturday. Voicing concern about the conflict, leading industrial nations urged both countries to sign the international treaty banning nuclear testing. India has been fighting to evict what it says are Pakistan-backed Afghan mercenaries and Pakistani troops from the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir. Pakistan denies its soldiers are involved. (AP)

keywords: PIRATES OF SILICON VALLEY (TV PROGRAM); JOBS, STEVEN P; TELEVISION; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET
headline: Just Wild And Crazy Geeks
snippet: THE way TNT's film ''Pirates of Silicon Valley'' tells it, the story of the computer revolution as we know it begins with Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak running in slow motion through tear gas during a student protest on the Berkeley campus in 1971. Of...
lead_paragraph: THE way TNT's film ''Pirates of Silicon Valley'' tells it, the story of the computer revolution as we know it begins with Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak running in slow motion through tear gas during a student protest on the Berkeley campus in 1971. Of course, a chronology that TNT has sent out with publicity releases about the film notes that Mr. Job and Mr. Wozniak didn't meet until 1973, when they were both employees of Hewlett-Packard. But then the film doesn't claim to be a documentary -- or even a docudrama. In it, the real-life events and real characters involved in the early days of the computer age are given the star treatment (as heroes or villains, depending on your perspective). The script also goes beyond the office wars and gets personal about its subjects.

headline: China Arrests 2 Leaders of Farmers' Protest
snippet: Five months after riot policemen violently dispersed a huge demonstration by angry farmers in the southern province of Hunan, two of the farmers' leaders have been arrested and charged with serious crimes.     The two leaders, Yang Yaojin and Hu...
lead_paragraph: Five months after riot policemen violently dispersed a huge demonstration by angry farmers in the southern province of Hunan, two of the farmers' leaders have been arrested and charged with serious crimes. The two leaders, Yang Yaojin and Hu Zhiping, had been fugitives since the demonstration in Daolin township on Jan. 8. On that day, thousands of villagers gathered to condemn what they said were illegal taxes and corruption on the part of local Communist Party officials.

lead_paragraph: Gunmen demanding jobs seized an orphanage run by former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide today, holding it for more than 12 hours before surrendering. snippet: As a paramedic on the Jefferson County disaster response team, Rick Robbins is typically called on to handle chemical spills and rescues. He has never encountered CS, a powerful kind of tear gas, on the job.    ''And I don't want to, either,'' said...
lead_paragraph: As a paramedic on the Jefferson County disaster response team, Rick Robbins is typically called on to handle chemical spills and rescues. He has never encountered CS, a powerful kind of tear gas, on the job. ''And I don't want to, either,'' said Mr. Robbins as he and a handful of his comrades were trained by a Federal expert in how to use a sampling kit to detect the tear gas and other poisons that can be spread through the air.

keywords: YESHITELA, OMALI; ST PETERSBURG (FLA); CITY COUNCILS; BLACKS
headline: Effort to Heal Old Racial Wounds Brings New Discord
snippet: The painting had hung in St. Petersburg City Hall all of Joe Waller's life, an eight-foot-long racial caricature that showed black people happily entertaining white picnickers. Every time Mr. Waller, a young black man,  saw it, anger and humiliation...
lead_paragraph: The painting had hung in St. Petersburg City Hall all of Joe Waller's life, an eight-foot-long racial caricature that showed black people happily entertaining white picnickers. Every time Mr. Waller, a young black man, saw it, anger and humiliation scorched him deep inside. In December 1966, he tore it down. With police officers in pursuit, he ran through St. Petersburg's downtown, the ripped painting flapping in his clenched fists like the captured flag of some oppressive government. To him, it was.

keywords: HUTTO, LEONARD; CONGO (FORMERLY ZAIRE); ANGOLA; NIGERIA; CHEVRON CORP; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE
headline: Deep in The Republic Of Chevron
snippet: The delta region of southern Nigeria, where the mighty Niger River drains into the Atlantic Ocean, includes some of the most inhospitable territory on earth. It's the world's largest mangrove swamp, 14,000 square miles of thickets, channels and...
lead_paragraph: The delta region of southern Nigeria, where the mighty Niger River drains into the Atlantic Ocean, includes some of the most inhospitable territory on earth. It's the world's largest mangrove swamp, 14,000 square miles of thickets, channels and lagoons all but impenetrable to any but the most practiced eye. It's also oil country, dotted with wells and flow stations, where about two million barrels of crude are collected each day and piped to central stations for transport abroad. Helicopter is the preferred mode of transport, for the lucky few who can afford it. One of those is Leonard Hutto, the superintendent of Chevron's operations in the eastern Niger Delta, and on this day it was his chopper that hovered tentatively above one of Chevron's 30-odd oil stations in the area. The landing pad, a few hundred feet below, was thronged with hundreds of angry young Nigerians peering up at the midmorning sky, clearly shouting and shaking their fists. Seeing that they did not have guns, Hutto finally told the pilot to land.

headline: World Briefing
snippet: THE AMERICAS    COLOMBIA: REBEL LEADERS INDICTED -- After formal peace talks that were to begin on Wednesday were delayed for two weeks, prosecutors indicted the seven leaders and five lower-ranking commanders of the nation's largest guerrilla...
lead_paragraph: THE AMERICAS COLOMBIA: REBEL LEADERS INDICTED -- After formal peace talks that were to begin on Wednesday were delayed for two weeks, prosecutors indicted the seven leaders and five lower-ranking commanders of the nation's largest guerrilla faction, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia on charges of homicide and kidnapping in a 1996 attack on an army base. To avoid affecting the peace talks, prosecutors suspended arrest orders against negotiators who were indicted. (AP)

headline: Trouble in the Backyard
snippet: More quickly than the political opponents of Slobodan Milosevic had dared hope, grass-roots dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav President is surfacing across much of Serbia.     Hostility toward Mr. Milosevic, bubbling up this week on the streets of...
lead_paragraph: More quickly than the political opponents of Slobodan Milosevic had dared hope, grass-roots dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav President is surfacing across much of Serbia. Hostility toward Mr. Milosevic, bubbling up this week on the streets of the most unlikely of towns, has raised expectations among opposition politicians that Mr. Milosevic's survival in power might now be measured not in years, but in months.

snippet: Iranian students were in a tense stand-off with security forces tonight after protests against curbs on press freedoms led to violent clashes, for which the Higher Education Ministry quickly blamed the police.    The students, hunkered down in...
lead_paragraph: Iranian students were in a tense stand-off with security forces tonight after protests against curbs on press freedoms led to violent clashes, for which the Higher Education Ministry quickly blamed the police. The students, hunkered down in Teheran University dormitories surrounded by hundreds of riot policemen and stick-wielding Islamic militants, demanded a personal visit from President Mohammad Khatami to resolve the dispute.

keywords: FREEDOM OF THE CITY, THE (PLAY); FRIEL, BRIAN; REVIEWS; LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL; THEATER
headline: They Sought Change and Found Death
snippet: It has been almost 30 years now since a night of deadly rioting in Belfast prompted Britain to send in army troops to try to restore order in Northern Ireland. Since then at least 3,200 people, many of whom were simply caught in the crossfire, have...
lead_paragraph: It has been almost 30 years now since a night of deadly rioting in Belfast prompted Britain to send in army troops to try to restore order in Northern Ireland. Since then at least 3,200 people, many of whom were simply caught in the crossfire, have been killed. In ''The Freedom of the City,'' whose evocative revival is being presented as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99, the Irish playwright Brian Friel tells the fictional story of three of them. The conflict known as ''the Troubles'' has provided at least a subtext for much of Irish literature, especially that written for the stage, over the last three decades. In Mr. Friel's ''Aristocrats,'' which is also being staged by the Gate Theater during the festival, and in ''Translations,'' the plight of a people at the mercy of powers beyond their control runs between the lines. But in ''The Freedom of the City,'' which concerns three ordinary protest marchers who accidentally occupy Derry's Guildhall and end up being gunned down as ''terrorists,'' Mr. Friel openly addresses the strife that at the time of its writing had just come to full boil.

keywords: FARMER, JAMES; BLACKS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: James Farmer, Civil Rights Giant In the 50's and 60's, Is Dead at 79
snippet: James Farmer, a principal founder of the Congress of Racial Equality and the last survivor of the ''Big Four'' who shaped the civil-rights struggle in the United States in the mid-1950's and 60's, died yesterday at Mary Washington Hospital, in...
lead_paragraph: James Farmer, a principal founder of the Congress of Racial Equality and the last survivor of the ''Big Four'' who shaped the civil-rights struggle in the United States in the mid-1950's and 60's, died yesterday at Mary Washington Hospital, in Fredericksburg, Va., where he lived. He was 79. Mr. Farmer had been in failing health for years, losing his sight and both his legs to severe diabetes.

keywords: MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; BELGRADE (SERBIA); SERBIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
headline: Belgrade's Bitter People Shun Protests for Now
snippet: During his 12 years in power, whenever Slobodan Milosevic has been on the ropes, most of the punches have been thrown here in the Serbian capital.     This is where the Serbian leader called out Yugoslav Army tanks and used tear gas eight years ago...
lead_paragraph: During his 12 years in power, whenever Slobodan Milosevic has been on the ropes, most of the punches have been thrown here in the Serbian capital. This is where the Serbian leader called out Yugoslav Army tanks and used tear gas eight years ago to put down a violent demonstration against state-controlled television, the key lever in his control of public opinion. It was here that the depth of urban middle-class revulsion with Mr. Milosevic's rule was shown to the world in three solid months of daily street demonstrations in the winter of 1996-97.

snippet: A day after a violent police raid on a Teheran University dormitory, more than 10,000 students demonstrated here and in other Iranian cities today, chanting slogans against Government hard-liners and clashing at times with the police.     The...
lead_paragraph: A day after a violent police raid on a Teheran University dormitory, more than 10,000 students demonstrated here and in other Iranian cities today, chanting slogans against Government hard-liners and clashing at times with the police. The eruption of student anger, set off by a police crackdown on Friday that left at least 20 people hospitalized and 125 students jailed, rippled through the top levels of the Iranian Government today.

lead_paragraph: The most widespread and sustained protests since Iran's revolution two decades ago spread throughout the country today, while security police and their vigilante supporters moved to crush pro-democracy student demonstrators outside Teheran University. Students demonstrated in 18 cities and towns, including major cosmopolitan cities like Tabriz, Shiraz and Isfahan and more traditional cities like Meshed and Yazd, Iran's official press agency reported.

lead_paragraph: In scenes eerily reminiscent of Iran's revolution two decades ago, the police fired tear gas today at thousands of demonstrators and passers-by and shot pistols and submachine guns in the air as street battles raged through huge swaths of the capital. The chaos and violence closed hundreds of stores, banks, gas stations, shopping centers and office buildings and finally, extraordinarily, even the vast bazaar in the south of Teheran.

keywords: KHATAMI, MOHAMMAD; IRAN; EDITORIALS; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Fateful Moment in Iran
snippet: The stifling Islamic dictatorship in Iran has never been a comfortable fit for a complex, youthful nation of nearly 70 million people. Now, thousands of students and other protesters in Teheran and other cities have taken to the streets to challenge...
lead_paragraph: The stifling Islamic dictatorship in Iran has never been a comfortable fit for a complex, youthful nation of nearly 70 million people. Now, thousands of students and other protesters in Teheran and other cities have taken to the streets to challenge the power of the fundamentalist ayatollahs. They have been greeted by violent repression. The clerics who control the security forces are in danger of misreading their nation as badly as the Shah did two decades ago if they think they can prevent change with tear gas, bullets and vigilantes. The student protesters are invoking the more democratic and liberal values espoused by President Mohammad Khatami and backed by a substantial majority of Iranians, particularly young people and women. In the long run, these more humane values are likely to prevail. Nearly two-thirds of Iranians are now under the age of 25. But the immediate course of events will depend on whether the clerical authorities led by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei understand that they must relax their stranglehold on Iranian society.

keywords: IRAN; TEHERAN (IRAN); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; IRAN-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US
headline: Turning Tables In Iran, Crowds Back Old Line
snippet: After six days of nationwide pro-democracy protests that deteriorated into violent rioting, huge crowds staged counterdemonstrations today in at least two dozen cities and towns, heeding the official call to praise the Islamic Republic and condemn...
lead_paragraph: After six days of nationwide pro-democracy protests that deteriorated into violent rioting, huge crowds staged counterdemonstrations today in at least two dozen cities and towns, heeding the official call to praise the Islamic Republic and condemn its enemies, particularly the United States. Calm returned to the capital as Teheran residents obeyed official warnings that the Government would use all necessary means to restore order. There were no signs of pro-democracy demonstrators or baton-wielding vigilantes, no smells of tear gas or bonfire smoke, no sounds of gunfire or ambulance sirens.

snippet: For the young men on the streets of this dusty, crowded, unexceptional town south of Teheran, the nationwide unrest of the last week is little more than a remote spectacle on the nightly news.    Unlike the students at Teheran University whose...
lead_paragraph: For the young men on the streets of this dusty, crowded, unexceptional town south of Teheran, the nationwide unrest of the last week is little more than a remote spectacle on the nightly news. Unlike the students at Teheran University whose demonstrations a week ago set off violent riots, these young men seem ill-informed about the closing of a newspaper and a harsh new press law.

keywords: IRAN; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: The World: Shadow Drama in Iran; For Once, the Veil That Hides Conflict Slips
snippet: THINGS are not always what they seem in this country of high walls and black veils. Invasions, occupations, foreign meddling and arbitrary rule over the centuries have have made politics a dangerous game, and Iranians have learned some survival...
lead_paragraph: THINGS are not always what they seem in this country of high walls and black veils. Invasions, occupations, foreign meddling and arbitrary rule over the centuries have have made politics a dangerous game, and Iranians have learned some survival strategies: improvisation, role-playing and even deception. So it was natural that the unrest last week in Iran, the worst since the early days of its 1979 revolution, produced images that sometimes betrayed reality: There were students who didn't look like students, policemen who didn't look like policemen, true believers who weren't really true believers.

keywords: CIUDAD JUAREZ (MEXICO); MEXICO; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Riot in Mexican Prison Leaves 79 Injured
snippet: Hundreds of law enforcement officers stormed a prison in this border city today to quell a violent riot by inmates that left as many as 79 people injured, including 20 authorities, the government news agency and local media reported.    The police...
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of law enforcement officers stormed a prison in this border city today to quell a violent riot by inmates that left as many as 79 people injured, including 20 authorities, the government news agency and local media reported. The police launched several canisters of tear gas into the prison and exchanged gunfire with inmates, who were rioting after the new prison warden reduced family visitations from six hours to two hours, a city official, Javier de Anda, was quoted by the government news agency, Notimex, as saying.

keywords: JOHNSON, FRANK MINIS JR; JUDGES; FEDERAL DISTRICT COURTS; COURTS; BLACKS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CIVIL RIGHTS; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Frank M. Johnson Jr., Judge Whose Rulings Helped Desegregate the South, Dies at 80
snippet: Frank M. Johnson Jr., the legendary Federal jurist from Alabama whose historic civil rights decisions led to ostracism, cross-burnings and death threats but helped to change the face of the segregationist South in the 1950's and 1960's, died...
lead_paragraph: Frank M. Johnson Jr., the legendary Federal jurist from Alabama whose historic civil rights decisions led to ostracism, cross-burnings and death threats but helped to change the face of the segregationist South in the 1950's and 1960's, died yesterday. He was 80. Judge Johnson fell last week and was hospitalized in Montgomery, Ala., but had returned home. He developed pneumonia, and died at home, said Wayne Greenhaw, a former reporter and a friend of the family. Burial will be on Tuesday in Haleyville, Ala.

keywords: BERKELEY BAR AND GRILL; REVIEWS; RESTAURANTS
headline: A Berkeley for the Prosperous 90's
snippet: BERKELEY, 1969. Tear gas. Jefferson Airplane. People's Park. Black Panthers. Gluey brown rice with chunks of unpeeled carrots and potatoes.    Like an acid flashback, precious memories surge to the forward area of the brain at Berkeley Bar and Grill,...
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, 1969. Tear gas. Jefferson Airplane. People's Park. Black Panthers. Gluey brown rice with chunks of unpeeled carrots and potatoes. Like an acid flashback, precious memories surge to the forward area of the brain at Berkeley Bar and Grill, where the curtains are tie-dyed, the soundtrack is heavy on Janis and Jimi, and Walter Cronkite broadcasts urgent news from the late 1960's in the bathrooms. For diners of a certain age, being confronted with these cultural artifacts is a sobering experience. I for one can now understand a little better the feelings of an American Indian looking at a birch bark canoe in the Museum of Natural History.

keywords: HARTFORD (CONN); MATTHEWS, DAVE, BAND; MEADOWS MUSIC THEATER; MUSIC; ATTACKS ON POLICE; VIOLENCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Rocks and Bottles Thrown at Police Outside Hartford Concert
snippet: Violence erupted outside the Meadows Music Theater during a Dave Matthews Band concert tonight as police officers in riot gear battled through a barrage of rocks and bottles being tossed at them in the theater's parking lot.    Sgt. Ed Pawlina of the...
lead_paragraph: Violence erupted outside the Meadows Music Theater during a Dave Matthews Band concert tonight as police officers in riot gear battled through a barrage of rocks and bottles being tossed at them in the theater's parking lot. Sgt. Ed Pawlina of the Hartford Police said there were no problems inside the theater, but the police had to contend with ''a heavy barrage'' of rocks and bottles in parking lots surrounding the theater. He said the situation was ''out of control'' at 9:15 P.M., and that more than a dozen arrests had been made at that point. The charges included assault on an officer, rioting and property damage, he said.

keywords: SOUTH KOREA; NORTH KOREA; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NORTH KOREA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-SOUTH KOREA
headline: Seoul Police Block March to the North
snippet: Armed with tear-gas launchers and water cannons, riot police officers blocked thousands of leftist students from marching to the border with North Korea today to promote national unification.    The confrontation occurred after a rally at Seoul...
lead_paragraph: Armed with tear-gas launchers and water cannons, riot police officers blocked thousands of leftist students from marching to the border with North Korea today to promote national unification. The confrontation occurred after a rally at Seoul National University that was one of the largest in recent years and called to mark the 54th anniversary of the liberation of Korea from Japan's colonial rule. Government officials expressed concern that the leftist student movement, which has waned in recent years, may be gathering momentum.

keywords: COULSON, DANNY; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; GRENADES
headline: National News Briefs; Former Official Disputes F.B.I. Account of Raid
snippet: Contradicting years of denial from the Federal Government, a former F.B.I. official says agents fired two pyrotechnic tear gas grenades into the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., the day it erupted in a deadly inferno.    But the former...
lead_paragraph: Contradicting years of denial from the Federal Government, a former F.B.I. official says agents fired two pyrotechnic tear gas grenades into the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., the day it erupted in a deadly inferno. But the former official, Danny Coulson, said the devices were fired hours before the blaze began on April 19, 1993, and were not to blame for the fire that consumed the compound where the cult leader David Koresh and his followers were barricaded. More than 80 people died in the fire.

keywords: BURTON, DAN; FREEH, LOUIS J; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; FIRES AND FIREMEN; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); TEAR GAS
headline: F.B.I. BACKS AWAY FROM FLAT DENIAL IN WACO CULT FIRE
snippet: The Federal Bureau of Investigation backed away from six years of unqualified denials to Congress and the public today, conceded that it used ''pyrotechnic'' tear-gas canisters on the final day of the 1993 standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near...
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation backed away from six years of unqualified denials to Congress and the public today, conceded that it used ''pyrotechnic'' tear-gas canisters on the final day of the 1993 standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex., and ordered a full inquiry. The bureau said the devices were ''pyrotechnic'' only in a limited sense and bounced harmlessly off a concrete structure six hours before the compound's main building, built of wood, erupted in flames. The bodies of about 80 people, including 25 children, were found after the fire.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 U.N. Rejects Serb Plea For Enclaves in Kosovo The United Nations Special Representative for Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, rejected pleas by the Serbs to formally partition Kosovo into ethnic cantons, at a heated meeting with Albanian and Serbian representatives. He said the peacekeeping force intended to protect the Serbs where they live, even if that meant guarding individual houses. A1

keywords: BURTON, DAN; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FRINGE GROUPS AND MOVEMENTS; EDITORIALS; TEAR GAS
headline: Red Faces at the F.B.I.
snippet: The Federal Bureau of Investigation now concedes that it used ''pyrotechnic'' tear-gas canisters capable of setting the disastrous fire that ended a standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex., in 1993. About 80 people were found dead...
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation now concedes that it used ''pyrotechnic'' tear-gas canisters capable of setting the disastrous fire that ended a standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex., in 1993. About 80 people were found dead after the fire. The bureau insists that the canisters played no role in the blaze, which they say was set by the cultists themselves. But the revelation that the devices were used at all contradicts six years of unqualified denials to Congress and the public by Attorney General Janet Reno and other senior officials, adding an embarrassing new element to one of the saddest chapters in F.B.I. history. Ms. Reno, who admitted yesterday that her credibility had been damaged, has ordered another inquiry into the events of April 19, 1993. Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, is also talking about reopening his Congressional investigation. These inquiries must be thorough and speedy. Some Americans are still eager to believe that the F.B.I. deliberately murdered the cultists. Unanswered questions can only reinforce these beliefs.

keywords: RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FRINGE GROUPS AND MOVEMENTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Reno Admits Credibility Loss In Waco Case
snippet: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that her credibility has been damaged by new disclosures of the use of pyrotechnic tear-gas canisters on the final day of the 1993 Government  standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex.    Six years...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that her credibility has been damaged by new disclosures of the use of pyrotechnic tear-gas canisters on the final day of the 1993 Government standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex. Six years ago, Ms. Reno survived the political fallout of her first major test in office, a fiery debacle at the Branch Davidian compound after which about 80 people, including 25 children, were found dead. Now, nearing the end of the Clinton Administration, she finds herself facing many of the same questions about the same incident.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-12    Inquiry Indicates Bank Missed Laundered Funds  Large sums of money were laundered through nine accounts at the Bank of New York for at least six months before the bank was aware of it, according to individuals with direct...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Inquiry Indicates Bank Missed Laundered Funds Large sums of money were laundered through nine accounts at the Bank of New York for at least six months before the bank was aware of it, according to individuals with direct knowledge of the investigation. More than $4.2 billion that investigators suspect was tied to organized crime in Russia passed through these accounts between early 1998 and last March. A12 A top Kremlin official denied corruption accusations made in an Italian newspaper against members of President Boris N. Yeltsin's family and inner circle, and dismissed the scandal as a fabrication by Mr. Yeltsin's political enemies. A12

keywords: VENEZUELA; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONS; CHURCH-STATE RELATIONS
headline: Rival Assemblies in Venezuela Reach a Shaky Accord
snippet: An agreement brokered today by the Roman Catholic Church averted, at least temporarily, a dangerous political showdown between the Congress and the rival Constitutional Assembly, which earlier this week stripped the legislature of its authority to...
lead_paragraph: An agreement brokered today by the Roman Catholic Church averted, at least temporarily, a dangerous political showdown between the Congress and the rival Constitutional Assembly, which earlier this week stripped the legislature of its authority to pass laws. Under the accord announced this afternoon by Msgr. Hernan Sanchez Porras, the president of the Venezuelan Conference of Bishops, Congressional leaders agreed to abandon their plan to convene a special session today in defiance of the decree the assembly approved Wednesday night. In return, the assembly agreed to begin a ''dialogue'' with legislators and to establish a joint commission to discuss their differences.

headline: August 22-28; Revisions After Waco
snippet: After six years of denials, Attorney General Janet Reno conceded that pyrotechnic tear gas canisters were used at the Branch Davidian compound in the 1993 assault that ended with the deaths of some 80 Davidians near Waco, Tex. While the disclosure...
lead_paragraph: After six years of denials, Attorney General Janet Reno conceded that pyrotechnic tear gas canisters were used at the Branch Davidian compound in the 1993 assault that ended with the deaths of some 80 Davidians near Waco, Tex. While the disclosure does not alter experts' conclusions that the fire that killed many of the members was set by them, Ms. Reno suggested that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had misled her. She ordered another inquiry into one of the worst law enforcement debacles of modern times. STEPHEN LABATON

keywords: IRAQ; AMMAN (JORDAN); LIBYA; ARAB GAMES; SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Soccer Riot at Arab Games
snippet: The police fired tear gas and beat Libyan fans with clubs today after violence broke out with Libya on the verge of losing a soccer match to Iraq in the Arab Games here.  With five minutes left in the match, fans ripped out seats and threw them on...
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas and beat Libyan fans with clubs today after violence broke out with Libya on the verge of losing a soccer match to Iraq in the Arab Games here. With five minutes left in the match, fans ripped out seats and threw them on the field. As the referee suspended the match, the police moved in and cleared the stands. Fans were seen scuffling with the police, and at least one policeman was seen clutching his head. After about 10 minutes, the referee blew the final whistle and awarded the match to Iraq with the score at 3-1. The Libyan players embraced their Iraqi counterparts and applauded.

keywords: SCHUMER, CHARLES E; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; RELIGIOUS CULTS
headline: Senator Seeks Outside Inquiry After F.B.I.'s Waco Disclosure
snippet: Senator Charles E. Schumer called today for ''a full, independent, outside investigation'' into Federal agents' use of incendiary devices at a cult compound in Texas in 1993 and the six years of official denials that followed.    But unlike other...
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer called today for ''a full, independent, outside investigation'' into Federal agents' use of incendiary devices at a cult compound in Texas in 1993 and the six years of official denials that followed. But unlike other lawmakers who have called for inquiries into the matter, Mr. Schumer, Democrat of New York, did not imply that there may have been a cover-up in the case.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Reno Admits Credibility Loss in Waco Case'' (front page, Aug. 25): You quote Henry S. Ruth Jr., who co-wrote a report critical of the Treasury Department's role in the 1993 raid on the Branch Davidian cult at Waco, Tex., as remarking that a Justice Department evaluation of the raid ''was a whitewash in the sense that it didn't tell the full facts about what was known [and] clearly was written to vindicate the Attorney General, for some reason.''

keywords: WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS
headline: Persecution, American-Style
snippet: The Japanese believe that the United States often emphasizes individual rights at the expense of society as a whole,'' a front-page article in The New York Times reported last week.    This was by way of explaining Japan's crackdown on Aum Shinrikyo,...
lead_paragraph: The Japanese believe that the United States often emphasizes individual rights at the expense of society as a whole,'' a front-page article in The New York Times reported last week. This was by way of explaining Japan's crackdown on Aum Shinrikyo, which carried out a nerve gas attack in the Tokyo subway four years ago, killing a dozen people and sickening thousands. Local governments have been refusing to grant followers of the sect residence permits, without which they cannot legally work or obtain driver's licenses, passports or public services. Children of Aum members have been turned away from public schools and parks. It appears that most Japanese do not object to these tactics.

keywords: ZEDILLO PONCE DE LEON, ERNESTO; CHIAPAS (MEXICO); MEXICO; ZAPATISTA NATIONAL LIBERATION ARMY; ROADS AND TRAFFIC; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
headline: Road Dispute Revives Zapatista Fight
snippet: A spat over a dirt road through a soggy jungle has reignited the clash between the Government and Zapatista rebels in the Mexican state of Chiapas, showing that five years of efforts by President Ernesto Zedillo to bring peace to the Indian region...
lead_paragraph: A spat over a dirt road through a soggy jungle has reignited the clash between the Government and Zapatista rebels in the Mexican state of Chiapas, showing that five years of efforts by President Ernesto Zedillo to bring peace to the Indian region have failed. The dispute began in mid-August when masked Zapatistas formed a human barrier in a faraway rain forest hamlet to block the Government from opening a roadway into their main stronghold. Army troops flew in to clear the way, activating tensions that led to the first direct skirmishes between the two sides in more than a year.

keywords: FREEH, LOUIS J; HYDE, HENRY J; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; FIRES AND FIREMEN; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); TEAR GAS
headline: F.B.I. Chief Says He Supports An Outside Inquiry on Waco
snippet: Hoping to head off any impression of a conflict of interest, Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. wholeheartedly supports an outside investigation into the bureau's failure to disclose the use of incendiary devices in the 1993 siege of the Branch...
lead_paragraph: Hoping to head off any impression of a conflict of interest, Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. wholeheartedly supports an outside investigation into the bureau's failure to disclose the use of incendiary devices in the 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound, a bureau spokesman said tonight. Another Justice Department official said Attorney General Janet Reno, too, had all but decided that an exhaustive inquiry totally independent of the Justice Department was the best way to find out why the use of the incendiary devices, heat-generating tear-gas canisters, during the Federal assault on the sect's compound near Waco, Tex., had been denied for six years.

keywords: RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; FIRES AND FIREMEN; EDITORIALS; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); TEAR GAS
headline: An Unbiased Inquiry on Waco
snippet: Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, has urged his boss, Attorney General Janet Reno, to appoint a qualified group of outsiders to investigate the agency's failure to keep Ms. Reno and Congress fully informed about all aspects of its role in the 1993...
lead_paragraph: Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, has urged his boss, Attorney General Janet Reno, to appoint a qualified group of outsiders to investigate the agency's failure to keep Ms. Reno and Congress fully informed about all aspects of its role in the 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex. This is the right thing to do, since it would be an appalling conflict of interest to have the F.B.I. and the Justice Department investigating themselves. Ms. Reno, who is said to have decided yesterday to mount an independent inquiry, should seek out and appoint qualified investigators as soon as possible.

keywords: RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; RECORDINGS (AUDIO); FIRES AND FIREMEN; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); TEAR GAS
headline: RENO ORDERS TAPE SEIZED FROM F.B.I.
snippet: Attorney General Janet Reno today ordered United States marshals to the F.B.I.'s headquarters to seize a previously undisclosed tape recording of voice communications between F.B.I. commanders and field agents during the 1993 tear gas assault at the...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Janet Reno today ordered United States marshals to the F.B.I.'s headquarters to seize a previously undisclosed tape recording of voice communications between F.B.I. commanders and field agents during the 1993 tear gas assault at the Branch Davidian compound, Justice Department officials said. The recording, officials said, contains the voices of agents asking for and receiving authorization from their operational commanders at Waco, Tex., to fire inflammable military tear-gas rounds at a covered bunker not far from the main Branch Davidian compound several hours before a deadly fire ignited, leaving about 80 people dead, including many children.

keywords: HARDY, DAVID; KORESH, DAVID; MCNULTY, MICHAEL; TEXAS; WACO (TEX); TEXAS RANGERS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; SUITS AND CLAIMS AGAINST GOVERNMENT; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
headline: Tenacity of 2 Played a Role In Reviving Inquiry on Waco
snippet: Michael McNulty and David Hardy refused to let go. In the six years since the Branch Davidian compound went up in flames on April 19, 1993, the two men have waged an obsessive quest to discredit the official account of what happened.    Espousing...
lead_paragraph: Michael McNulty and David Hardy refused to let go. In the six years since the Branch Davidian compound went up in flames on April 19, 1993, the two men have waged an obsessive quest to discredit the official account of what happened. Espousing views popular with many right-wing groups, Mr. McNulty, in particular, has blamed Federal agents for the deaths of the Branch Davidian leader, David Koresh, and about 80 of his followers, a position many critics regard as anti-Government propaganda. Mr. McNulty and Mr. Hardy, however, regard as Government propaganda the official explanation that Mr. Koresh and his followers carried out a suicide pact by setting fire to the cult compound and shooting themselves on the 51st day of a siege by Federal agents.

The statement came in response to reports of money laundering in which billions of dollars were sent by Russians through the Bank of New York. A8
