headline: Justice Dept. Talking to Ex-Missouri Senator About Leading a Waco Inquiry
snippet: Justice Department officials have held serious discussions with former Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican, about leading a new, broad-based inquiry into what happened at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., in 1993, Clinton...
lead_paragraph: Justice Department officials have held serious discussions with former Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican, about leading a new, broad-based inquiry into what happened at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., in 1993, Clinton Administration officials said tonight. The officials said that a final decision had not been made and that there was at least one other plausible candidate. That person is a former United States attorney, whom the officials would not name, but whom they characterized as being thought of as a fallback choice.

keywords: FREEH, LOUIS J; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FRINGE GROUPS AND MOVEMENTS; RECORDINGS (AUDIO); RELIGIOUS CULTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Tension Between Reno and Freeh Reaches Breaking Point on Waco
snippet: In the early years of the Clinton Administration, aides portrayed Janet Reno and Louis J. Freeh as one of the capital's perfect power pairings -- a tough, down-to-earth Attorney General who was happy to have the ex-F.B.I. agent, former Mafia...
lead_paragraph: In the early years of the Clinton Administration, aides portrayed Janet Reno and Louis J. Freeh as one of the capital's perfect power pairings -- a tough, down-to-earth Attorney General who was happy to have the ex-F.B.I. agent, former Mafia prosecutor and Federal judge as her chief law-enforcement officer. But officials who know them both said the image never really fit the reality, and, in recent days, the disclosures that the F.B.I. used heat-generating tear-gas canisters in the April 1993 assault on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., and then failed to produce tape recordings from its files confirming that fact, have split open a seam of discontent. The Justice Department has talked to former Senator John C. Danforth about leading a new investigation into the events at the compound. [Page A14.]

keywords: RENO, JANET; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS
headline: As Pressure Builds, Reno Appears Calm
snippet: At this morning's weekly press briefing, Attorney General Janet Reno answered virtually every question by saying she was ''dedicated to finding the truth,'' wanted to ''use the process to get to the truth'' and planned to ''continue to pursue the...
lead_paragraph: At this morning's weekly press briefing, Attorney General Janet Reno answered virtually every question by saying she was ''dedicated to finding the truth,'' wanted to ''use the process to get to the truth'' and planned to ''continue to pursue the truth.'' In half an hour, she referred to the truth a total of 25 times.

keywords: DANFORTH, JOHN C; KORESH, DAVID; FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FIRES AND FIREMEN
headline: RENO VOWS TO GET AT TRUTH ON FIRE AT CULT COMPOUND
snippet: Attorney General Janet Reno, swept up once again in a furious law-enforcement controversy, said today that she would demand the facts to determine whether the F.B.I. played any role in starting a deadly fire that broke out during the 1993 assault on...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Janet Reno, swept up once again in a furious law-enforcement controversy, said today that she would demand the facts to determine whether the F.B.I. played any role in starting a deadly fire that broke out during the 1993 assault on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. Sounding resolute at her weekly news conference, Ms. Reno said that she was determined to uncover the truth behind previously undisclosed F.B.I. audio recordings that clearly show how agents fired combustible tear gas rounds, even though officials, including Ms. Reno, had said for six years that the F.B.I. took no action that could have ignited the fire.

keywords: CARSTENS, ROGER; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); TEAR GAS
headline: Placing the Blame for the Disaster at Waco; Federal Credibility
snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''F.B.I. Chief Says He Supports an Outside Inquiry on Waco'' (front page, Sept. 1): It is now evident that despite the Federal Bureau of Investigation's claims to the contrary, its agents used pyrotechnic tear-gas canisters...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''F.B.I. Chief Says He Supports an Outside Inquiry on Waco'' (front page, Sept. 1): It is now evident that despite the Federal Bureau of Investigation's claims to the contrary, its agents used pyrotechnic tear-gas canisters against the Branch Davidians at Waco, Tex., in 1993. The issue is not whether the F.B.I. used a potential fire starter, but rather that it lied about it. Tactics, techniques and critical decisions about the level of force used during a crisis will always come under close scrutiny, especially when a decision results in an unforeseen outcome.

keywords: ASPIN, LES; WACO (TEX); DEFENSE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Documents on Waco Point To a Close Commando Role
snippet: The Pentagon's elite Special Operations Command sent observers to the siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Texas more than a month before the final assault on the compound, suggesting that military commandos had a far longer and closer...
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon's elite Special Operations Command sent observers to the siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Texas more than a month before the final assault on the compound, suggesting that military commandos had a far longer and closer involvement in the disastrous 1993 operation than previously divulged, according to declassified Government documents. The documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act also show for the first time that officials at the highest levels of the Defense Department, including Secretary of Defense Les Aspin and the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were briefed by the Special Operations Command about the events near Waco.

keywords: DANFORTH, JOHN C; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; RELIGIOUS CULTS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: Reno Is Said to Be Near Naming Ex-Senator To Head Investigation Into Waco Attack
snippet: Attorney General Janet Reno has all but decided to select former Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri to head an independent investigation into the F.B.I.'s disastrous assault on the Branch Davidian compound in 1993, law-enforcement officials said...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Janet Reno has all but decided to select former Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri to head an independent investigation into the F.B.I.'s disastrous assault on the Branch Davidian compound in 1993, law-enforcement officials said today. Justice Department officials continued today to review Mr. Danforth's background and deliberated the breadth of the legal mandate for the re-examination of the ill-fated tear-gas operation and deadly fire that swept through the ramshackle building near Waco, Tex.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 U.S. Resists Imposing Sanctions on Indonesia The United States is resisting direct threats of economic or military sanctions against Indonesia over the violence and chaos in East Timor in hopes of preserving its relationship with that vast nation. The Administration, officials say, has made the calculation that the United States must put its relationship with Indonesia ahead of its concern over the political fate of East Timor. A1

headline: EX-SENATOR PICKED BY RENO TO HEAD NEW WACO INQUIRY
snippet: Attorney General Janet Reno has selected John C. Danforth, a former Republican senator from Missouri, to lead an independent re-examination of the tear-gas assault on the Branch Davidian compound by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1993,...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Janet Reno has selected John C. Danforth, a former Republican senator from Missouri, to lead an independent re-examination of the tear-gas assault on the Branch Davidian compound by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1993, officials said today. After a hurried seven-day search, Ms. Reno met with Mr. Danforth today to discuss the scope of his inquiry. She is to announce his appointment on Thursday.

keywords: DANFORTH, JOHN C; LOTT, TRENT; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; EDITORIALS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: A Search for Truth About Waco
snippet: The naming of former Senator John Danforth to conduct an independent inquiry into the Federal Bureau of Investigation's disastrous 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., is a promising development. The need for such an inquiry has...
lead_paragraph: The naming of former Senator John Danforth to conduct an independent inquiry into the Federal Bureau of Investigation's disastrous 1993 siege of the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., is a promising development. The need for such an inquiry has been obvious from the moment the F.B.I. acknowledged, after six years of firm denials by the agency and Attorney General Janet Reno, that it had used incendiary tear-gas canisters during the siege. Mr. Danforth, a Missouri Republican, has a strong background in law enforcement and a reputation among his former Capitol Hill colleagues for balance and honesty. His Congressional record was blemished by his overly zealous defense of Judge Clarence Thomas during the tumultuous Supreme Court confirmation hearings in 1991. Mr. Danforth at the time seemed more interested in painting Anita Hill as a possible psychopath than getting to the bottom of her accusations of sexual harassment by Judge Thomas. A lot now rides on Mr. Danforth's ability and determination, in his new role, to avoid the lack of objectivity that marked his performance in that regrettable episode.

keywords: CONYERS, JOHN; DANFORTH, JOHN C; HYDE, HENRY J; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS
headline: Danforth Says He'll 'Answer the Dark Questions' on Waco
snippet: John C. Danforth, named today to be the Government's special counsel investigating the fiery death of some 80 members of the Branch Davidian cult, as well as the aftermath, said his job would be ''to answer the dark questions.''     In a news...
lead_paragraph: John C. Danforth, named today to be the Government's special counsel investigating the fiery death of some 80 members of the Branch Davidian cult, as well as the aftermath, said his job would be ''to answer the dark questions.'' In a news conference at the Justice Department, Mr. Danforth, a former three-term Republican Senator from Missouri, said that in re-examining the F.B.I.'s raid on the cult's compound near Waco, Tex., six years ago, he would concentrate on a handful of crucial issues:

keywords: WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FRINGE GROUPS AND MOVEMENTS; TEAR GAS
headline: F.B.I. Report to Congress Left Off Page on Tear Gas
snippet: The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent Congress in 1995 a laboratory report about the agency's assault on the Branch Davidian compound without a page that referred to the use of flammable tear-gas canisters, according to a Justice Department...
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent Congress in 1995 a laboratory report about the agency's assault on the Branch Davidian compound without a page that referred to the use of flammable tear-gas canisters, according to a Justice Department memorandum. The disclosure that such devices were used in the 1993 assault has sparked a crisis for officials at both agencies, who have said the Government did nothing that could have started a fire at the compound. Investigators later found the bodies of about 80 people.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Militias Menace Refugees At U.N. Witnesses said the men looted supplies with the help of Indonesian soldiers and fired at refugees who tried to flee. Indonesia's armed forces chief, Gen. Wiranto, said his country might accept the deployment of a United Nations peacekeeping force. A1

lead_paragraph: Violence exploded on the streets of this divided city for a second day, forcing French and Italian troops to disperse hundreds of stone-throwing demonstrators. The security forces took no chances and moved quickly to stop a crowd of 300 Albanian youths who were pushing through their lines and crossing the bridge to the Serbian side, where another jeering crowd had gathered.

headline: September 5-11; Danforth to Examine Waco
snippet: Attorney General Attorney General Janet Reno named John C. Danforth, the former Republican Senator from Missouri, to lead an independent reexamination of the F.B.I.'s tear-gas assault in 1993 on the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex. Mr. Danforth...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Attorney General Janet Reno named John C. Danforth, the former Republican Senator from Missouri, to lead an independent reexamination of the F.B.I.'s tear-gas assault in 1993 on the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex. Mr. Danforth was granted full investigative and prosecutorial powers to charge Federal agents with crimes if he finds the law was broken. In part, the choice reflected an effort by Ms. Reno to quiet her Republican critics in Congress. But the outcry grew louder, with Republican Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, telling reporters, ''I am beginning to think that she should resign.'' DAVID JOHNSTON

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Indonesia Invites U.N. To Send Forces to Timor President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia capitulated to international pressure and invited the United Nations to send a peacekeeping force to East Timor, conceding that Indonesian forces have been unable to control the violence there. A1 For many of the nearly 100,000 people who have fled or been forced out of East Timor, the nightmare has not ended. Militia men roam the refugee camps, harassing aid workers and journalists, searching for refugees who they believe voted for independence for East Timor. A1

lead_paragraph: Angered by the failure of the Justice Department to produce crucial documents, Republican lawmakers today promised a broader investigation of the tear-gas assault on the Branch Davidian compound than the one planned by a special counsel appointed by Attorney General Janet Reno. Republicans today continued to press for Ms. Reno to step down, with the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, saying President Clinton should name a new Attorney General.

keywords: WAXMAN, HENRY A; CLINTON, BILL; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS
headline: Tear-Gas Type Used at Waco Reported in '95
snippet: Internal F.B.I. documents disclosed today by a Democratic lawmaker show that information about the use of combustible tear-gas canisters at the 1993 Branch Davidian siege near Waco, Tex., has sat in the Justice Department's files for years and was...
lead_paragraph: Internal F.B.I. documents disclosed today by a Democratic lawmaker show that information about the use of combustible tear-gas canisters at the 1993 Branch Davidian siege near Waco, Tex., has sat in the Justice Department's files for years and was even sent to Congress no later than 1995. The documents cast new light on when different parts of the Government first had information about the use of the tear gas cannisters and may alter the dynamics of the renewed outcry over events surrounding the Federal Bureau of Investigation tear-gas attack at the Branch Davidian compound, which burned to the ground on April 19, 1993.

headline: National News Briefs; Top Waco Prosecutor Removes Staff From Case
snippet: The top Federal prosecutor in Texas responsible for handling all legal matters related to the F.B.I. tear-gas assault near Waco, Tex., has asked for and received permission from the Justice Department to be recused from the case, according to legal...
lead_paragraph: The top Federal prosecutor in Texas responsible for handling all legal matters related to the F.B.I. tear-gas assault near Waco, Tex., has asked for and received permission from the Justice Department to be recused from the case, according to legal papers disclosed today in Texas. The request by the United States Attorney in San Antonio, James W. Blagg, applies to other prosecutors in the Western District of Texas who have any involvement in the case. That would include Bill Johnston, an outspoken critic of his superiors.

snippet: Riot policemen fired tear gas and water cannon here today at thousands of supporters of the imprisoned former Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, during a demonstration at the main mosque.    Protesters threw stones at the police and yelled, ''Dogs...
lead_paragraph: Riot policemen fired tear gas and water cannon here today at thousands of supporters of the imprisoned former Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, during a demonstration at the main mosque. Protesters threw stones at the police and yelled, ''Dogs of the government!'' while officers beat demonstrators with batons. Policemen were seen dragging at least half a dozen protesters into vans.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    First Peacekeepers Arrive in East Timor  The first units of an international peacekeeping force landed in East Timor to quell a campaign of terror unleashed when residents voted for independence from Indonesia three weeks...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 First Peacekeepers Arrive in East Timor The first units of an international peacekeeping force landed in East Timor to quell a campaign of terror unleashed when residents voted for independence from Indonesia three weeks ago. In advance of the deployment, the mission's commander, Maj. Gen. Peter Cosgrove of Australia, visited Dili, the capital, to coordinate the effort. A1 Tokyo and Seoul Draw Closer The Governments of South Korea and Japan are drawing dramatically closer, bringing a new spirit of respect and reconciliation to one of Asia's most bitter relationships. Officials say South Korea and Japan have been driven together by a variety of factors, including a common threat from North Korea. A1

keywords: JAKARTA (INDONESIA); INDONESIA; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: New Indonesian Security Law Sets Off Protests by Students
snippet: In a hastily arranged vote just before it was to go into recess, Indonesia's Parliament today approved a security law that opponents say could grant strong new powers to the military.    The approval, which was expected, unleashed a surge of protests...
lead_paragraph: In a hastily arranged vote just before it was to go into recess, Indonesia's Parliament today approved a security law that opponents say could grant strong new powers to the military. The approval, which was expected, unleashed a surge of protests in Jakarta and other cities, some of which turned violent. More than 5,000 students here tried to march to Parliament, clashing with riot policemen and soldiers who fired plastic bullets and tear gas to turn them back.

keywords: HABIBIE, B J; INDONESIA; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; MARTIAL LAW; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Jakarta Delays Security Bill as Riots Rage
snippet: Yielding to a wave of violent unrest, President B. J. Habibie said today that he would delay signing an unpopular security law that was rushed through Parliament on Thursday.    The passage of the law ignited the most violent turmoil here since...
lead_paragraph: Yielding to a wave of violent unrest, President B. J. Habibie said today that he would delay signing an unpopular security law that was rushed through Parliament on Thursday. The passage of the law ignited the most violent turmoil here since November. Students objected both to the content of the law, which they said would grant sweeping new powers to the military to impose martial law, and to the way it was approved, in a hastily arranged vote on the next-to-last day of the Parliament session.

keywords: HABIBIE, B J; JAKARTA (INDONESIA); SUMATRA (INDONESIA); EAST TIMOR; INDONESIA; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Protests Against Military Shift To Indonesia City on Sumatra
snippet: While calm returned to Indonesia's capital today after anti-military riots here left at least six people dead, students took to the streets of another large Indonesian city and hurled rocks and burning tires at soldiers and the police in a protest...
lead_paragraph: While calm returned to Indonesia's capital today after anti-military riots here left at least six people dead, students took to the streets of another large Indonesian city and hurled rocks and burning tires at soldiers and the police in a protest over a proposed law that would grant sweeping new powers to the army. There were no immediate reports of injuries as a result of the riots today in Medan, a city of 1.2 million people on the northern Indonesian island of Sumatra. But accounts from Indonesian news agencies said that there had been fierce street clashes between nearly 2,000 student demonstrations and a joint force of soldiers and the police.

lead_paragraph: In the beginning, they were just two little boys who shared the same dream. In his ramshackle township, the black boy strung sticks into pretend pistols and shouted ''Boom, boom, boom!'' The white boy pictured himself in spit-shined shoes and crisp green uniforms.

lead_paragraph: Peacekeepers dropped from helicopters today and fanned out through the nearly deserted coastal town of Liquica, extending their control in East Timor. With tensions in the country still high, reports emerged today that as many as 16 people, including two nuns and two seminary students, were killed over the weekend during a mercy mission to refugees.

headline: The Legacy Of Apartheid: More Violence At a Funeral
snippet: At least three people were wounded today when the police fired live ammunition and tear gas during the funeral of a black Army lieutenant who killed seven white military officers and a white civilian in a shooting rampage last month.    Some 2,000...
lead_paragraph: At least three people were wounded today when the police fired live ammunition and tear gas during the funeral of a black Army lieutenant who killed seven white military officers and a white civilian in a shooting rampage last month. Some 2,000 mourners screamed and scattered when the police opened fire after two shots were fired by mourners who wanted to honor Lieut. Sibusiso Madubela with a 12-gun salute forbidden by the police.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: EUROPE    BRITAIN: THE TORIES' PROGRAM -- The Conservative leader, William Hague, opened his party's annual convention with a 60-point proposal for a ''common-sense revolution'' that would reduce taxes, end benefits to welfare recipients who turn...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE BRITAIN: THE TORIES' PROGRAM -- The Conservative leader, William Hague, opened his party's annual convention with a 60-point proposal for a ''common-sense revolution'' that would reduce taxes, end benefits to welfare recipients who turn down work and increase parents' control of schools. He accused Prime Minister Tony Blair, whose Labor Party runs far ahead of the Tories in polls, of ''breathtaking hypocrisy.'' Warren Hoge (NYT) GERMANY: SUPPORT FOR SAME-SEX MARRIAGES -- The Green Party, coalition partner in Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's center-left Government, is pressing ahead with a bill to recognize same-sex marriages. ''The legal recognition of same-sex cohabitation will become a central focus of the parliamentary Greens' work,'' the party said. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: World Briefing
snippet: EUROPE    FRANCE: CHEFS PROTEST TAX -- Hundreds of French chefs and restaurant owners, many wearing tall white hats and banging pots, converged on Parliament to demand lower taxes. When riot policemen blocked their way, the shouting marchers fought...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE FRANCE: CHEFS PROTEST TAX -- Hundreds of French chefs and restaurant owners, many wearing tall white hats and banging pots, converged on Parliament to demand lower taxes. When riot policemen blocked their way, the shouting marchers fought back with eggs and flour before being dispersed with tear gas. The restaurateurs want a reduction in the 20.6 percent value-added tax, or VAT, that they must charge their clients. They say it is too hard to compete with fast-food chains, which can charge only a 5.5 percent tax. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: As the Finale Nears, Indonesians Face Off
snippet: Indonesia entered the final and most intense days of its political transition today with demonstrators and security forces battling in the streets as President B. J. Habibie pleaded with an electoral assembly to choose him for a full five-year term. ...
lead_paragraph: Indonesia entered the final and most intense days of its political transition today with demonstrators and security forces battling in the streets as President B. J. Habibie pleaded with an electoral assembly to choose him for a full five-year term. The occasion was the President's ''accountability speech'' in which Mr. Habibie described what he saw as his accomplishments -- civil rights and openness, a degree of economic stability and the political transition itself -- since the forced resignation of his autocratic predecessor, Suharto, 17 months ago.

headline: French Clash With Albanians in Kosovo Town
snippet: In a shower of stones, tear gas and percussion grenades, French-led troops and foreign police officers drove back hundreds of Albanians trying to storm across a bridge to the Serbian side of this  town today.    More than 100 people were injured --...
lead_paragraph: In a shower of stones, tear gas and percussion grenades, French-led troops and foreign police officers drove back hundreds of Albanians trying to storm across a bridge to the Serbian side of this town today. More than 100 people were injured -- none seriously -- in the two-hour melee, the most violent clash here in a month, NATO officials said.

keywords: BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; BETHLEHEM (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Link Opens West Bank to Gaza's Job Hunters
snippet: Khader Juneed, 23, had never set foot outside Gaza in his life, and his family didn't want him to, either. His parents feared he might never return, and so when he came home proudly last week with a shiny new Israeli-issued permit that would allow...
lead_paragraph: Khader Juneed, 23, had never set foot outside Gaza in his life, and his family didn't want him to, either. His parents feared he might never return, and so when he came home proudly last week with a shiny new Israeli-issued permit that would allow him to travel to the West Bank, they forbade him to use it. Early this morning, many hours before the first ''safe passage'' route between the Gaza Strip and the West Bank opened, Mr. Juneed said, he acted as if he were leaving for work. He put his construction boots in one black plastic bag and his painter's pants in another. And then he hitched a ride to the border with Israel without saying goodbye, not even to his wife and three children.

keywords: BETHLEHEM (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS
headline: Clashes in Bethlehem Cast Shadow on Millennium Plans
snippet: Street battles engulfed the entrance to Bethlehem today for the third day in a row, casting a shadow over preparations for millennium celebrations in the town revered as the birthplace of Jesus.    From morning until dusk, Palestinian youths enraged...
lead_paragraph: Street battles engulfed the entrance to Bethlehem today for the third day in a row, casting a shadow over preparations for millennium celebrations in the town revered as the birthplace of Jesus. From morning until dusk, Palestinian youths enraged by the killing of a local man by an Israeli soldier on Monday hurled stones at helmeted troops guarding Rachel's Tomb, a holy site on the city's outskirts.

keywords: DIABATE, HENRIETTE; ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Abidjan Journal; Political Woman Goes From Ivory Tower to Street
snippet: The often told story about Henriette Diabate went like this: the woman with the impeccably proper upbringing once lost an election because instead of making sure that the ballots were being counted properly after a long day, she daintily went home to...
lead_paragraph: The often told story about Henriette Diabate went like this: the woman with the impeccably proper upbringing once lost an election because instead of making sure that the ballots were being counted properly after a long day, she daintily went home to take a bath. ''It's a legend,'' Ms. Diabate said recently, describing the story as a crude attempt to discredit the rarity of rarities, a female African political leader. ''But the legend survives.''

keywords: ARAFAT, YASIR; CLINTON, HILLARY RODHAM; ARAFAT, SUHA; ISRAEL; JORDAN; PALESTINIANS
headline: A Day Later, Mrs. Clinton Rebukes Arafat's Wife and Explains Herself
snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton rebuked the wife of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, today for accusing Israel on Thursday of causing cancer among Palestinians through the use of toxic gas, calling her statements inflammatory rhetoric that harmed peace...
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton rebuked the wife of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, today for accusing Israel on Thursday of causing cancer among Palestinians through the use of toxic gas, calling her statements inflammatory rhetoric that harmed peace efforts. Against a backdrop of rugged desert mountains in this valley of rock-hewn Nabatean tombs that is Jordan's most famous tourist attraction, Mrs. Clinton went out of her way to denounce the remarks by Suha Arafat, even as critics at home wondered aloud why she had waited a day to react.

keywords: ARAFAT, YASIR; GIULIANI, RUDOLPH W; CLINTON, HILLARY RODHAM; ARAFAT, SUHA; NEW YORK STATE; ISRAEL; SENATE; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; ELECTION ISSUES; ELECTIONS
headline: Hillary Clinton Strikes Back At Giuliani on Mideast Trip
snippet: Taking a jab at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for criticizing her behavior during a West Bank visit in which Yasir Arafat's wife accused Israel of using poison gas, Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she was in the Middle East to support peace...
lead_paragraph: Taking a jab at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for criticizing her behavior during a West Bank visit in which Yasir Arafat's wife accused Israel of using poison gas, Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she was in the Middle East to support peace efforts, and expected every American to do so. On the last day of her visit to the region, Mrs. Clinton was still handling the fallout from the incident on Thursday in the West Bank town of Ramallah, where Suha Arafat charged that Israeli occupation had left the Palestinians with contaminated water and land, and that ''toxic gases'' used by the Israelis, a reference to tear gas, had caused cancer among women and children.

keywords: STEPHANOPOULOS, KONSTANDINOS; CLINTON, BILL; GREECE; ATHENS (GREECE); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; GREECE-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: President's Visit to Greece Yields a Toast and a Tumult
snippet: President Clinton raised a glass to American-Greek relations tonight in the dignified confines of Presidential Mansion as thousands of demonstrators clashed with riot-equipped policemen in an ugly but contained protest against the president's...
lead_paragraph: President Clinton raised a glass to American-Greek relations tonight in the dignified confines of Presidential Mansion as thousands of demonstrators clashed with riot-equipped policemen in an ugly but contained protest against the president's arrival. Chanting ''Clinton is a fascist'' and ''The streets of Athens belong to us,'' protesters threw stones and gasoline bombs, looted stores and set fires in the streets.

headline: Defiant Muslims Begin Building Nazareth Mosque
snippet: Thousands of jubilant Muslims  chanted prayers to Allah, threw fists into the air and set off firecrackers today as they defiantly laid the marble cornerstone of a mosque in the shadow of the Basilica of the Annunciation.    A nun in white, a monk in...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of jubilant Muslims chanted prayers to Allah, threw fists into the air and set off firecrackers today as they defiantly laid the marble cornerstone of a mosque in the shadow of the Basilica of the Annunciation. A nun in white, a monk in brown and a priest in black watched the celebration glumly from the crenelated roof of the church, which, like all the major churches in the Holy Land, has been shuttered for two days in protest.

headline: Moving to Ease Doubts, First Lady Says She Will Enter Senate Race
section: Front Page; New York and Region
snippet: Seeking to dispel a cloud of doubt that has shadowed her emerging campaign for public office, Hillary Rodham Clinton flew to New York yesterday to declare that she was in the race for the United States Senate to stay. She said she would move into her...
lead_paragraph: Seeking to dispel a cloud of doubt that has shadowed her emerging campaign for public office, Hillary Rodham Clinton flew to New York yesterday to declare that she was in the race for the United States Senate to stay. She said she would move into her new house in Chappaqua, N.Y., as soon as the Secret Service said she could, and begin campaigning ''as vigorously as possible.'' ''It's time to get moving and get started,'' she said at a news conference at the United Federation of Teachers headquarters in Midtown Manhattan. Mrs. Clinton said that after four months of traveling across the state, ''I just became more and more convinced that this is a campaign that needs to be made, that the issues at stake are important ones, and that I have a lot to say about them.''

keywords: SMITH, WALTER S; KORESH, DAVID; WACO (TEX); FIRES AND FIREMEN; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); SUITS AND LITIGATION
headline: Years After Davidian Cult Fire, Legal Battles Gather Force
snippet: Six years after David Koresh's strange ministry of God and guns ended in flames at the Branch Davidians' compound near Waco, more questions than answers continue to rise out of the ashes.    And the legal battle that has kept the case alive has...
lead_paragraph: Six years after David Koresh's strange ministry of God and guns ended in flames at the Branch Davidians' compound near Waco, more questions than answers continue to rise out of the ashes. And the legal battle that has kept the case alive has gained steam in the last week, with a federal judge stepping in to settle disputes over evidence and issuing rulings that are providing new insights into the case.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: ASIA    PAKISTAN: MORE CHARGED FOR CORRUPTION -- Shahbaz Sharif, left, has joined his older brother, the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, on the list of those accused by the new military government of treason and hijacking. ''I am innocent, why...
lead_paragraph: ASIA PAKISTAN: MORE CHARGED FOR CORRUPTION -- Shahbaz Sharif, left, has joined his older brother, the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, on the list of those accused by the new military government of treason and hijacking. ''I am innocent, why am I in police custody?'' the younger Mr. Sharif said in a court appearance. Two other Sharif family loyalists have also been accused in the case -- Saifur Rehman, the former chief of the government's anti-corruption unit, and Saeed Mehdi, who was Nawaz Sharif's principal secretary. Barry Bearak (NYT) INDIA: MORE MILITARY SPENDING SOUGHT -- The military budget should be increased from 2.3 percent of India's gross domestic product to 3 percent, the defense minister, George Fernandes, told a military conference in New Delhi, according to the Press Trust of India. The conflict with Pakistan in Kashmir this year demonstrated the need for more spending, he said. Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
snippet: Conseco, Its Stock Sagging, Focuses on Balance Sheet  Conseco, an insurance holding company with a sagging stock price, announced a reversal of strategy. It cut its common stock dividend and agreed to raise $478 million by selling convertible...
lead_paragraph: Conseco, Its Stock Sagging, Focuses on Balance Sheet Conseco, an insurance holding company with a sagging stock price, announced a reversal of strategy. It cut its common stock dividend and agreed to raise $478 million by selling convertible preferred stock on extraordinarily generous terms to a private investment firm. Conseco's shares rose $1.6875, to $20.25, on the news. And Moody's Investors Service said that when the financing by the investment firm is completed, it would raise Conseco's rating from junk bond level to investment grade. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [Page C18.]

headline: National Guard Is Called to Quell Trade-Talk Protests; Seattle Is Under Curfew After Disruptions
snippet: Downtown Seattle was placed under curfew and the National Guard was called in tonight, after the city was engulfed in demonstrations that threw the opening of global trade talks into turmoil.     The protesters surrounded the convention hall, pinned...
lead_paragraph: Downtown Seattle was placed under curfew and the National Guard was called in tonight, after the city was engulfed in demonstrations that threw the opening of global trade talks into turmoil. The protesters surrounded the convention hall, pinned trade dignitaries in their hotels and stopped traffic at several intersections. By late afternoon, clouds of tear gas set off by the police wafted through downtown streets populated by Nordstrom, Nike and Starbucks, and Mayor Paul Schell declared a state of emergency and a curfew that he said would last until sunrise on Wednesday.

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; LOOT AND LOOTING; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; VANDALISM
headline: Black Masks Lead to Pointed Fingers in Seattle
snippet: It took only a few minutes for the people in the monarch butterfly costumes and union jackets to realize that what was planned as the biggest American demonstration yet against global trade here had turned into a burst of window-breaking and looting...
lead_paragraph: It took only a few minutes for the people in the monarch butterfly costumes and union jackets to realize that what was planned as the biggest American demonstration yet against global trade here had turned into a burst of window-breaking and looting late Tuesday afternoon. A surge of violence that ended in a civil emergency began when a knot of people dressed in black broke away from the main demonstration and started overturning trash containers, stoking fires and smashing windows of stores and restaurants. It died out with the image of a grinning young man in a Gap sweatshirt trying to cart off a satellite dish from a Radio Shack store.

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Internationally, Embarrassment for U.S.
snippet: If Seattle had wanted to use the World Trade Organization meeting as a postcard demonstrating its idiosyncratic charms to the rest of the world, it would surely have hoped for some better pictures.     International responses to the images of rioting...
lead_paragraph: If Seattle had wanted to use the World Trade Organization meeting as a postcard demonstrating its idiosyncratic charms to the rest of the world, it would surely have hoped for some better pictures. International responses to the images of rioting and chaos in Seattle varied as widely as countries' own views of the trade group and of American domination of world markets. Broadly speaking, though, Tuesday's events were seen as an embarrassment to the United States and to Seattle, as well as a sometimes welcome opportunity to train attention on trade issues dear to various regions.

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; LABOR; REFORM AND REORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ENVIRONMENT; EDITORIALS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Messages for the W.T.O.
snippet: Tuesday's street scene in Seattle -- the chanting demonstrators, the tear gas, the National Guard -- seemed a flashback to the 1960's. That the protests were aimed not at a divisive war but a peaceable meeting of the World Trade Organization made the...
lead_paragraph: Tuesday's street scene in Seattle -- the chanting demonstrators, the tear gas, the National Guard -- seemed a flashback to the 1960's. That the protests were aimed not at a divisive war but a peaceable meeting of the World Trade Organization made the whole thing even more surreal. The chaos conveyed a warning to both sides. The violence and property destruction diverted attention from the basic point the demonstrators sought to make -- the need to reform the W.T.O.'s procedures and values. Protest leaders were right to condemn the lawlessness quickly. But the W.T.O.'s 135 members will make a huge mistake if they fail to grasp the core belief fueling these unruly protests -- that the W.T.O. is far too insular, that it has displayed too little sensitivity for issues like workers' rights and the environment, and that its secretive procedures undermine public trust. It is possible to agree with the W.T.O.'s goal of free trade, as this page does, and also to agree with President Clinton that the protesters' causes merit sympathy.

keywords: CLINTON, BILL; SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; NATIONAL GUARD; LABOR; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ENVIRONMENT; CELLULAR TELEPHONES; CURFEWS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TELEPHONES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS; TEAR GAS
headline: PRESIDENT CHIDES WORLD TRADE BODY IN STORMY SEATTLE
snippet: With Seattle's streets locked down by the police and National Guard, President Clinton delivered two impassioned pleas today for nations of the world to use trade agreements to protect the rights of laborers and the environment, and delivered a...
lead_paragraph: With Seattle's streets locked down by the police and National Guard, President Clinton delivered two impassioned pleas today for nations of the world to use trade agreements to protect the rights of laborers and the environment, and delivered a pointed attack on the World Trade Organization for the secrecy of its operations. In several appearances here that took him past the shattered windows and closed shops of a normally vibrant downtown, Mr. Clinton sided with the cause of many of the peaceful demonstrators who jammed Seattle's streets on Tuesday, even as he denounced those who engaged in violence. [Excerpts, Page A17.]

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; NATIONAL GUARD; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CURFEWS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Seattle Is Stung, Angry and Chagrined as Opportunity Turns to Chaos
snippet: Police officers and unarmed National Guard troops imposed a tense version of order to downtown Seattle today. About 40 blocks were sealed off from any demonstrations, more than 400 protesters were under arrest, and the windows of some of the city's...
lead_paragraph: Police officers and unarmed National Guard troops imposed a tense version of order to downtown Seattle today. About 40 blocks were sealed off from any demonstrations, more than 400 protesters were under arrest, and the windows of some of the city's most fashionable stores and coffee shops were smashed or boarded up. Parts of the city's center remained under a nighttime curfew. This evening, as tear gas wafted in the streets near the city's venerable Pike Place Market, a simple question was on the lips of many people, especially angry merchants: why, exactly, did we decide to be the host of these global trade talks?

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; EDITORIALS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Police Tactics in Question; Handling Protest in Seattle
snippet: Seattle is a city with a tradition of liberal politics and civility in public discourse. So it was a shock to see the host city of the World Trade Organization meeting face down protesters with tear gas, rubber pellets and the National Guard this...
lead_paragraph: Seattle is a city with a tradition of liberal politics and civility in public discourse. So it was a shock to see the host city of the World Trade Organization meeting face down protesters with tear gas, rubber pellets and the National Guard this week. The root problem seems to be a failure by Seattle's mayor and police chief to prepare for the size of the demonstrations and possible violence. The mayor's instincts were commendable -- to give demonstrators who had come from around the country the opportunity to protest peacefully in the center of the city. He has argued that a big show of police force would have unfairly squelched free speech and possibly incited the crowd. At first his approach seemed to be working. An orderly, festive parade of more than 30,000 labor and environmentalist demonstrators did march through the heart of the city to the sound of brass bands.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: THE AMERICAS    COLOMBIA: U.S. SEEKS DRUG SUSPECTS   The United States has requested the extradition of 30 people arrested two months ago in a nationwide operation, including a leader of the Medellin cartel. Colombia stopped extraditing its...
lead_paragraph: THE AMERICAS COLOMBIA: U.S. SEEKS DRUG SUSPECTS The United States has requested the extradition of 30 people arrested two months ago in a nationwide operation, including a leader of the Medellin cartel. Colombia stopped extraditing its nationals in 1991, but President Andres Pastrana has resumed the practice. Larry Rohter (NYT) ARGENTINA: EX-GENERAL HELD A former general, Guillermo Suarez Mason, 75, who ran the First Army Corps under the juntas of the 1976-83 dictatorship, was arrested in investigations into the theft of hundreds of babies from women in torture centers. He was the ninth senior junta official to be held on charges of kidnapping babies and changing their identities. (Reuters)

headline: Turbulent Talks, Converging Currencies
snippet: Billowing tear gas and shattering plate glass brought an unaccustomed atmosphere of chaos and menace to the World Trade Organization talks in Seattle last week, but the currency markets seemed headed for an unexpected and somewhat eerie simplicity:...
lead_paragraph: Billowing tear gas and shattering plate glass brought an unaccustomed atmosphere of chaos and menace to the World Trade Organization talks in Seattle last week, but the currency markets seemed headed for an unexpected and somewhat eerie simplicity: one euro to the dollar, one penny to the yen, give or take. Two unrelated forces -- a flood of money into the long-battered Japanese stock market and a hunt for growth by Europeans who see dimming prospects at home -- combined to push exchange rates close to both milestones last week. The euro slipped briefly below one-for-one parity several times during trading Thursday and Friday before finishing the week at $1.0017, while the yen made its closest approach to 100 to the dollar, a level not seen since 1995, on Tuesday; by week's end a dollar bought 102.53 yen.

keywords: CLINTON, BILL; SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; LABOR; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ENVIRONMENT
headline: Impasse on Trade Delivers A Stinging Blow to Clinton
snippet: President Clinton's effort to shape an ambitious agenda to liberalize trade and broaden the mandate of the World Trade Organization collapsed here Friday night, after a rebellion by developing countries and deadlock among America's biggest trading...
lead_paragraph: President Clinton's effort to shape an ambitious agenda to liberalize trade and broaden the mandate of the World Trade Organization collapsed here Friday night, after a rebellion by developing countries and deadlock among America's biggest trading partners forced the administration to all but abandon one of its major foreign policy goals for the end of Mr. Clinton's presidency. The collapse of the talks ended a tumultuous week of riots on the streets of Seattle, the arrest of more than 600 protesters, and bitter infighting among 135 nations. They could not agree even on whether to discuss workers' rights and the environment in trade negotiations that were supposed to be started here. In the end, weary ministers headed for the airport without even issuing a final communique.

headline: The Nation: New World Disorder; Free Trade Takes On Free Speech
snippet: THE biggest trade conference ever held on American soil was supposed to go like this: a Pacific rim city, grown wealthy on sales of software and planes to the global economy, would show off the fruits of unfettered commerce. Meanwhile, carefully...
lead_paragraph: THE biggest trade conference ever held on American soil was supposed to go like this: a Pacific rim city, grown wealthy on sales of software and planes to the global economy, would show off the fruits of unfettered commerce. Meanwhile, carefully choreographed street protests would enable President Clinton to nudge the delegates into taking action against such excesses of the global economy as child labor and pollution. In this narrative, Seattle was to play the hero, while its companies and citizens were cast as bit players. Here was a dynamo of dot.com millionaires. A port full of ships stuffed with goods from every nation. A region that provides half the world's commercial jets. Protesters who behave while walking on stilts.

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: After Riots, Seattle Is Chagrined Yet Cheerful
snippet: At the beginning of the week that was to showcase Seattle to the world as a friend to free trade and free expression alike, the city's Public Development Authority promised yet more good news for local merchants.     ''PDA + WTO = Business as Usual...
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the week that was to showcase Seattle to the world as a friend to free trade and free expression alike, the city's Public Development Authority promised yet more good news for local merchants. ''PDA + WTO = Business as Usual -- Maybe Better!'' proclaimed a bright yellow flier distributed to businesses as the World Trade Organization got under way here, adding: ''Thousands of potential customers with time on their hands and money in their pockets will descend upon the Downtown area.''

keywords: SCHELL, PAUL; STAMPER, NORM; SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Seattle Police Chief Resigns in Aftermath of Protests
snippet: Amid continuing criticism over the police department's handling of the protests last week in Seattle that eclipsed the World Trade Organization meeting here, the city's police chief announced today that he would resign.     The chief, Norm Stamper,...
lead_paragraph: Amid continuing criticism over the police department's handling of the protests last week in Seattle that eclipsed the World Trade Organization meeting here, the city's police chief announced today that he would resign. The chief, Norm Stamper, said he wished to ''depoliticize'' the investigations that are under way into police preparations for the global trade talks, which drew 35,000 protesters downtown. The demonstrations quickly turned into a tumultuous affair, televised worldwide, in which the police sprayed tear gas and rubber pellets at many peaceful protesters along police lines near the meeting but failed to stop the window-smashing and looting by a relatively small group of vandals less than a block away. The National Guard was called in to help restore order.

headline: Clinton's Words to Press: On the Mideast, Chechnya and Other Matters
snippet: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today in the Dean Acheson Auditorium at the State Department, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:    Opening Statement      We are at a pivotal moment in...
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today in the Dean Acheson Auditorium at the State Department, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: Opening Statement We are at a pivotal moment in the Middle East peace process, one that can shape the face of the region for generations to come. As I have said on numerous occasions, history will not forgive a failure to seize this opportunity to achieve a comprehensive peace. We've made good progress on the Palestinian track, and I am determined to help Prime Minister Barak and Chairman Arafat move forward in accordance with their very ambitious timetable.

headline: December 5-11; Seattle's Latest Casualty
snippet: The protests in Seattle may have calmed down since the World Trade Organization talks ended, but turmoil continues. The police chief announced his resignation, saying he wanted to ''de-politicize'' investigations into how his force handled...
lead_paragraph: The protests in Seattle may have calmed down since the World Trade Organization talks ended, but turmoil continues. The police chief announced his resignation, saying he wanted to ''de-politicize'' investigations into how his force handled demonstrators. More than 600 people were arrested, and the police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse some crowds, while vandals went unchecked elsewhere. Irate protesters, merchants and bystanders jammed the first City Council meeting focusing on the debacle. SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

headline: Clinton's Final Chapter: Single-Minded, Full-Steam Run at a Global Agenda
snippet: For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the...
lead_paragraph: For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty last fall to a tear-gas-filled week in Seattle that badly damaged his global economic agenda. But some of his biggest victories in 1999 were also scored abroad, from the air campaign over Serbia that largely halted ethnic bloodshed to the Northern Ireland accord that offers the first prospect of peace there.

headline: $8 Million Offered to End Attica Inmates' Suit
section: Front Page; New York and Region
snippet: Determined to conclude one of the longest and ugliest chapters in criminal justice history, a federal judge announced today that the inmates who were beaten and tortured during the 1971 Attica prison uprising have been offered a settlement of $8...
lead_paragraph: Determined to conclude one of the longest and ugliest chapters in criminal justice history, a federal judge announced today that the inmates who were beaten and tortured during the 1971 Attica prison uprising have been offered a settlement of $8 million from New York State. The settlement, which provides an additional $4 million for lawyers' fees, is believed to be the biggest ever in a prisoners' rights case. But it may also be remembered as one of the longest and most vexing to hammer out, coming 25 years after a class-action civil suit was filed on behalf of 1,281 inmates over the storming of the western New York prison by state troopers. The uprising and siege left 43 people dead and more than 80 wounded.

headline: Seattle Will Drop Most of Trade Protest Cases
snippet: Seattle officials said today that they were dropping all but about 40 of the unresolved misdemeanor cases stemming from the tumultuous street protests of the World Trade Organization meeting here a month ago.    At least a few protesters said they...
lead_paragraph: Seattle officials said today that they were dropping all but about 40 of the unresolved misdemeanor cases stemming from the tumultuous street protests of the World Trade Organization meeting here a month ago. At least a few protesters said they opposed the city's move because they hoped to use their trials to showcase the city's mishandling of the demonstrations, which grew so raucous and tense that the National Guard was called in and the police used tear gas and rubber pellets to disperse the crowds.

headline: In Turbulent Times, a Prison Boiled Over
snippet: Even before the rioting started on Sept. 9, 1971, the state prison in Attica, N.Y., was in ferment. So was the entire country.    Two months earlier, angry Attica inmates had petitioned state correction officials to ease chronic overcrowding and...
lead_paragraph: Even before the rioting started on Sept. 9, 1971, the state prison in Attica, N.Y., was in ferment. So was the entire country. Two months earlier, angry Attica inmates had petitioned state correction officials to ease chronic overcrowding and censorship rules, and to improve conditions that limited them to one shower a week and one roll of toilet paper a month. A sign of the brewing unrest was a fast that the prisoners held on Aug. 22 in memory of George Jackson, a prominent black radical who had been killed by prison guards in California during a breakout attempt.

headline: Irate Cuban-Americans Paralyze Miami
snippet: Energized by a new cause, hundreds of Cuban-Americans shut down much of Miami today with waves of civil disobedience, temporarily blocking access to the Port of Miami and choking traffic on dozens of busy streets to protest the Clinton...
lead_paragraph: Energized by a new cause, hundreds of Cuban-Americans shut down much of Miami today with waves of civil disobedience, temporarily blocking access to the Port of Miami and choking traffic on dozens of busy streets to protest the Clinton administration's decision to return 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez to his father in Cuba. About 135 protesters were arrested by riot police officers, who led most of them away peacefully in plastic handcuffs as the crowd chanted, ''Libertad Elian, libertad Elian.''

headline: Attica: Settled, But Not Healed
snippet: Nearly 30 years after 43 people were killed and more than 80 were injured at the uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in upstate New York, a court settlement will require the state to pay $8 million to surviving inmates and $4 million to...
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years after 43 people were killed and more than 80 were injured at the uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in upstate New York, a court settlement will require the state to pay $8 million to surviving inmates and $4 million to their lawyers. But New York has not admitted, and will not have to admit, any wrongdoing, even though inmates were killed, beaten and tortured after state troopers stormed the prison.

headline: The Nation; Attica: Exorcising the Demons, Redeeming the Deaths
snippet: THE immediate spark, not that it matters after so many years, was a series of misunderstandings. One evening, hours after a prison guard mistakenly thought they had been fighting, two inmates were taken from their cells for punishment. A rumor, no...
lead_paragraph: THE immediate spark, not that it matters after so many years, was a series of misunderstandings. One evening, hours after a prison guard mistakenly thought they had been fighting, two inmates were taken from their cells for punishment. A rumor, no more true than the phantom fight, spread through the cellblock that both had been beaten. In a way, the whole thing was pretty silly. The consequences were anything but.

headline: Mom, Dad: Where Were You in the 60's?
snippet: SOME bearded, beaded sage once remarked that if you could remember the 1960's, you probably weren't a part of them. This, of course, raises the shagadelic question: how can you forget something that will not go away?    From the repackaging of the...
lead_paragraph: SOME bearded, beaded sage once remarked that if you could remember the 1960's, you probably weren't a part of them. This, of course, raises the shagadelic question: how can you forget something that will not go away? From the repackaging of the music (more and better quality is available now from Rhino, Rycodisc and Sony Legacy than was ever available at the time), the artifacts to the resurrection of the zeitgeist with Austin Powers, Woodstock 99 and the street theater at the World Trade Organization protests in Seattle, the decade seems to want to stick around.

headline: Acting Editor, Specialist in Business Coverage, Is Made Permanent at The Post
snippet: The New York Post, which has built its rowdy reputation on front-page coverage of crime (''Headless Body in Topless Bar''), sports (''Bellichicken'') and politics (''Shame on Hillary'') is naming as its editor a journalist who has spent her entire...
lead_paragraph: The New York Post, which has built its rowdy reputation on front-page coverage of crime (''Headless Body in Topless Bar''), sports (''Bellichicken'') and politics (''Shame on Hillary'') is naming as its editor a journalist who has spent her entire career covering business (as in ''You've Got Deal''). Xana Antunes (pronounced SHAH-na An-TOON-ess), who joined The Post as deputy business editor in 1995, has been acting editor of The Post since October, when Kenneth Chandler, the editor in chief, assumed the title of publisher and stepped down from day-to-day newsroom management.

headline: 7 Killed and 9 Hurt in Kosovo Rampage, Worst Since War
snippet: In the worst violence Kosovo has seen since the end of the war, seven Albanians were killed and at least nine wounded on Thursday night when about 500 people rampaged through the streets, bursting into apartments, firing guns and throwing grenades.  ...
lead_paragraph: In the worst violence Kosovo has seen since the end of the war, seven Albanians were killed and at least nine wounded on Thursday night when about 500 people rampaged through the streets, bursting into apartments, firing guns and throwing grenades. The fierce fighting had subsided by daybreak, but the tension remained in this divided city as angry crowds of Serbs and Albanians gathered on either side of a bridge that spans the Ibar River, which runs through the heart of this industrial city 30 miles northwest of Kosovo's provincial capital, Pristina. The river separates the two communities; about 9,000 Serbs control the north bank, and 90,000 ethnic Albanians live on the south side.

keywords: AUTOMOBILES; UTILITY VEHICLES AND OTHER LIGHT TRUCKS; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS
headline: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: Salient Facts: Armored S.U.V.'s; Gangsta on Board
snippet: According to law-enforcement officials, Puffy Combs -- the rapper recently charged with throwing a 9-millimeter handgun out the window of his speeding Lincoln Navigator -- had installed a secret trap door to hide a weapon. The problem? The trap...
lead_paragraph: According to law-enforcement officials, Puffy Combs -- the rapper recently charged with throwing a 9-millimeter handgun out the window of his speeding Lincoln Navigator -- had installed a secret trap door to hide a weapon. The problem? The trap door's security system was so elaborate that in the heat of the moment no one in the car could figure out how to get it open. According to a report in The New York Post, one witness told the grand jury that Combs yelled: ''Trap! Trap! Open the trap!'' (Combs has pleaded not guilty to charges of illegal gun possession.) Police say that secret gun vaults are increasingly common among certain high-risk drivers. And for those who have enough money and know the right auto-body mechanic, they are just one of the many options available. Trap Doors First used by drug gangs, these discreet compartments can keep illegal contraband (or legitimate cargo, should the need arise) safe and out of sight. As long as you can open them, that is: law-enforcement officials in New York have discovered traps -- inside dashboards, behind back seats, in door panels and floorboards -- that pop open only when the operator turns on the heat while the radio is set to a certain station, or when he inserts a hairpin into connections in the doorjamb while stepping on the brakes. More high-tech versions involve a series of microswitches that must be flipped in sequence. A few years ago, a drug gang in Washington Heights had a whole fleet of nondescript sedans whose traps could be opened only by inserting fuses into the second and fourth slots on the right column of the fuse box and then activating the rear-window defroster. ''Five years ago,'' one veteran New York City lawman said, ''these things were unusual. Now they're commonplace.'' Then again, he added, ''to some degree that's a function that we know to look for them now.'' Trap doors aren't actually illegal. Still, many alarm shops or auto detailers are leery of installing them. ''The police department frowns upon that kind of stuff,'' said the owner of a custom shop in the Bronx. ''If you start putting it in they give you a hard time. People ask me for safes, and I won't do it, because it's just too much to have in my head.'' Michael Trusio, a senior sales executive at Krystal Enterprises in Brea, Calif., agrees that it's business he'd rather not have. But, he added, ''we don't want to tell somebody no and then have someone come around and burn our plant down.'' Armor Car armor, which can include bulletproof glass in the windows, ballistic steel in the doors and body and Kevlar shields for the floorboards and gas tank, was once used for skittish billionaires and presidential motorcades. Today, it's just another accessory for the nation's wealthiest drivers. But all that security doesn't come cheap. Outfitting the family Mercedes in this bulletproof material can cost $100,000. And for some, that's just the beginning. ''I can think of 10 or 12 families who have armored cars for everyone,'' said Craig Fingold, the president of Beverly Hills Motoring, which has dubbed itself the Neiman Marcus of automotive accessories. Depending on the thickness, armor can add from 400 to 4,000 pounds to the weight of the car. Fingold said that a record mogul who had been threatened with death by a rapper had recently come in and had his Suburban outfitted with 4-inch metal -- enough to stop machine-gun fire. And Notorious B.I.G. stopped in to check out an armoring system but did not buy it. A few months later, he was shot to death in his Suburban. The Works Even drivers whose security concerns don't involve wielding or dodging heavy firepower have a number of self-defense toys to consider. Auto Taser ($200) delivers a powerful electric shock to anyone who lays an unwelcome hand on the steering wheel. Tiny video cameras ($800) that are installed with a clear view of the front seat can be useful for those who want evidence of police harassment; Fingold says they're especially popular with celebrities and sports figures. But for some wary drivers, the best defense is a good offense. Outfits like the Counter Spy Shops sell devices that spew oil, leaving a dangerous slick behind them ($1,300); they are reportedly popular in Russia, as are similar devices that spray a mist of oil on the windshield of the car behind ($1,300). Contraptions that scatter a large number of tacks in a car's wake -- first seen on countless Saturday-morning cartoons -- cost slightly more. (They start at $1,500.) Counter Spy claims it installed one for the Shah of Iran. Thankfully for the average American driver, however, most are available for export only. Finally, for those less afraid of fellow motorists than of airborne hazards, the smart choice is a tear-gas deterrent system that seals the car against unfiltered air ($5,000).

headline: In Kosovo, More Clashes Between Peacekeepers and Albanians
snippet: Peacekeepers clashed with Kosovo Albanians for a second day today in this town, firing percussion grenades and tear gas to push back angry crowds from the bridge that divides the city.    Two Albanians and eight soldiers were reported wounded in the...
lead_paragraph: Peacekeepers clashed with Kosovo Albanians for a second day today in this town, firing percussion grenades and tear gas to push back angry crowds from the bridge that divides the city. Two Albanians and eight soldiers were reported wounded in the clash as Albanian youths threw bottles and stones at troops guarding the bridge. Police in riot gear with helmets and shields reacted forcefully, advancing in formation, backed up by four Dutch armored vehicles.

headline: Denver Police Chief Pushed Out After a Series of Problems
snippet: Mayor Wellington Webb began a search today for a new police chief after a series of problems, including the accidental shooting death of a man in a botched drug raid, led him to seek the resignation of a 30-year veteran of the force who served less...
lead_paragraph: Mayor Wellington Webb began a search today for a new police chief after a series of problems, including the accidental shooting death of a man in a botched drug raid, led him to seek the resignation of a 30-year veteran of the force who served less than 18 months as its chief. In announcing his request late Tuesday after meeting with the chief, Tom Sanchez, the city's first Hispanic police chief and one of the few Hispanics leading a big-city police force, Mayor Webb said, ''At certain times, due to a convergence of issues, a leadership change is necessary.''

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); GREAT BRITAIN; SERBIA; FRANCE
headline: British Troops Replace French in Riot-Torn Kosovo Town
snippet: British peacekeeping forces took over guard duties on a bridge in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo today, replacing French troops that had been accused of failing to protect ethnic Albanians and Serbs.    The arrival of the...
lead_paragraph: British peacekeeping forces took over guard duties on a bridge in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo today, replacing French troops that had been accused of failing to protect ethnic Albanians and Serbs. The arrival of the British -- about 150 men from the Royal Green Jackets who are based in central Kosovo -- is the latest effort by peacekeepers to ensure security and reduce tension in the area, which was the scene of riots last week. During an all-night rampage, angry Serbs took to the streets in retaliation for the deaths of two Serbs killed in a bus ambush.

keywords: METROSTARS; SOCCER
headline: A New Striker Is Coming
snippet: METROSTARS       The MetroStars, the worst team in Major League Soccer last season, made another move yesterday, trading away one Colombian striker for another. The MetroStars sent Henry Zambrano to the Colorado Rapids and replaced him with Alex...
lead_paragraph: METROSTARS The MetroStars, the worst team in Major League Soccer last season, made another move yesterday, trading away one Colombian striker for another. The MetroStars sent Henry Zambrano to the Colorado Rapids and replaced him with Alex Comas, who played with Colombia's Atletico National for the past three years.

keywords: NEW YORK STATE; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; ATTICA STATE PRISON (NY); CLASS-ACTION SUITS; SUITS AND CLAIMS AGAINST GOVERNMENT; GUARDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TORTURE
headline: Ex-Attica Inmates Recount Shattered Lives and Dreams
snippet: Gary Haynes, Attica survivor, waited almost 30 years for this day.    Dressed in a weathered suit with his mother, Betty, at his side, Mr. Haynes showed up at the federal district courthouse here almost an hour early this morning. He wanted to talk...
lead_paragraph: Gary Haynes, Attica survivor, waited almost 30 years for this day. Dressed in a weathered suit with his mother, Betty, at his side, Mr. Haynes showed up at the federal district courthouse here almost an hour early this morning. He wanted to talk about how the guards had beaten him and burned his chest with cigarettes. He wanted to tell people about the kidney transplant that he says was a result of the beating -- as well as the broken ankle, the broken feet, the broken hip and the thwarted dreams that ensued.

keywords: CHERNOKOZOVO (RUSSIA); INGUSHETIA (RUSSIAN REPUBLIC); RUSSIA; CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; SEX CRIMES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; TORTURE
headline: Chechens Tell of Torture in Russian Camp
snippet: Three men seized by Russian troops and imprisoned at a detention camp in northern Chechnya this winter have told human rights observers of beatings, torture and rapes they say took place there before they bribed their way to freedom this month.    ...
lead_paragraph: Three men seized by Russian troops and imprisoned at a detention camp in northern Chechnya this winter have told human rights observers of beatings, torture and rapes they say took place there before they bribed their way to freedom this month. The three, who are now in the neighboring Russian province of Ingushetia, gave their accounts to researchers for Human Rights Watch, which relayed them to news organizations this week.

keywords: LEBANON; AKUR (LEBANON); ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Army Breaks Up Beirut Demonstration at U.S. Embassy
snippet: Popular anger erupted outside the United States Embassy today, a week after Israel retaliated against Lebanon for guerrilla attacks that killed several Israeli soldiers. Hundreds of Lebanese students joined with other protesters in throwing rocks and...
lead_paragraph: Popular anger erupted outside the United States Embassy today, a week after Israel retaliated against Lebanon for guerrilla attacks that killed several Israeli soldiers. Hundreds of Lebanese students joined with other protesters in throwing rocks and tomatoes at Lebanese army and police detachments, which responded with batons, tear gas canisters and high-pressure water hoses. The protests appeared to have been organized with the help of Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Party of God, whose guerrillas have mounted an offensive in southern Lebanon that has killed seven Israeli soldiers in less than three weeks. In a fiery speech on Wednesday, the Hezbollah leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, citing official American statements that supported the Israeli bombing, called on this nation of 3.5 million people to boycott the United States ambassador, David Satterfield, whom he described as ''the U.S.-Israeli ambassador in Lebanon.''

keywords: ISRAEL; CABLE NEWS NETWORK; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; TELEVISION; LEBANON-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Protests in Beirut Against U.S. and Israel Turn Wrath on CNN
snippet: A second day of angry street protests against Israel and the United States turned today against the American cable network CNN, with Lebanese soldiers and policemen in riot gear firing tear gas to drive back about 3,000 demonstrators who tried to...
lead_paragraph: A second day of angry street protests against Israel and the United States turned today against the American cable network CNN, with Lebanese soldiers and policemen in riot gear firing tear gas to drive back about 3,000 demonstrators who tried to reach CNN's Beirut offices. The demonstrators, mostly university students, dispersed after about an hour without breaking through barricades. Their anger at CNN, the only American television network with a news bureau here, appeared to be as much an outgrowth of resentment of the United States' support of Israel as an attack on CNN's Middle East coverage, although that, too, was widely condemned.

keywords: KIM DAE JUNG; SOUTH KOREA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
headline: Korean Fights For Coalition And His Aims As a Reformer
snippet: Two years into his five-year term as president, Kim Dae Jung is locked in a surprisingly ugly fight for his political life -- or at least to avoid having the remainder of his term turned into an ornamental presidency.     The depth of his predicament...
lead_paragraph: Two years into his five-year term as president, Kim Dae Jung is locked in a surprisingly ugly fight for his political life -- or at least to avoid having the remainder of his term turned into an ornamental presidency. The depth of his predicament was driven home the other day when one of South Korea's leading politicians compared the president, who took office as a reformer with a long history of opposition dissent, to Mao Zedong.

headline: Rudolph Patzert, 88; Transported Jews to Palestine After War
snippet: Rudolph W. Patzert, the captain of a rusty 1904 gunboat that carried more than 1,380 Jewish refugees from Europe to Palestine as part of a secret rescue operation after World War II, died on Jan. 21 in a nursing home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 88.  ...
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Patzert, the captain of a rusty 1904 gunboat that carried more than 1,380 Jewish refugees from Europe to Palestine as part of a secret rescue operation after World War II, died on Jan. 21 in a nursing home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 88. The cause was cancer, said his son Bill.

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Albanians Rally to Oust Serbs From a City in Kosovo
snippet: Thousands of ethnic Albanians from throughout Kosovo marched on this divided city today and clashed with a phalanx of NATO-led troops, who used tear gas and fists to keep them from reaching the Serbian district.    A throng of protesters -- some...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of ethnic Albanians from throughout Kosovo marched on this divided city today and clashed with a phalanx of NATO-led troops, who used tear gas and fists to keep them from reaching the Serbian district. A throng of protesters -- some estimates put their number at 25,000, others at twice that -- tried to cross the main bridge that divides the Serbian and Albanian sections of this mining town. The crowd was turned back as thousands of Serbs stood on the other side, waving flags and playing nationalist songs.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-11    China Threatens Taiwan On Reunification Issue  Beijing issued the bluntest warning yet that it would not wait indefinitely for Taiwan to reunite with the mainland, saying that if Taiwan, which is to hold presidential...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 China Threatens Taiwan On Reunification Issue Beijing issued the bluntest warning yet that it would not wait indefinitely for Taiwan to reunite with the mainland, saying that if Taiwan, which is to hold presidential elections on March 18, indefinitely refused to pursue reunification, then China would ''adopt all drastic measures possible, including the use of force.''
