headline: Inmate Dies and 12 Are Hurt as Riot Erupts in California Prison
snippet: One inmate was killed today and 12 others were wounded in a riot at a maximum-security prison here  that guards quelled with gunfire.    The violence came on the same day that a federal indictment of two former guards for attacks on inmates at the...
lead_paragraph: One inmate was killed today and 12 others were wounded in a riot at a maximum-security prison here that guards quelled with gunfire. The violence came on the same day that a federal indictment of two former guards for attacks on inmates at the prison was made public in San Francisco.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: EUROPE    RUSSIA: FUNERAL IN ST. PETERSBURG -- Under heavy security because of a rumored assassination plot, President Vladimir V. Putin, left, attended the St. Petersburg funeral of his mentor and that city's first elected mayor, Anatoly Sobchak....
lead_paragraph: EUROPE RUSSIA: FUNERAL IN ST. PETERSBURG -- Under heavy security because of a rumored assassination plot, President Vladimir V. Putin, left, attended the St. Petersburg funeral of his mentor and that city's first elected mayor, Anatoly Sobchak. Mr. Putin said Mr. Sobchak, who fled Russia from 1997 to 1999 after being accused of corruption, was a democratic visionary destroyed by persecution. Mr. Sobchak died after a heart attack last weekend. Michael Wines (NYT) SERBIA: MORE POLICE FOR KOSOVO -- Responding to the need for more civilian police officers in Kosovo and for other peacekeeping missions, the United States said it would create a permanent reserve of 2,000 officers to be available without delay. ''The recent slowness in deploying desperately needed civilian police to Kosovo provides only the latest evidence that present international capabilities are not adequate,'' said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

keywords: SOUTH KOREA; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; REFORM AND REORGANIZATION; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; LAW AND LEGISLATION; ELECTIONS; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET
headline: Internet Recharges Reformers In Korea
snippet: With his one-day beard and tousled hair, Park Byung Ok retains a hint of the look of the student protesters who lobbed rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who replied with tear gas and rubber bullets, in the often turbulent 1980's here.    But...
lead_paragraph: With his one-day beard and tousled hair, Park Byung Ok retains a hint of the look of the student protesters who lobbed rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who replied with tear gas and rubber bullets, in the often turbulent 1980's here. But these days, Mr. Park, 39, and his associates are launching nothing more lethal than e-mails -- many thousands -- to officials and political parties from civic groups that are sprouting around the country. The effects are rocking South Korea in ways never imagined by the radical opposition that many of the protesters belonged to a generation ago.

keywords: CHERNOKOZOVO (RUSSIA); RUSSIA; CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; INDEPENDENCE MOVEMENTS AND SECESSION; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: At Russian Camp, 2 Views of Chechen Prisoners
snippet: The heavy steel doors, freshly painted for visitors, swung open one by one along a 100-foot-long corridor to reveal cold cells, gauzy from cigarette smoke and poor ventilation, where the sallow faces of Chechen men and women peered out from the...
lead_paragraph: The heavy steel doors, freshly painted for visitors, swung open one by one along a 100-foot-long corridor to reveal cold cells, gauzy from cigarette smoke and poor ventilation, where the sallow faces of Chechen men and women peered out from the shadows -- their eyes frozen by the flash of intruding cameras. Their guards barked orders at them to ''stand back from the door!'' or to ''turn around!'' or ''speak up!'' and to report to a group of visitors on the conditions in this notorious ''filtration'' camp. Some who have passed through here have alleged that brutal beatings and torture have taken place.

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Troops Open Path for Kosovars to Return Home
snippet: Firing tear gas and stun grenades and using armored personnel carriers, security forces punched a corridor through a crowd of Serbian protesters today, returning dozens of ethnic Albanians to their homes in this divided city.    More than 30 people...
lead_paragraph: Firing tear gas and stun grenades and using armored personnel carriers, security forces punched a corridor through a crowd of Serbian protesters today, returning dozens of ethnic Albanians to their homes in this divided city. More than 30 people crossed the three-foot-deep Ibar River in the personnel carriers, bypassing demonstrators on the main bridge nearby, United Nations officials said. Those who crossed included members of 24 families, mostly said to be in their 50's or 60's.

keywords: CLINTON, BILL; SELMA (ALA); ALABAMA; BLACKS; DISCRIMINATION; ELECTIONS
headline: Looking Back at a Day in Selma, 35 Years On
snippet: Thirty-five years after Alabama state troopers waged a bloody attack on civil rights demonstrators here, President Clinton renewed the call for racial equality today at an anniversary gathering that drew thousands to the site of the march.    So much...
lead_paragraph: Thirty-five years after Alabama state troopers waged a bloody attack on civil rights demonstrators here, President Clinton renewed the call for racial equality today at an anniversary gathering that drew thousands to the site of the march. So much has changed, everyone agreed, since that day in 1965 when the brutal racism of the South flared up for all to see. But so many challenges remain.

keywords: HAZING
headline: First, The Ordeal
snippet: The incidents are notable for their brutality. A freshman football player on Long Island is badly beaten by his senior teammates; a high school wrestler in Trumbull, Conn., is hogtied, confined inside a gym locker and then sexually violated with a...
lead_paragraph: The incidents are notable for their brutality. A freshman football player on Long Island is badly beaten by his senior teammates; a high school wrestler in Trumbull, Conn., is hogtied, confined inside a gym locker and then sexually violated with a knife handle; a freshman hockey player at the University of Vermont is forced to perform a series of homoerotic acts. Hazing incidents, which are more and more in the news, are thought to reflect a rising level of violent incidents in our society and, as such, they have been roundly denounced. Some critics take it further and say all hazing must stop. The recent acts are criminal and should be prosecuted. But the very pervasiveness of hazing should also alert people that something else is going on. Unlike most violence, hazings are, to some degree, elective, and they result in an increase in status on the part of the victim. Moreover, hazing practices can be found in virtually every culture in the world.

keywords: FRANCE; MCDONALD'S CORP; RESTAURANTS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; FAST FOOD INDUSTRY
headline: Egalite, Fraternite et Burgers
snippet: My grandmother was shocked when I went to work for McDonald's. She thought I was cooking fries on Boulevard St.-Michel. It was 1984. McDonald's had 17 restaurants in France. Its headquarters was in an apartment. But I thought if I wanted to get...
lead_paragraph: My grandmother was shocked when I went to work for McDonald's. She thought I was cooking fries on Boulevard St.-Michel. It was 1984. McDonald's had 17 restaurants in France. Its headquarters was in an apartment. But I thought if I wanted to get ahead, I should join an American company. It would take me forever to run a French company: I'd have to know all the right people. I was 39 when I became McDonald's president two years ago -- very, very unusual for France. When I was invited to the World Cup, I sat in the box with French executives. I think they thought I was there to serve the drinks. Then one asked: ''Is your chauffeur waiting for you outside?'' I said: ''No, I have my subway ticket in my pocket.'' He couldn't believe it.

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); ITALY; MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; FRANCE; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: U.S. Troops Seize Weapons From Albanians in Kosovo
snippet: American troops in Kosovo carried out raids on the strongholds of ethnic Albanian guerrillas on Wednesday, capturing bombs and other weapons in the largest effort to date by American forces there to end the guerrillas' threat to the NATO-led...
lead_paragraph: American troops in Kosovo carried out raids on the strongholds of ethnic Albanian guerrillas on Wednesday, capturing bombs and other weapons in the largest effort to date by American forces there to end the guerrillas' threat to the NATO-led peacekeeping mission, American officials said. No one was reported injured in the raids, which were conducted in villages and guerrilla posts in the eastern sector of Kosovo, where the bulk of the nearly 6,000 American troops in the territory are stationed. It was unclear if the American troops fired their weapons.

keywords: DANFORTH, JOHN C; KORESH, DAVID; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; RECORDINGS (VIDEO); RELIGIOUS CULTS; SUITS AND LITIGATION
headline: Seeking Clues By Simulating Davidian Siege
snippet: Early this Sunday, a select group of government officials and private lawyers will meet at nearby Fort Hood, the nation's largest military base. For several hours, maybe longer, they will watch an extraordinary simulation intended to answer a...
lead_paragraph: Early this Sunday, a select group of government officials and private lawyers will meet at nearby Fort Hood, the nation's largest military base. For several hours, maybe longer, they will watch an extraordinary simulation intended to answer a question that has raged from Internet chat rooms to the halls of Congress: Did federal agents fire gunshots into the Branch Davidian compound occupied by David Koresh and his followers shortly before it burned to the ground on April 19, 1993, claiming the lives of about 80 men, women and children?

keywords: PALCZYNSKI, JOSEPH C; MARYLAND; HOSTAGES; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; MENTAL HEALTH AND DISORDERS
headline: Maryland Hostage Siege Drags on Into Third Night
snippet: A former convict with a history of mental illness, hunted in a shooting spree that took four lives, maintained a standoff against the police today, crackling the air with warning gunfire as he held three hostages in this tense suburban neighborhood. ...
lead_paragraph: A former convict with a history of mental illness, hunted in a shooting spree that took four lives, maintained a standoff against the police today, crackling the air with warning gunfire as he held three hostages in this tense suburban neighborhood. ''Come on, Joby, pick up the phone,'' police officers pleaded over a loudspeaker from an armored car parked near the building where the suspect, Joseph Palcyzinski, known as Joby, had been holed up almost three days.

keywords: DORISMOND, PATRICK M; SHARPTON, AL; GIULIANI, RUDOLPH W; DORISMOND, MARIE; NEW YORK CITY; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ATTACKS ON POLICE; BLACKS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Angry Mourners and Police Clash At Funeral of Man Shot by Officer
snippet: On a day of solemnity and outrage that degenerated into violence, Patrick M. Dorismond, the unarmed son of Haitian immigrants who was shot to death in a confrontation with the police on March 16, was carried across Brooklyn, eulogized as a martyr and...
lead_paragraph: On a day of solemnity and outrage that degenerated into violence, Patrick M. Dorismond, the unarmed son of Haitian immigrants who was shot to death in a confrontation with the police on March 16, was carried across Brooklyn, eulogized as a martyr and laid to rest yesterday after a march and funeral that drew thousands of anguished mourners and angry protesters. Before and after his funeral, there were clashes between protesters and the police, and wild scenes and sounds of chaos: barricades tumbling under surging crowds, American flags burning, the clashing chords of car horns, and the crash of glass thrown from a height, all beneath the airborne staccato of police helicopters.

headline: World Briefing
snippet: MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: TALIBAN FOE FLEES -- Iran's official news agency said Ismail Khan, the former governor of Herat Province in Afghanistan and a major figure in the opposition to the ruling Taliban, had crossed into Iran and reached the city of...
lead_paragraph: MIDDLE EAST IRAN: TALIBAN FOE FLEES -- Iran's official news agency said Ismail Khan, the former governor of Herat Province in Afghanistan and a major figure in the opposition to the ruling Taliban, had crossed into Iran and reached the city of Meshed after escaping from a Taliban prison. Mr. Khan, a hero to many Afghans for his fight against Soviet forces in the 1980's, was said to have reached Iran with another anti-Taliban leader who escaped from prison with him, Hafiz Qadir. Iran strongly opposes the Taliban. John F. Burns (NYT)

keywords: CHICAGO (ILL); GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; TRAVEL AND VACATIONS
headline: Big Shoulders, Buffed for Action
snippet: When friends from abroad come to the United States, I always send them to Chicago, or try to. It is the quintessential American city: muscular, inventive, wonderfully diverse, worldly-wise (if a bit oafish at times) and as unpretentious as its...
lead_paragraph: When friends from abroad come to the United States, I always send them to Chicago, or try to. It is the quintessential American city: muscular, inventive, wonderfully diverse, worldly-wise (if a bit oafish at times) and as unpretentious as its prairie-flat vowels. ''Chicago is American in every chitling and sparerib,'' H. L. Mencken wrote wickedly during the era when the city's stockyards, since demolished, were the biggest anywhere. ''It is alive from snout to tail.''

headline: Zimbabwe Protesters Are Beaten by Government Supporters
snippet: A peaceful anti-government march in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, erupted in violence today as a group of armed men wielding machetes and clubs attacked the crowd of several thousand marchers, leaving several people seriously injured.    About 200...
lead_paragraph: A peaceful anti-government march in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, erupted in violence today as a group of armed men wielding machetes and clubs attacked the crowd of several thousand marchers, leaving several people seriously injured. About 200 men, who were described by witnesses as supporters of President Robert Mugabe, hurled bricks and stones and beat several protesters bloody until riot policemen intervened with tear gas.

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Seattle Police Admit Failure In '99 Protests
snippet: Referring to protesters as a ''well-trained and equipped adversary,'' Seattle police officials issued a report today blaming inadequate financing and lack of preparation for the violence that marked the World Trade Organization's meeting here last...
lead_paragraph: Referring to protesters as a ''well-trained and equipped adversary,'' Seattle police officials issued a report today blaming inadequate financing and lack of preparation for the violence that marked the World Trade Organization's meeting here last year. Even as it admitted its own organizational failures in preparing for the protests, which led to the resignation of the police chief, the report angered many protesters.

keywords: ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DISCRIMINATION; ARABS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Israel Is Slowly Shedding Harsh Treatment of Arabs
snippet: Justice Minister Yossi Beilin calls it a ''quiet revolution.''     Through the years, Israel has been consistently criticized by many human and civil rights organizations for invoking national security to explain practices that were considered...
lead_paragraph: Justice Minister Yossi Beilin calls it a ''quiet revolution.'' Through the years, Israel has been consistently criticized by many human and civil rights organizations for invoking national security to explain practices that were considered exclusionary, discriminatory and coercive toward Israeli Arabs and Palestinians. But since the right-wing government was replaced last summer by a broad coalition including several leftists and human rights advocates, crucial policy changes have been made that, together with a spate of High Court decisions, point toward a sea change.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Bosnia War Crimes Suspect Is Charged by Tribunal Momcilo Krajisnik, the most senior war crimes defendant so far from the Bosnian conflict, responded ''not guilty'' to each of nine charges, including genocide, made against him by the international war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. Putin acted on his promise to build a better foundation for the country's still shaky market economy. Mr. Fischer, the fund's acting director, met with Mr. Putin before making his remarks. A6 American Not Charged The United States said Russia had not formally charged an American arrested on suspicion of spying. The United States Embassy identified the American as Edmond Pope, 53, and said he had been visited by a consular officer. A6 Haiti Election Protest Two top officials have resigned at the urging of the center-left opposition coalition to protest the government's failure to schedule local and parliamentary elections. Environment Minister Yves Cadet and Jean Ronald Joseph, labor undersecretary at the Social Affairs Ministry, held their posts since March 1999. (AP) Bolivians Protest Water Rates The police fired tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannons to scatter crowds in Cochabamba, Bolivia's third-largest city, during protests against an increase in water rates. Chaos enveloped some streets of the city, which is 350 miles east of La Paz, as protesters threw rocks and firebombs at the police, who then stormed the rioters. Hundreds of police officers and soldiers have virtually taken control of the streets. (AP) World Briefing A6 NATIONAL A7-10, 14 Senate Adopts G.O.P. Plan For $1.8 Trillion Budget The Senate, voting 51 to 45 largely along party lines, approved a budget plan for next year that would raise spending on the military and education, cut or freeze spending in many domestic programs, reduce taxes by at least $150 billion over five years, add a $40 billion prescription drug benefit to Medicare and pay down publicly held debt with the surplus generated by Social Security. A1 Medicaid Rolls to Be Restored The Clinton administration ordered states to restore benefits to families improperly deprived of health insurance when they were left off the welfare rolls as an unintended consequence of the 1996 welfare law. Kennedy, who has accused another general of sexual misconduct in 1996, senior defense officials said. The inquiry began after the Pentagon's inspector general received an electronic message from a retired officer who accused General Kennedy of personal misconduct during the mid-1980's. A9 U.S. to Let Elian Return Attorney General Janet Reno said government lawyers would prepare an order as early as next week allowing Elian Gonzalez to return to Cuba with his father. She appealed to the boy's Miami relatives to promptly and peacefully turn him over. Bush said he had invited a small group of gay Republicans to meet with him next week, a development that stood in contrast to his longstanding refusal to meet formally with the Log Cabin Republicans, a leading gay political organization. A9 Finding Against Big Tobacco A Miami jury found that the diseases of three smokers chosen to represent hundreds of thousands of Florida residents in a class-action lawsuit had been caused by cigarettes, setting the stage for a potentially huge blow to the tobacco industry. A7 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Ad Asked Welfare Workers To Fill In for Strikers The city distributed a flier offering welfare recipients who work for their benefits security jobs at residential buildings if doormen and other building workers went on strike. A Human Resources Administration official said the city had turned down a request to supply such workers, because it amounted to strike breaking, and she expressed puzzlement at the flier's distribution. keywords: TUCKER, KEN; SUSOEFF, JOHN; SEX PISTOLS; MUSIC
headline: Mellow,' Not Fresh
snippet: To the Editor:    Ken Tucker says the Sex Pistols existed to ''release an invigorating blast of poisonous gas into the clean, crisp air of the 70's pop-music industry'' [''This Time, the Sex Pistols' Point of View,'' April 2]. He should know better....
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Ken Tucker says the Sex Pistols existed to ''release an invigorating blast of poisonous gas into the clean, crisp air of the 70's pop-music industry'' [''This Time, the Sex Pistols' Point of View,'' April 2]. He should know better. That clean, crisp air he describes was nothing more than the combined flatulence of a herd of jaded, aging AOR or Album-Oriented Rock stars. I grew up in Los Angeles listening to not one, not two, but three horrible album rock stations that combined with the aforementioned rock stars to grind music into a droning, ''mellow,'' ''progressive'' haze. The fresh air was definitely delivered by the Pistols, the Ramones, the Clash and many others. It may have had remnants of tear gas in it, but it was definitely fresh. JOHN SUSOEFF Long Beach, Calif.

keywords: BANZER, HUGO; BOLIVIA; UNEMPLOYMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Bolivia Calls An Emergency After Protest Over Water
snippet: Bolivia's president declared a state of emergency today, fueling a week of widening unrest that left three people dead in fresh clashes between police and demonstrators.     The move came after a week of protests over rising water rates, unemployment...
lead_paragraph: Bolivia's president declared a state of emergency today, fueling a week of widening unrest that left three people dead in fresh clashes between police and demonstrators. The move came after a week of protests over rising water rates, unemployment and other economic difficulties plaguing the Andean country of eight million people.

keywords: COCHABAMBA (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: 5 More Die in Bolivia Protests After Emergency Is Declared
snippet: Protests and police mutinies that have left eight people dead continued in cities around Bolivia today, after the government's declaration of a state of emergency this weekend inflamed anger over the country's worsening economic troubles.    ...
lead_paragraph: Protests and police mutinies that have left eight people dead continued in cities around Bolivia today, after the government's declaration of a state of emergency this weekend inflamed anger over the country's worsening economic troubles. Tensions were centered in Cochabamba, the country's third largest city, where a wave of protests over government plans to raise rates for drinking water began a week ago.

keywords: WASHINGTON (DC); SEATTLE (WASH); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Washington Braces to Handle Flood of Globalization Protesters
snippet: A law enforcement armada from a half-dozen city and federal agencies is preparing for mass rallies here this week as organizers try to extend the protest against global economics that plunged Seattle into violent street confrontations in November.   ...
lead_paragraph: A law enforcement armada from a half-dozen city and federal agencies is preparing for mass rallies here this week as organizers try to extend the protest against global economics that plunged Seattle into violent street confrontations in November. ''We're in the process of training drills with our mounted units and SWAT teams,'' said Sgt. Rob MacLean of the United States Park Police. ''If a situation occurs like the one in Seattle, we'll be prepared.''

headline: PERUVIAN'S LEAD IN VOTE PROMPTS CHARGE OF FRAUD
snippet: Official returns today showed President Alberto K. Fujimori approaching a first-round victory in Peru's presidential election, prompting cries of fraud and threats of civil disturbance.     At the end of Sunday's voting, polls of voters and...
lead_paragraph: Official returns today showed President Alberto K. Fujimori approaching a first-round victory in Peru's presidential election, prompting cries of fraud and threats of civil disturbance. At the end of Sunday's voting, polls of voters and independent counts suggested that neither Mr. Fujimori, running for a third five-year term, nor his challenger, Alejandro Toledo, would garner a majority.

keywords: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CUBAN-AMERICANS
headline: For Reno, a Custody Case Is Now a Personal Crusade
snippet: The custody battle over Elian Gonzalez has thrust Attorney General Janet Reno into what is most likely to be one of her last starring roles as she returned to her hometown, Miami, yesterday in a gesture that transformed a Justice Department legal...
lead_paragraph: The custody battle over Elian Gonzalez has thrust Attorney General Janet Reno into what is most likely to be one of her last starring roles as she returned to her hometown, Miami, yesterday in a gesture that transformed a Justice Department legal fight into a one-woman crusade. The case has seemingly energized the 62-year-old Ms. Reno in the eighth and final year of her stewardship at the Justice Department. And today, at considerable risk to her credibility and reputation, she began a personal mission to reunite Elian with his father.

headline: Malaysian Police Break Up Opposition Protest and Arrest 46
snippet: Defying tear gas and beatings by the police, hundreds of supporters of the jailed former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, marked the anniversary of his conviction today with a protest that led to 46 arrests.    The police cordoned off several...
lead_paragraph: Defying tear gas and beatings by the police, hundreds of supporters of the jailed former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, marked the anniversary of his conviction today with a protest that led to 46 arrests. The police cordoned off several streets in downtown Kuala Lumpur, chased the demonstrators down alleys and beat them with canes in an attempt to disperse crowds that had gathered since late afternoon.

keywords: WASHINGTON (DC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
headline: FINANCIAL LEADERS MEET AS PROTESTS CLOG WASHINGTON
snippet: Thousands of protesters trying to shut down meetings of world financial leaders swarmed through the streets of the capital today, sealed off from their target by a virtual wall of police officers. A few brief clashes ensued, but for the most part, a...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters trying to shut down meetings of world financial leaders swarmed through the streets of the capital today, sealed off from their target by a virtual wall of police officers. A few brief clashes ensued, but for the most part, a day that some had feared would descend into chaos passed peacefully. The finance ministers and other delegates from around the world were loaded onto buses early this morning and escorted by the police so their meetings could take place as scheduled. This evening, they tacitly acknowledged the shouting on the streets by conceding in a communique issued by the International Monetary Fund that their role had become a matter ''of growing public debate.''

keywords: WILLIAMS, ANTHONY; WOLFENSOHN, JAMES D; WASHINGTON (DC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CUSTOMS (TARIFF); CREDIT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FOREIGN AID
headline: World Trade Officials Pledging To Step Up Effort Against AIDS
snippet: The world's top financial officials, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protesters braved a chilling rain and an impenetrable police force outside, pledged to pay more attention to globalization's victims and to commit ''unlimited money'' to...
lead_paragraph: The world's top financial officials, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protesters braved a chilling rain and an impenetrable police force outside, pledged to pay more attention to globalization's victims and to commit ''unlimited money'' to fight AIDS in poor countries. The finance ministers and central bank governors who oversee the World Bank said the bank should intensify its fight against AIDS because the disease is as much a problem of poverty as public health. More than 50 million people are infected with the virus that causes the disease, and it is spreading fastest in Africa, India, China and the Caribbean, all major World Bank clients. The bank has been active for more than a decade in fighting the disease.

keywords: WASHINGTON (DC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: On a Day of Protests, K Street Takes the Day Off
snippet: The protesters marching downtown today failed to disrupt the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its partner organization, the World Bank. But the protesters managed to halt the business of another influential Washington...
lead_paragraph: The protesters marching downtown today failed to disrupt the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its partner organization, the World Bank. But the protesters managed to halt the business of another influential Washington institution: the law firms and lobbying shops of K Street. K Street, both as an address and a symbol of the capital's influence industry, was the spine of a 20-block area that the city police cordoned off from traffic early today. Demonstrators marched up and down the avenue in their bid to stop the world financial leaders from pursuing their agenda. They failed, but, in a sense, they might have accomplished more than they realized.

keywords: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; ASYLUM (POLITICAL); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CUBAN-AMERICANS
headline: Justice Dept. Is Uncertain About Next Step
snippet: The Federal appellate court ruling today preventing the return to Cuba of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez caught the Justice Department by surprise and left officials there uncertain about how to proceed in the highly politicized case.    Despite what the...
lead_paragraph: The Federal appellate court ruling today preventing the return to Cuba of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez caught the Justice Department by surprise and left officials there uncertain about how to proceed in the highly politicized case. Despite what the officials acknowledged was a setback, they said they could still remove the child from the custody of his Miami relatives and turn him over to his father. Today's ruling only blocks the child from leaving the United States.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: TALKS CONTINUE  Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland will be in London today for the second round of talks in 48 hours with his British counterpart, Tony Blair. Mr. Blair visited Dublin, too, as part of a continuing...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE NORTHERN IRELAND: TALKS CONTINUE Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland will be in London today for the second round of talks in 48 hours with his British counterpart, Tony Blair. Mr. Blair visited Dublin, too, as part of a continuing effort to resurrect the Protestant-Catholic coalition government suspended in February when the Irish Republican Army failed to make expected disarmament moves. Warren Hoge (NYT) BOSNIA: SERB DEFENDANTS FREED Two Bosnian Serbs facing war crimes charges were released until their trial begins because they have been in custody too long, the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague said. Miroslav Tadic, 62, and Simo Zaric, 51, surrendered in February 1998. Their trial has been delayed because of complaints by a co-defendant. (Reuters)

keywords: NAIROBI (KENYA); KENYA; MALAWI; SOUTH AFRICA; NIGERIA; WORLD CUP (SOCCER); SOCCER; ARSON; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Three African Teams Advance in Qualifiers
snippet: Kenyan fans rioted, causing a World Cup qualifier to be abandoned with several minutes remaining yesterday, and Nigeria and South Africa advanced to the second round of African play.     At Nairobi, fans in the crowd of 20,000 threw bottles and...
lead_paragraph: Kenyan fans rioted, causing a World Cup qualifier to be abandoned with several minutes remaining yesterday, and Nigeria and South Africa advanced to the second round of African play. At Nairobi, fans in the crowd of 20,000 threw bottles and stones on the field and ripped out seats in Moi International Stadium. Kenya, which lost the opener of the home-and-home, total-goals series by 2-0 April 8, was scoreless in injury time against Malawi, leaving little hope it would be one of 25 nations in Africa's second round.

keywords: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; FLORIDA; IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CUBA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; SEARCH AND SEIZURE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CUBAN-AMERICANS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: CUBAN BOY SEIZED BY U.S. AGENTS AND REUNITED WITH HIS FATHER
snippet: Armed United States immigration agents smashed their way into the Little Havana home of Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives before dawn today, took the sobbing 6-year-old boy from a bedroom closet and flew him to a reunion with his father outside...
lead_paragraph: Armed United States immigration agents smashed their way into the Little Havana home of Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives before dawn today, took the sobbing 6-year-old boy from a bedroom closet and flew him to a reunion with his father outside Washington. As demonstrators wept in rage and coughed from pepper spray and tear gas, the agents wrapped the child in a blanket and carried him to an airport to fly him to Washington. The action touched off a fury in the streets outside the home where Cuban exiles have kept a vigil since November.

keywords: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CUBA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; SEARCH AND SEIZURE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CUBAN-AMERICANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Police Fire Tear Gas as Hundreds of Angry Protesters Take to the Streets in Miami
snippet: Outraged that Elian Gonzalez was taken from them, hundreds of Cuban-American protesters took to a major road here today, burning tires and throwing rocks as police officers in riot gear moved in, firing tear gas and making hundreds of arrests.   ...
lead_paragraph: Outraged that Elian Gonzalez was taken from them, hundreds of Cuban-American protesters took to a major road here today, burning tires and throwing rocks as police officers in riot gear moved in, firing tear gas and making hundreds of arrests. Roaming along Flagler Street, a four-lane avenue that cuts east-west through Little Havana not far from the house where 6-year-old Elian had stayed, the demonstrators overturned Dumpsters and threw old appliances and garbage into the street. The police initially appeared to fall back along the perimeter of the troubled streets, allowing the protesters, many of them young Cuban-Americans carrying Cuban flags and placards denouncing the Clinton Administration, to slow traffic.

keywords: DELAY, TOM; GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION; PUBLIC OPINION; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CUBAN-AMERICANS
headline: Raid in Miami Opens New Front In Struggle Over the Cuban Boy
snippet: Both the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez and the federal government battled to sway public opinion today by mustering new details about the raid to return the boy to his father, focusing on the issues of tactics and trust during the 48 hours...
lead_paragraph: Both the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez and the federal government battled to sway public opinion today by mustering new details about the raid to return the boy to his father, focusing on the issues of tactics and trust during the 48 hours leading up to the predawn operation. The Justice Department revealed that negotiators with close ties to Attorney General Janet Reno were on the phone with her when the raid occurred, having tried until the last minutes to broker a deal that would have resulted in a peaceful transfer of Elian to his father.

keywords: PORTUGAL; PORTO SEGURO (BRAZIL); BRAZIL; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; HOLIDAYS AND SPECIAL OCCASIONS; HISTORY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: 500 Years Later, Brazil Looks Its Past in the Face
snippet: It was envisioned as a feel-good patriotic festival like the American Bicentennial. But the Brazilian government should have known that its plans to mark the 500th anniversary of the landing of the Portuguese were doomed when an irate Indian chief...
lead_paragraph: It was envisioned as a feel-good patriotic festival like the American Bicentennial. But the Brazilian government should have known that its plans to mark the 500th anniversary of the landing of the Portuguese were doomed when an irate Indian chief marched into Congress earlier this month, drew his bow and arrow and threatened to kill the Senate president. Sure enough, the yearlong commemoration got off to a bumpy start on Saturday, when military police officers used tear gas, nightsticks and rubber bullets to disperse 2,000 Indian-led demonstrators taking part in a ''march of the excluded'' in Porto Seguro, the focal point of the official celebrations.

headline: SENATE WILL HOLD HEARINGS ON RAID ON HOUSE IN MIAMI
snippet: The political storm over Elian Gonzalez grew fiercer today as the Republican leadership of the Senate called for hearings on the Justice Department's decision to use armed agents to seize the 6-year-old boy, and as Vice President Al Gore distanced...
lead_paragraph: The political storm over Elian Gonzalez grew fiercer today as the Republican leadership of the Senate called for hearings on the Justice Department's decision to use armed agents to seize the 6-year-old boy, and as Vice President Al Gore distanced himself again from the government's handling of the case. Attorney General Janet Reno defended the raid in meetings today on Capitol Hill, but her answers did not satisfy Republican leaders.

headline: Castro Emerges as Conflict's Clear Winner
snippet: At the corner of Flagler Street and 22nd Avenue, a procession of cars filled with teenagers, salsa music blaring, crawled slowly across the intersection with Cuban flags fluttering from radio antennas and a big American flag flying upside down, in...
lead_paragraph: At the corner of Flagler Street and 22nd Avenue, a procession of cars filled with teenagers, salsa music blaring, crawled slowly across the intersection with Cuban flags fluttering from radio antennas and a big American flag flying upside down, in scorn. In Little Havana, in the days since Elian Gonzalez was taken from his Miami relatives' home in a blur of tear gas and armed federal agents, upside-down flags and disdain for the United States are fashionable.

keywords: LONDON (ENG); BERLIN (GERMANY); MAY DAY; LABOR; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: May Day Is Marked With Demonstrations On Right and Left
snippet: Anti-capitalist protesters clashed with the police today in central London, tearing down the golden arches of a McDonald's and spray-painting a hammer and sickle on a statue of Winston Churchill in a May Day protest.    In Berlin, a march against...
lead_paragraph: Anti-capitalist protesters clashed with the police today in central London, tearing down the golden arches of a McDonald's and spray-painting a hammer and sickle on a statue of Winston Churchill in a May Day protest. In Berlin, a march against ''capitalism and imperialism'' this evening erupted into violence in the Kreuzberg neighborhood, a stronghold of leftist activism. More than 100 police officers were injured as they used water cannons, tear gas and nightsticks against a crowd of 10,000 anarchists. At least three dozen leftists were arrested.

headline: Suspected Drug Trafficker Seized in Shootout in Mexico
snippet: A major drug trafficker who officials said oversaw daily smuggling operations for the Tijuana drug cartel has been arrested and charged with racketeering and murder, Mexican authorities said today.    The trafficker, Ismael Higuera Guerrero, was...
lead_paragraph: A major drug trafficker who officials said oversaw daily smuggling operations for the Tijuana drug cartel has been arrested and charged with racketeering and murder, Mexican authorities said today. The trafficker, Ismael Higuera Guerrero, was seized on Wednesday in what American officials called a major victory in the fight against drugs. He was captured after traffickers and soldiers exchanged gunfire and the soldiers lobbed tear gas grenades into a Pacific coast mansion at Ensenada, 60 miles south of Tijuana, the authorities said.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    U.S. and Britain Agree To Aid U.N. in Sierra Leone  The United States and Britain will help bail out a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone that appears to be overwhelmed, with rebels killing civilians in the...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 U.S. and Britain Agree To Aid U.N. in Sierra Leone The United States and Britain will help bail out a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone that appears to be overwhelmed, with rebels killing civilians in the capital, Freetown, and holding more than 500 peacekeepers hostage. Britain will send about 700 troops to secure the airport, so that Europeans can leave. The Clinton administration agreed to provide transport planes. A1

lead_paragraph: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas today to break up a demonstration by students protesting a 17-year-old novel they said insulted Islam. At the height of the protest this morning at Al Azhar University, the most prestigious Islamic educational institution in the Middle East, about 2,000 students hurled rocks and insults at the police and chanted ''God is great!'' and ''Back to Islam!''

keywords: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION AGAINST TORTURE; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE
headline: Forum on Torture Hears of U.S. Efforts to End Police Brutality
snippet: In its first report on its compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Torture, the United States today defended its efforts to eliminate any such practices, including police brutality and inmate abuse, which human rights advocates maintain...
lead_paragraph: In its first report on its compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Torture, the United States today defended its efforts to eliminate any such practices, including police brutality and inmate abuse, which human rights advocates maintain are regular occurrences in America. The United States, like the 117 other countries that have signed the 1984 convention, is obliged to detail to the body's review committee every four years incidents of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment of its citizens and to describe the steps taken to stamp out such practices.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: ASIA    INDONESIA: ACEH TRUCE -- The government and representatives of separatist rebels from Aceh Province signed an agreement described as a ''humanitarian pause,'' resulting in the first cease-fire in more than two decades. While both sides...
lead_paragraph: ASIA INDONESIA: ACEH TRUCE -- The government and representatives of separatist rebels from Aceh Province signed an agreement described as a ''humanitarian pause,'' resulting in the first cease-fire in more than two decades. While both sides welcomed the truce, signed at an undisclosed location in Geneva, as a milestone, both sides were quick to qualify it. The rebels pledged to continue pushing for independence, and Jakarta ruled out recognizing the insurgents. The cease-fire will begin June 2. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; TRAVEL AND VACATIONS
headline: Seattle
snippet: Seattle certainly made a name for itself last December as host to the World Trade Organization meeting. The boosters' idea of using the summit to show off their city as a world-class friend to free trade didn't exactly pan out, amid all the...
lead_paragraph: Seattle certainly made a name for itself last December as host to the World Trade Organization meeting. The boosters' idea of using the summit to show off their city as a world-class friend to free trade didn't exactly pan out, amid all the demonstrations and the tear gas, but many residents think that the raucous protests against globalization amounted to a badge of honor for Seattle. Now the long-running tension here, between those who revel in the high-tech, high-wealth place Seattle has become and those who fret that the city is losing its quirky small-town charm, has a new focus: next month, a museum designed by Frank Gehry, known as the Experience Music Project, opens at the base of the Space Needle. Wildly curvy and colorful, built roughly in the shape of a guitar with the Seattle Center's monorail running through it, the museum is a celebration of modern music and includes a sound lab that, the museum says, lets you ''plug in, jam, dance, wail, scratch, learn, connect and, ultimately, experience the euphoria of making music.'' Some consider the building a brilliant addition to the architectural scene; some call it a curse on the civic landscape. Come and judge for yourself.

headline: New Arab-Israeli Strains Explode Into Street Clashes
snippet: Thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza poured into the streets today for angry protests, some of which were marked by violent confrontations with Israeli troops that recalled scenes from the intifada, or uprising, of the late 1980's.    ...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza poured into the streets today for angry protests, some of which were marked by violent confrontations with Israeli troops that recalled scenes from the intifada, or uprising, of the late 1980's. The Israelis soldiers used rubber-coated bullets and, according to witnesses, some live ammunition, and the Palestinians hurled stones and firebombs. In the northern west bank town of Qalqilya, one Palestinian man was killed by a rubber bullet to the chest.

lead_paragraph: For nearly four hours, Palestinians were riveted today by the spectacle of Israeli troops on Ramallah's northern outskirts furiously trading automatic-weapon fire with gunmen -- many of them members of uniformed Palestinian security forces. ''Games,'' tersely commented a Palestinian officer in the red beret and camouflage of the military intelligence services. ''Games between them and us.''

headline: Palestinian Forces Exchange Gunfire With Israeli Troops
snippet: For the first time in almost four years, Israelis and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank today as a wave of violent protest swept through the Palestinian territories. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won his...
lead_paragraph: For the first time in almost four years, Israelis and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank today as a wave of violent protest swept through the Palestinian territories. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won his Parliament's approval to cede three villages near Jerusalem to the Palestinian Authority in an effort to advance the peace talks. The gun battle, which broke out at a junction near the Palestinian city of Ramallah, accompanied chaotic confrontations throughout the West Bank and Gaza, in which Israeli forces suppressed unruly Palestinian demonstrators by shooting tear gas, rubber-coated bullets and, at some sites, live ammunition into crowds charging at them with stones and firebombs.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: MIDDLE EAST    PALESTINIANS: CLASHES CONTINUE -- Sporadic clashes between young Palestinians and Israeli troops continued in the West Bank and near Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets at...
lead_paragraph: MIDDLE EAST PALESTINIANS: CLASHES CONTINUE -- Sporadic clashes between young Palestinians and Israeli troops continued in the West Bank and near Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters who threw stones and firebombs; they also reported that Israeli posts had been fired upon and that they responded with live fire. Deborah Sontag (NYT) ISRAEL: TYING UP BARAK -- Two opposition bills that could tie Prime Minister Ehud Barak's hands in negotiations with the Palestinians passed preliminary votes, although both require three more readings to become law. They would require absolute majority approval of the Parliament to change the municipal boundaries of Jerualem and to allow the right of return of Palestinian refugees to Israel. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

keywords: COPENHAGEN (DENMARK); GALATASAREY; ARSENAL; UEFA CUP (SOCCER); VIOLENCE; SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Galatasaray Wins UEFA Cup After Day of Rioting by Fans
snippet: Galatasaray became the first Turkish team to win the UEFA Cup when it beat Arsenal of England, 4-1, in a penalty shootout yesterday in Copenhagen after a day of fan violence.     The game ended 0-0 after regulation and extra time.
lead_paragraph: Galatasaray became the first Turkish team to win the UEFA Cup when it beat Arsenal of England, 4-1, in a penalty shootout yesterday in Copenhagen after a day of fan violence. The game ended 0-0 after regulation and extra time.

keywords: DRASKOVIC, VUK; DJINDJIC, ZORAN; BELGRADE (SERBIA); SERBIA; MONTENEGRO; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; TELEVISION; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Protests Flare As Belgrade Takes Control Of TV Station
snippet: About 20,000 people gathered again tonight to protest the Serbian government's seizure of the main opposition television station here, Studio B, but as they were dispersing, policemen in riot gear charged them.    There were clashes with the...
lead_paragraph: About 20,000 people gathered again tonight to protest the Serbian government's seizure of the main opposition television station here, Studio B, but as they were dispersing, policemen in riot gear charged them. There were clashes with the demonstrators, some of whom then threw stones and homemade firebombs at the police, who responded in turn with truncheons and a lavish use of tear gas. At least 19 people were hurt, beaten by the police, and ambulances picked them up at City Hall, where once again opposition political leaders conferred with one another but did not address the crowd.

keywords: ABDULLAH II; EGYPT; IRAQ; KUWAIT; MIDDLE EAST; JORDAN; UNITED ARAB EMIRATES; SAUDI ARABIA; FOREIGN INVESTMENTS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Jordan's Long Road To the Free-Trade Club
snippet: MOHAMMED A. HALAIQAH'S trip to Seattle last November was to have been the culmination of his career. As Jordan's most experienced trade negotiator, he had spent five years arduously preparing for his country's entry into the World Trade Organization....
lead_paragraph: MOHAMMED A. HALAIQAH'S trip to Seattle last November was to have been the culmination of his career. As Jordan's most experienced trade negotiator, he had spent five years arduously preparing for his country's entry into the World Trade Organization. After a thorough and painful overhaul of its tariffs and investment rules, putting domestic industries like pharmaceuticals at risk, Jordan was finally poised to become the W.T.O.'s next full member. As the only country scheduled to join the group at its Seattle summit meeting, it hoped to attract worldwide publicity -- and American investment in the high-technology industries it sees as the key to its future.

keywords: BARAK, EHUD; JERICHO (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: ISRAEL SUMMONING NEGOTIATORS HOME AFTER NEW ATTACK
snippet: Prime Minister Ehud Barak recalled his peace negotiators from Sweden today after a firebomb critically wounded a 2-year-old Israeli girl in a car passing through the sleepy Palestinian-ruled city of Jericho.    The attack prompted Israel to block...
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Ehud Barak recalled his peace negotiators from Sweden today after a firebomb critically wounded a 2-year-old Israeli girl in a car passing through the sleepy Palestinian-ruled city of Jericho. The attack prompted Israel to block entrance to the Palestinian territories, declaring them unsafe for Israelis and tourists, and temporarily undercut a year of normalization efforts. The incident also undermined Palestinian attempts to restore order, although the Palestinians did clamp down on street fighting for the first time in 10 days.

keywords: CLINTON, BILL; FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; LIMA (PERU); PERU; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: As Protests Grow Violent, Peru Says Runoff Will Go On
snippet: The government of President Alberto K. Fujimori said today that a runoff presidential election would be held on Sunday as scheduled despite nationwide protests and calls from Washington and other allies that it be postponed to ensure a clean ballot...
lead_paragraph: The government of President Alberto K. Fujimori said today that a runoff presidential election would be held on Sunday as scheduled despite nationwide protests and calls from Washington and other allies that it be postponed to ensure a clean ballot count. The decision appeared to increase the possibility of economic sanctions against Peru after it ignored the recommendations of the Clinton administration, the Organization of American States and several European and Latin American governments.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: ASIA    JAPAN: PREMIER APOLOGIZES -- Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori apologized for remarks last week that seemed to endorse emperor worship. After several days of heavy criticism, Mr. Mori, left, expressed regret in a tense news conference that his...
lead_paragraph: ASIA JAPAN: PREMIER APOLOGIZES -- Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori apologized for remarks last week that seemed to endorse emperor worship. After several days of heavy criticism, Mr. Mori, left, expressed regret in a tense news conference that his remarks had caused misunderstanding, but declined to retract his statement altogether. In his original remarks, which critics said echoed Japan's prewar militarism, Mr. Mori said Japan was ''a divine nation with the emperor at its core.'' Howard French (NYT) SRI LANKA: MILITARY PLEA -- The government asked retired officers and policemen to re-enlist in the armed forces in hopes of bolstering 30,000 troops under assault from separatist ethnic Tamils in the northern Jaffna Peninsula. Those who rejoined would take the noncombat positions of younger soldiers, who would then be shifted to the front lines. The rebels threatened a bloodbath for soldiers who failed to surrender by today. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

keywords: MONTREAL CANADIENS; HOCKEY, ICE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: Rocket Richard, Montreal's Goal-Scoring Hero, Dies at 78
snippet: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal-scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died...
lead_paragraph: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal-scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died yesterday in a hospital in Montreal. He was 78. He had been suffering from stomach cancer and Parkinson's disease, and he was hospitalized early this month.

keywords: TOLEDO, ALEJANDRO; FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; MORALES BERMUDEZ, FRANCISCO; PERU; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTION RESULTS
headline: FUJIMORI IS VICTOR IN PERU'S RUNOFF AS PROTESTS GROW
snippet: In a runoff vote long on protest but short on suspense, President Alberto K. Fujimori swept to victory today against an opponent who had urged his supporters to abstain because of what he called vote fraud and an array of campaign irregularities.    ...
lead_paragraph: In a runoff vote long on protest but short on suspense, President Alberto K. Fujimori swept to victory today against an opponent who had urged his supporters to abstain because of what he called vote fraud and an array of campaign irregularities. Mr. Fujimori had hoped for a third landslide victory that would venerate his successes in defeating two terrorist groups and hyperinflation and making peace with Ecuador after decades of border tensions. Instead, the 61-year-old president won a hollow victory leaving the country badly polarized and facing possible economic sanctions just as it tries to emerge from recession.

keywords: SPORTS OF THE TIMES (TIMES COLUMN); RICHARD, MAURICE; MONTREAL CANADIENS; HOCKEY, ICE
headline: Richard Is Real Rocket, the Only Rocket
snippet: OTHER athletes are known today as the Rocket, notably pitcher Roger Clemens, the tennis legend Rod Laver and receiver Raghib Ismael, but they plagiarized the nickname. To anyone who saw Maurice Richard play hockey, he was not only the original...
lead_paragraph: OTHER athletes are known today as the Rocket, notably pitcher Roger Clemens, the tennis legend Rod Laver and receiver Raghib Ismael, but they plagiarized the nickname. To anyone who saw Maurice Richard play hockey, he was not only the original Rocket, he also deserved to be remembered as the real Rocket, the only Rocket. Just as Babe defined George Herman Ruth, Rocket defined the Montreal Canadiens' folk hero who set all the National Hockey League goal-scoring records that Gordie Howe and Wayne Gretzky eventually shattered.

keywords: MONTREAL CANADIENS; HOCKEY, ICE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Rocket Richard, Montreal's Goal-Scoring Hero, Dies at 78
snippet: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died...
lead_paragraph: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died Saturday in a hospital in Montreal. He was 78. He had been suffering from stomach cancer and Parkinson's disease, and he was hospitalized early this month.
