headline: 4 Die in Election Violence in Northern Egypt
snippet: The police fired live ammunition and tear gas today in clashes with voters in three northern villages. Elsewhere, fistfights between supporters of rival candidates in the parliamentary elections turned to gunfire.     As night fell, 4 people were...
lead_paragraph: The police fired live ammunition and tear gas today in clashes with voters in three northern villages. Elsewhere, fistfights between supporters of rival candidates in the parliamentary elections turned to gunfire. As night fell, 4 people were dead and more than 60 people injured.

keywords: IVORY COAST; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY; ISLAM
headline: 2 Religions Clashing in Ivory Coast
snippet: Up a winding street here in a sprawling, working-class neighborhood, a mosque, a Roman Catholic church and a Protestant church have long stood close to one another -- symbols of the religious and ethnic tolerance that made this country the envy of...
lead_paragraph: Up a winding street here in a sprawling, working-class neighborhood, a mosque, a Roman Catholic church and a Protestant church have long stood close to one another -- symbols of the religious and ethnic tolerance that made this country the envy of other Africans. But after a popular revolt that began against a military dictator on Oct. 24 quickly degenerated into deadly political clashes, Christians attacked the Aisha Niangon Mosque, in this neighborhood, Yopougon. The walls surrounding the building are pockmarked with holes the assailants used as toeholds to clamber over. In the courtyard, the burned-out skeleton of the imam's car lay not too far from a palm tree that had also been set on fire.

keywords: DANFORTH, JOHN C; JOHNSTON, BILL; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; ETHICS
headline: Prosecutor Is Indicted in Davidian Inquiry
snippet: A federal prosecutor who warned Attorney General Janet Reno last year that Justice Department officials might have withheld evidence in the investigation of the 1993 standoff with the Branch Davidians outside Waco, Tex., was indicted today on charges...
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor who warned Attorney General Janet Reno last year that Justice Department officials might have withheld evidence in the investigation of the 1993 standoff with the Branch Davidians outside Waco, Tex., was indicted today on charges of obstructing justice and making false statements to investigators. The five-count federal indictment of the prosecutor, Bill Johnston, was initiated by John C. Danforth, the special counsel looking into the standoff.

keywords: OBAIYAT, HUSSEIN; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; BETHLEHEM (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; FATAH, AL; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; PALESTINIANS
headline: After Funeral for a Slain Palestinian Paramilitary Leader, More Death for Both Sides
snippet: In Manger Square, spiffed up just last Christmas for what was supposed to be a banner year for the now-dead Palestinian tourism industry, thousands of Muslims bowed in prayer today to mourn a paramilitary leader assassinated by the Israelis.    The...
lead_paragraph: In Manger Square, spiffed up just last Christmas for what was supposed to be a banner year for the now-dead Palestinian tourism industry, thousands of Muslims bowed in prayer today to mourn a paramilitary leader assassinated by the Israelis. The dead man, Hussein Obaiyat, 34, a baker by trade, a gun collector by avocation, was not well known here beyond his clan and the paramilitary unit that he ran for Yasir Arafat's Fatah organization. But when Israel used helicopter gunships to kill him on Thursday, and killing two middle-aged women as well, it instantly secured him a place in the pantheon of Palestinian heroes.

keywords: MARCENARO, RICARDO; PANIAGUA, VALENTIN; FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; HILDEBRANDT, MARTHA; PERU; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
headline: Peru Opposition Picks Successor for Fujimori's Ally in Congress
snippet: Two days after ousting a head of Congress loyal to President Alberto K. Fujimori, opposition lawmakers named their candidate today to lead the legislature, threatening to undermine further Mr. Fujimori's fading hold on power.    Also today, the...
lead_paragraph: Two days after ousting a head of Congress loyal to President Alberto K. Fujimori, opposition lawmakers named their candidate today to lead the legislature, threatening to undermine further Mr. Fujimori's fading hold on power. Also today, the police used tear gas to disperse hundreds of leftist-led construction workers who were demonstrating outside the Government Palace. The protesters carried an effigy with two heads, Mr. Fujimori's and that of the former spy chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, in a cage. Tear gas canisters flew after some protesters, carrying wood poles and shouting, ''There is no president!'' charged at the police.

keywords: GANTZ, BENJAMIN; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS
headline: Resolute Commander of Israeli Forces in the West Bank
snippet: It is Wednesday, and just another day at the office for Brig. Gen. Benjamin Gantz, commander of Israel's forces throughout the West Bank.     In the morning, undercover commando units abducted 15 Palestinians who Israel said were Fatah militia...
lead_paragraph: It is Wednesday, and just another day at the office for Brig. Gen. Benjamin Gantz, commander of Israel's forces throughout the West Bank. In the morning, undercover commando units abducted 15 Palestinians who Israel said were Fatah militia members responsible for the shooting deaths of two soldiers and a teacher. In the evening, a few hundred yards from his fortress headquarters, General Gantz's troops battled rioters, firing tear gas, rubber-coated bullets and sporadic bursts of live ammunition.

keywords: WILLIAMS, HOSEA; KING, MARTIN LUTHER JR; BLACKS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Hosea Williams, 74, Rights Crusader, Dies
snippet: Hosea Williams, a field general for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in civil rights clashes of the 1960's, and more recently an Atlanta politician with a talent for confounding friends and enemies alike, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 74 and...
lead_paragraph: Hosea Williams, a field general for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in civil rights clashes of the 1960's, and more recently an Atlanta politician with a talent for confounding friends and enemies alike, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 74 and had been suffering from cancer. Rambunctious, fearless and blunt, Mr. Williams was just the man for a certain kind of work in Dr. King's efforts to desegregate the South. Dr. King called him ''my wild man, my Castro,'' and deployed him as heavy artillery to soften up resistance.

headline: The Endgame in Peru
snippet: Pressure mounted on Alberto Fujimori, president of Peru, to leave office before his announced July resignation date.     First, the state prosecutor asked the attorney general to investigate a Colombian news magazine article that in 1989 Mr. Fujimori...
lead_paragraph: Pressure mounted on Alberto Fujimori, president of Peru, to leave office before his announced July resignation date. First, the state prosecutor asked the attorney general to investigate a Colombian news magazine article that in 1989 Mr. Fujimori received money from Pablo Escobar, the Colombian drug baron who was later killed.

keywords: HAVIVIAN, YORAM; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; JORDAN; GAZA STRIP; JORDANIAN ISLAMIC RESISTANCE MOVEMENT; AHMED DAKAMSHE UNIT; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Israeli Diplomat Wounded in Jordan, but Fighting Tapers Off
snippet: An Israeli diplomat was shot and slightly wounded outside his home in Jordan today, raising fresh concerns that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is affecting neighboring countries that have already made peace with Israel.    But the conflict...
lead_paragraph: An Israeli diplomat was shot and slightly wounded outside his home in Jordan today, raising fresh concerns that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is affecting neighboring countries that have already made peace with Israel. But the conflict continued to taper off here, with Israel's senior security officials reporting a decline in stone-throwing and shooting incidents in the West Bank and Gaza. The Israelis also said the Palestinian police were making a visible effort to prevent shooting for the first time since the violence began in late September.

keywords: FOX QUESADA, VICENTE; MEXICO CITY (MEXICO); MEXICO; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: In Mexico, a Man With a Badge Isn't the Good Guy
snippet: Ramiro Ayala Zambrano and his wife, Edith, have raised four children in a gritty barrio brimming with violence and corruption, so they know an outlaw when they see one.    In their eyes, the worst criminals here in a neighborhood called Tepito are...
lead_paragraph: Ramiro Ayala Zambrano and his wife, Edith, have raised four children in a gritty barrio brimming with violence and corruption, so they know an outlaw when they see one. In their eyes, the worst criminals here in a neighborhood called Tepito are not the thousands who sell stolen stereos, handguns, endangered birds or pirated videocassettes from the maze of concession stands that crowd the sidewalks. The couple is most afraid of the few dozen bad guys who prowl in police uniforms.

keywords: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: An Orderly Anniversary for a Great Global Trade Protest
snippet: For the people in sea turtle costumes, for the masked anarchists, for the protesters on stilts who took a rubber bullet with pride, the Battle of Seattle one year ago today has become the Alamo in their fight against corporate globalization.     But...
lead_paragraph: For the people in sea turtle costumes, for the masked anarchists, for the protesters on stilts who took a rubber bullet with pride, the Battle of Seattle one year ago today has become the Alamo in their fight against corporate globalization. But as they gathered today on the anniversary of the ruckus that led to more than 600 arrests, and nearly shut down the World Trade Organization's ministerial meetings in Seattle, protesters could do little more than recall the near-legendary days of tear gas and smashed windows, and shout at Christmas shoppers to holster their credit cards.

headline: World Briefing
snippet: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: HUME STEPS DOWN  John Hume, the Nobel Prize-winning architect of the Northern Ireland peace accord, resigned from the new power-sharing assembly that the settlement created, citing the workload involved with being a...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE NORTHERN IRELAND: HUME STEPS DOWN John Hume, the Nobel Prize-winning architect of the Northern Ireland peace accord, resigned from the new power-sharing assembly that the settlement created, citing the workload involved with being a member of the British and European Parliaments and leader of the Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party. Mr. Hume, 63, who announced his decision this fall, will be replaced by a party member without the need for a by-election. Warren Hoge (NYT) BRITAIN: PARATROOPERS CHARGED Three British paratroopers have been charged in connection with the July 3 shooting deaths in Pristina of two Kosovo Liberation Army fighters who were firing celebratory shots into the air from the roof of a car. The Ministry of Defense did not identify the soldiers, who were members of the NATO peacekeeping force, or specify what the charges were. They remain in service pending court-martial. Warren Hoge (NYT)

keywords: EUROPE; NICE (FRANCE); EUROPEAN UNION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Europeans, and Protesters, Meet on the Riviera
snippet: As protesters clashed violently with the police in the streets, European Union leaders began a crucial three-day summit meeting today by promising to come up with a new decision-making structure that would allow them to accept new countries as...
lead_paragraph: As protesters clashed violently with the police in the streets, European Union leaders began a crucial three-day summit meeting today by promising to come up with a new decision-making structure that would allow them to accept new countries as members. When the leaders arrived today at this Riviera city, so much tear gas filled the streets that it seeped into the convention hall's air conditioning system. At one point, the fumes forced the French president, Jacques Chirac, to sneeze and blow his nose as he waited to have his picture taken.

snippet: As the new year passed through various time zones last Dec. 31, television cameras captured the glow and dazzle of one millennium celebration after another: jubilant, confetti-covered masses in rolling moments of shared euphoria.    Then there was...
lead_paragraph: As the new year passed through various time zones last Dec. 31, television cameras captured the glow and dazzle of one millennium celebration after another: jubilant, confetti-covered masses in rolling moments of shared euphoria. Then there was Denver.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Rally Against Possible Clemency
snippet: About 500 active and retired F.B.I. agents and employees marched to the White House today in a highly unusual protest, angered that President Clinton might commute the life sentence of an American Indian activist convicted of killing two F.B.I....
lead_paragraph: About 500 active and retired F.B.I. agents and employees marched to the White House today in a highly unusual protest, angered that President Clinton might commute the life sentence of an American Indian activist convicted of killing two F.B.I. agents 25 years ago. Many agents wore their F.B.I. badges pinned to their coats as they walked two-by-two in a long, silent protest around the Ellipse, the park immediately south of the White House, to the presidential mansion. A banner held by agents at the front of the line said, ''Never Forget.''

keywords: JOHN PAUL II; HAIDER, JORG; ITALY; AUSTRIA; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Right-Winger From Austria Meets Pope Amid Clamor
snippet: In an encounter bracketed by political clashes and public protest, Pope John Paul II met briefly today at the Vatican with Jorg Haider, the far-right Austrian politician, who is persona non grata to many European leaders.     Mr. Haider, leading a...
lead_paragraph: In an encounter bracketed by political clashes and public protest, Pope John Paul II met briefly today at the Vatican with Jorg Haider, the far-right Austrian politician, who is persona non grata to many European leaders. Mr. Haider, leading a group of 250 Austrians and presenting a gift of an 80-foot Christmas tree from Carinthia, the state of which he is governor, did not receive a private audience with the pope. The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said Mr. Haider and Bishop Egon Kapellari of Carinthia spoke with the pope for a few minutes before the meeting only to exchange greetings.

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); RUSSIA; SERBIA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: 2 Serbs Die in Weekend Clashes In Tense Kosovo Border Region
snippet: Violence continued over the weekend in the tense border area between Kosovo and the rest of Serbia. On Saturday, two Serbs died and one was wounded in a melee with peacekeepers in the town of Leposavic.    Today, gunmen fired on a joint...
lead_paragraph: Violence continued over the weekend in the tense border area between Kosovo and the rest of Serbia. On Saturday, two Serbs died and one was wounded in a melee with peacekeepers in the town of Leposavic. Today, gunmen fired on a joint American-Russian patrol as it tried to seal the boundary between Kosovo and part of southern Serbia where Albanian rebels have been challenging Yugoslav forces, the United States Army said. Kosovo is a province of Serbia, which is the dominant republic remaining in Yugoslavia.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: EUROPE    TURKEY: PRISON SIEGE ENDS -- Soldiers used tear gas to subdue about 400 inmates at a prison in Istanbul, ending five days of raids to reassert government control over 20 prisons across the country. At least 27 people died. The raids were...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE TURKEY: PRISON SIEGE ENDS -- Soldiers used tear gas to subdue about 400 inmates at a prison in Istanbul, ending five days of raids to reassert government control over 20 prisons across the country. At least 27 people died. The raids were made after hunger strikers refused to end fasts protesting transfers from prisons where up to 100 inmates shared a dormitory-style room to prisons with small cells. Inmates say they fear torture and isolation in the new cells. Douglas Frantz (NYT) SPAIN: RUSSIAN GETS BAIL -- A judge ordered Vladimir Gusinsky, left, to be released from jail and confined to his luxury villa in southern Spain under police guard while the Russian media magnate fought Moscow's efforts to extradite him. Judge Baltasar Garzon ruled Mr. Gusinsky must pay $5.55 million in bail to secure his freedom after being detained 10 days ago on an international arrest warrant sought by Russia, where he faces fraud charges. (Reuters)

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; GORE, AL; FLORIDA; VOTING MACHINES; SUITS AND LITIGATION; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2000; ELECTIONS
headline: THE 43rd PRESIDENT; Excerpts From Florida Supreme Court Ruling on Ballot-Counting Methods
snippet: Following are excerpts from the Florida Supreme Court's decision yesterday that said the State Legislature should develop a standard for counting ballots. The court issued a per curiam or unsigned decision in the case of Albert Gore Jr. and Joseph I....
lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Florida Supreme Court's decision yesterday that said the State Legislature should develop a standard for counting ballots. The court issued a per curiam or unsigned decision in the case of Albert Gore Jr. and Joseph I. Lieberman v. Katherine Harris as Secretary of State. Justices Leander B. Shaw, Harry Lee Anstead, R. Fred Lewis, Barbara J. Pariente and Peggy A. Quince concurred, with Justices Shaw and Pariente filing separate opinions. Justice Major B. Harding and Chief Justice Charles T. Wells concurred in result only, with the chief justice filing a separate one-sentence opinion. FROM THE OPINION This case is before the court on remand from the United States Supreme Court. In our previous opinion, we ordered the Circuit Court of Leon County to tabulate by hand 9,000 contested Dade County ballots. This court further held that relief would require manual recounts in all Florida counties where undervotes existed which had not previously been subject to manual tabulation.

keywords: SAMAN, MUHAMMAD; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; NETZARIM (ISRAEL); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
headline: Playing War
snippet: A little before noon on the last day of his life, 15-year-old Ahmed Abutayeh invented a toothache. This was the first time he had ever complained of a health problem in school, so his science teacher wrote him a permission slip to visit a nearby...
lead_paragraph: A little before noon on the last day of his life, 15-year-old Ahmed Abutayeh invented a toothache. This was the first time he had ever complained of a health problem in school, so his science teacher wrote him a permission slip to visit a nearby clinic. Ahmed shouldered his plaid-patterned book bag and walked out of the Rimal Boys' School and onto the chaotic streets of Beach Camp, where 75,000 Palestinian refugees are corralled into a half-square-mile block, at the northern end of the Gaza Strip. It was Nov. 1 of this year. The previous day, Ahmed had sold his pet nightingale for a few shekels, and now, carrying this money, he caught a taxi and asked to be driven to a place called Karni crossing. He was wearing the nicest shirt he owned, a light blue button-down, and a few dabs of his father's cologne. On the outside of his book bag, in blue ink, he had inscribed a four-word epitaph: ''The Martyr Ahmed Abutayeh.'' Karni crossing, as its name implies, is an intersection. It's where the Karni Road crosses the so-called Green Line, the razor-wire border dividing the occupied territory of Gaza from Israel proper. The Gaza Strip is a place small enough to be easily fenced. It pokes from the northern end of the Egypt-Israel border and follows the shoreline of the Mediterranean Sea; its silhouette is roughly that of a pistol, aimed just west of Jerusalem. Karni crossing is at a point about midway along the pistol's barrel.

keywords: THABET, THABET; KAHANE, TALIA; CLINTON, BILL; KAHANE, BINYAMIN; KAHANE, MEIR; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS
headline: Son of Slain Rabbi Kahane Dies With Wife in West Bank Ambush
snippet: Binyamin Kahane, a radical right-wing settler and son of the late Rabbi Meir Kahane, was killed today along with his wife in an ambush shooting in the West Bank.     Hours after the attack, which came a decade after the Brooklyn-born Meir Kahane was...
lead_paragraph: Binyamin Kahane, a radical right-wing settler and son of the late Rabbi Meir Kahane, was killed today along with his wife in an ambush shooting in the West Bank. Hours after the attack, which came a decade after the Brooklyn-born Meir Kahane was assassinated in New York City, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a senior Palestinian health official, Dr. Thabet Thabet, near his West Bank home.

keywords: GREAT BRITAIN; SOCCER
headline: Manchester United Extends Lead
snippet: Arsenal suffered a damaging blow to its Premier League title aspirations yesterday in a 1-0 loss to Charlton Athletic. Jonatan Johansson's first-half header gave Charlton the victory, and enabled Manchester United to widen its lead over Arsenal to 11...
lead_paragraph: Arsenal suffered a damaging blow to its Premier League title aspirations yesterday in a 1-0 loss to Charlton Athletic. Jonatan Johansson's first-half header gave Charlton the victory, and enabled Manchester United to widen its lead over Arsenal to 11 points after it beat West Ham, 3-1. Nelson Vivas's penalty kick in the 75th minute was saved by Charlton goalkeeper Dean Kiely to conclude a dismal start to the new year for the Gunners. Arsenal also lost two points on Saturday when it wasted a 2-0 lead and settled for a 2-2 tie against Sunderland.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: THE AMERICAS    CHILE: PINOCHET STARTS TESTS  Gen. Augusto Pinochet obeyed a judicial order by entering a military hospital to begin several days of psychological and neurological examinations to test whether he is fit to stand trial on possible...
lead_paragraph: THE AMERICAS CHILE: PINOCHET STARTS TESTS Gen. Augusto Pinochet obeyed a judicial order by entering a military hospital to begin several days of psychological and neurological examinations to test whether he is fit to stand trial on possible murder and kidnapping charges. The start of the examinations culminated nearly a week of legal maneuvering during which the former dicatator's lawyers tried to block the tests as well as an interrogation scheduled for next week. A finding that General Pinochet is mentally impaired could end any future prosecution, but it could also be open to appeal. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

keywords: ARONOFF, MURRAY; FRANCE; MIDDLE EAST; JEWS; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Murray Aronoff, 75; Defended Jews at Sea
snippet: Murray Aronoff, a crew member of a retired steamship, the Exodus 1947, on its aborted voyage to transport 4,500 Jewish refugees from France to Palestine in 1947, died on Dec. 30 at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in...
lead_paragraph: Murray Aronoff, a crew member of a retired steamship, the Exodus 1947, on its aborted voyage to transport 4,500 Jewish refugees from France to Palestine in 1947, died on Dec. 30 at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in Plainview. He was 75. The cause was complications resulting from Alzheimer's disease, said his son, Aaron.

keywords: RENO, JANET; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
headline: Reno Ponders the Future And Reflects on the Past
snippet: For now, at least, the mood seems placidly subdued in the office of the attorney general after nearly eight years of trouble, strife and controversy. At last, the spotlight has shifted away from Janet Reno.    One morning this week, Ms. Reno seemed...
lead_paragraph: For now, at least, the mood seems placidly subdued in the office of the attorney general after nearly eight years of trouble, strife and controversy. At last, the spotlight has shifted away from Janet Reno. One morning this week, Ms. Reno seemed buoyant and jaunty -- in contrast to the grim visage she often displayed at Congressional hearings -- as she contemplated her future outside the government and her return to her home in Miami.

headline: 4 of 7 Texas Fugitives Captured In Colorado as 5th Kills Himself
snippet: For nearly six frantic weeks until today, the search for seven heavily armed escapees from a maximum-security prison in Texas had gone nowhere, an endless trail of useless tips and fruitless leads that led investigators from Mexico to Mississippi to...
lead_paragraph: For nearly six frantic weeks until today, the search for seven heavily armed escapees from a maximum-security prison in Texas had gone nowhere, an endless trail of useless tips and fruitless leads that led investigators from Mexico to Mississippi to New York City. But acting on a tip from local residents, the manhunt today led to a trailer park in this small, rural community about 20 miles west of Colorado Springs, where the fugitives deemed the most dangerous men in America had been quietly hiding since about New Year's Day.

headline: Forum in Switzerland Focuses on U.S. Economic Slowdown
snippet: The slowdown in the American economy will cut the global growth rate but will probably not drag the world into recession, a top International Monetary Fund official told world business and political leaders at an annual economic forum here today.    ...
lead_paragraph: The slowdown in the American economy will cut the global growth rate but will probably not drag the world into recession, a top International Monetary Fund official told world business and political leaders at an annual economic forum here today. The I.M.F.'s deputy director, Stanley Fischer, said the slowdown was causing the fund to predict that growth in the global economy would be considerably lower, ''possibly in the range of 3.5 percent.'' That was scaled back from its prediction of 4.2 percent in September.

keywords: DOHA (QATAR); SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Ideas & Trends; The Next Center of the World
snippet: WHEN the World Trade Organization invited bids to host its next global trade summit, it promised a convention marketer's dream: 6,000 delegates and lobbyists; reels of media attention; the chance to make history.    But just as Geneva-based...
lead_paragraph: WHEN the World Trade Organization invited bids to host its next global trade summit, it promised a convention marketer's dream: 6,000 delegates and lobbyists; reels of media attention; the chance to make history. But just as Geneva-based bureaucrats were preparing to cull applications, the trade body held its 1999 ministerial meeting in Seattle, which became synonymous with tear gas and gridlock.

keywords: LONDONDERRY (NORTHERN IRELAND); NORTHERN IRELAND
headline: Lives; An Unreliable Witness
snippet: No one expected it to end with killing. In 1972, I was a junior TV journalist assigned to watch events in Northern Ireland, which that weekend happened to include a protest march in Derry. At most, I figured there would be the customary low-level...
lead_paragraph: No one expected it to end with killing. In 1972, I was a junior TV journalist assigned to watch events in Northern Ireland, which that weekend happened to include a protest march in Derry. At most, I figured there would be the customary low-level standoff between protesters and the army, some stone-throwing and tear gas. But once the shooting started, that day was destined to be known as Bloody Sunday. My nationalist sources and the police had forecast no real trouble, so I told my bosses at the London network that I would not need a film crew. Like everyone else, I was taken completely by surprise when paratroops burst through barriers, ran toward the crowd and almost instantly began firing. This is the last damn straw! I remember thinking as I crushed my nose into the roadway's asphalt with high-velocity bullets cracking and whining over me. I was 23 and scared witless, but my thoughts came embroidered with bravado. I had covered enough of ''the troubles'' to have been threatened at gunpoint by Protestant paramilitaries and another time been forced to run from I.R.A. sniper fire. Now, I blustered to myself, it is my own national army who's firing at me.

keywords: ZANZIBAR (TANZANIA); TANZANIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Voting Dispute Turns Violent in Zanzibar
snippet: Protesters seeking new elections fought running battles with the police today as violence spread across Tanzania and left as many as 17 people dead.     Opposition officials and doctors said 16 protesters had been killed on Zanzibar's main islands of...
lead_paragraph: Protesters seeking new elections fought running battles with the police today as violence spread across Tanzania and left as many as 17 people dead. Opposition officials and doctors said 16 protesters had been killed on Zanzibar's main islands of Unguja and Pemba as demonstrations across the archipelago calling for a rerun of disputed elections turned violent. One member of the security forces was decapitated, a police official said.

keywords: CHINA; FALUN GONG; AGRICULTURE; LABOR; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Chinese Officials Order Cities To Bolster Riot Police Forces
snippet: The Chinese authorities, facing constant protests by aggrieved workers and farmers and a prospect of unending defiance by die-hard Falun Gong believers,  have ordered cities across the country to augment their anti-riot police.     Reflecting the...
lead_paragraph: The Chinese authorities, facing constant protests by aggrieved workers and farmers and a prospect of unending defiance by die-hard Falun Gong believers, have ordered cities across the country to augment their anti-riot police. Reflecting the leadership's obsession with ''social stability,'' which has reached a new pitch as China seeks to be awarded the 2008 Olympic Games, the Ministry of Public Security has ordered ''intensive efforts'' to build up anti-riot squads and said they are ''expected to play key roles in handling group violence and terrorism cases.''

keywords: WAHID, ABDURRAHMAN; JAKARTA (INDONESIA); BRUNEI; INDONESIA; EMBEZZLEMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Hints of Graft by Indonesian President
snippet: As protests against President Abdurrahman Wahid erupted into violence outside Parliament today, an investigative committee inside submitted a report to lawmakers that suggested that Mr. Wahid acted improperly in two multimillion-dollar corruption...
lead_paragraph: As protests against President Abdurrahman Wahid erupted into violence outside Parliament today, an investigative committee inside submitted a report to lawmakers that suggested that Mr. Wahid acted improperly in two multimillion-dollar corruption scandals. In a closed-door session, the 50-member committee presented the findings of its six-month inquiry into accusations that Mr. Wahid may have been involved in the embezzlement of $3.7 million from a government agency and that he improperly accepted $2 million from the sultan of Brunei.

keywords: CHINA; BEIJING (CHINA); TIANANMEN SQUARE (BEIJING); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Tiananmen's Shadow
snippet: Throughout the spring of 1989, Tiananmen Square, the political heart of Beijing, was engulfed in protests. By June, many of the people filling the square and surrounding streets were spectators with only the vaguest political motives. It was into...
lead_paragraph: Throughout the spring of 1989, Tiananmen Square, the political heart of Beijing, was engulfed in protests. By June, many of the people filling the square and surrounding streets were spectators with only the vaguest political motives. It was into these crowds that the People's Liberation Army opened fire in the early hours of June 4, killing hundreds or even thousands of civilians. No one outside the inner councils of the Chinese government knows for certain how many people died or why. The recently published ''Tiananmen Papers,'' transcripts of government documents reportedly smuggled out of the country by a disaffected Chinese official, claim to tell what happened behind the high red walls of China's leadership compound in the weeks before the massacre. Their appearance suggests that, even within the government, the wounds of Tiananmen still fester, and that some insiders are ready to reassess the wisdom of the decisions that led to the shooting that night.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: EUROPE    BRITAIN, FRANCE: ASYLUM ACCORD -- The two countries agreed to impose tighter controls on their cross-Channel rail link to try to stem record numbers of asylum seekers slipping into Britain. President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Tony...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE BRITAIN, FRANCE: ASYLUM ACCORD -- The two countries agreed to impose tighter controls on their cross-Channel rail link to try to stem record numbers of asylum seekers slipping into Britain. President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Tony Blair, after a day of talks, also called for wider European efforts to tackle the trafficking. France said it would try to ratify by June a pact allowing French and British immigration officers to check passengers boarding the Eurostar train in Paris. (Reuters) NORTHERN IRELAND: FIRM AGAINST SINN FEIN -- David Trimble, first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly and leader of the province's largest Protestant party, said he would continue to bar ministers from Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from attending cross-border meetings with their counterparts in the Irish government because of the I.R.A.'s refusal to begin disarming. A Belfast High Court judge ruled the ban unlawful last month, but Mr. Trimble is appealing the decision. Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: World Briefing
snippet: EUROPE    POLICY ON MAD COW DISEASE -- The director of farm policy for the European Union proposed far-reaching changes to deal with the financial and biological consequences of mad cow disease, which has caused a crisis across Western Europe. Franz...
lead_paragraph: EUROPE POLICY ON MAD COW DISEASE -- The director of farm policy for the European Union proposed far-reaching changes to deal with the financial and biological consequences of mad cow disease, which has caused a crisis across Western Europe. Franz Fischler, left, outlined incentives that would cut back beef production and encourage organic farming to grow crops for animal feed. Contaminated bone meal is believed to be the cause of the epidemic. The proposals will cost about $1 billion next year alone. Marlise Simons (NYT)

keywords: ACUNA (MEXICO); MEXICO; ALCOA INC; FOREIGN INVESTMENTS; LABOR; SURVEYS AND SERIES; ENVIRONMENT; WAGES AND SALARIES; WORKING HOURS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS
headline: Profits Raise Pressures On U.S.-Owned Factories In Mexican Border Zone
snippet: Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly-line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here.    After...
lead_paragraph: Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly-line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here. After Paul H. O'Neill, the Alcoa chief executive who became President Bush's treasury secretary last month, trumpeted the company's growing profits, Mr. Tovar stepped to a microphone. At the time Mr. Tovar, who was earning about $6 a day, described Alcoa managers so stingy that they stationed a janitor at bathroom doors to limit workers to just three pieces of toilet paper. He also recounted an incident in which more than 100 workers had been overcome by fumes from a gas leak and taken to hospitals.

keywords: ABU ELBA, KHALIL; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; AZUR (ISRAEL); ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; BUSES; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
headline: Arab Drives Bus Into Crowd, Killing 8 Israelis
snippet: After years of shuttling Gazan laborers into Israel without incident, a Palestinian bus driver who passed a strict Israeli security clearance just two weeks ago veered wildly off course today with deadly consequences.    Plowing into a crowd of...
lead_paragraph: After years of shuttling Gazan laborers into Israel without incident, a Palestinian bus driver who passed a strict Israeli security clearance just two weeks ago veered wildly off course today with deadly consequences. Plowing into a crowd of soldiers and commuters at a bus stop here, the Palestinian driver killed eight Israelis during the morning rush hour. His hit-and-run assault, which was presumed to be an unorthodox terror attack by an unlikely terrorist, caused the highest single-day Israeli death toll since the Palestinian uprising erupted early last fall.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: EUROPE    SERBIA: BUFFER WITH KOSOVO  NATO told Serbian officials that it was prepared as part of an overall peace plan to consider changes to the buffer zone on Kosovo's eastern boundary, which ethnic Albanian separatists are using as a safe haven....
lead_paragraph: EUROPE SERBIA: BUFFER WITH KOSOVO NATO told Serbian officials that it was prepared as part of an overall peace plan to consider changes to the buffer zone on Kosovo's eastern boundary, which ethnic Albanian separatists are using as a safe haven. But while welcoming a plan by Belgrade to stabilize the region, NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, above, said any ultimatum or use of force by Serbian forces to regain control of the zone would be unacceptable. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

snippet: An Israeli Arab couple lost control today as a border police officer suspected of fatally shooting their son took the witness stand a few feet from them.     Attending the first public hearing into police killings of 13 people during a wave of...
lead_paragraph: An Israeli Arab couple lost control today as a border police officer suspected of fatally shooting their son took the witness stand a few feet from them. Attending the first public hearing into police killings of 13 people during a wave of violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October, the grief-stricken parents, Hatem and Rushdiyeh Gara, erupted.

lead_paragraph: In media-crazy Peru, it's no surprise that the government would be toppled by a wall-to-wall outpouring of raunchy and scandalous videos.

headline: National Briefs; Festivities Turn Violent In Austin and Seattle
snippet: Some participants in weekend Mardi Gras festivities here threw beer bottles and punches and smashed windows, injuring about 30 people. More than 50 people were arrested.    The Austin police arrested 35 people early today and an additional 21 early...
lead_paragraph: Some participants in weekend Mardi Gras festivities here threw beer bottles and punches and smashed windows, injuring about 30 people. More than 50 people were arrested. The Austin police arrested 35 people early today and an additional 21 early Saturday on charges including indecent exposure and public intoxication. Police used tear gas and shot rubber pellets this morning to disperse the crowd , estimated at about 100,000 people.

keywords: TACOMA (WASH); OLYMPIA (WASH); SEATTLE (WASH); WASHINGTON (STATE); EARTHQUAKES
headline: Big Quake Jolts Northwest; Damage Estimated in Billions
snippet: The Pacific Northwest was rocked today by the most powerful earthquake to hit the area in 52 years, a 40-second tremor that shattered windows, crumbled bricks and buckled pavement across Seattle and cracked the Capitol dome in Olympia, Wash., a dozen...
lead_paragraph: The Pacific Northwest was rocked today by the most powerful earthquake to hit the area in 52 years, a 40-second tremor that shattered windows, crumbled bricks and buckled pavement across Seattle and cracked the Capitol dome in Olympia, Wash., a dozen miles from the quake's epicenter. At least 215 people were injured, at least 8 seriously, and officials said property damage would easily run into the billions of dollars. And there was a report of a fatal heart attack related to the quake, which struck at 10:54 a.m. Pacific time and sent a wave of fright through schools and offices.

keywords: ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Pentagon Unveils Plans for a New Crowd-Dispersal Weapon
snippet: The Pentagon today unveiled what some military officials hope will become the rubber bullet of the 21st century: a weapon that uses electromagnetic waves to disperse crowds without killing, maiming or, military officials say, even injuring anyone...
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon today unveiled what some military officials hope will become the rubber bullet of the 21st century: a weapon that uses electromagnetic waves to disperse crowds without killing, maiming or, military officials say, even injuring anyone slightly. Known in Pentagon patois as an ''active denial system,'' the weapon is the fruit of 10 years of research and is intended to help American soldiers in the quasi-military roles they have increasingly been asked to play as peacekeepers or police in places like Kosovo and Ethiopia.

keywords: SCHELL, PAUL; SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; MAYORS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; EARTHQUAKES; ELECTION ISSUES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: An Earthquake Puts a Political Career on Firmer Ground
snippet: AT 10:56 a.m. on Wednesday, Paul SchellPaul Schell was precisely four minutes away from starting a difficult news  conference, this one in response to Mardi Gras mayhem on the Seattle streets that had left a  young man dead, dozens of people injured...
lead_paragraph: AT 10:56 a.m. on Wednesday, Paul SchellPaul Schell was precisely four minutes away from starting a difficult news conference, this one in response to Mardi Gras mayhem on the Seattle streets that had left a young man dead, dozens of people injured and the sort of disturbing image that he never thought would be an emblem of his mayoralty: the police firing tear gas and rubber pellets to disperse a crowd. The same police scenes played out in the raucous December 1999 protests against a World Trade Organization meeting here. And now Mr. Schell was moments from once again having to explain what happened.

headline: Dogeaters': Memories of Manila Under the Marcoses
snippet: HINAYON mo ang tingog mo!" my Lola Adela exclaimed, cautioning us to lower our voices. Growing up a martial-law baby in the slums of 1970's Old Manila, I had become somewhat inured to my grandma's frequent exhortations to watch what we said in...
lead_paragraph: HINAYON mo ang tingog mo!" my Lola Adela exclaimed, cautioning us to lower our voices. Growing up a martial-law baby in the slums of 1970's Old Manila, I had become somewhat inured to my grandma's frequent exhortations to watch what we said in public. She warned us of unseen goons who roamed the streets and countryside with concealed guns and a mandate to shoot on the spot any subversive caught criticizing Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos.

keywords: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; POLICE; TORTURE
headline: The Way We Live Now: 3-11-01: The Old Economy; Pain and Gain
snippet: A new study from Amnesty International, titled ''Stopping the Torture Trade,'' reports that over the last 10 years the United States has been the world's biggest exporter of high-tech restraint devices. The market is now dominated by electronic...
lead_paragraph: A new study from Amnesty International, titled ''Stopping the Torture Trade,'' reports that over the last 10 years the United States has been the world's biggest exporter of high-tech restraint devices. The market is now dominated by electronic devices like stun guns, stun batons, stun shields and stun belts -- nonlethal devices that are used by law-enforcement officials all across this country. Amnesty International has provided the following sample of recent products and manufacturers or exporters. The human rights group is careful to note that none of these companies are involved in the production or export of torture equipment -- merely that this type of equipment has been used for torture, and that its trade should be more closely regulated. Arianne International, Palm Beach, Fla. Produces Myotron ''Checkmate'' pulse weapon.

keywords: BEN-ELIEZER, BINYAMIN; SHARON, ARIEL; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
headline: Sharon Blockades a Palestinian Center in the West Bank
snippet: The Israeli Army today sealed off this city, the unofficial seat of government of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank, blocking roads with trenches, mounds of earth  and checkpoints backed by tanks and armored troop carriers.    It was the...
lead_paragraph: The Israeli Army today sealed off this city, the unofficial seat of government of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank, blocking roads with trenches, mounds of earth and checkpoints backed by tanks and armored troop carriers. It was the first action against the Palestinians by the newly inaugurated government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and the most severe blockade imposed by the Israelis on this community of 60,000, a major commercial and cultural center.

keywords: MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); TETOVO (MACEDONIA); UNIVERSITY OF TETOVO; MINORITIES (US); COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; ALBANIAN LANGUAGE
headline: Another Balkan Battle: Higher Learning
snippet: A new Albanian-language university, sponsored and financed by the international community, was supposed to be a significant response to the grievances that have underpinned the Albanian rebellion now building in the hills above Tetovo and threatening...
lead_paragraph: A new Albanian-language university, sponsored and financed by the international community, was supposed to be a significant response to the grievances that have underpinned the Albanian rebellion now building in the hills above Tetovo and threatening the cohesion of the Macedonian state. But the new private university, due to open in October on land donated by the government, has instead created a political storm that shows the fissures in this fragile, multi-ethnic state and the complications that surround the good intentions of foreigners.

keywords: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; HAMAS; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES
headline: Sharon Orders His First Raid After Bombing
snippet: Israeli helicopter gunships bombarded bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces tonight after a Palestinian suicide bombing this morning killed two Israeli teenagers in central Israel.    It was Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's...
lead_paragraph: Israeli helicopter gunships bombarded bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces tonight after a Palestinian suicide bombing this morning killed two Israeli teenagers in central Israel. It was Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's first military response since he took office three weeks ago to a spate of Palestinian attacks that escalated this week. Pressure inside Israel had been mounting on Mr. Sharon, who was elected largely because of his iron-fisted image, to take decisive action.

headline: National Briefing
snippet: SOUTHWEST    TEXAS: EXPANDED USE OF DNA TESTS -- A bill making it easier for inmates to use DNA tests to try to prove their innocence received final approval from the Legislature, and Gov. Rick Perry is expected to sign it into law. The legislation...
lead_paragraph: SOUTHWEST TEXAS: EXPANDED USE OF DNA TESTS -- A bill making it easier for inmates to use DNA tests to try to prove their innocence received final approval from the Legislature, and Gov. Rick Perry is expected to sign it into law. The legislation requires prosecutors to preserve biological evidence and provides state-paid DNA testing if it was not available at trial and could clear an inmate. One amendment to the bill requires courts to provide lawyers for indigent inmates; another allows inmates who pleaded guilty to request testing. AP

keywords: THOMAS, TIMOTHY; LUKEN, CHARLIE; REECE, ALICIA; ROACH, STEVEN; CINCINNATI (OHIO); AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Appeals for Peace in Ohio After Two Days of Protests
snippet: This city's clergy and political leaders pleaded for peace on the streets today after two days of sporadic protests and vandalism that followed the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white policeman.    ''This situation has been...
lead_paragraph: This city's clergy and political leaders pleaded for peace on the streets today after two days of sporadic protests and vandalism that followed the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white policeman. ''This situation has been festering for over five years,'' City Councilwoman Alicia Reece said. She surveyed the 66 arrests and damage to dozens of city stores as evidence of deepening tensions between the police and black residents who have long complained of racial profiling by officers.

keywords: ECEVIT, BULENT; ANKARA (TURKEY); TURKEY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; TEAR GAS
headline: Economic Protest in Turkey Turns Into a Melee
snippet: An estimated 50,000 people, mostly tradesmen and owners of small businesses , tried to march to Parliament in Ankara today to press demands that Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit resign over his handling of the two-month-old economic crisis, but the...
lead_paragraph: An estimated 50,000 people, mostly tradesmen and owners of small businesses , tried to march to Parliament in Ankara today to press demands that Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit resign over his handling of the two-month-old economic crisis, but the police used tear gas, water cannon and riot sticks to beat them back. Scores of demonstrators and police officers were injured in the melee. On the eighth day of protests, and the most violent, the demonstrators chanted ''Ecevit, quit!'' and ''Government, resign!'' to protest soaring prices and the collapse of the lira.

keywords: THOMAS, TIMOTHY; LUKEN, CHARLIE; ROACH, STEVEN; CINCINNATI (OHIO); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; DISCRIMINATION; CURFEWS; POLICE
headline: Cincinnati Mayor Imposes Curfew to Quell Violence
snippet: This racially tense city was placed under a strict nightlong curfew today as the authorities struggled to stop sporadic vandalism and the confrontations with police officers that followed the fatal shooting of a black teenager by the police.   ...
lead_paragraph: This racially tense city was placed under a strict nightlong curfew today as the authorities struggled to stop sporadic vandalism and the confrontations with police officers that followed the fatal shooting of a black teenager by the police. ''Despite the best efforts of the good citizens of our city, the violence on our streets is uncontrolled and it runs rampant,'' Mayor Charlie Luken declared as he announced a state of emergency and ordered that the streets be kept clear of most people from 8 p.m. until 6 a.m. until further notice.

keywords: BLACKWELL, J KENNETH; THOMAS, TIMOTHY; CINCINNATI (OHIO); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Blacks in Cincinnati Hear Echoes Amid the Violence
snippet: Charles Wimms looked back today from some fresh scars on storefronts in the black Avondale neighborhood to the old, still chilling memories of the last time local youths erupted in violent protest, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was...
lead_paragraph: Charles Wimms looked back today from some fresh scars on storefronts in the black Avondale neighborhood to the old, still chilling memories of the last time local youths erupted in violent protest, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated more than three decades ago. ''This wouldn't have happened if they had listened to us in those years back then,'' said Mr. Wimms, a 39-year-old construction worker, recalling that police treatment of black Cincinnatians -- the issue that drove the wave of protest and vandalism by clusters of angry blacks this week -- was also a principal issue in the 1968 violence.

headline: April 8-14; Riots in Cincinnati
snippet: The scene in Cincinnati seemed a time-warp from the 1960's as protests over alleged racial profiling by police degenerated into hit-and-run vandalism, centered in black neighborhoods. The city declared a state of emergency and a curfew after four...
lead_paragraph: The scene in Cincinnati seemed a time-warp from the 1960's as protests over alleged racial profiling by police degenerated into hit-and-run vandalism, centered in black neighborhoods. The city declared a state of emergency and a curfew after four nights in which the police used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop clusters of young black men who looted stores and intimidated whites. ''Knock it off,'' demanded Mayor Charlie Luken, even as he conceded there were ''very legitimate'' concerns over police killings of 15 black male suspects in six years. Francis X. Clines

headline: Grief and Fury at Funeral for Slain Youth
snippet: Inside a packed church today, the black community's grief reached a crescendo with the singing of a hymn about suffering and resolve addressed to Jesus: ''I've been up and I've been down, but I'm not going to turn around because I'm fighting.''   ...
lead_paragraph: Inside a packed church today, the black community's grief reached a crescendo with the singing of a hymn about suffering and resolve addressed to Jesus: ''I've been up and I've been down, but I'm not going to turn around because I'm fighting.'' Minutes later, the shiny metallic coffin containing the body of 19-year-old Timothy Thomas was carried out and down the steps, where a phalanx of Black Panthers raised clenched fists in bidding an angry farewell.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
snippet: AMERICAS    MEXICO: PRAISE FROM HELMS  Senator Jesse Helms, leading a delegation from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, concluded a three-day goodwill visit after meeting with Mexican officials. In a speech before his committee's Mexican...
lead_paragraph: AMERICAS MEXICO: PRAISE FROM HELMS Senator Jesse Helms, leading a delegation from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, concluded a three-day goodwill visit after meeting with Mexican officials. In a speech before his committee's Mexican counterparts, the North Carolina Republican praised the new government for economic and democratic reforms. Graham Gori (NYT)

headline: BUSH WILL PRESS FREE-TRADE ISSUE AT QUEBEC TALKS
snippet: President Bush arrived at his first summit meeting today declaring that he would make the expansion of economic and political ties with Latin America his first foreign policy priority.     But before Mr. Bush and other leaders could get down to work,...
lead_paragraph: President Bush arrived at his first summit meeting today declaring that he would make the expansion of economic and political ties with Latin America his first foreign policy priority. But before Mr. Bush and other leaders could get down to work, tonight's opening ceremony of the Summit of the Americas was delayed for an hour, to about 7:30, as thousands of mostly young protesters clogged the narrow streets of this walled city seeking to block talks over a Free Trade Area of the Americas.

headline: Demonstrators At the Summit Are Greeted With Tear Gas
snippet: The Summit of the Americas got under way in this fortified city today with 34 leaders passing through color guards and red-coated Mounties inside the delegates' hall, while outside hooded protesters tangled with riot policemen under billowing clouds...
lead_paragraph: The Summit of the Americas got under way in this fortified city today with 34 leaders passing through color guards and red-coated Mounties inside the delegates' hall, while outside hooded protesters tangled with riot policemen under billowing clouds of tear gas. A crowd that the police estimated at 2,000 tore down about 150 feet of a chain-link fence atop concrete barricades that had been erected near the convention center where President Bush and the other leaders of the Western Hemisphere gathered this afternoon.

keywords: QUEBEC CITY (QUEBEC); SUMMIT OF THE AMERICAS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: In the Streets, Fervor, Fears and a Gamut of Issues
snippet: For a second day, the old streets of this historic city were mobbed today with people protesting the proceedings of the third Summit of the Americas. The biggest crowd -- a good mile long and a boulevard wide -- marched for hours without incident or...
lead_paragraph: For a second day, the old streets of this historic city were mobbed today with people protesting the proceedings of the third Summit of the Americas. The biggest crowd -- a good mile long and a boulevard wide -- marched for hours without incident or trouble yet with evident concern for the panoply of issues that angered, frightened or frustrated them enough to come here. But on the other side of Quebec, police officers used a water cannon, rubber bullets and a continual shower of tear gas to repeatedly push back the front ranks of more than 6,000 protesters at a few key points not far from the meeting site. One of the most prolonged confrontations took place at a weak point in the concrete and chain-link fence around the official summit meeting area that had been breached briefly during protests on Friday afternoon.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; FOX QUESADA, VICENTE; WESTERN HEMISPHERE; QUEBEC CITY (QUEBEC); SUMMIT OF THE AMERICAS; LABOR; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; ENVIRONMENT
headline: BUSH LINKS TRADE WITH DEMOCRACY AT QUEBEC TALKS
snippet: President Bush told the leaders of the Western Hemisphere today that after almost a decade of delays in creating a single market from the Arctic to the tip of South America, the time had come to ''build an age of prosperity in a hemisphere of...
lead_paragraph: President Bush told the leaders of the Western Hemisphere today that after almost a decade of delays in creating a single market from the Arctic to the tip of South America, the time had come to ''build an age of prosperity in a hemisphere of liberty.'' At the same time, Mr. Bush cautiously reached out to the thousands here who were protesting his drive to expand the Nafta accord throughout Central and South America. He sent members of his administration to meet a variety of labor, environmental and human rights groups that Republicans have previously dismissed as protectionists and the enemy of trade accords.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; LATIN AMERICA; CARIBBEAN AREA; QUEBEC PROVINCE (CANADA); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
headline: Biggest Obstacle to Selling Trade Pact: Sovereignty
snippet: Midway through President Bush's first summit meeting, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he was unfazed by the raucous demonstrations that greeted the 34 leaders trying to turn the Western Hemisphere into a single market.    ''An old infantryman...
lead_paragraph: Midway through President Bush's first summit meeting, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he was unfazed by the raucous demonstrations that greeted the 34 leaders trying to turn the Western Hemisphere into a single market. ''An old infantryman always remembers what tear gas and pot smell like when you walk in the barracks,'' he joked with reporters, recalling his days as a young Army officer.

keywords: LUKEN, CHARLIE; CINCINNATI (OHIO); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION; BLACKS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: In Aftershock of Unrest, Cincinnati Seeks Answers
snippet: Amid the aftershocks of three days of racial protest and vandalism, this proud but careworn city is seeking to right itself by moving quickly toward mediation of a federal lawsuit that accuses the police of abusing black citizens.    ''In terms of...
lead_paragraph: Amid the aftershocks of three days of racial protest and vandalism, this proud but careworn city is seeking to right itself by moving quickly toward mediation of a federal lawsuit that accuses the police of abusing black citizens. ''In terms of achieving improvement and restoring some trust, I view the racial profiling lawsuit as an important vehicle to do that,'' said Mayor Charlie Luken, who presides over a racially divided city facing an uphill recovery from street disruptions that drew national attention to the anger of blacks here.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; LATIN AMERICA; CANADA; CARIBBEAN AREA; QUEBEC PROVINCE (CANADA); INTER-AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Talks Tie Trade In the Americas To Democracy
snippet: Pledging equal support to democracy and free trade, 34 leaders of the Western Hemisphere closed a summit meeting today by reinforcing their commitment to a vast Free Trade Area of the Americas, vowing to ensure that its benefits are shared by the...
lead_paragraph: Pledging equal support to democracy and free trade, 34 leaders of the Western Hemisphere closed a summit meeting today by reinforcing their commitment to a vast Free Trade Area of the Americas, vowing to ensure that its benefits are shared by the hemisphere's 800 million people. ''There's no question in my mind that we have challenges ahead of us, but there's also no question in my mind that we can meet those challenges,'' President Bush said after he and the other leaders signed a closing declaration.

keywords: JERSEY CITY (NJ); FIRES AND FIREMEN; TEAR GAS
headline: 50 Hurt After Tear-Gas Can Is Tossed Into Building Lobby
snippet: About 50 people, most of them firefighters, were injured late Monday when someone threw a canister of military-strength tear gas into the lobby of an apartment building here, spreading a thick white smoke that burned the skin and eyes.    ''It was...
lead_paragraph: About 50 people, most of them firefighters, were injured late Monday when someone threw a canister of military-strength tear gas into the lobby of an apartment building here, spreading a thick white smoke that burned the skin and eyes. ''It was the most horrifying, terrifying experience of my life,'' said Minda Manalac, 39, who fled her second-floor apartment to the lobby. ''I didn't think I could make it because I couldn't see at all, and I was gagging and vomiting, and I kept tripping and falling. I thought I was going to die.''

lead_paragraph: Panicked crowds crushed at least seven people to death yesterday in a riot at a game between two of Congo's top teams in Lubumbashi. Another 51 people were injured, Congo's information minister, Kikaya Bin Karubi, said.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Germany Proposes Union In a European Federation  Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's governing party proposed a far-reaching plan to turn the European Union into a more centralized federal system. The plan, modeled after the...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Germany Proposes Union In a European Federation Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's governing party proposed a far-reaching plan to turn the European Union into a more centralized federal system. The plan, modeled after the structure of Germany, would give much more power to the European Parliament, but it is expected to cause national anxiety in Britain and France. A1

keywords: ESTRADA, JOSEPH; ARROYO, GLORIA MACAPAGAL; PHILIPPINES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ETHICS; BRIBERY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: 4 in Manila Die in Protest for Ousted President
snippet: Security forces fired warning shots, tear gas and water cannons early today to fend off supporters of the ousted former president, Joseph Estrada, as they tried to storm the presidential palace, demanding that his successor quit. At least four people...
lead_paragraph: Security forces fired warning shots, tear gas and water cannons early today to fend off supporters of the ousted former president, Joseph Estrada, as they tried to storm the presidential palace, demanding that his successor quit. At least four people were reported dead. It was the second time in as many nights that President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo survived an attempt to force her from office. She said Mr. Estrada and his allies had incited the protest in an effort to seize power.

keywords: ALGERIA; KABYLIA (ALGERIA); BERBERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Ethnic Anger Erupts Again in Algeria
snippet: Clashes between protesters and security forces resumed today in the Berber region around Kabylia. Anger over reports that 40 people had died in ethnic-based rioting spread to the capital, Algiers.    This city of 600,000 remained paralyzed as...
lead_paragraph: Clashes between protesters and security forces resumed today in the Berber region around Kabylia. Anger over reports that 40 people had died in ethnic-based rioting spread to the capital, Algiers. This city of 600,000 remained paralyzed as stone-throwing rioters fought battles with police officers who fired tear-gas canisters. Gunshots wounded two people, medical sources said. Some calm returned in the afternoon to streets strewn with debris, burned tires and felled trees.

keywords: ESTRADA, JOSEPH; ARROYO, GLORIA MACAPAGAL; MANILA (PHILIPPINES); PHILIPPINES; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: State of Rebellion' Declared After Siege at Manila Palace
snippet: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a ''state of rebellion'' in the Philippine capital today and ordered the arrests of opposition leaders whom she accused of conspiring to topple her fledgling government.    Her move came hours after a mob of...
lead_paragraph: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a ''state of rebellion'' in the Philippine capital today and ordered the arrests of opposition leaders whom she accused of conspiring to topple her fledgling government. Her move came hours after a mob of protesters loyal to her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, stormed the gates of the presidential palace, resulting in three deaths and more than a hundred injuries.

keywords: FREEH, LOUIS J; CLINTON, BILL; BUSH, GEORGE W; FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS
headline: DIRECTOR OF F.B.I. SAYS HE'LL RESIGN AFTER EIGHT YEARS
snippet: Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. said today that he would resign in June after an eight-year tenure in which he energetically expanded the bureau's reach around the world but warred almost continuously with Bill Clinton, the president who...
lead_paragraph: Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. said today that he would resign in June after an eight-year tenure in which he energetically expanded the bureau's reach around the world but warred almost continuously with Bill Clinton, the president who appointed him. Mr. Freeh, who had long told aides that he planned to step down after the November elections, agreed instead to President Bush's request to stay on through the transition. But while visiting the White House on Monday, Mr. Freeh informed the president of his decision to resign, two years short of completing his 10-year term.

keywords: ACCRA (GHANA); AFRICA; SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Death Toll Thought to Top 100 In a Soccer Stampede in Ghana
snippet: More than 100 people were feared dead in a soccer stadium stampede here in the capital tonight, state television and private radio said. It was the third soccer disaster in Africa in a month.     A state television official said the unconfirmed death...
lead_paragraph: More than 100 people were feared dead in a soccer stadium stampede here in the capital tonight, state television and private radio said. It was the third soccer disaster in Africa in a month. A state television official said the unconfirmed death toll was 120. A private radio broadcaster said he had counted more than 100 bodies in a hospital and a senior government official said he had seen 50 to 60.

keywords: ACCRA (GHANA); CONGO (FORMERLY ZAIRE); IVORY COAST; SOUTH AFRICA; GHANA; SOCCER; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Soccer in Africa Once More Turns Deadly
snippet: The official toll issued by Ghana to day  at least 123 deaths and 93 injuries -- turned a stampede at a soccer match on Wednesday into the worst sporting disaster in Africa's history and pushed to nearly 180 the number of spectators killed across the...
lead_paragraph: The official toll issued by Ghana to day at least 123 deaths and 93 injuries -- turned a stampede at a soccer match on Wednesday into the worst sporting disaster in Africa's history and pushed to nearly 180 the number of spectators killed across the continent in the last month. The deaths in a stadium in Accra, the capital of the West African nation, followed similar incidents in Ivory Coast, in Congo and in South Africa. In all cases, many have accused the police of having failed to control the unruly crowds and, in at least two incidents, of making the stampedes worse by firing excessive amounts of tear gas.

headline: May 6-12; Soccer Stampede in Ghana
snippet: Africa's fourth soccer tragedy in a month became its deadliest, as 123 fans were killed in a soccer stampede in Accra, Ghana, during a match between two of the country's top teams. It raised to about 180 the total number of spectators killed across...
lead_paragraph: Africa's fourth soccer tragedy in a month became its deadliest, as 123 fans were killed in a soccer stampede in Accra, Ghana, during a match between two of the country's top teams. It raised to about 180 the total number of spectators killed across the continent, since 43 fans died trying to get into a packed stadium in South Africa last month. The incident also highlighted the poor security in most of Africa's stadiums. Few have security personnel managing crowds and rely instead on police officers who tend to overreact in riots by indiscriminately firing tear gas. Norimitsu Onishi

keywords: MCVEIGH, TIMOTHY; OKLAHOMA CITY (OKLA); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
headline: The Nation: A Conspiracy So Vast; How Crimes Become Obsessions
snippet: THE disclosure that the Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld documents from Timothy McVeigh's lawyers seems certain to ignite a controversy that will burn for years, perhaps decades.    ''If any questions or doubts remain about this case, it...
lead_paragraph: THE disclosure that the Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld documents from Timothy McVeigh's lawyers seems certain to ignite a controversy that will burn for years, perhaps decades. ''If any questions or doubts remain about this case, it would cast a permanent cloud over justice,'' said Attorney General John D. Ashcroft in delaying Mr. McVeigh's execution until at least June 11.

keywords: PYDYSZEWSKI, KURT; UNIVERSITY OF NORTHERN COLORADO; ALCOHOL ABUSE; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
headline: A Suicide Draws Attention to Campus Melees
snippet: The little house on Ninth Avenue stands as a shrine to what happened here on the last Saturday of April. The front lawn has a small cross, adorned with flowers and a poem, in memory of Kurt Pydyszewski, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of...
lead_paragraph: The little house on Ninth Avenue stands as a shrine to what happened here on the last Saturday of April. The front lawn has a small cross, adorned with flowers and a poem, in memory of Kurt Pydyszewski, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of Northern Colorado who lived inside. Mr. Pydyszewski killed himself with a gunshot to the head on May 4, the result, friends said, of his participation in a showdown with the police that grew out of a block party where many of the 1,000 students became drunk. The Greeley police arrested Mr. Pydyszewski and more than two dozen other students, most of whom were also facing disciplinary action by the school.

keywords: FRANCE; TELEVISION
headline: Reality TV in France: A Smash Hit With Dialectics
snippet: So the truth is out. With the arrival of the reality show ''Big Brother'' here this month, the French are proving to be no more highbrow than Spaniards, Italians, Britons, Americans and others before them. Overnight the French have become hooked,...
lead_paragraph: So the truth is out. With the arrival of the reality show ''Big Brother'' here this month, the French are proving to be no more highbrow than Spaniards, Italians, Britons, Americans and others before them. Overnight the French have become hooked, tuning in by the millions every evening to watch five men and five woman engaged in an elimination contest in an enclosed space under the eyes of 26 cameras. But wait. Perhaps the French are different after all. ''Loft Story'' (the show's title is in English) may be as hypnotically banal as earlier versions of ''Big Brother'' elsewhere, but at least here there is the additional entertainment of an immense furor stirred by the show off screen. The question is even being posed: Should the land of Molière, Montaigne and Voltaire be allowed to watch ''trash TV,'' as reality shows have been tagged here?

keywords: WAHID, ABDURRAHMAN; INDONESIA; IMPEACHMENT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Parliament In Indonesia Votes to Start Impeachment
snippet: Parliament voted today to begin impeachment proceedings against President Abdurrahman Wahid, raising the prospect of another turbulent change of power in this restive archipelago.    Mr. Wahid, the 60-year-old Muslim leader, now seems likely to...
lead_paragraph: Parliament voted today to begin impeachment proceedings against President Abdurrahman Wahid, raising the prospect of another turbulent change of power in this restive archipelago. Mr. Wahid, the 60-year-old Muslim leader, now seems likely to become the latest casualty of a wave of upheaval that has swept across Asia from Indonesia and Thailand to the Philippines and Taiwan.

keywords: HUSSEINI, FAISAL; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; DOME OF THE ROCK (SHRINE); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: A Funeral in Jerusalem Arouses Palestinian Nationalism
snippet: Tens of thousands of Palestinians waving Palestinian flags marched through East Jerusalem today as the Israeli police stood back and watched the most fervent, open display of Palestinian nationalism in the heart of this city in more than three...
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Palestinians waving Palestinian flags marched through East Jerusalem today as the Israeli police stood back and watched the most fervent, open display of Palestinian nationalism in the heart of this city in more than three decades. The Palestinians were accompanying the coffin of Faisal Husseini, the senior Palestinian official in Jerusalem, to the Aksa mosque in the Old City. As the Israeli police kept to the edges, Palestinian officials directed the crowds in what Israelis called a singular moment of security cooperation in these tense times.

keywords: TEL AVIV (ISRAEL); ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
headline: Victims' Accounts of a Night of Horror
snippet: Ana Sinichkin lay sobbing in a hospital bed in a suburb of this city today, shrapnel in her leg and her hand cradled by a friend who tried to comfort her.    A 16-year-old who moved to Israel a year and a half ago from Russia with her widowed mother...
lead_paragraph: Ana Sinichkin lay sobbing in a hospital bed in a suburb of this city today, shrapnel in her leg and her hand cradled by a friend who tried to comfort her. A 16-year-old who moved to Israel a year and a half ago from Russia with her widowed mother and sister, Ms. Sinichkin was just starting to come to grips with the devastation of Friday night's suicide bombing that killed 18 young people and wounded scores outside a beach-front disco in Tel Aviv.

headline: Riots Break Out as Nepal Gets 3rd King in 4 Days
