lead_paragraph: Rioting erupted here in Nepal's capital today, just hours after the enthronement of a new king, this Himalayan nation's third monarch in the last four wrenching days. After the death of King Dipendra before dawn today, his uncle, Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah, was proclaimed king.

keywords: QUEVEDO, HUGO; ECUADOR; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: More Turmoil In Congress
snippet: After a failed attempt to declare a monthlong recess, the president of the country's one-chamber congress, Hugo Quevedo, has resigned rather than face a vote intended to replace him on charges of corruption and administrative incompetence. The action...
lead_paragraph: After a failed attempt to declare a monthlong recess, the president of the country's one-chamber congress, Hugo Quevedo, has resigned rather than face a vote intended to replace him on charges of corruption and administrative incompetence. The action comes with Congress's approval rating at an all-time low and follows recent incidents in which fistfights broke out during legislative sessions and tear gas was released during a debate on a disputed tax measure. Larry Rohter (NYT)

keywords: JOHNSTON, BILL; WACO (TEX); BRANCH DAVIDIANS; SENTENCES (CRIMINAL)
headline: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Probation In A Waco Case
snippet: Bill Johnston, a former federal prosecutor, was sentenced by a federal court in St. Louis to two years of probation for withholding evidence in connection with the 1993 standoff and fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. Mr. Johnston...
lead_paragraph: Bill Johnston, a former federal prosecutor, was sentenced by a federal court in St. Louis to two years of probation for withholding evidence in connection with the 1993 standoff and fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. Mr. Johnston admitted in February that he had withheld from investigators one page of notes involving F.B.I. agents' use of pyrotechnic tear gas canisters during the 51-day siege. In return for his plea, prosecutors dropped charges of obstructing justice and lying to investigators and a federal grand jury. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

headline: Macedonia Expands Attacks Against Rebels
snippet: The Macedonian government intensified its attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels today, despite a rebel offer of a cease-fire, pounding rebel-held villages north of the capital with heavy artillery and fire from helicopter gunships.     The rebels...
lead_paragraph: The Macedonian government intensified its attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels today, despite a rebel offer of a cease-fire, pounding rebel-held villages north of the capital with heavy artillery and fire from helicopter gunships. The rebels seemed undeterred, holding their positions under the assault and even appearing in uniform in a suburb Aracinovo, less than four miles from the capital, Skopje.

keywords: DOYLE, CLIVE; MARTIN, SHEILA; MCVEIGH, TIMOTHY JAMES; WACO (TEX); OKLAHOMA CITY (OKLA); BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); CAPITAL PUNISHMENT; RELIGIOUS CULTS; TERRORISM
headline: Branch Davidians Shed No Tears for McVeigh
snippet: Their ranks are small these days, outnumbered by the 80 crape myrtles planted at the Mount Carmel compound to commemorate each of the Branch Davidians who died here eight years ago.     Their arguments are fierce, for no fewer than three factions of...
lead_paragraph: Their ranks are small these days, outnumbered by the 80 crape myrtles planted at the Mount Carmel compound to commemorate each of the Branch Davidians who died here eight years ago. Their arguments are fierce, for no fewer than three factions of Branch Davidians have laid legal claim to the 77-acre property outside the city, producing yet another bizarre standoff, with separate churches for two factions and a histrionic display by the third, which dismisses the entire 51-day siege by federal agents at the compound as a diversion.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    China Is Said to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions  China has greatly slowed emissions of carbon dioxide in the last decade, Chinese and Western energy experts say, pushing back the day that China will presumably pass the...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 China Is Said to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions China has greatly slowed emissions of carbon dioxide in the last decade, Chinese and Western energy experts say, pushing back the day that China will presumably pass the United States as the biggest source of the air pollution that scientists believe is warming the planet. The specter of runaway Chinese emissions has been cited by President Bush as a major reason for why the Kyoto climate accord is ''fatally flawed.'' A1 At a European Union meeting, President Bush and European leaders expressed differences and conflicting intentions on global warming. A6

keywords: ALGIERS (ALGERIA); ALGERIA; BERBERS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: 2 Die in Big Berber Rally in Algiers
snippet: The police fired water cannon and tear gas at rioters today as hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on Algeria's presidential palace demanding greater democracy. Two  people died and more than 400 were injured in the turmoil.    Ethnic Berbers...
lead_paragraph: The police fired water cannon and tear gas at rioters today as hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on Algeria's presidential palace demanding greater democracy. Two people died and more than 400 were injured in the turmoil. Ethnic Berbers organized the mass protest against discrimination and they were joined by opposition parties demanding greater freedom, presenting Algeria's military-backed government with a growing challenge even as it battles the separate threat of an Islamic insurgency.

keywords: ISRAEL; ARABS
headline: Police Killings of Israeli Arabs Being Questioned by Inquiry
snippet: A formal inquiry this month into the police killing of 13 people in violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October has raised questions about several of the shootings, particularly whether the police needed to fire live ammunition. It has also served...
lead_paragraph: A formal inquiry this month into the police killing of 13 people in violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October has raised questions about several of the shootings, particularly whether the police needed to fire live ammunition. It has also served as a platform to air what Israeli Arabs say is discrimination that has gone on for decades. The three-member commission, headed by a Supreme Court judge, Theodor Or, drew attention last week during its inquiry into the death of Asel Asleh, a 17-year-old Israeli Arab peace advocate killed by police gunfire during a stone-throwing protest, part of a wave of Israeli Arab protests last fall in support of the Palestinian uprising.

keywords: ALGERIA; BERBERS; MINORITIES (US); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Berber Unrest Threatens Algeria's Government
snippet: Two months of slowly mounting protests by the Berber minority exploded last week into the biggest popular outpouring since independence in 1962 when thousands of Algerians seized the chance to vent their own grievances against the government.   ...
lead_paragraph: Two months of slowly mounting protests by the Berber minority exploded last week into the biggest popular outpouring since independence in 1962 when thousands of Algerians seized the chance to vent their own grievances against the government. While the hundreds of thousands of Berbers who descended on the capital have since returned to their home provinces, the challenge they have opened to a government widely seen as repressive and ineffective is far from dissipated.

keywords: NEW YORK CITY; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; MACE (CHEMICAL)
headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Spray Sickens 13 In School
snippet: Two adults and 11 children at Public School 191 on the Upper West Side were sickened yesterday when a student discharged a canister of Mace, a form of tear gas, the police said. The student, an 11-year-old girl in special education, reached into her...
lead_paragraph: Two adults and 11 children at Public School 191 on the Upper West Side were sickened yesterday when a student discharged a canister of Mace, a form of tear gas, the police said. The student, an 11-year-old girl in special education, reached into her purse at 10:30 a.m., when she uncapped the irritant, apparently by accident, the police said. It was unclear why the girl carried the canister. The students, a teacher and a parent were taken to St. Mary's Hospital, where they were treated for inflamed eyes and throat and released. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

keywords: BEATTY, RUSSELL A; SAN FRANCISCO (CALIF); ALCATRAZ (SAN FRANCISCO); GARDENS AND GARDENING
headline: The Plant Men of Alcatraz
snippet: PLANTS, like buildings, hold memories. They are flourishing beneath the cellblock here on Alcatraz, this famously foreboding rock, as they have since military days, when this island -- buffeted by winds and currents -- was a fortress defending San...
lead_paragraph: PLANTS, like buildings, hold memories. They are flourishing beneath the cellblock here on Alcatraz, this famously foreboding rock, as they have since military days, when this island -- buffeted by winds and currents -- was a fortress defending San Francisco Bay. The sweet scent of honeysuckle mingles with the salty air. The old warden's house, now a ruin overtaken by a fugitive garden, looks like an Aubusson carpet of roses and nasturtiums. Flowers are everywhere on Alcatraz at this time of year -- snaking up barbed wire fences, threatening to subsume the hillside where Al Capone traveled from his cell to laundry detail. Some ancient roses are holdovers from the 19th-century military era, when officers' wives sipped iced tea in cottage gardens. Others were planted and tended by inmates like Elliott Michener, who arrived in 1941, a convicted counterfeiter who couldn't resist a geranium.

keywords: JAPAN; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TEAR GAS
headline: Japanese Children Get Scary Lessons in Fighting Violence
snippet: Ever since a knife-wielding man killed eight children at an elementary school near Osaka on June 8, schools across Japan have wasted little time adopting security measures that until the stabbing would have been unthinkable in a country of little...
lead_paragraph: Ever since a knife-wielding man killed eight children at an elementary school near Osaka on June 8, schools across Japan have wasted little time adopting security measures that until the stabbing would have been unthinkable in a country of little violence. School officials have locked gates, posted guards, organized parent patrols, installed cameras and enrolled teachers in self-defense courses.

keywords: MORRISON, JIM; PARIS (FRANCE); MUSIC; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: 30 Years Later, He Still Lights His Fans' Fire
snippet: In the decades since Jim Morrison died, his grave, with his name on a simple bronze tablet and the words, in Greek, ''True to his own spirit,'' has attracted crowds of pilgrims that have made it a special place of homage for the international rock...
lead_paragraph: In the decades since Jim Morrison died, his grave, with his name on a simple bronze tablet and the words, in Greek, ''True to his own spirit,'' has attracted crowds of pilgrims that have made it a special place of homage for the international rock scene and the principal attraction in the big Père-Lachaise cemetery in eastern Paris. So today, on the 30th anniversary of Morrison's death in a Paris apartment of an overdose of alcohol and drugs, the crowds were heavy. Le Monde, the arbiter of French tastes, said that he had become a cult object with Père-Lachaise as its Lourdes.

keywords: GREAT BRITAIN; BRADFORD (ENG); ATTACKS ON POLICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Race Riot in Another City in Northern England Is Worst So Far
snippet: It was the worst race riot so far in what has been a tense summer in Britain's restive north. And today, hours after the end of a rampage in Bradford that injured 120 police officers, community leaders and government officials said they were bracing...
lead_paragraph: It was the worst race riot so far in what has been a tense summer in Britain's restive north. And today, hours after the end of a rampage in Bradford that injured 120 police officers, community leaders and government officials said they were bracing for further unrest. Thirty-six people were arrested today after pitched battles with the police during nine hours of violence. Shop windows were broken and cars were set on fire as rioters used bricks, bats, hammers, fireworks and firebombs against the police and against local businesses.

keywords: MCVEIGH, TIMOTHY JAMES; ASHCROFT, JOHN; OKLAHOMA CITY (OKLA); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES
headline: Ashcroft Says F.B.I.'s Failings Have Led Public to Lose Trust
snippet: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today in a speech at F.B.I. headquarters that public trust in the agency had been eroded by recent humiliations, among them a case in which an  agent pleaded guilty to spying for Russia and another in which the...
lead_paragraph: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today in a speech at F.B.I. headquarters that public trust in the agency had been eroded by recent humiliations, among them a case in which an agent pleaded guilty to spying for Russia and another in which the bureau failed to turn over thousands of pages of investigative reports to defense lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case. ''All institutions -- even great ones like the Federal Bureau of Investigation -- have problems,'' Mr. Ashcroft said in his speech to about 500 F.B.I. employees, among them supervisors, agents and technical analysts. ''Our challenge is how we respond to these problems, how we, working together, answer the call to protect the people's trust, reinforce freedom and preserve justice.''

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; GENOA (ITALY); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Protesters at Bay, Rich Nations' Chiefs to Meet in Genoa
snippet: Multiple checkpoints, bomb-sniffing dogs and 13-foot iron gratings put up across cobbled alleys to seal off secure zones have given the medieval port city of Genoa the look of pre-1989 East Berlin.     On Friday, a summit meeting for the world's...
lead_paragraph: Multiple checkpoints, bomb-sniffing dogs and 13-foot iron gratings put up across cobbled alleys to seal off secure zones have given the medieval port city of Genoa the look of pre-1989 East Berlin. On Friday, a summit meeting for the world's major industrial nations will begin here and is expected to draw more than 100,000 antiglobalization protesters. Tension and security fears are already high.

keywords: SRI LANKA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Protesters Defy Ban
snippet: More than 10,000 people in the political opposition defied a government ban on a rally in Colombo and assembled to protest President Chandrika Kumaratunga's suspension of Parliament. The police used tear gas, rubber bullets and riot sticks to...
lead_paragraph: More than 10,000 people in the political opposition defied a government ban on a rally in Colombo and assembled to protest President Chandrika Kumaratunga's suspension of Parliament. The police used tear gas, rubber bullets and riot sticks to disperse the crowds. Parliament, which was to take a no-confidence vote on the government that Mrs. Kumaratunga feared losing, is to remain suspended until Sept. 7. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

keywords: CIAMPI, CARLO AZEGLIO; AGNOLETTI, VITTORIO; BERLUSCONI, SILVIO; GIULIANI, CARLO; GENOA (ITALY); GENOA SOCIAL FORUM; GROUP OF EIGHT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: ITALIAN PROTESTER IS KILLED BY POLICE AT GENOA MEETING
snippet: A 23-year-old Italian protester was shot and killed today by a police officer during a riot less than two miles from a gathering of leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations, who were protected by a 13-foot fence that anti-globalization...
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old Italian protester was shot and killed today by a police officer during a riot less than two miles from a gathering of leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations, who were protected by a 13-foot fence that anti-globalization demonstrators had vowed to breach. The killing in Genoa, a medieval seaport converted into a 21st-century citadel, is the first death during an anti-globalization demonstration since the movement tempestuously surfaced at a World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in 1999. Today's grim milestone deepened an already widespread feeling that these kinds of international conferences -- and the vast and often violent protests they inspire -- cannot go on unchanged any longer.

keywords: CHRETIEN, JEAN; BUSH, GEORGE W; JAPAN; GERMANY; CANADA; FRANCE; GENOA (ITALY); KYOTO PROTOCOL; WEATHER; GLOBAL WARMING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: ALLIES TELL BUSH THEY'LL ACT ALONE ON CLIMATE ACCORD
snippet: As tens of thousands of demonstrators marched toward the center of this ancient city and occasionally clashed with the police, the United States' leading allies told President Bush today that they intended to move ahead and ratify the Kyoto Protocol...
lead_paragraph: As tens of thousands of demonstrators marched toward the center of this ancient city and occasionally clashed with the police, the United States' leading allies told President Bush today that they intended to move ahead and ratify the Kyoto Protocol on global warming by next year, even without American participation. At the summit meeting of top industrial nations, protesters and riot police clashed anew, one day after a protester was killed. Today as many as 50,000 demonstrators flowed through the streets of Genoa, but outside the center of the city, where the leaders were sequestered.

keywords: GENOA (ITALY); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: G-8 and Main Protest Groups Concur on Stopping Violence
snippet: As both sides left Genoa, the leaders of the major industrialized nations who met here and the mainstream protest leaders began reflecting today on how to carry out their goals while avoiding the fatal violence that marred this year's meeting.   ...
lead_paragraph: As both sides left Genoa, the leaders of the major industrialized nations who met here and the mainstream protest leaders began reflecting today on how to carry out their goals while avoiding the fatal violence that marred this year's meeting. About all they agreed upon was: never again.

headline: A Day After Seeing Putin, a Harder-Line Bush Emerges
snippet: President Bush said today that ''time is of the essence'' in his new arms talks with Moscow and warned that he would move ahead with testing missile shield technology even if he did not reach an agreement that would scrap the Antiballistic Missile...
lead_paragraph: President Bush said today that ''time is of the essence'' in his new arms talks with Moscow and warned that he would move ahead with testing missile shield technology even if he did not reach an agreement that would scrap the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. Mr. Bush's comments came only a day after he and President Vladimir V. Putin agreed to begin ''consultations'' that would tie deep cuts in the nuclear arsenals of both nations to the discussions on new defensive technologies. They were much more toughly worded than anything he had said publicly in Mr. Putin's presence in Genoa, Italy.

keywords: IBRAHIM-NEJAD, EZAT; IRAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
headline: Iran Court Won't Pursue Slain Protester's Case
snippet: A court has ruled that it has no authority to pursue a murder prosecution in the case of a man who was killed two years ago in a clash between pro-reform students and hard-line vigilantes. The court found that the man brought on the attack by taking...
lead_paragraph: A court has ruled that it has no authority to pursue a murder prosecution in the case of a man who was killed two years ago in a clash between pro-reform students and hard-line vigilantes. The court found that the man brought on the attack by taking part in the protest. The Revolution Court, in a decision published a week ago in a daily, Norouz, said the victim, Ezat Ibrahim-nejad, 25, had provoked the students to violence by chanting songs that urged them to defend themselves in their demonstration on July 8, 1999, in support of President Mohammad Khatami. Mr. Ibrahim-nejad had been visiting friends at the dormitory on the day of the protest.

headline: Melee at Jerusalem's Most Sacred, and Explosive, Site
snippet: Jerusalem and its sacred places returned to the center of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today when Palestinians on an elevated Muslim compound hurled stones at Jews praying below, provoking a battle with the Israeli police.    Hundreds of Israeli...
lead_paragraph: Jerusalem and its sacred places returned to the center of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today when Palestinians on an elevated Muslim compound hurled stones at Jews praying below, provoking a battle with the Israeli police. Hundreds of Israeli officers in riot gear rushed into the Aksa compound after a barrage of rocks, some quite large, sent Jewish worshipers fleeing from the Western Wall. The attack came on a day when Jews traditionally gather there to mourn the destruction of two ancient temples.

keywords: HAGER, MORGAN; HAGER, SUSAN; BERLUSCONI, SILVIO; ITALY; GENOA (ITALY); GROUP OF EIGHT; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Outcry Grows Over Police Use of Force in Genoa
snippet: More than two weeks ago, Susan Hager received a telephone call in Portland, Ore., about her daughter, a student who had stopped off in Genoa to join protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting on her way to a junior year abroad program in Siena.   ...
lead_paragraph: More than two weeks ago, Susan Hager received a telephone call in Portland, Ore., about her daughter, a student who had stopped off in Genoa to join protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting on her way to a junior year abroad program in Siena. ''Her friend had found her bloody belongings'' at the Armando Diaz school complex in Genoa where protesters had been staying, Mrs. Hager said. There, in the early hours of July 22, 92 young people were dragged from their beds by squads of Italian anti-riot police officers who beat and jailed them.

keywords: MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); RESTAN (MACEDONIA); TETOVO (MACEDONIA); CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
headline: Violence on Both Sides in Macedonia Mars Peace Accord
snippet: Do you want to see my boy?'' Sabir Veseli asked. He climbed up to the porch where, on muggy nights like last night, his three children go out to sleep.     Last night, after 11 p.m., two bullets were fired from the road. The children scattered. A...
lead_paragraph: Do you want to see my boy?'' Sabir Veseli asked. He climbed up to the porch where, on muggy nights like last night, his three children go out to sleep. Last night, after 11 p.m., two bullets were fired from the road. The children scattered. A dozen more shots hit the porch, one of which passed through his oldest son, Tafil, 11. The bullet went in at the small of his back and out just below his navel.

keywords: FISHER, PETE; COACHES AND MANAGERS; SEX CRIMES; TENNIS
headline: Paroled Ex-Coach Is Upbeat
snippet: On the bus trip toward a prison in the California desert three years ago, Pete Fischer sat motionless, with his eyes fixed straight ahead and his mouth shut tight.    He wanted to blend in, not create a stir. And yet, his camouflage as an...
lead_paragraph: On the bus trip toward a prison in the California desert three years ago, Pete Fischer sat motionless, with his eyes fixed straight ahead and his mouth shut tight. He wanted to blend in, not create a stir. And yet, his camouflage as an inconspicuous inmate vanished. A seat away, another prisoner recognized Fischer's face from the news as the prominent Los Angeles pediatrician who drew up the blueprint for Pete Sampras's career but had been convicted of molesting some of his young patients.

keywords: BECK, JAMES; KUREDJIAN, HAGOP; SANTA CLARITA (CALIF); ATTACKS ON POLICE; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; FIREARMS; TEAR GAS
headline: Gunman Kills Deputy and Is Believed to Die in Fire
snippet: A man sought by federal agents shot and killed a sheriff's deputy today, the authorities said, then barricaded himself inside his home, which caught fire after officers lobbed tear gas inside.    The authorities said they believed that the gunman...
lead_paragraph: A man sought by federal agents shot and killed a sheriff's deputy today, the authorities said, then barricaded himself inside his home, which caught fire after officers lobbed tear gas inside. The authorities said they believed that the gunman remained inside as the blaze gutted the house. A search of the rubble was under way this evening, but officers said that although the man was probably dead, they had not yet found his body.

keywords: SCHELL, PAUL; SIDRAN, MARK; NICKELS, GREG; SEATTLE (WASH); MAYORS; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; ELECTIONS; PRIMARIES
headline: Primary Voters Reject Seattle Mayor After One Term
snippet: For the first time in 65 years, voters here have thrown out an incumbent mayor in a primary election, ousting the one-term mayor, Paul Schell, on Tuesday after a turbulent four years in which the city's image took a battering and its economy...
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 65 years, voters here have thrown out an incumbent mayor in a primary election, ousting the one-term mayor, Paul Schell, on Tuesday after a turbulent four years in which the city's image took a battering and its economy stumbled. Two veteran city leaders will now face each other in the November election.

keywords: WACKENHUT, RICHARD R; NEW YORK CITY; WASHINGTON (DC); WACKENHUT CORP; WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; COMPANY AND ORGANIZATION PROFILES; HIJACKING; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; GUARDS; TERRORISM
headline: Private Sector; A Security Virtuoso's Big Test
snippet: RICHARD R. WACKENHUT grew up in the security business. He is the son of an F.B.I. special agent who started his own company 47 years ago. It provided Mr. Wackenhut's first employment. He started as a guard, then graduated to investigator, then sales...
lead_paragraph: RICHARD R. WACKENHUT grew up in the security business. He is the son of an F.B.I. special agent who started his own company 47 years ago. It provided Mr. Wackenhut's first employment. He started as a guard, then graduated to investigator, then sales representative, then management. Today the Wackenhut Corporation, which he took over in 1986 from his father, George R. Wackenhut, is one of the largest independent security companies in the United States, a leading provider of private security overseas and a major operator of privatized prisons. It has contracts with the government to protect many of the nation's nuclear sites, Defense Department installations and some American embassies..

keywords: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Arab-Israeli Cease-Fire? The Deaths Are Mounting, Along With the Finger-Pointing
snippet: Here is what a quiet day looks like during the nominal ceasefire in Israel: today, just one car, packed with explosives, nails, and ammunition, blew up along a busy street here, and it did not hurt anybody.     The Bush administration has urgently...
lead_paragraph: Here is what a quiet day looks like during the nominal ceasefire in Israel: today, just one car, packed with explosives, nails, and ammunition, blew up along a busy street here, and it did not hurt anybody. The Bush administration has urgently sought a truce between Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's coalition government and Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority. But so far the antagonists' mincing steps toward peace have yielded what is, even by this region's standards, a most unstable situation: a cease-fire that won't, a unity government that isn't, and a Palestinian Authority that doesn't have much, or at least won't exercise it to the Israelis' satisfaction.

keywords: NEW YORK CITY; PAKISTAN; WASHINGTON (DC); QUETTA (PAKISTAN); AFGHANISTAN; WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PENTAGON BUILDING; MISSING PERSONS; HIJACKING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: In Streets of Pakistani Cities, Cries of 'Death to America!'
snippet: Chaudary Umadali stood in the blackened ruins of his movie theater this afternoon, a dignified man trying to make sense of the rage that led to its destruction.    ''They broke the windows and came inside with petrol bottles,'' he said, gazing at...
lead_paragraph: Chaudary Umadali stood in the blackened ruins of his movie theater this afternoon, a dignified man trying to make sense of the rage that led to its destruction. ''They broke the windows and came inside with petrol bottles,'' he said, gazing at puddles of sooty water and shards of glass. ''There were a thousand people. They set fire to my cinema'' -- because it was playing an American film, ''Desperado.''

keywords: ARAFAT, YASIR; NEW YORK CITY; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; AFGHANISTAN; WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; PENTAGON BUILDING; MISSING PERSONS; HIJACKING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Arafat's Policemen Kill 2 Palestinians At Anti-U.S. Rally
snippet: Protests against the airstrikes in Afghanistan erupted into extraordinary confrontations today in the Gaza Strip, when Palestinian security forces opened fire on Palestinian student demonstrators and killed at least two people, including a...
lead_paragraph: Protests against the airstrikes in Afghanistan erupted into extraordinary confrontations today in the Gaza Strip, when Palestinian security forces opened fire on Palestinian student demonstrators and killed at least two people, including a 13-year-old boy. In sending his own police against a crowd of some 2,000 Palestinians, Yasir Arafat appeared to make a clear choice in the international battle against terror: he is with the United States, and against Osama bin Laden. But, on a day when Mr. Arafat, like many other Arab leaders, enveloped himself in silence, it was not clear why he had decided to act as he did.

keywords: NEW YORK CITY; WASHINGTON (DC); WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; PALESTINIANS; PENTAGON BUILDING; MISSING PERSONS; HIJACKING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Arafat Decides to Take A Gamble on the West
snippet: Today, Yasir Arafat took a gamble, confronting a radical Palestinian crowd in a bid to shore up his own position and assert his international credibility as the possible leader of a Palestinian state.     For the first time in years, Mr. Arafat's...
lead_paragraph: Today, Yasir Arafat took a gamble, confronting a radical Palestinian crowd in a bid to shore up his own position and assert his international credibility as the possible leader of a Palestinian state. For the first time in years, Mr. Arafat's security forces used deadly force against Palestinians to suppress a demonstration in support of Osama bin Laden. In a cloud of tear gas and a hail of bullets, two Palestinians -- one of them only 13 -- were slain. Another was close to death.

snippet: Anti-American demonstrations widened in Indonesia today, with riot police firing tear gas to disperse angry protesters outside the United States Embassy in Jakarta.    The protests, in at least four cities, remained relatively small, but radical...
lead_paragraph: Anti-American demonstrations widened in Indonesia today, with riot police firing tear gas to disperse angry protesters outside the United States Embassy in Jakarta. The protests, in at least four cities, remained relatively small, but radical Muslim groups said they were preparing larger demonstrations and repeated their warnings that they might attack foreigners here.

headline: Thousands of Pakistanis Demonstrate but Police Hold Down the Violence
snippet: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets across Pakistan today to protest American attacks on Afghanistan and their country's support for the American-led alliance.    But a bristling display of troops and weaponry kept violence to a minimum in...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets across Pakistan today to protest American attacks on Afghanistan and their country's support for the American-led alliance. But a bristling display of troops and weaponry kept violence to a minimum in what appeared to be a victory for President Pervez Musharraf's get-tough policy with protesters.

headline: Shaping Young Islamic Hearts and Hatreds
snippet: A thousand years ago, in the days of the camel caravans, storytellers gathered here in the tea shops and brought the outside world and all its thoughts and ideas to the bazaar. As the vendors hawked silk, spice and rich tapestries and traders herded...
lead_paragraph: A thousand years ago, in the days of the camel caravans, storytellers gathered here in the tea shops and brought the outside world and all its thoughts and ideas to the bazaar. As the vendors hawked silk, spice and rich tapestries and traders herded beasts through streets thick with smoke from cooking fires, travelers from distant lands and differing religions told stories about moguls, magic, wit and wisdom. In time, the bazaar came to be known as Qissa Khwani -- the Bazaar of the Storytellers. Now, the streets are still choked with donkey carts, and meat still sizzles on open pits, but the vendors are poor men selling simple things. Blaring car horns drown out all other sound, just as the teachers and students in the Islamic seminaries that surround this bazaar have drowned out all conflicting ideas, all unacceptable thoughts.

lead_paragraph: Two demonstrators were killed and at least six were wounded today when the police fired on a stone-throwing crowd trying to block entrances to an airport where American aircraft are based to provide logistical support for airstrikes on Afghanistan. Several thousand protesters evaded a security cordon set up around the city of Jacobabad in southern Pakistan and tried to reach the airport, prompting police officers and paramilitary rangers to open fire with live ammunition and tear gas.

headline: Reporter's Notebook; In Quiet Corners, the Roots of Afghan Rebellion
snippet: While bombs fall in Afghanistan, a quieter war is being waged in the dusty border city of Quetta and, farther north, in the mud-brick city of Peshawar. It is a clandestine affair, intended to win converts for an attempt to overthrow the Taliban.   ...
lead_paragraph: While bombs fall in Afghanistan, a quieter war is being waged in the dusty border city of Quetta and, farther north, in the mud-brick city of Peshawar. It is a clandestine affair, intended to win converts for an attempt to overthrow the Taliban. Mujahedeen commanders, tribal chiefs and other prominent Afghans opposed to the ruling Taliban gather in carpet shops, in coffee houses and behind closed doors in both cities to discuss shifting alliances and strategies for exploiting a schism among Taliban leaders. Some travel from Afghanistan, crossing the mountains for talks that could shape the future of their country and the outcome of the American war.

headline: Carry-On Rules: List Grows Long
snippet: DO not try flying US Airways with a pinned-up hem, or for that matter, with a red, white and blue ribbon affixed to your shirt. Because a safety pin -- along with all sharp objects and anything else that could be used as a weapon -- will be...
lead_paragraph: DO not try flying US Airways with a pinned-up hem, or for that matter, with a red, white and blue ribbon affixed to your shirt. Because a safety pin -- along with all sharp objects and anything else that could be used as a weapon -- will be confiscated if you try to take it aboard, according to signs posted throughout La Guardia's US Airways terminal. Cigarette lighters and hockey sticks are also on the carrier's list of prohibited objects. The list was taken from an Federal Aviation Administration directive issued after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and has inspired just some of the adjustments passengers will have to accept as part of the attempt by the United States to make the skies safe.

snippet: The police in Nairobi have arrested 70 people who were campaigning on behalf of political prisoners for holding what the authorities called an illegal political meeting. Using tear gas, the police raided the offices of Release Political Prisoners on...
lead_paragraph: The police in Nairobi have arrested 70 people who were campaigning on behalf of political prisoners for holding what the authorities called an illegal political meeting. Using tear gas, the police raided the offices of Release Political Prisoners on Saturday and made the arrests. Willy Mutunga, executive director of the Kenya Human Rights Commission, said the detainees had now become political prisoners themselves. Marc Lacey (NYT)

keywords: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN; MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY; FOOTBALL
headline: In Michigan, Very Different States of Mind
snippet: Although the skies were overcast, the man who called himself John Spirit wore sunglasses as he scanned the perimeter of the traffic island for potential vandals. He was protecting ''The Spartan,'' a 10-foot ceramic statue of a barely clothed warrior...
lead_paragraph: Although the skies were overcast, the man who called himself John Spirit wore sunglasses as he scanned the perimeter of the traffic island for potential vandals. He was protecting ''The Spartan,'' a 10-foot ceramic statue of a barely clothed warrior near the football stadium of the Michigan State Spartans. The autumn wind swirled dead leaves around the feet of both ''The Spartan'' and John Spirit. Both stood strong and vigilant. In the past, before the big game between Michigan State and Michigan, students drove 60 miles from the Michigan campus in Ann Arbor to splash the big icon with maize and blue paint, the colors of the Michigan Wolverines.

lead_paragraph: Sayira Marín's hands still tremble as she recalls the Americans' invasion of Panama in 1989 and how her impoverished neighborhood, El Chorrillo, was caught in the cross-fire. Ms. Marín, now 25, wonders how Afghan civilians will emerge after weeks of bombing, which, no matter how precise, has already claimed some innocent lives.

lead_paragraph: A Nepalese man was indicted today on a federal charge of trying to carry weapons onto an airplane, after the authorities said airline workers caught him boarding a flight to Omaha this weekend with several knives, a stun gun and a can of pepper spray. Eight employees of a private security company have been suspended for failing to detect the weapons in the man's carry-on bags at an earlier security checkpoint, although they did find two other knives in his pockets.

lead_paragraph: ANYONE gathering evidence to support growing suspicions that the airport security system is pretty much out of control has to be looking this week at Subash Bahadur Gurung as Exhibit A. Mr. Gurung, 27, a Napalese national living in Chicago on a student visa that expired in 1999, was at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago for a flight to Omaha, late Saturday afternoon when he set off the metal detector at the security gate. Security guards found two knives in his pocket.

snippet: Three security workers who let a man carrying knives, a stun gun and tear gas through a checkpoint at O'Hare International Airport were fired, and a fourth resigned, according to Argenbright Security, the company that employed them. The Federal...
lead_paragraph: Three security workers who let a man carrying knives, a stun gun and tear gas through a checkpoint at O'Hare International Airport were fired, and a fourth resigned, according to Argenbright Security, the company that employed them. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating Saturday's lapse at the United Airlines checkpoint. The weapons were found by United employees during a hand search at the gate. Subash Gurang, 27, of Chicago, a Nepal native in the United States on an expired student visa, was arrested by Chicago police. He was scheduled to appear today at a hearing before United States Magistrate Judge Morton Denlow.

keywords: QATAR; DOHA (QATAR); SEATTLE (WASH); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; EDITORIALS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
headline: Up From Seattle
snippet: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and...
lead_paragraph: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and wealthy countries' priorities blew up in a cloud of tear gas. The whole world has an interest in seeing this gathering turn out better. With the world's terrorized economy stuck at a standstill, the time is ripe for a cooperative, international push for growth through trade. The ministers' goal in Qatar is to launch a new set of comprehensive trade negotiations. During the original Uruguay Round, which led to the creation of the W.T.O., rich countries pledged to open their markets to textiles, crops and other basic exports from the developing world. There has been some progress in that area, but arcane customs rules, unnecessary red tape, stingy quotas and anti-dumping programs still keep poor nations' exports out of wealthy markets. Now protectionist politicians are trying to erect more barriers by exploiting concerns about border security and food safety.

snippet: Thousands of supporters of Pakistan's Islamic parties marched in several cities today, blocking roads, burning tires and clashing with police officers who lobbed tear gas canisters and, in one case, killed at least three protesters.    But the...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of supporters of Pakistan's Islamic parties marched in several cities today, blocking roads, burning tires and clashing with police officers who lobbed tear gas canisters and, in one case, killed at least three protesters. But the protests fell short of the parties' goal of paralyzing the country. A significant number of shops remained open and cars moved freely here just south of the capital, Islamabad, and elsewhere.

lead_paragraph: Organized labor and students come together. 1940-50 As interest in Communism and Socialism flourishes, the party forms many youth adjuncts on campuses. Labor unions also recruit heavily and openly, mobilizing labor-led student groups like the American Youth for Democracy, the American Student Union and the American Student Congress to fight, among other issues, low pay and racial discrimination in the workplace.

headline: Nathan Pusey, Harvard President Through Growth and Turmoil Alike, Dies at 94
snippet: Nathan M. Pusey, who led Harvard University through tremendous growth and liberalization only to be swept away in a storm over Vietnam-era protests, died yesterday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 94 and lived on the East Side.  ...
lead_paragraph: Nathan M. Pusey, who led Harvard University through tremendous growth and liberalization only to be swept away in a storm over Vietnam-era protests, died yesterday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 94 and lived on the East Side. In Dr. Pusey's tenure as Harvard's 24th president, from 1953 to 1971, the university's budget quadrupled, as did its endowments. The campus was transformed by the construction of more than 30 buildings, which almost doubled its floor space. The permanent population of teachers and administrators swelled to 8,500 from 3,000, and Dr. Pusey made higher salaries and improved benefits a priority.

headline: I.M.F. Plans For Recovery, But Avoids Terror Issue
snippet: The International Monetary Fund pressed the world's leading nations today to cut interest rates further if needed to shore up a bleak world economy, while outside the meeting globalization protesters braved the Canadian chill.    Finance ministers...
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund pressed the world's leading nations today to cut interest rates further if needed to shore up a bleak world economy, while outside the meeting globalization protesters braved the Canadian chill. Finance ministers and central bankers from around the world met to chart the actions the fund would take in the months ahead to try to counter an increasingly dour and uncertain global economic outlook.

lead_paragraph: Riot police officers fired rubber bullets and tear gas today at hundreds of supporters of President Hugo Chávez who attacked some 2,000 antigovernment demonstrators on the streets of the capital. Several people were injured in skirmishes around the National Assembly building. The city police struggled to separate about 300 government loyalists from demonstrators carrying placards reading ''Chávez Out.''

headline: Israeli Missiles Hit Arafat Compound and Other Sites
snippet: In the most wide-ranging attack on Palestinian areas in 14 months of conflict, Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded security offices today in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores.  ...
lead_paragraph: In the most wide-ranging attack on Palestinian areas in 14 months of conflict, Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded security offices today in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores. Helicopters fired three missiles into the walled compound here of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat. The missiles destroyed several cars and punched a hole in the stone wall of a police building less than 100 yards from Mr. Arafat's office, where he was said to have been at work.

headline: A Bare Budget Provokes Another Strike In Argentina
snippet: Several major unions staged a 24-hour nationwide strike today, crippling businesses and government functions. They were protesting austerity measures intended to avert a default on the $132 billion public sector debt and economic collapse.    Retail...
lead_paragraph: Several major unions staged a 24-hour nationwide strike today, crippling businesses and government functions. They were protesting austerity measures intended to avert a default on the $132 billion public sector debt and economic collapse. Retail businesses, railroads, bus service, schools, theaters and garbage collection all halted operations, and hospitals were open only for emergency services. Tens of thousands of workers who did not strike stayed home because of breakdowns in transportation.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 Argentine Leader Declares State of Siege Amid Looting President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across the country. The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas in several cities, and four people were killed. The disturbances appeared to be a mix of spontaneous pilferage by unemployed workers and organized protests by government opponents. A3 New Terms for Colombia Aid The House attached a series of conditions to aid to Colombia, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. headline: Reeling From Riots, Argentina Declares a State of Siege
snippet: President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across Argentina today, and the police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at rock-throwing protesters in Buenos Aires and several provincial cities....
lead_paragraph: President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across Argentina today, and the police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at rock-throwing protesters in Buenos Aires and several provincial cities. Five people were killed in the rioting. The most widespread social disturbances since the 1980's came on a sweltering summer day. The near anarchy in many cities appeared to be a mix of spontaneous pilferage by the unemployed seeking to put food on their Christmas tables and organized protests to force the tottering government of Mr. de la Rúa to give up power.

headline: Challenge for Algeria: Berber Anger
snippet: When Ouardia Guermah tells the story, her eyes rest on the spot where her son used to do his math homework, right there at the brown Formica dining room table, with the metal legs and the clean white doily on top.     Her son, Massinissa, was seated...
lead_paragraph: When Ouardia Guermah tells the story, her eyes rest on the spot where her son used to do his math homework, right there at the brown Formica dining room table, with the metal legs and the clean white doily on top. Her son, Massinissa, was seated there the evening he heard a fight outside and went to investigate. He never came back. Witnesses say the gendarmes took him down the road to the station house. There, while he was already semiconscious from a beating, they shot him 27 times, Mrs. Guermah said.

lead_paragraph: Guards fired tear gas and wooden bullets today to quell a riot by about 300 inmates at a crowded state prison that left 5 inmates seriously injured, the authorities said. Fighting broke out in a prison yard about 10:45 a.m., Margot Bach, a state prison spokeswoman, said.

snippet: As Israeli military pressure on Yasir Arafat eased slightly today, the pressure on him from Palestinian extremists grew.    Defying efforts by Mr. Arafat to arrest him and to restrain his militant group, Dr. Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, a top political...
lead_paragraph: As Israeli military pressure on Yasir Arafat eased slightly today, the pressure on him from Palestinian extremists grew. Defying efforts by Mr. Arafat to arrest him and to restrain his militant group, Dr. Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, a top political leader of Hamas, said today that Hamas's military wing intended to continue sending suicidal attackers against Israel. For a second night, forces of Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority clashed with Hamas supporters near Dr. Rantisi's house.

headline: ARGENTINE LEADER, HIS NATION FRAYED, ABRUPTLY RESIGNS
snippet: President Fernando de la Rúa resigned today, halfway through his four-year term, swamped by violent protests and looting that erupted when his government failed to reverse a deepening economic crisis.    The resignation letter, which was delivered...
lead_paragraph: President Fernando de la Rúa resigned today, halfway through his four-year term, swamped by violent protests and looting that erupted when his government failed to reverse a deepening economic crisis. The resignation letter, which was delivered to Congress late in the day, followed violent food riots and protests here and in several cities. At least five demonstrators were killed today, bringing the death toll to 21 since the protests began early Wednesday.

headline: 500 Asylum-Seekers Try to Dash Through Channel Tunnel
snippet: More than 500 asylum-seekers broke through fences overnight and early today in two waves and stormed into the Channel tunnel as they made a mad dash for Britain, forcing the tunnel to close for 10 hours and raising new tensions between France and...
lead_paragraph: More than 500 asylum-seekers broke through fences overnight and early today in two waves and stormed into the Channel tunnel as they made a mad dash for Britain, forcing the tunnel to close for 10 hours and raising new tensions between France and Britain over illegal migration. All the escapees were captured by the French, said the British police, who had 60 officers waiting for them with dogs at a point halfway through the tunnel.

keywords: BERENSON, LORI HELENE; PERU; SEX CRIMES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Mistreatment Of Berenson Denied
snippet: The government denied assertions that Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year sentence for aiding a leftist rebel group, was mistreated while being transferred to another prison last week. But her lawyer said he would broaden a complaint he had...
lead_paragraph: The government denied assertions that Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year sentence for aiding a leftist rebel group, was mistreated while being transferred to another prison last week. But her lawyer said he would broaden a complaint he had filed to include an accusation of sexual abuse. Her father, Mark Berenson, has also said she was molested. The justice ministry said that it ''denies the 'grave injury' her lawyers have denounced'' and that Ms. Berenson, 32, is ''in good health.'' Ms. Berenson's lawyer, José Luís Sandoval, said she was beaten and sprayed with tear gas by the police when she and another prisoner were taken from their cells last Friday. He also said Ms. Berenson had been fondled by a police officer. The justice ministry said that the transfer had been carried out according to regulations and that tear gas had been used when prisoners resisted the police.

headline: Bons Mots? You Decide''
snippet: THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness.    Were you paying attention? Try...
lead_paragraph: THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness. Were you paying attention? Try this test. PART 1 Who spoke these words and about what? 1) ''It is not good news for America.'' 2) ''She has the full support of the board and will continue to lead the company through these challenging times.'' 3) ''The more I see about this deal, the less I like it.'' 4) ''I was smiling going in, because how often in your life do you and your company have an opportunity to make a difference?'' 5) ''I have no desire to be next at bat.'' 6) ''We are on the side of angels.'' 7) ''This is an industrial policy designed for shareholders of the winning companies.'' 8) ''It would be a good time for all parties to sit down together and see what kind of resolution can be worked out.'' 9) ''Today, America goes back to business.'' 10) ''What keeps me up at night is doing my own e-mail. I wouldn't say that anything keeps me up at night worrying.'' PART 2 What were these people talking about when they spoke these words? 1) In April, a senior Bush administration official said, ''It would be like having a cheeseburger without cheese.'' 2) In March, Dick Conway, an economist in Seattle, said, ''Well, it has made us forget the earthquake all of a sudden.'' 3) In September, Alexander Danielides, a junior at the Bronx High School of Science, said, ''The Vietnam generation is a little more cautious than we would be.'' 4) In April, Ira Kay, a consultant at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, said, ''It's the gift that keeps on giving.'' 5) In June, Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana, said: ''It is one thing for one shark to eat another. It is quite another for the shark to eat the minnows.'' 6) In April, Elliot Schrage, senior vice president for global affairs at Gap Inc., said: ''We are not the all-powerful Oz that rules over what happens in every factory. Do we have leverage? Yes. Is it as great as our critics believe? Not by a long shot.'' 7) In March, Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, said, ''I've decided to take this issue off the table.'' 8) In December, Thomas R. Eisenmann, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, said, ''This was another big move in this continuing clash of titans.'' 9) In January, Kathleen Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman for Lucent Technologies, said, ''Henry decided it was not the best use of our assets.'' 10) In September, Fay Weldon said: ''I thought: 'Oh no, dear me, I am a literary author. You can't do this kind of thing; my name will be mud forever.' But then after a while I thought: 'I don't care. Let it be mud.' '' ''Answers to the Quiz'' PART 1 1) President Bush, commenting on the October unemployment rate. 2) Stanley Silverstein, general counsel of Warnaco, speaking about its chief executive, Linda J. Wachner, as Warnaco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June. Mrs. Wachner was fired in November. 3) Walter B. Hewlett, declaring his opposition to Hewlett-Packard's plan to merge with Compaq Computer. 4) Helge H. Wehmeier, chief executive of Bayer's American operations, referring to the company's agreement to sell its anthrax medicine, Cipro, to the government at a discounted price. 5) Robert W. Pittman, chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, after his peer and rival, Richard D. Parsons, was named to succeed Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive, next May. 6) Jeffrey K. Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, in March, dismissing critics who saw Enron as a profiteer in California's energy crisis. 7) Robert B. Reich, former secretary of labor, criticizing the legislation passed to bail out the nation's airlines after the terrorist attacks. 8) Bill Gates, in June, commenting after a federal appeals court threw out a lower court's order that Microsoft be broken up. 9) Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, reopening the exchange after it was closed for four days as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks. 10) Gordon E. Moore, co-founder of Fairchild Semiconductor and the Intel Corporation, upon his retirement last spring, discussing the widespread use of personal computers. PART 2 1) He was referring in general to the demonstrations that accompany world trade talks (in this case, the Summit of the Americas that took place in Quebec) and specifically to the tear gas that authorities use to break up the protests. 2) He was commenting on the announcement that Boeing was moving its corporate headquarters out of Seattle after decades as the mainstay of the region's economy. 3) This teenage investor was talking, a few days after Sept. 11, about the willingness of his generation to stay in the stock market when conventional wisdom suggested otherwise. 4) He was describing reload stock options, a form of compensation that gives executives who exercise them both a share of stock and a new option. 5) He was questioning Wall Street's erosion of ethical conduct at a Congressional hearing on conflicts among brokerage firm research analysts. 6) He was commenting on the difficulties of trying to improve conditions in foreign factories. 7) He was announcing his decision to sell about $100 million worth of Alcoa stock and options that he had planned to keep. 8) He was referring to the battle over broadband between AOL Time Warner and Microsoft after Comcast outbid rivals for AT&T's cable television business. 9) She was discussing the decision by Henry B. Schacht, the interim chief executive of Lucent, to sell the Hamilton Farm Golf Club, an expensive white elephant that the company developed before its fortunes plunged, causing huge layoffs, write-offs and restructuring. 10) She was commenting on her new novel, ''The Bulgari Connection,'' for which Bulgari, the Italian jewelry company, paid her an undisclosed amount in return for a prominent place in the book.

headline: STORMING THE CHUNNEL
snippet: About 500 asylum-seekers who live at a refugee camp near the French end of the Channel Tunnel made a break for England. In two waves, the men -- mostly Afghans, Iranians and Kurds -- broke the electric fence guarding the entrance. Some poured into...
lead_paragraph: About 500 asylum-seekers who live at a refugee camp near the French end of the Channel Tunnel made a break for England. In two waves, the men -- mostly Afghans, Iranians and Kurds -- broke the electric fence guarding the entrance. Some poured into the tunnel to be chased down by the French police. Others were captured in the barrage of tear gas laid down in the rail yards. Some ran for miles, but none reached the middle of the 30-mile tunnel -- where they would have met British officers with dogs. The incident prompted increased calls for the camp's closure. Donald G. McNeil Jr.

keywords: WEST BANK; BEIT UMAR (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS; PALESTINIANS; TERRORISM
headline: Israelis Bring Help to Arabs In a Village Under Siege
snippet: Hundreds of Israelis and Palestinians met at the barricades outside this embattled village today, but instead of bullets and stones the air was filled with hands lifting sacks of rice, bags of sugar and jugs of cooking oil.    In a rare gesture in...
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Israelis and Palestinians met at the barricades outside this embattled village today, but instead of bullets and stones the air was filled with hands lifting sacks of rice, bags of sugar and jugs of cooking oil. In a rare gesture in this weary land, more than 250 Israeli peace advocates delivered about two tons of food and clothing to 12,000 Palestinian residents of Beit Umar, which has been closed by the Israeli military blockade for more than a year.

keywords: CAMANO, EDUARDO; RODRIGUEZ SAA, ADOLFO; PUERTA, RAMON; BUSH, GEORGE W; ARGENTINA; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ARGENTINA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; ELECTIONS
headline: Argentina Drifts, Leaderless, as Economic Collapse Looms
snippet: Without a president, a cabinet or a functioning government, Argentina drifted rudderless today, as people waited for the Peronist party to resolve its bitter internal differences over who should run the country and for how long.    The surprise...
lead_paragraph: Without a president, a cabinet or a functioning government, Argentina drifted rudderless today, as people waited for the Peronist party to resolve its bitter internal differences over who should run the country and for how long. The surprise resignation of the interim president, Adolfo Rodríguez Saá, late Sunday means that by Tuesday Argentina is likely to have its fifth leader in less than two weeks, counting temporary caretakers.

keywords: LIMA (PERU); FIRES AND FIREMEN; EXPLOSIONS; FIREWORKS
headline: Grieving and Looking for Survivors in a Charred Lima
snippet: From the charred and soggy streets of the empty Mesa Redonda shopping district to clogged and sun-baked sidewalks outside the central morgue, people were desperately clinging today to the old year. For many of them, the remaining hours offered the...
lead_paragraph: From the charred and soggy streets of the empty Mesa Redonda shopping district to clogged and sun-baked sidewalks outside the central morgue, people were desperately clinging today to the old year. For many of them, the remaining hours offered the slimmest hope that their loved ones survived the fireworks explosions that sent fireballs racing through the narrow streets of the district on Saturday night, setting four blocks ablaze and killing nearly 300 people. Wilfredo Palomino spent the morning holding a fruitless vigil outside the morgue, where the line of relatives snaked down the busy block and onto the lawn. His wife, Rosa, had taken a job selling fireworks with one of the many street vendors in Mesa Redonda only last Friday, after he lost his tailor's job on Christmas Eve. Poverty cost her her life, her mother said, but he refused to believe it.

keywords: MWANAWASA, LEVY; ZAMBIA; INAUGURATIONS; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Charging Vote Fraud, Crowds Storm Zambian Supreme Court
snippet: More than a thousand angry opposition party supporters took to the streets today and clashed with the riot police as dozens of protesters stormed into the Supreme Court to accuse the Zambian government of rigging the presidential election last week. ...
lead_paragraph: More than a thousand angry opposition party supporters took to the streets today and clashed with the riot police as dozens of protesters stormed into the Supreme Court to accuse the Zambian government of rigging the presidential election last week. Judge Peter Chitengi, who was considering delaying the presidential inauguration because of the reported electoral irregularities, rushed into his chambers when he heard the shouts and whistles of the oncoming crowd. Behind closed doors, he ordered the government not to release the final election results tonight.

keywords: DUHALDE, EDUARDO; ARGENTINA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Populist Argentine Senator Steps In to Fill the Void, Becoming 5th President in 2 Weeks
snippet: Eduardo Duhalde, a veteran Peronist politician with a strong populist streak, was chosen late tonight as Argentina's fifth president in less than two weeks. He immediately announced that he would form a ''government of national unity'' in a...
lead_paragraph: Eduardo Duhalde, a veteran Peronist politician with a strong populist streak, was chosen late tonight as Argentina's fifth president in less than two weeks. He immediately announced that he would form a ''government of national unity'' in a last-ditch effort to bring the country back from what he called ''the verge of disintegration and chaos.'' ''We're at the limit and we know it,'' he said after being sworn in to run the country until the end of 2003. Though he acknowledged that ''we have no external or domestic credit,'' he nevertheless promised to run a government that will carry out ''a more just distribution of riches.''

keywords: MWANAWASA, LEVY; ZAMBIA; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Uneasy but Outwardly Calm, Zambia Swears In a President
snippet: The battered gate at the Supreme Court swung awkwardly on its hinges and shards of glass from smashed streetlights littered Independence Avenue. But with riot police preventing mass protests, this uneasy country inaugurated its president peacefully...
lead_paragraph: The battered gate at the Supreme Court swung awkwardly on its hinges and shards of glass from smashed streetlights littered Independence Avenue. But with riot police preventing mass protests, this uneasy country inaugurated its president peacefully today. Levy Mwanawasa, the candidate for the governing Movement for Multiparty Democracy, took his oath of office at the Supreme Court a day after more than a thousand opposition party supporters stormed the building, accusing the government of rigging the presidential election last week.

keywords: BLOOMBERG, MICHAEL R; NEW YORK CITY; WALDORF-ASTORIA HOTEL; WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: City Girds for Protests at Economic Summit Meeting
snippet: In the fall, the organizers of an annual summit meeting for the world's economic, political and academic leaders decided to move the conference from its usual site in Switzerland to New York City as a show of solidarity in the aftermath of the terror...
lead_paragraph: In the fall, the organizers of an annual summit meeting for the world's economic, political and academic leaders decided to move the conference from its usual site in Switzerland to New York City as a show of solidarity in the aftermath of the terror attacks. Security, the organizers were told by city and police officials of the Giuliani administration, would be little problem for a force accustomed to dealing with large-scale demonstrations. City and police officials of the Bloomberg administration have not backed off that pledge. But they acknowledge that the demonstrations expected during the World Economic Forum, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria from Jan. 31 to Feb. 4, could be unlike any seen before in the city.

keywords: LONDONDERRY (NORTHERN IRELAND); NORTHERN IRELAND; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY; REVIEWS; PHOTOGRAPHY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Is the Camera a Reliable Witness?
snippet: PHOTOGRAPHY walks many fine lines. Democratic and prolific by nature, it undermines old genius-at-work, precious-object ideas of art. At the same time, it keeps laying claim to art's special powers and perks. One of its traditional selling points is...
lead_paragraph: PHOTOGRAPHY walks many fine lines. Democratic and prolific by nature, it undermines old genius-at-work, precious-object ideas of art. At the same time, it keeps laying claim to art's special powers and perks. One of its traditional selling points is objectivity. Yet it's a medium of calculation: of measured light and chosen angles, of zooming in and editing out. These opposites define its tensions. Such tensions can be felt even in an exhibition as anti-elitist and programmatically didactic as ''Hidden Truths: Bloody Sunday 1972'' at the International Center of Photography. The show doesn't pretend for an instant to be art. Most of its dozens of pictures are digital scans of umpteenth generation press prints, images made to be transferred to newsprint and valued for information, not formal finesse.

keywords: DUHALDE, EDUARDO; ARGENTINA; CURRENCY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Argentine Peso Drops Sharply After Link to the Dollar Ends
snippet: Freed from its link to the American dollar for the first time in nearly 11 years, the Argentine peso dropped sharply on foreign exchange markets here today as the government ended an emergency bank holiday that had halted normal economic activity...
lead_paragraph: Freed from its link to the American dollar for the first time in nearly 11 years, the Argentine peso dropped sharply on foreign exchange markets here today as the government ended an emergency bank holiday that had halted normal economic activity since before Christmas. An initial wave of nervousness quickly drove down the peso's value to as low as 1.70 to the dollar on the open market, far from the fixed rate of one peso to one dollar that had prevailed before President Eduardo Duhalde was given sweeping economic powers on Sunday. The official exchange rate set then was 1.4 pesos to the dollar, but it applies almost exclusively to foreign trade transactions and is not available to individual Argentines.

headline: Nigerian Unions Strike, and Riots Erupt, Over Rising Fuel Prices
snippet: Rioters smashed windows and blocked streets with burning tires here today as labor unions began a general strike to protest higher fuel prices.    Demonstrators hurled stones at the police and attacked taxis and buses that ventured onto the streets....
lead_paragraph: Rioters smashed windows and blocked streets with burning tires here today as labor unions began a general strike to protest higher fuel prices. Demonstrators hurled stones at the police and attacked taxis and buses that ventured onto the streets. In several neighborhoods, the police responded with tear gas and by firing bullets into the air.

snippet: Israeli forces continued to step up military operations here after a Palestinian gunman opened fire on Thursday night on a Jewish family's celebration in the northern city of Hadera, killing 6 and wounding more than 30.    Israeli troops blew up the...
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces continued to step up military operations here after a Palestinian gunman opened fire on Thursday night on a Jewish family's celebration in the northern city of Hadera, killing 6 and wounding more than 30. Israeli troops blew up the Voice of Palestine radio station just before dawn this morning, engulfing the five-story building in flames and smoke, witnesses said.

headline: Arab Slays 2 and Wounds 20 After 4 Die in a Raid by Israel
snippet: Wearing a blue jacket and carrying an M-16 semiautomatic rifle, the young man looked like just another Israeli soldier, on guard even if off duty, as he strolled through Jerusalem's crowded shopping district late Tuesday afternoon.    But with a cry...
lead_paragraph: Wearing a blue jacket and carrying an M-16 semiautomatic rifle, the young man looked like just another Israeli soldier, on guard even if off duty, as he strolled through Jerusalem's crowded shopping district late Tuesday afternoon. But with a cry in Arabic of ''God is great!'' the man, a member of a Palestinian militant group, turned the rifle on passers-by, killing two women and wounding 20 other people as he sprayed bullets at two bus stops and several stores.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Unrest In Southern City
snippet: Riot police officers in the southern city of Maan used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who set fire to the main police station and post office, ransacked other government buildings and looted a bank. The protests started over the death on Saturday...
lead_paragraph: Riot police officers in the southern city of Maan used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who set fire to the main police station and post office, ransacked other government buildings and looted a bank. The protests started over the death on Saturday of a 15-year-old boy held by the police on robbery charges. Relatives said he had been tortured to death; the police said he had died of kidney failure. In the past, unrest in Maan has spread throughout Jordan. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)
