headline: Demonstrators, Ignoring a Ban, Clash With Riot Police in Tehran
snippet: In a powerful expression of popular frustration with repressive government, protesters clashed with the police at two sites today, marking the third anniversary of a violent crackdown on student protests at Tehran University.    First at the...
lead_paragraph: In a powerful expression of popular frustration with repressive government, protesters clashed with the police at two sites today, marking the third anniversary of a violent crackdown on student protests at Tehran University. First at the university and later in the affluent north Tehran neighborhood of Mother Square, police officers and vigilante volunteers wielding riot sticks lashed out at demonstrators, who had gathered in the thousands in defiance of a ban on protests.

keywords: AFRICA; AFRICAN UNION; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Ideas & Trends; A Hint of the Coming Battle for Africa's Future
snippet: THE trumpets blared, the drums thundered and Africa's leaders -- democrats and despots alike -- gathered here last week to proclaim a new era of democracy, stability and good governance.    ''This is the place to draw the line on the past,'' said...
lead_paragraph: THE trumpets blared, the drums thundered and Africa's leaders -- democrats and despots alike -- gathered here last week to proclaim a new era of democracy, stability and good governance. ''This is the place to draw the line on the past,'' said President John Kufuor of Ghana, who came to celebrate the birth of the African Union, a new regional group that requires its members -- 53 presidents and prime ministers -- to renounce corruption, conflict and autocracy.

keywords: IRAN; LABOR; WAGES AND SALARIES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Workers Protest In Capital
snippet: Several thousand workers clashed with the riot police outside the Ministry of Labor and the government Welfare Organzation in Tehran, protesting poor working conditions, low pay and insufficient welfare services. The police clubbed them and used tear...
lead_paragraph: Several thousand workers clashed with the riot police outside the Ministry of Labor and the government Welfare Organzation in Tehran, protesting poor working conditions, low pay and insufficient welfare services. The police clubbed them and used tear gas to disperse them after they threw rocks and smashed windows. The protest followed one last Tuesday, when thousands of people clashed with the police in Tehran and Isfahan in defiance of a ban on demonstrations to mark the third anniversary of a crackdown against students. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

keywords: PARAGUAY; ASUNCION (PARAGUAY); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Protests Taper Off
snippet: Vice President Julio César Franco demanded that his rival, President Luis González Macchi, step down, but protesters mostly stayed off the streets of the capital, Asunción, after the declaration of a five-day state of emergency on Monday to quell...
lead_paragraph: Vice President Julio César Franco demanded that his rival, President Luis González Macchi, step down, but protesters mostly stayed off the streets of the capital, Asunción, after the declaration of a five-day state of emergency on Monday to quell street demonstrations against the government's economic policies. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to break up roadblocks in the north and south of the country, but in contrast to Monday, when two people were killed, no deaths were reported. Larry Rohter (NYT)

keywords: NAIROBI (KENYA); KENYA; UNIVERSITY OF NAIROBI; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC; MARIJUANA
headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Clash At University
snippet: Students angered by the death of a youth at police hands clashed with authorities at the University of Nairobi. An official of the Kenya Red Cross Society said at least 17 students and 10 police officers were injured in the fighting, in which...
lead_paragraph: Students angered by the death of a youth at police hands clashed with authorities at the University of Nairobi. An official of the Kenya Red Cross Society said at least 17 students and 10 police officers were injured in the fighting, in which students threw stones and officers wielded batons and eventually used tear gas and water cannon. The riots forced closure of all major highways connecting the city center to its western suburbs. The authorities said the police were questioning a group suspected of selling marijuana and shot the student in self-defense when he rushed them with a knife.

keywords: WESTCHESTER COUNTY (NY); SKUNKS; DOGS
headline: The Menace This Year: Skunkings
snippet: SELDOM a week passes when Carmine Formisano, beagle breeder, fails to encounter what local animal experts call the latest wildlife menace to hit Westchester County.    This time it's not tick-infested deer, rabid racoons or disease-laden mosquitoes....
lead_paragraph: SELDOM a week passes when Carmine Formisano, beagle breeder, fails to encounter what local animal experts call the latest wildlife menace to hit Westchester County. This time it's not tick-infested deer, rabid racoons or disease-laden mosquitoes. The problem is skunks, whose spray, usually directed at dogs, can result in weeks or even months of lingering odor. And this year, the risks seem particularly high.

keywords: RHEINGOLD, HOWARD; TELEPHONES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS
headline: New Economy; In the tech meccas, masses of people, or 'smart mobs,' are keeping in touch through wireless devices.
snippet: SMART MOBS.'' The odd phrase might bring to mind rowdies partying after the Harvard-Yale football game. But, in fact, it has been coined by the author Howard Rheingold to describe groups of people equipped with high-tech communications devices that...
lead_paragraph: SMART MOBS.'' The odd phrase might bring to mind rowdies partying after the Harvard-Yale football game. But, in fact, it has been coined by the author Howard Rheingold to describe groups of people equipped with high-tech communications devices that allow them to act in concert -- whether they know each other or not. This phenomenon is showing up among teens in tech meccas like Tokyo, where wireless text messages have caught on in a big way. American hip-hop fans, using two-way pagers, spontaneously appear for parties. And in Finland, members of a local cooperative mix the virtual and the physical by communicating via pagers and cellphones to meet at their club.

keywords: AHMEDABAD (INDIA); INDIA; GUJARAT STATE (INDIA); HINDUISM; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Religious Riots Loom Over Indian Politics
snippet: Here in the adopted hometown of Mohandas K. Gandhi, the great apostle of nonviolence, Hindu mobs committed acts of unspeakable savagery against Muslims this spring.    Mothers were skewered on swords as their children watched. Young women were...
lead_paragraph: Here in the adopted hometown of Mohandas K. Gandhi, the great apostle of nonviolence, Hindu mobs committed acts of unspeakable savagery against Muslims this spring. Mothers were skewered on swords as their children watched. Young women were stripped and raped in broad daylight, then doused with kerosene and set on fire. A pregnant woman's belly was slit open, her fetus raised skyward on the tip of a sword and then tossed onto one of the fires that blazed across the city.

keywords: ISRAEL; NABLUS (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; CURFEWS; TERRORISM
headline: As Israel Eases Its Grip, Palestinians in Nablus Say: 'Curfew? What Curfew?'
snippet: This is what a curfew declared by the Israeli Army looked like here today: taxis jammed downtown streets, vendors hawked fruits and vegetables at the central market and thousands of townspeople shopped in stores and strolled the sidewalks.    No...
lead_paragraph: This is what a curfew declared by the Israeli Army looked like here today: taxis jammed downtown streets, vendors hawked fruits and vegetables at the central market and thousands of townspeople shopped in stores and strolled the sidewalks. No Israeli soldiers were to be seen, though they guarded checkpoints and kept watch from the mountains surrounding this commercial center, one of seven West Bank cities occupied by Israeli troops for more than a month in an effort to forestall suicide bombings.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Rebellion Case in Venezuela Ignites Clashes
snippet: The police used tear gas and fired shots into the air today to break up fights outside Venezuela's Supreme Court, which is deciding whether four military officers should be tried for rebellion.    At least five people were injured, and several were...
lead_paragraph: The police used tear gas and fired shots into the air today to break up fights outside Venezuela's Supreme Court, which is deciding whether four military officers should be tried for rebellion. At least five people were injured, and several were arrested. Scuffles between supporters of President Hugo Chávez and riot police officers spread to streets surrounding the court building in downtown Caracas.

keywords: ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; THEATER
headline: Drama as a DMZ in Israel; Arab and Jewish Actors Share the Stage as Partners in Provocative Works
snippet: One Friday night in October 2000, several bloody weeks into the Palestinian uprising called the Aksa intifada, the Arab-Hebrew Theater here presented an open-mike night. It went by the title ''In Jaffa, We Talk,'' and it was meant to reinforce in...
lead_paragraph: One Friday night in October 2000, several bloody weeks into the Palestinian uprising called the Aksa intifada, the Arab-Hebrew Theater here presented an open-mike night. It went by the title ''In Jaffa, We Talk,'' and it was meant to reinforce in wrenching times the theater's commitment to partnership between the Jewish and Arab citizens of Israel. At one point Igal Ezraty, the theater's artistic director, began to read aloud the names of the intifada's fatalities, and he asked the audience to stand in mourning. But when he mentioned several Israeli soldiers who were killed, some Arab spectators shouted back that they could not commemorate ''our oppressors, our murderers.'' And when Mr. Ezraty listed the dead Palestinians and Israeli Arabs, some Jews pointedly took their seats.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Violence Worsens in Downtown Caracas
snippet: Gunmen shot and wounded a policeman and four civilians in Caracas today and supporters of President Hugo Chávez clashed with riot police in the most serious outbreak of street violence since a short-lived coup in April.    In the third day of...
lead_paragraph: Gunmen shot and wounded a policeman and four civilians in Caracas today and supporters of President Hugo Chávez clashed with riot police in the most serious outbreak of street violence since a short-lived coup in April. In the third day of violent protests, gunmen with rifles ambushed a police armored vehicle in the impoverished and crime-ridden January 23 district, piercing the truck's armor and wounding an officer in the leg, Mayor Alfredo Peña said.

keywords: COUNTER SPY SHOPS; CCS INTERNATIONAL LTD; COMPANY AND ORGANIZATION PROFILES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TERRORISM
headline: Outfitter to the Suspicious
snippet: ON the busy stretch of Huguenot Street here, the Chevrolet dealership and Pizza Hut mix easily with the New Roc City entertainment complex and a sprinkling of office buildings. It is the unlikely home for headquarters to one of the world's leading...
lead_paragraph: ON the busy stretch of Huguenot Street here, the Chevrolet dealership and Pizza Hut mix easily with the New Roc City entertainment complex and a sprinkling of office buildings. It is the unlikely home for headquarters to one of the world's leading spy supply companies. CCS International, Ltd., the parent company of the Counter Spy Shops, has its showrooms, a factory, a training center and corporate offices there. Clients can view an array of security, surveillance and counter surveillance gadgetry: anti-bug alerts that vibrate silently in a pocket to inform the bearer that someone is secretly recording or transmitting conversations; package and letter bomb detectors; personal protection gear ranging from gas masks to bulletproof clothing; and hand-held radar probes that ''see'' contraband through walls.

keywords: WARRI (NIGERIA); ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP; CHEVRON TEXACO INC; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Women Block Chevron and Shell Offices in Nigeria
snippet: Hundreds of women blocked the gates of Chevron Texaco and Shell offices in separate protests aimed at forcing community development aid and other concessions from oil multinationals in southern Nigeria, company officials said today.    The protests...
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of women blocked the gates of Chevron Texaco and Shell offices in separate protests aimed at forcing community development aid and other concessions from oil multinationals in southern Nigeria, company officials said today. The protests were like incidents last month that paralyzed Chevron Texaco's Nigeria operations for two weeks. As in those, groups of women gathered outside offices in the southern port of Warri and prevented workers from entering or leaving the premises of the two companies for several hours on Thursday.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
headline: Venezuela Supreme Court Clears 4 Military Officers in Uprising
snippet: The Supreme Court of Venezuela today dismissed the case against four military officers the government had accused of rebelling against President Hugo Chávez in April. The ruling set off violent protests by supporters of the president in the streets...
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of Venezuela today dismissed the case against four military officers the government had accused of rebelling against President Hugo Chávez in April. The ruling set off violent protests by supporters of the president in the streets of the capital. By a vote of 11 to 8, the justices held that the four officers -- the former commander of the army, two navy admirals and an air force general -- should not stand trial on charges they had risen up against the government on April 11, temporarily forcing Mr. Chávez from power. He returned to office two days later when his supporters rose up against an interim government that replaced him.

keywords: LAWAL, AMIN; NIGERIA; ADULTERY; SENTENCES (CRIMINAL); CAPITAL PUNISHMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; WOMEN; CONSTITUTIONS; CHURCH-STATE RELATIONS; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
headline: Court Upholds Stoning for Nigerian Mother
snippet: An Islamic high court in northern Nigeria rejected an appeal today from a single mother sentenced to be stoned to death for having had sex out of wedlock.    The woman's lawyers said they planned to file an appeal to a yet higher Islamic court. If...
lead_paragraph: An Islamic high court in northern Nigeria rejected an appeal today from a single mother sentenced to be stoned to death for having had sex out of wedlock. The woman's lawyers said they planned to file an appeal to a yet higher Islamic court. If that failed, they could appeal to the Supreme Court, where the case would force a showdown between Nigeria's constitutional and religious authorities.

keywords: HUSSEIN, SADDAM; GERMANY; IRAQ; BERLIN (GERMANY); DEMOCRATIC IRAQI OPPOSITION OF GERMANY; HOSTAGES; FOREIGN SERVICE
headline: Anti-Hussein Iraqis Briefly Seize Embassy in Berlin
snippet: An Iraqi opposition group seized control of Iraq's embassy here this afternoon and held the small staff hostage until the German police stormed the compound, freeing the captives and arresting five members of the group.    Two people were slightly...
lead_paragraph: An Iraqi opposition group seized control of Iraq's embassy here this afternoon and held the small staff hostage until the German police stormed the compound, freeing the captives and arresting five members of the group. Two people were slightly injured in the police action, which took about five minutes, the police said.

keywords: ARAFAT, YASIR; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); JENIN (WEST BANK); TULKARM (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; NABLUS (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; CURFEWS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Arafat Remains Defiant Amid Rubble of His Compound
snippet: Sealed up with at least 200 men in his dust-choked offices while Israeli bulldozers leveled buildings just outside and issued dire warnings over loudspeakers, Yasir Arafat defiantly declared today that he would not capitulate. At the same time, he...
lead_paragraph: Sealed up with at least 200 men in his dust-choked offices while Israeli bulldozers leveled buildings just outside and issued dire warnings over loudspeakers, Yasir Arafat defiantly declared today that he would not capitulate. At the same time, he called on Palestinians to halt attacks inside Israel. Outside the compound, an Israeli commander said the siege and the demolitions would continue until all the Palestinians inside who are wanted by Israel, whose number rose today to about 50, surrendered. Mr. Arafat has refused to give up the men.

keywords: MEREDITH, JAMES; MEREDITH, JOSEPH H; OXFORD (MISS); UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI; NATIONAL GUARD; EQUAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES; RECORDINGS (VIDEO); BLACKS; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: 40 Years After Infamy, Ole Miss Looks to Reflect and Heal
snippet: Ole Miss is looking for witnesses to the night of Sept. 30, 1962.    It was the night James H. Meredith integrated the University of Mississippi, backed by 300 federal marshals and 30,000 troops, as thousands of white students and outsiders ran riot...
lead_paragraph: Ole Miss is looking for witnesses to the night of Sept. 30, 1962. It was the night James H. Meredith integrated the University of Mississippi, backed by 300 federal marshals and 30,000 troops, as thousands of white students and outsiders ran riot over the campus. Two men were left dead and at least 300 wounded, yet not one student was expelled, not one attacker convicted.

keywords: KAUSHIK, K S; AHMEDABAD (INDIA); INDIA; GUJARAT STATE (INDIA); HINDUISM; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: After Attack on Temple, Indian City Remains Quiet
snippet: Late Tuesday night, as gunmen were still battling police forces inside a Hindu temple complex about 20 miles from here, this city's police commissioner, K.S. Kaushik, called a meeting of his top officers.    His instructions were clear and...
lead_paragraph: Late Tuesday night, as gunmen were still battling police forces inside a Hindu temple complex about 20 miles from here, this city's police commissioner, K.S. Kaushik, called a meeting of his top officers. His instructions were clear and unequivocal: the police were to keep the peace, and ''effective force should be used without any hesitation'' to do it. If that meant clubs and tear gas, so be it. If firearms needed to be used, use them, he said.

keywords: DEIF, MOHAMMED; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; HAMAS; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
headline: Israel Strikes at a Suspected Bomb Maker
snippet: Israel killed at least two members of the Islamic group Hamas today with missiles fired from helicopter gunships into a busy Gaza City street, in a strike at the organization's top bomb maker, Muhammad Deif.    In the wreckage of body parts, smashed...
lead_paragraph: Israel killed at least two members of the Islamic group Hamas today with missiles fired from helicopter gunships into a busy Gaza City street, in a strike at the organization's top bomb maker, Muhammad Deif. In the wreckage of body parts, smashed cars and shattered windows, it was not certain if Mr. Deif, an elusive figure at the top of Israel's wanted list for a decade, was killed. Hamas and hospital officials denied that he had died. Senior Israeli military officials said that three men died in the target car, a green Mercedes.

keywords: ABRAHAM; ISRAEL; HEBRON (WEST BANK); JEWS; PALESTINIANS; TOMB OF THE PATRIARCHS (HEBRON, ISRAEL); SUKKOT (JEWISH HOLIDAY); HOLY DAYS
headline: A Holiday in Hebron, Just for Jews, but Death Attends
snippet: It has been a particularly strange week in this particularly strange place: a week of dances and curfews, of celebratory palm fronds and blasting rifles, of rage and death on both sides of this torn city's stark Israeli-Palestinian divide.    As they...
lead_paragraph: It has been a particularly strange week in this particularly strange place: a week of dances and curfews, of celebratory palm fronds and blasting rifles, of rage and death on both sides of this torn city's stark Israeli-Palestinian divide. As they have for almost 3,000 years, Jews around the world this week celebrated the annual holiday of Sukkot, marking the autumn harvest and recalling the fragility and transience of life in the wilderness after the exodus from Egypt.

keywords: CORNELL UNIVERSITY; UNIVERSITY OF TEL AVIV; CRYING; DRILLING AND BORING (ROCK AND STONE); MICROWAVES; ENZYMES; ENCEPHALITIS; BIRDS; RESEARCH; ONIONS
headline: OBSERVATORY
snippet: Onions May Not Always Be Nature's Tear-Jerkers      An onion is nature's idea of a tear-gas grenade. Left intact, it's a harmless thing. But once it is sliced and diced, cell walls are broken, and chemicals mix to form a real tear-jerker of a...
lead_paragraph: Onions May Not Always Be Nature's Tear-Jerkers An onion is nature's idea of a tear-gas grenade. Left intact, it's a harmless thing. But once it is sliced and diced, cell walls are broken, and chemicals mix to form a real tear-jerker of a compound, thiopropanal-S-oxide.

keywords: RUSSIA; MOSCOW (RUSSIA); CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; HOSTAGES; POISON GASES
headline: Official Silence on Gas Raises Vexing Questions
snippet: The light gray gas filtered down like a mist in the theater hall before sunrise on Saturday, and the effect on hostages and hostage-takers alike was nearly instant. Most simply lost consciousness, as their breath and blood slowed and Russian security...
lead_paragraph: The light gray gas filtered down like a mist in the theater hall before sunrise on Saturday, and the effect on hostages and hostage-takers alike was nearly instant. Most simply lost consciousness, as their breath and blood slowed and Russian security troops began to surge through the theater. Some of Russia's top health officials said tonight that the gas was a nonlethal anesthetic, like the ones used in general surgery. But in the chaos of a predawn commando operation against heavily armed guerrillas, the result was all too lethal. Of the 117 hostages confirmed dead so far, all but one appear to have died from the effects of the gas, according to the Health Committee of Moscow.

keywords: RUSSIA; MOSCOW (RUSSIA); CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); HOSTAGES; HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC SUBSTANCES; POISON GASES; TERRORISM
headline: Hostage Toll in Russia Over 100; Nearly All Deaths Linked to Gas
snippet: The number of hostages who died as a result of a raid on a Moscow theater jumped to 117 today, as more people succumbed to the effects of a debilitating gas that Russian security forces used as they stormed the building being held by Chechen...
lead_paragraph: The number of hostages who died as a result of a raid on a Moscow theater jumped to 117 today, as more people succumbed to the effects of a debilitating gas that Russian security forces used as they stormed the building being held by Chechen guerrillas. The mounting number of dead, from among more than 750 hostages, cast a deep shadow over a predawn raid that the authorities had at first hailed as a successful operation. Also darkening the mood were disclosures that doctors were almost completely unprepared to treat the hostages for gas-related problems.

keywords: RUSSIA; MOSCOW (RUSSIA); CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; HOSTAGES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; POISON GASES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; FENTANYL (DRUG); TERRORISM
headline: U.S. Suspects Opiate in Gas In Russia Raid
snippet: American officials said yesterday that they suspected the Russian security police who raided a Moscow theater early Saturday might have used an aerosol version of a powerful, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl to knock out Chechen extremists and...
lead_paragraph: American officials said yesterday that they suspected the Russian security police who raided a Moscow theater early Saturday might have used an aerosol version of a powerful, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl to knock out Chechen extremists and prevent them from killing the 750 hostages they were holding. The gas killed 117 hostages, all but one of those who died in the Russian assault to retake the theater.

keywords: RUSSIA; MOSCOW (RUSSIA); CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; HOSTAGES; EDITORIALS; POISON GASES; FENTANYL (DRUG); TERRORISM
headline: The Search for a Knockout Weapon
snippet: Russia's use of a dangerous incapacitating gas to knock out Chechen terrorists who had seized more than 750 hostages at a Moscow theater has underscored the urgent need to develop safer methods to immobilize hostage takers without harming their...
lead_paragraph: Russia's use of a dangerous incapacitating gas to knock out Chechen terrorists who had seized more than 750 hostages at a Moscow theater has underscored the urgent need to develop safer methods to immobilize hostage takers without harming their hostages. The powerful gas, which was pumped in through the theater's ventilation system, killed at least 116 of the hostages and sent hundreds more to the hospital. Whether the high death toll was deemed acceptable collateral damage or was the result of a terrible miscalculation is not known. Russia needs to provide fuller details on the assault and its harm to the hostages. Such information could help this country and others prepare to deal with future terrorist takeovers. The agent used against the Chechen terrorists was most likely an aerosol version of a potent, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl that is used as an anesthetic for horses. Whatever the specific chemical, it falls into the category of incapacitating agents, which are supposed to be nonlethal.

keywords: CONTENT OF MY CHARACTER (BOOK); GROWING UP KING: AN INTIMATE MEMOIR (BOOK); GROWING UP X (BOOK); KING, YOLANDA; DUE, PATRICIA STEPHENS; DUE, TANANARIVE; WILEY, RALPH; ABERNATHY, DONZALEIGH; SHABAZZ, ILYASAH; KING, DEXTER SCOTT; BLACKS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
headline: Offspring Of the Dream Recount The Struggle
snippet: The children of the leaders and of the foot soldiers of the civil rights movement, and those who are but the offspring of the dream, are telling their stories in a cluster of books recently published or about to be. The hope of the writers is that...
lead_paragraph: The children of the leaders and of the foot soldiers of the civil rights movement, and those who are but the offspring of the dream, are telling their stories in a cluster of books recently published or about to be. The hope of the writers is that these narratives will engrave the movement as a defining event in the 20th century, particularly for this generation of Americans, in much the same way that Tom Brokaw and Stephen E. Ambrose did for World War II remembrance. The books are by King and Abernathy and Shabazz, a daughter of Malcolm X. And Patricia Stephens Due, who was arrested at a lunch counter sit-in and describes herself as a ''foot soldier'' and who wrote a book with her daughter, the novelist Tananarive Due. And by a magazine editor, Patrik Henry Bass, ''a child of the dream.''

keywords: BIN AL-SHIBH, RAMZI; MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; MOHAMMED, KHALID SHAIKH; NEW YORK CITY; KARACHI (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; WASHINGTON (DC); AL QAEDA; WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; HIJACKING; TERRORISM; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET
headline: Qaeda Uses Teeming Karachi As New Base, Pakistanis Say
snippet: As the United States hunted worldwide for leaders of Al Qaeda this summer, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a key planner of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was living quietly in an apartment about 10 miles from the American Consulate here, according to Pakistani...
lead_paragraph: As the United States hunted worldwide for leaders of Al Qaeda this summer, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a key planner of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was living quietly in an apartment about 10 miles from the American Consulate here, according to Pakistani law enforcement officials. He and his Qaeda friends spent their days logging on to the Internet via satellite telephones. At night, neighbors saw them playing cards and laughing.

keywords: UPPER WAIAKEA FOREST RESERVE (HAWAII); HAWAII; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; SARIN (NERVE GAS); TESTS AND TESTING; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: U.S. Tested A Nerve Gas In Hawaii
snippet: In the latest release of once-classified reports on chemical warfare tests during the cold war, the Pentagon said today that it detonated artillery shells and rockets filled with deadly Sarin gas in Hawaii in 1967.    There were no reports of...
lead_paragraph: In the latest release of once-classified reports on chemical warfare tests during the cold war, the Pentagon said today that it detonated artillery shells and rockets filled with deadly Sarin gas in Hawaii in 1967. There were no reports of military personnel or civilians being exposed to the nerve agent during the tests, conducted in the Upper Waiakea Forest Reserve, a dense rain forest on the island of Hawaii, Pentagon officials said.

keywords: CLINTON, BILL; BUSH, GEORGE W; GERMANY; BERLIN (GERMANY); AL QAEDA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PUBLIC OPINION; RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION; BRANDENBURG GATE (BERLIN); TERRORISM
headline: The American Idol
snippet: If you think Germany is turning anti-American, pay attention to what happened here last month when the president visited Berlin. No, not President Bush -- President Clinton. Mr. Clinton, who helped unveil the refurbished Brandenburg Gate, was swarmed...
lead_paragraph: If you think Germany is turning anti-American, pay attention to what happened here last month when the president visited Berlin. No, not President Bush -- President Clinton. Mr. Clinton, who helped unveil the refurbished Brandenburg Gate, was swarmed as Germans clamored to see, hear or shake hands with him. Elvis was in the house. If Mr. Bush visited Germany today there would also be street riots -- the sort they use tear gas to control.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Capital Tense After Clashes
snippet: Tensions remained high in Caracas the day after security forces battled with supporters of President Hugo Chávez who were attacking members of the opposition. In confused exchanges of gunfire, tear gas, stones and bottles on Tuesday, one person was...
lead_paragraph: Tensions remained high in Caracas the day after security forces battled with supporters of President Hugo Chávez who were attacking members of the opposition. In confused exchanges of gunfire, tear gas, stones and bottles on Tuesday, one person was killed and at least 20 were wounded. The clashes came as the government and opposition held talks aimed at ending the bitter political dispute over what Mr. Chávez calls his ''revolution.'' The populist president was briefly ousted in April by military officers.

keywords: MUDENGE, STAN; ZUMA, NKOSAZANA; GREAT BRITAIN; ZIMBABWE; SOUTH AFRICA; AGRICULTURE; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; LAND USE POLICIES; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: South Africa Urges the West To Ease Censure of Zimbabwe
snippet: Cameras flashed and reporters scribbled as the foreign ministers of South Africa and Zimbabwe met this week with hearty handshakes. Then South Africa announced that it was time for the world to ease the pressure on its troubled neighbor.    The South...
lead_paragraph: Cameras flashed and reporters scribbled as the foreign ministers of South Africa and Zimbabwe met this week with hearty handshakes. Then South Africa announced that it was time for the world to ease the pressure on its troubled neighbor. The South African foreign minister, Dr. Nkosazana Zuma, said it was time for Western nations to consider ending penalties they imposed on Zimbabwe for intimidating opposition party supporters, judges, journalists and white farmers, and manipulating the presidential election.

keywords: VAJPAYEE, ATAL BIHARI; TOGADIA, PRAVIN; INDIA; GODHRA (INDIA); HINDUISM; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: India Blocks Hindu Rally By Arresting Militant Chief
snippet: India took a small step forward today toward taming violence between Hindus and Muslims, as the Hindu nationalist government arrested the leader of a militant Hindu group, preventing a provocative rally here that could have led to bloodshed.    Prime...
lead_paragraph: India took a small step forward today toward taming violence between Hindus and Muslims, as the Hindu nationalist government arrested the leader of a militant Hindu group, preventing a provocative rally here that could have led to bloodshed. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee led his Bharatiya Janata Party to national power by extolling and catering to the country's Hindu majority. But today, the state government of Gujarat, also controlled by Mr. Vajpayee's party, sent thousands of constables and paramilitary riot policemen to crack down on militant Hindus.

keywords: PENA, ALFREDO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); EXPLOSIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Caracas Riot Police Battle Anti-Chávez Marchers
snippet: National Guard troops fired tear gas and shotgun pellets to disperse antigovernment demonstrators here today as President Hugo Chávez's struggle with his political foes persisted.    The disturbances followed a weekend of tumult caused in part by...
lead_paragraph: National Guard troops fired tear gas and shotgun pellets to disperse antigovernment demonstrators here today as President Hugo Chávez's struggle with his political foes persisted. The disturbances followed a weekend of tumult caused in part by the government's decision on Saturday to wrest control of the Caracas city police from Mayor Alfredo Peña, an outspoken opponent of the president.

keywords: PENA, ALFREDO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; POLICE
headline: Venezuelan Marchers Want Police Restored to Civilian Rule
snippet: Thousands of people opposed to President Hugo Chávez and his military takeover of this city's police marched through the streets today demanding that the force be restored to civilian control.    The protest, which was smaller than previous marches,...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people opposed to President Hugo Chávez and his military takeover of this city's police marched through the streets today demanding that the force be restored to civilian control. The protest, which was smaller than previous marches, was peaceful though boisterous, as throngs of middle-class protesters banged on pots, blew whistles and chanted anti-Chávez slogans.

headline: Religious Violence in Nigeria Drives Out Miss World Event
snippet: After days of sectarian violence linked to the Miss World beauty competition in Nigeria, the organizers announced late tonight that the pageant would be moved to London ''in the overall interest of Nigeria and the contestants.''    At least 105...
lead_paragraph: After days of sectarian violence linked to the Miss World beauty competition in Nigeria, the organizers announced late tonight that the pageant would be moved to London ''in the overall interest of Nigeria and the contestants.'' At least 105 people have been reported killed in the fighting between Christians and Muslims in the northern city of Kaduna in the past few days. The violence spread today to Abuja, the capital, where the Miss World Pageant was to have had its finale on Dec. 7.

keywords: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA; CLEMSON UNIVERSITY; UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA; OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY; ARSON; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FOOTBALL
headline: Fan Violence Erupts During Victory Celebrations
snippet: The police fired tear gas and wooden pellets to break up rioting by fans who set fire to cars, threw bottles and burned furniture in the streets early today in celebration of Ohio State University's victory over rival Michigan.    Other celebrations...
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas and wooden pellets to break up rioting by fans who set fire to cars, threw bottles and burned furniture in the streets early today in celebration of Ohio State University's victory over rival Michigan. Other celebrations also got out of hand in South Carolina, California, North Carolina and Washington, leaving several people injured.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; PETROLEOS DE VENEZUELA SA; LABOR; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; ELECTIONS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Troops Disrupt Protest as Caracas Oil Workers Join Strike
snippet: Soldiers firing tear gas put down a peaceful protest by striking antigovernment workers from the state oil company today, prompting dissident managers to announce that their walkout against President Hugo Chávez's left-leaning government would...
lead_paragraph: Soldiers firing tear gas put down a peaceful protest by striking antigovernment workers from the state oil company today, prompting dissident managers to announce that their walkout against President Hugo Chávez's left-leaning government would extend for a third day. The workers from Petróleos de Venezuela, one of the world's largest oil companies and a key supplier of oil to the United States, on Monday joined a national general strike convened by business leaders and politicians pressuring Mr. Chávez to hold an early referendum on his rule.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Haiti: Protests Are Stopped
snippet: The police fired tear gas to break up demonstrations by thousands of antigovernment protesters, as President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's supporters used whips and hurled rocks to drive away government opponents. At least 14 people were reported injured....
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas to break up demonstrations by thousands of antigovernment protesters, as President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's supporters used whips and hurled rocks to drive away government opponents. At least 14 people were reported injured. Two men were shot by Aristide backers in the town of Petit-Goâve, where the police lobbed tear gas canisters into about 2,000 marchers, witnesses said. Thousands more protested in cities including the capital, Port-au-Prince. Those protests were stopped.

keywords: MOI, DANIEL ARAP; KIBAKI, MWAI; KENYATTA, UHURU; KENYA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; ELECTIONS; CRIME AND CRIMINALS
headline: Kenya's Democracy Prepares for an Important Test
snippet: Daniel arap Moi, supreme ruler of Kenya for 24 years and one of Africa's longest surviving leaders, is ceding power this month in an election that many see as a test not only of this spirited if struggling country, but of the viability of democracy...
lead_paragraph: Daniel arap Moi, supreme ruler of Kenya for 24 years and one of Africa's longest surviving leaders, is ceding power this month in an election that many see as a test not only of this spirited if struggling country, but of the viability of democracy across the continent. Mr. Moi arrives in Washington on Thursday for a meeting with President Bush, one that is expected to touch on both the Nov. 28 terrorist attacks in Mombasa and the importance of the looming transition in Kenya. If all goes well and Mr. Moi steps gracefully aside, Mr. Bush is planning a trip to Kenya early next year, with one possible stop being the newly constructed American Embassy in Nairobi, which replaces the one destroyed by a terrorist bombing in 1998.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; ELECTIONS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Chávez's Foes Plan to Extend General Strike In Venezuela
snippet: Government opponents said tonight that they were extending a paralyzing general strike into a fourth day, possibly damaging informal agreements made earlier today between the government and its foes in discussions mediated by the Organization of...
lead_paragraph: Government opponents said tonight that they were extending a paralyzing general strike into a fourth day, possibly damaging informal agreements made earlier today between the government and its foes in discussions mediated by the Organization of American States, people involved in the talks said. The strike by Venezuelan businessmen and workers opposed to the left-leaning government of President Hugo Chávez threatens to cripple the Venezuelan economy, Latin America's fourth largest, and disrupt oil supplies to the United States. This evening, the captain of a tanker carrying 280,000 barrels of refined gasoline for the domestic market told a Venezuelan television network he was anchoring his ship in the middle of the Lake Maracaibo shipping channel, possibly blocking a key route for oil tankers.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; ELECTIONS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Venezuelan Showdown: Chávez in Peril
snippet: President Hugo Chávez may have thought the gravest threat to his rule had passed in April, when four days of swelling protests temporarily removed him from power.    But at that time he faced a hodgepodge of opponents without a central goal. His...
lead_paragraph: President Hugo Chávez may have thought the gravest threat to his rule had passed in April, when four days of swelling protests temporarily removed him from power. But at that time he faced a hodgepodge of opponents without a central goal. His opposition was unfocused and fractured -- united not even in what it wanted or what methods to use to shorten the presidency of a mercurial leader whose left-leaning policies have antagonized opponents certain he is leading their country to ruin.

keywords: LAWAL, AMINA; AKIN, AZRA; LONDON (ENG); NIGERIA; LAGOS (NIGERIA); BEAUTY CONTESTS; MISS WORLD; ADULTERY; CAPITAL PUNISHMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Pageant Goes Ahead Over Protests; A Turk Wins
snippet: The Miss World contest, relocated here from Nigeria after religious riots in connection with the pageant left more than 200 people dead, went ahead tonight despite protests and was won by Miss Turkey, Azra Akin.    A 21-year-old model raised in the...
lead_paragraph: The Miss World contest, relocated here from Nigeria after religious riots in connection with the pageant left more than 200 people dead, went ahead tonight despite protests and was won by Miss Turkey, Azra Akin. A 21-year-old model raised in the Netherlands by her Turkish parents, Miss Akin told reporters after the crowning ceremony that she had been shocked by the violence in Nigeria, adding, ''I wish people in the world would be more respectful to each other.''

keywords: AGHAJARI, HASHEM; IRAN; TEHRAN UNIVERSITY; CAPITAL PUNISHMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Iran Student Movement Finds New Vitality
snippet: University students protested again today, and the government cracked down with scores of arrests, witnesses said.    Thousands of people marched outside the Tehran University campus, and security forces used tear gas to disperse them, the witnesses...
lead_paragraph: University students protested again today, and the government cracked down with scores of arrests, witnesses said. Thousands of people marched outside the Tehran University campus, and security forces used tear gas to disperse them, the witnesses said.

keywords: GAVIRIA, CESAR; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; LABOR; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES
headline: Venezuela On the Brink Of Violence, Mediator Says
snippet: Ten days into a nationwide strike that has crippled Venezuela's economy, a diplomat trying to break the impasse between President Hugo Chávez and strike organizers said today that the government's denial of the grave nature of the crisis was...
lead_paragraph: Ten days into a nationwide strike that has crippled Venezuela's economy, a diplomat trying to break the impasse between President Hugo Chávez and strike organizers said today that the government's denial of the grave nature of the crisis was impeding negotiations. He warned that violence could erupt within days if an agreement was not reached.

keywords: ITALY; GENOA (ITALY); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: The Ghosts of Last Year's Economic Demonstrations Haunt Italy
snippet: The bombing that shattered windows and lodged shrapnel in the walls of Genoa's police headquarters last Monday reminded many Italians of the fighting between the police and antiglobalization protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting there last...
lead_paragraph: The bombing that shattered windows and lodged shrapnel in the walls of Genoa's police headquarters last Monday reminded many Italians of the fighting between the police and antiglobalization protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting there last year. The purported bombers even offered a mnemonic device to jog the country's memory. The little-known July 20 Brigade, which claimed responsibility for the two explosions, is named for the date last year on which a police officer shot dead a young rioter, a day when smashed storefront glass blanketed the sidewalks and tear gas filled the air.

keywords: INDIA; GUJARAT STATE (INDIA); HINDUISM; ISLAM; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; CHURCH-STATE RELATIONS; TERRORISM
headline: Hindu Nationalists Win Landslide Vote in Indian State
snippet: In an election that was widely viewed as a referendum on India's secular character, Hindu nationalists won a landslide re-election victory today in the western state of Gujarat, which was convulsed by Hindu-Muslim riots early this year.    The vote...
lead_paragraph: In an election that was widely viewed as a referendum on India's secular character, Hindu nationalists won a landslide re-election victory today in the western state of Gujarat, which was convulsed by Hindu-Muslim riots early this year. The vote seemed to affirm the success of the campaign strategy of the incumbent Bharatiya Janata Party, which had focused on uniting Hindus against a threat of Islamic terrorism and implicitly, and sometimes explicitly, against the state's Muslims.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; LATIN AMERICA; BRAZIL; ECUADOR; PERU; RECESSION AND DEPRESSION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; ELECTIONS
headline: If Saddam Were Only Brazilian
snippet: Two mobs were hurling bottles at each other on a Caracas street the other night. The ground was littered with broken glass, a few gunshots had been fired, and the army was popping tear gas to forestall a riot (though Venezuelan gas is wimpish stuff,...
lead_paragraph: Two mobs were hurling bottles at each other on a Caracas street the other night. The ground was littered with broken glass, a few gunshots had been fired, and the army was popping tear gas to forestall a riot (though Venezuelan gas is wimpish stuff, like onion-scented air freshener). My mob was made up of Chavistas, militant supporters of President Hugo Chávez, and we could see what looked like anti-Chávez forces 100 yards down the road. I slipped away to have a look at them before the enraged mobs tore each other apart . . . but more on that in a moment.

keywords: GUATEMALA; DOW JONES REUTERS BUSINESS INTERACTIVE LLC; PAVONCITO (PRISON); PRISONS AND PRISONERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA; FOOD
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Deadly Prison Riot
snippet: Eighteen inmates died in rioting over poor food and limited visiting rights at a medium-security prison outside Guatemala City. As the police waited to retake the Pavoncito prison, the ground was littered with shotgun shells and tear gas canisters,...
lead_paragraph: Eighteen inmates died in rioting over poor food and limited visiting rights at a medium-security prison outside Guatemala City. As the police waited to retake the Pavoncito prison, the ground was littered with shotgun shells and tear gas canisters, while the courtyard was littered with blood and flesh, Reuters reported. The dead inmates had been mutilated. The Guatemalan authorities said they were in control, although they were still negotiating with a group of inmates. David Gonzalez (NYT)

keywords: MOI, DANIEL ARAP; KIBAKI, MWAI; KENYATTA, UHURU; KENYA; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; PUBLIC OPINION; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; ELECTIONS
headline: Kenyans Cast Ballots and Wait, Mostly Peacefully
snippet: Today was a day of waiting in Kenya  in queues that stretched down city blocks, through rural fields, down the muddy paths of the slums. Many Kenyans were up at dawn to cast their ballots in East Africa's most widely anticipated election in a...
lead_paragraph: Today was a day of waiting in Kenya in queues that stretched down city blocks, through rural fields, down the muddy paths of the slums. Many Kenyans were up at dawn to cast their ballots in East Africa's most widely anticipated election in a generation, a vote that offered many their first true choice after 24 years of rule by President Daniel arap Moi. There were scenes of the violence and blatant vote rigging that have marred previous elections here. But by and large it was a day of muted rejoicing that Kenya, which under Mr. Moi has suffered an economic nosedive and become notoriously corrupt, might receive a fresh start under a new leader.

keywords: DAVOS (SWITZERLAND); SWITZERLAND; WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Davos Forum Seeks Accommodation With Peaceful Protesters
snippet: The theme of the World Economic Forum this year is trust, and the Swiss police say they will try to maintain that spirit with the protesters who have planned demonstrations against globalization during the meeting in Davos at the end of the month.   ...
lead_paragraph: The theme of the World Economic Forum this year is trust, and the Swiss police say they will try to maintain that spirit with the protesters who have planned demonstrations against globalization during the meeting in Davos at the end of the month. After a year's hiatus in which the annual forum was held in New York, Davos's 13,000 villagers are bracing for its return, anxious to avoid the tear gas and destruction that marred the 2000 and 2001 events.

snippet: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose after Venezuelan soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse protesters near an army base. In New York, crude oil for February delivery gained $1.23, or 3.9 percent, to $33.08 a barrel.
lead_paragraph: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose after Venezuelan soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse protesters near an army base. In New York, crude oil for February delivery gained $1.23, or 3.9 percent, to $33.08 a barrel.

headline: Gunfire Kills 2 in Venezuela as March Turns Into Street Fight
snippet: At least two people were shot to death today and dozens of others were wounded in clashes between opponents of President Hugo Chávez and pro-government groups, as a peaceful protest involving thousands deteriorated into a huge street fight.    It is...
lead_paragraph: At least two people were shot to death today and dozens of others were wounded in clashes between opponents of President Hugo Chávez and pro-government groups, as a peaceful protest involving thousands deteriorated into a huge street fight. It is unclear who fired the shots.

keywords: CHADERTON, ROY; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Venezuelan Minister Says Chávez Won't Give In to Strikers
snippet: Venezuela's foreign minister said today that the government regretted the violence that erupted Friday during a march against President Hugo Chávez, and acknowledged that the monthlong strike aimed at forcing Mr. Chávez out of office had taken a...
lead_paragraph: Venezuela's foreign minister said today that the government regretted the violence that erupted Friday during a march against President Hugo Chávez, and acknowledged that the monthlong strike aimed at forcing Mr. Chávez out of office had taken a serious toll on the nation's economy. But the minister, Roy Chaderton, accused strike leaders -- particularly executives at the state-owned oil company -- of shutting down the heart of this nation's economy in an effort to overthrow the government. He also insisted that Mr. Chávez would not give in to opposition calls for early elections.

keywords: GAVIRIA, CESAR; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; COCA-COLA CO; LABOR; ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION; SOFT DRINKS; SHUTDOWNS (INSTITUTIONAL); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; WOMEN; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Venezuelan Soldiers Try to Reopen Beverage Plants
snippet: Venezuela's national guard today seized warehouses full of beer, soft drinks and bottled water, which had been closed since the start of a seven-week strike that has crippled business and industry and caused food shortages.     The seizures were...
lead_paragraph: Venezuela's national guard today seized warehouses full of beer, soft drinks and bottled water, which had been closed since the start of a seven-week strike that has crippled business and industry and caused food shortages. The seizures were considered a crackdown against opponents of President Hugo Chávez, who have led the strike to demand new elections.

keywords: GREAT BRITAIN; LONDON (ENG); BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; RICIN (POISON); ISLAM; TERRORISM
headline: Mosque Raid in London Results in 7 Arrests in Connection With Discovery of Poison
snippet: The police today stormed a London mosque that has been widely depicted as a recruiting ground for violent Islamic radicals, and arrested seven people on charges related to the discovery of the deadly poison ricin in a London house earlier this month....
lead_paragraph: The police today stormed a London mosque that has been widely depicted as a recruiting ground for violent Islamic radicals, and arrested seven people on charges related to the discovery of the deadly poison ricin in a London house earlier this month. Acting a day after the government promised a toughened antiterror policy in light of the killing of a police officer in Manchester, 150 policemen in riot gear broke into the Finsbury Park mosque with battering rams and ladders in a surprise 2 a.m. raid while helicopters circled, bathing the building in floodlight.

keywords: ISRAEL; HEZBOLLAH; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
headline: Israel Destroys Arabs' Shops in West Bank
snippet: The Israeli Army used bulldozers to flatten dozens of shops today in one of the only thriving Palestinian commercial centers near the West Bank boundary, saying that the store owners lacked permits.    Across Israel's northern border, Hezbollah...
lead_paragraph: The Israeli Army used bulldozers to flatten dozens of shops today in one of the only thriving Palestinian commercial centers near the West Bank boundary, saying that the store owners lacked permits. Across Israel's northern border, Hezbollah guerrillas fired mortar rounds and antitank rockets at Israeli Army positions, prompting return fire from tanks, artillery and helicopters, as well as stern warnings from Israeli officials.

keywords: DAVOS (SWITZERLAND); WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Clashes Begin Near Forum As Security Clamps Down
snippet: While participants in the World Economic Forum here nibbled on canapés and debated the consequences of a possible war in Iraq, police officers with tear-gas grenades and water cannons mounted a huge security operation to keep protesters away from...
lead_paragraph: While participants in the World Economic Forum here nibbled on canapés and debated the consequences of a possible war in Iraq, police officers with tear-gas grenades and water cannons mounted a huge security operation to keep protesters away from the delegates, who included Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. At the railroad junction of Landquart, about 25 miles down the road from Davos, antiwar and antiglobalization protesters, some hiding their faces with ski masks and goggles, pelted the police with snowballs after the authorities refused to allow them to travel to Davos unimpeded. Police officers lobbed tear-gas canisters after protesters fired flares. German police officers reinforced the Swiss by firing water cannons into small knots of demonstrators.

keywords: TRANSPORTATION SECURITY ADMINISTRATION; AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; AIRPORTS; WESTCHESTER COUNTY AIRPORT; LUGGAGE; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TERRORISM
headline: Air Travel Under a More Watchful Eye
snippet: TRACEY WEISBERG was holding her 4-year-old son, Clayton, while her daughter, Margot, 5, tugged at her sleeve. But Mrs. Weisberg was distracted. While her husband, Martin, was confirming the family's seats at an airline ticket counter here, Mrs....
lead_paragraph: TRACEY WEISBERG was holding her 4-year-old son, Clayton, while her daughter, Margot, 5, tugged at her sleeve. But Mrs. Weisberg was distracted. While her husband, Martin, was confirming the family's seats at an airline ticket counter here, Mrs. Weisberg was watching a federal screener from the Transportation Security Administration methodically unpack one of the family suitcases. Wearing plastic gloves, an agent ran a small white card along the inside of the bag and then inserted the card into a machine, which scanned it for traces of explosives. He had already done the same with the outside of the bag. He then began to unpack the suitcase and search it thoroughly.

keywords: OAKLAND RAIDERS; TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS; SUPER BOWL; FOOTBALL
headline: Raiders Fans March
snippet: Young Raiders fans in East Oakland marched in small clusters in the street chanting, ''Raiders! Raiders!'' after Oakland lost the Super Bowl today. Other fans drove up International Boulevard waving Raider flags and honking horns.     For at least an...
lead_paragraph: Young Raiders fans in East Oakland marched in small clusters in the street chanting, ''Raiders! Raiders!'' after Oakland lost the Super Bowl today. Other fans drove up International Boulevard waving Raider flags and honking horns. For at least an hour, a heavy police presence kept the gathering peaceful. But in some cases, the police fired tear gas to break up the crowds.

keywords: GBAGBO, LAURENT; ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; FRANCE; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; FOREIGN SERVICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Angry at Accord, Mobs Attack French Embassy in Ivory Coast
snippet: Mobs throwing stones attacked the French Embassy and army base in Ivory Coast today as thousands marched in an explosion of anger over a peace accord they said France had imposed to the advantage of rebels.    The large protests underlined the...
lead_paragraph: Mobs throwing stones attacked the French Embassy and army base in Ivory Coast today as thousands marched in an explosion of anger over a peace accord they said France had imposed to the advantage of rebels. The large protests underlined the problems facing the power-sharing deal agreed to in Paris on Saturday by President Laurent Gbagbo to end the four-month war that has split Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa producer, along ethnic lines.

keywords: EL PASO (TEX); EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Student Melee
snippet: A protest by about 1,000 students at Montwood High School in El Paso turned violent, resulting in minor injuries and a school lockdown, the police said. About 10 people were arrested and nearly 30 injured. Students walked out of school to protest a...
lead_paragraph: A protest by about 1,000 students at Montwood High School in El Paso turned violent, resulting in minor injuries and a school lockdown, the police said. About 10 people were arrested and nearly 30 injured. Students walked out of school to protest a switch to block scheduling, which means longer classes, and refused to return, according to the police, then began attacking security personnel with stones and glass bottles. The police used tear gas to control the crowd; about 20 students who were exposed were treated at the scene.

keywords: MULUZI, BAKILI; MALAWI; BLANTYRE (MALAWI); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: No Third Term
snippet: Facing growing opposition, the governing party withdrew a bill from Parliament that would have amended the Constitution to allow President Bakili Muluzi to run for a third term. It was the second time in a year that Mr. Muluzi's supporters had...
lead_paragraph: Facing growing opposition, the governing party withdrew a bill from Parliament that would have amended the Constitution to allow President Bakili Muluzi to run for a third term. It was the second time in a year that Mr. Muluzi's supporters had unsuccessfully tried to push the matter. This week, angry crowds filled the streets in Blantyre, the commercial hub, and the police fired tear gas and bullets to disperse them. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

keywords: SHARON, ARIEL; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; HEBRON (WEST BANK); TULKARM (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
headline: Israeli Forces Raid 2 Cities in West Bank
snippet: Israeli forces staged two major operations in the West Bank today, fatally shooting two Palestinians in Tulkarm and sending scores of soldiers into this battered city, where they closed television stations and demolished a blocklong fruit and...
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces staged two major operations in the West Bank today, fatally shooting two Palestinians in Tulkarm and sending scores of soldiers into this battered city, where they closed television stations and demolished a blocklong fruit and vegetable market. The operations in Tulkarm and Hebron, along with other Israeli military activity, came just two days after an overwhelming election victory by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who pledged a tough approach toward the current conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

keywords: CHAVEZ FRIAS, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Neighborhood Barricades in Caracas
snippet: Like a true spy, Franklin Chaparro was careful not to give away too many details about his assignment.     Mr. Chaparro, who once was the government's chief explosives specialist and director of Venezuela's state intelligence agency, has begun using...
lead_paragraph: Like a true spy, Franklin Chaparro was careful not to give away too many details about his assignment. Mr. Chaparro, who once was the government's chief explosives specialist and director of Venezuela's state intelligence agency, has begun using his expertise as the architect of his neighborhood watch association.

headline: Everybody Has a Mother
snippet: Aicha el-Wafi, mother of the accused terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui, has just finished a crème caramel and is on her way out of a restaurant in Narbonne, France, when a waiter stops her. ''I saw your son the other day on television,'' he says. ''He...
lead_paragraph: Aicha el-Wafi, mother of the accused terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui, has just finished a crème caramel and is on her way out of a restaurant in Narbonne, France, when a waiter stops her. ''I saw your son the other day on television,'' he says. ''He was very good -- very interesting.'' He's not referring to Zacarias, who is being held in isolation in Virginia, charged with conspiracy in the Sept. 11 attacks. The waiter is talking about her other son, Abd-Samad Moussaoui, author of ''Zacarias, My Brother: The Making of a Terrorist,'' an account of his younger brother's life until 1995, when Zacarias was 27, after which the two fell permanently out of touch. Neither Abd-Samad nor the boys' mother knew what had become of Zacarias until Sept. 12, 2001, when the television news started flashing a mug shot of the man thought to be the ''20th hijacker.'' His head was shaved, and his face had gotten beefier, but the Moussaoui family knew it was Zacarias. ''You think it was very interesting?'' el-Wafi says with an engaging smile. Dressed in a camel's hair coat and leopard-print scarf, she shifts her weight to a more comfortable stance; she might be there awhile. Her tone shifts as well, taking on an edge. ''You think it was very impressive? You think it was 'très bien'? Let me ask you something: Is that what you would do if your brother was in jail? Would you write a book telling the world your brother is a racist, an extremist, denouncing your brother, complaining about your mother? Is that what you would do?''

keywords: SANCHEZ DE LOZADA, GONZALO; LA PAZ (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; TAXATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: 10 Die as Bolivian Troops Fire on Striking Police and Protesters
snippet: Striking police officers and civilian protesters clashed with government troops today, leaving at least 10 people dead, 53 injured and the ruling party headquarters and the main jail in flames here in the capital.    Government troops fired tear gas,...
lead_paragraph: Striking police officers and civilian protesters clashed with government troops today, leaving at least 10 people dead, 53 injured and the ruling party headquarters and the main jail in flames here in the capital. Government troops fired tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition at the demonstrators, who stormed the presidential palace to protest government proposals to raise taxes and cut spending on social programs.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; HUSSEIN, SADDAM; IRAQ; GREAT BRITAIN; CZECH REPUBLIC; ATOMIC WEAPONS; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: From New York To Melbourne, Cries for Peace
snippet: Confronting America's countdown to war, throngs of chanting, placard-waving demonstrators converged on New York and scores of cities across the United States, Europe and Asia yesterday in a global daisy chain of largely peaceful protests against the...
lead_paragraph: Confronting America's countdown to war, throngs of chanting, placard-waving demonstrators converged on New York and scores of cities across the United States, Europe and Asia yesterday in a global daisy chain of largely peaceful protests against the Bush administration's threatened invasion of Iraq. Three years after vast crowds turned out around the world to celebrate the new millennium, millions gathered again yesterday in a darker mood of impending conflict, forming a patchwork of demonstrations that together, organizers said, made up the largest, most diverse peace protest since the Vietnam War.

keywords: AMANDLA! (MOVIE); MASEKELA, HUGH; HIRSCH, LEE; SOUTH AFRICA; MOTION PICTURES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DOCUMENTARY FILMS AND PROGRAMS
headline: With Fury Silenced, Song Raised Its Voice
snippet: TEN years ago, a 20-year-old New Yorker named Lee Hirsch left for Johannesburg with $600 in his pocket and the phone numbers of two local contacts. Mr. Hirsch was on a mission: he had become obsessed with the popular music that had sprung up around...
lead_paragraph: TEN years ago, a 20-year-old New Yorker named Lee Hirsch left for Johannesburg with $600 in his pocket and the phone numbers of two local contacts. Mr. Hirsch was on a mission: he had become obsessed with the popular music that had sprung up around the antiapartheid movement, and he was determined to make a film about it. If his undertaking seemed quixotic -- Mr. Hirsch was white, had never before been to South Africa and had no previous research to guide him -- well, he thought, so be it. ''The music just grabbed me,'' said Mr. Hirsch, now 30, in his Upper West Side apartment. ''There was an urgency in the music that appealed to me, and I wanted to learn more, I wanted to hear more.''

snippet: Shortly before setting off this afternoon to strut down the spine of this city's neighborhood of South Asian restaurants and shops, Cynthia Castiglione came to Mark Messing, the leader of the newly formed Antiwar Marching Band, with a suggestion.   ...
lead_paragraph: Shortly before setting off this afternoon to strut down the spine of this city's neighborhood of South Asian restaurants and shops, Cynthia Castiglione came to Mark Messing, the leader of the newly formed Antiwar Marching Band, with a suggestion. ''What about a fallout?'' she asked. ''At one point, we all just die.'' Mr. Messing agreed, noting, ''We'll need a cue for that.''

headline: Good as Goldie
snippet: I always thought she was an exalted blonde. She was a deeply joyful blonde! I never thought of her as dumb.'' -- Goldie Hawn, on her screen persona   The morning after she received an Oscar for her film role as Walter Matthau's young lover in...
lead_paragraph: I always thought she was an exalted blonde. She was a deeply joyful blonde! I never thought of her as dumb.'' -- Goldie Hawn, on her screen persona The morning after she received an Oscar for her film role as Walter Matthau's young lover in ''Cactus Flower,'' Goldie Hawn got a call from her publicist telling her that she had won. ''Oh, my God, they were on last night!'' shrieked the ingénue. ''I totally forgot.''

headline: MetroStars' Bradley Continues Casting Call
snippet: MetroStars Coach BOB BRADLEY took a page from the tattered and maligned playbook of SVEN-GORAN ERIKSSON, England's national team coach, when he also experimented and sent out two teams in a preseason exhibition against the Chicago Fire, a 2-0 loss,...
lead_paragraph: MetroStars Coach BOB BRADLEY took a page from the tattered and maligned playbook of SVEN-GORAN ERIKSSON, England's national team coach, when he also experimented and sent out two teams in a preseason exhibition against the Chicago Fire, a 2-0 loss, in Florida over the weekend. The difference is that while Eriksson was excoriated for his novel approach in using 22 players, changing the entire team after 45 minutes, in a friendly against Australia on Feb. 12, Bradley has little choice if he wants to get a good look at the 29 players on his bulging roster less than two months before the start of Major League Soccer's eighth season.

keywords: KHADER, SAMI; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; QALQILIYA (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; ZOOS; EMBALMING; MUSEUMS
headline: Qalqiliya Journal; In the Man-Ravaged West Bank, a Petrified Zoo
snippet: Palestinians here say that the zebras succumbed to tear gas and that the giraffe died when he collapsed in terror during a burst of gunfire. The lion, they say, died of old age.    But with Qalqiliya enclosed now by Israeli fences, ditches and...
lead_paragraph: Palestinians here say that the zebras succumbed to tear gas and that the giraffe died when he collapsed in terror during a burst of gunfire. The lion, they say, died of old age. But with Qalqiliya enclosed now by Israeli fences, ditches and soldiers, its tourists gone and its economy in ruins, the zookeepers have not been able to bring in any new animals.

keywords: CORRIE, RACHEL; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; RAFAH (GAZA); INTERNATIONAL SOLIDARITY MOVEMENT; ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: Israeli Army Bulldozer Kills American Protesting in Gaza
snippet: An Israeli Army bulldozer today crushed to death an American woman who had kneeled in the dirt to prevent the armored vehicle from destroying a Palestinian home in the southern Gaza Strip, witnesses and hospital officials said.    The Israeli...
lead_paragraph: An Israeli Army bulldozer today crushed to death an American woman who had kneeled in the dirt to prevent the armored vehicle from destroying a Palestinian home in the southern Gaza Strip, witnesses and hospital officials said. The Israeli military said the driver of the bulldozer had not seen the woman, and called it a ''very regrettable accident.'' The woman, Rachel Corrie, 23, from Olympia, Wash., was among eight Americans and Britons who had been acting has ''human shields'' to try to stop the almost daily house demolitions by Israeli forces in Rafah, a town on Gaza's border with Egypt. When the bulldozer approached a house today, Ms. Corrie, who was wearing a bright orange jacket, dropped to her knees, a practice that members of the group to which she belonged, the International Solidarity Movement, have used repeatedly, her colleagues at the scene said. As the bulldozer reached her without slowing up, she began to rise, but was trapped beneath a pile of dirt generated by its blade and the blade itself, said one member of the group, Tom Dale, who said he was standing about 30 feet away. ''We were shouting and waving our arms at the driver,'' said Mr. Dale, who is British. ''We even had a megaphone. But the bulldozer kept going until she was under the body or the tracks of the bulldozer.'' The bulldozer stopped for a few seconds and pulled back, Mr. Dale added. Her colleagues rushed to Ms. Corrie, who was bleeding from the head and face and badly wounded, but still breathing. An ambulance took her to Najar Hospital, where she died. She had a fractured skull and other injuries, said Dr. Ali Moussa, a hospital administrator. At the time Ms. Corrie was run over, she was in an open area in front of the house, Mr. Dale said. The bulldozer came from some distance away, and ''there was nothing to obscure the driver's view,'' he said. But Capt. Jacob Dallal, an army spokesman, said that the armored bulldozer had small windows and limited visibility, and that the driver had not been aware that Ms. Corrie was in his path. In a statement, the Israeli military said soldiers ''were dealing with a group of protesters who were acting very irresponsibly, putting everyone in danger -- the Palestinians, themselves and our forces -- by intentionally placing themselves in a combat zone.'' About an hour before Ms. Corrie was killed, troops fired tear gas and shot into the air during a confrontation with the protesters at a nearby house, both Mr. Dale and the Israeli military said. The International Solidarity Movement is made up mostly of Americans and Europeans in their 20's and 30's who are sympathetic to the Palestinians and oppose the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. They have repeatedly placed themselves in front of Israeli forces operating in those areas. Last May, several members dashed past Israeli troops into the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, where Palestinian gunmen had been holed up for more than a month. The protesters remained for several days, until the standoff ended with the surrender of the gunmen. Ms. Corrie, who was to graduate from the Evergreen State College in Olympia this year, had been in Rafah for two months, living with Palestinians in areas where homes were being demolished, her colleagues said. In Olympia, Colin Reese, a student at Evergreen State and a close friend of Ms. Corrie, said she had focused much of her studies on community organizing. Describing her work in Gaza, he said, ''She was particularly touched by the Palestinian situation and wanted to use her privilege as an American citizen to help defend against the Israeli occupation.'' One of Ms. Corrie's teachers at Evergreen was Larry Mosqueda, a professor of political economy and social change, who said her work in Gaza was a reflection of lessons taught at Evergreen that encourage students to put their education to practical use while still in college. ''She has a strong sense of social justice,'' he said. ''Basically, she wanted to do something about it instead of just talk about it.'' In an e-mail message this month, Ms. Corrie described a Feb. 14 standoff in which members of her group ''stood in the path of the bulldozers and were physically pushed with the shovel backwards, taking shelter in a house.'' She added that ''the bulldozer then proceeded on its course, demolishing one side of the house'' with the protesters still inside. The Israeli Army and Palestinian militants wage frequent gun battles in Rafah. An unarmed Palestinian man was shot and killed by Israeli fire today in the town, said Palestinian security sources and hospital officials. The Israeli Army said it was checking the report. The military has flattened dozens of homes in Rafah, some because militants were using them for cover. The Israeli authorities have said the International Solidarity Movement's protesters prevent soldiers from acting against militants, and they have deported some members. Demonstrators have been hurt on a number of occasions, but Ms. Corrie was the first one killed. The Israeli troops ''have shot over our heads, and shot near our feet -- they have fired tear gas at us,'' said Michael Shaik, media coordinator for the group. ''But we thought we had an understanding. We didn't think they would kill us.''

keywords: YEMEN; IRAQ; EUROPE; MIDDLE EAST; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; IRAQ-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Crowds Protest Iraq War In Cities Around World
snippet: Demonstrations against the American-led war in Iraq roiled cities around the world today, with the riot police in several Arab nations turning water cannons, tear gas, batons and finally bullets on unruly protesters who surged by the thousands into...
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations against the American-led war in Iraq roiled cities around the world today, with the riot police in several Arab nations turning water cannons, tear gas, batons and finally bullets on unruly protesters who surged by the thousands into the streets after Friday Prayers. But the reaction in some countries was more muted than expected.
