headline: Hamas Urges Iraqis to Make Suicide Attacks on the Invaders
snippet: As Muslim preachers in the Gaza Strip inveighed today against war in Iraq as a war on Islam, leaders of the Palestinian group Hamas urged Iraqis to use suicide as a weapon against invading troops.    ''As long as there is an American aggression...
lead_paragraph: As Muslim preachers in the Gaza Strip inveighed today against war in Iraq as a war on Islam, leaders of the Palestinian group Hamas urged Iraqis to use suicide as a weapon against invading troops. ''As long as there is an American aggression against a Muslim country, Iraqis must defend themselves, using all means,'' Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, a Hamas leader, said in a telephone interview from Gaza City. He said the Iraqis should conduct ''martyrdom operations, using explosive belts against the American and British soldiers.''

keywords: TONGUE TIED (BOOK); SOUL CIRCUS (BOOK); VANISHED MAN, THE (BOOK); HEX (BOOK); KEEPING WATCH (BOOK); ESTEP, MAGGIE; KING, LAURIE R; STEVENSON, RICHARD; PELECANOS, GEORGE P; DEAVER, JEFFERY; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
headline: CRIME
snippet: The characters in George P. Pelecanos's proletarian crime novels all work hard for a living, but none of the honest entrepreneurs in the Anacostia neighborhood of Washington run their operations with the ruthless efficiency of the gun merchants and...
lead_paragraph: The characters in George P. Pelecanos's proletarian crime novels all work hard for a living, but none of the honest entrepreneurs in the Anacostia neighborhood of Washington run their operations with the ruthless efficiency of the gun merchants and drug dealers in SOUL CIRCUS (Little, Brown, $24.95). With the territorial gang lord Granville Oliver out of commission and on trial for his life, business ethics dictate that two rival gangs should beef up their arsenals and fight it out for his drug trade. To the despair of Derek Strange, Pelecanos's salt-of-the-earth private investigator, more children are recruited for the gang war, and the only person who really benefits is Ulysses Foreman, the local gun dealer and an expert in supply and demand. ''Long as kids down here had no fathers and were looking to belong to something,'' Foreman says, ''then there was gonna be gangs and a need for guns.'' Pelecanos is fascinated with the way things work, and he takes apart the gun trade like an urban anthropologist, fitting the pieces into the drug business and the gang culture with an exactness that is breathtaking -- and depressing. At the same time, he treats his criminals like human beings, talking their talk, driving their cars, listening to their music, getting into their world with something that can only be called sympathy.

keywords: EAST LANSING (MICH); MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY; NCAA BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; BASKETBALL; VANDALISM
headline: Michigan State Fans Go on Rampage
snippet: Michigan State basketball fans overturned four cars, tipped vending machines and set fires in trash bins in East Lansing, Mich., after the Spartans lost in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday.     Police officers in riot gear dispersed the crowd using...
lead_paragraph: Michigan State basketball fans overturned four cars, tipped vending machines and set fires in trash bins in East Lansing, Mich., after the Spartans lost in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday. Police officers in riot gear dispersed the crowd using tear gas. Seven people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct, six of them Michigan State students, police said.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; IRAQ; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; TEAR GAS
headline: U.S. Use of Tear Gas Could Violate Treaty, Critics Say
snippet: President Bush has authorized American military forces to use tear gas in Iraq, the Pentagon says, a development that some weapons experts say other countries might see as a breach of the Chemical Weapons Convention.    The Defense Department said...
lead_paragraph: President Bush has authorized American military forces to use tear gas in Iraq, the Pentagon says, a development that some weapons experts say other countries might see as a breach of the Chemical Weapons Convention. The Defense Department said tear gas, which has been issued to American troops, would be used only to save civilian lives and in accordance with the convention, ratified by the United States in 1997. But critics say any battlefield use of tear gas would violate the treaty, offend crucial allies, including Britain, and hand Saddam Hussein a possible pretext for using chemical weapons against the United States.

headline: With Current War, Professors Protest, As Students Debate
snippet: It is not easy being an old lefty on campus in this war.     At the University of Wisconsin at Madison, awash in antiwar protests in the Vietnam era, a columnist for a student newspaper took a professor to task for canceling classes to protest the...
lead_paragraph: It is not easy being an old lefty on campus in this war. At the University of Wisconsin at Madison, awash in antiwar protests in the Vietnam era, a columnist for a student newspaper took a professor to task for canceling classes to protest the war in Iraq, saying the university should reprimand her and refund tuition for the missed periods.

headline: 10 Countries Sign to Join European Union
snippet: During a momentous ceremony in the cradle of democracy, the leaders of 10 countries signed treaties here today to join the European Union, extending its reach to a broad swath of Europe once allied with the Soviet Union.    At the same time, leaders...
lead_paragraph: During a momentous ceremony in the cradle of democracy, the leaders of 10 countries signed treaties here today to join the European Union, extending its reach to a broad swath of Europe once allied with the Soviet Union. At the same time, leaders of the 15 countries already in the union sought to bridge the profound rifts between them that had been opened by the war in Iraq.

lead_paragraph: A man was shot dead when a gunman fired on opponents of President Hugo Chávez after tens of thousands of pro- and anti-Chávez demonstrators jammed Caracas streets in competing May Day marches. In confused running skirmishes, the police fired tear gas after the shooting to disperse rival bands of demonstrators who clashed in the capital with volleys of rocks and bottles.

keywords: BERKELEY ART MUSEUM; PACIFIC FILM ARCHIVE; UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA; BLACK PANTHERS; PHOTOGRAPHY
headline: The Black Panthers' Beauty Moment
snippet: FOR certain Americans, the Black Panthers, one the most potent revolutionary groups of the late 1960's, were very over by 1970. That was the year Tom Wolfe's ''Radical Chic & Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers'' appeared. His account of media-savvy young...
lead_paragraph: FOR certain Americans, the Black Panthers, one the most potent revolutionary groups of the late 1960's, were very over by 1970. That was the year Tom Wolfe's ''Radical Chic & Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers'' appeared. His account of media-savvy young African-Americans wearing berets and shades and hustling a scam, and of rich white types (Leonard Bernstein, Carter Burden) tripping all over themselves in support, was the Panther story people had been waiting for: a Rowan and Martin ''Laugh-In'' skit. A spoof, a circus, a farce. Mortified, the haute bourgeois Left turned off its largesse. The Panthers dropped in status from superstars to superfluous. ''Delicious,'' purred The Wall Street Journal of Mr. Wolfe's caustic little neo-conservative classic. The mainstream press did nothing to help Black Panther Party credibility. The party's membership, and its neighborhood-based food and medical programs, grew. So did F.B.I. surveillance and infiltration. (J. Edgar Hoover called the Panthers ''the greatest threat to the internal security of the United States.'')

headline: Troops and Police Clash With Protesters as Unrest Grows in Peru
snippet: Soldiers fired into the air and police used tear gas and water hoses today in violent clashes across Peru with protesters who vowed to continue crippling strikes despite a government state of emergency.    The police said at least seven farmers were...
lead_paragraph: Soldiers fired into the air and police used tear gas and water hoses today in violent clashes across Peru with protesters who vowed to continue crippling strikes despite a government state of emergency. The police said at least seven farmers were wounded in Barranca, north of Lima, as soldiers fired shots to disperse rock-throwing protesters a day after President Alejandro Toledo imposed a 30-day state of emergency, banning strikers from the streets and giving the military and the police more powers to use force and conduct searches.

keywords: TOLEDO, ALEJANDRO; PUNO (PERU); AREQUIPA (PERU); LIMA (PERU); PERU; LABOR; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Student Killed As Protesters Defy President
snippet: A student was killed and nearly 50 people injured as demonstrators clashed with troops in some of the worst violence since President Alejandro Toledo declared a state of emergency this week to curb a wave of strikes and protests. Soldiers opened fire...
lead_paragraph: A student was killed and nearly 50 people injured as demonstrators clashed with troops in some of the worst violence since President Alejandro Toledo declared a state of emergency this week to curb a wave of strikes and protests. Soldiers opened fire on protesting students at a university in the southern city of Puno, while in the city of Arequipa, the police fired tear gas at striking teachers. In Lima, police officers in riot gear chased striking judiciary workers at the National Justice building. Teachers, demanding a pay raise, began a nationwide strike two weeks ago, and demonstrations gradually escalated to include farmers, court workers and other sectors. After the emergency decree, some farmers and health workers suspended their strikes, but court workers and teachers vowed to press on.

Rolex also ringed its second story with garlands of barbed wire.

headline: Scores of Thousands Protest Conference, Some Violently
snippet: The protester, his face swathed in black, carried a long ax with a bright blue blade. And when he reached Route de Malagnou in the eastern part of this city, he began smashing a bus shelter, destroying one of its glass panels.    ''Stop! Stop!''...
lead_paragraph: The protester, his face swathed in black, carried a long ax with a bright blue blade. And when he reached Route de Malagnou in the eastern part of this city, he began smashing a bus shelter, destroying one of its glass panels. ''Stop! Stop!'' shouted demonstrators who were part of a huge protest against the Group of 8 summit meeting that opened today in the nearby French town of Évian-les-Bains. But there were no police officers on the demonstration route, and the ax-wielding man swiftly blended back into the marching crowd.

headline: BUSH PRESSES CASE ON IRAN AND KOREA AT ECONOMIC TALKS
snippet: President Bush stepped onto French soil today to meet the European leaders who vociferously opposed the war in Iraq, but rather than rehash their differences he spent the day trying to increase pressure on two other nations he regards as major...
lead_paragraph: President Bush stepped onto French soil today to meet the European leaders who vociferously opposed the war in Iraq, but rather than rehash their differences he spent the day trying to increase pressure on two other nations he regards as major threats -- Iran and North Korea -- to give up their nuclear weapons programs. Mr. Bush arrived here from St. Petersburg, Russia, after a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin that both men used to put differences over Iraq behind them, and to sign the recently ratified treaty that requires both sides to reduce their nuclear arsenals.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    Iran, North Korea Warned To Curb Nuclear Programs  At the conclusion of a meeting of the Group of 8 leading industrial democracies, President Bush and other leaders called nuclear proliferation ''the pre-eminent threat to...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Iran, North Korea Warned To Curb Nuclear Programs At the conclusion of a meeting of the Group of 8 leading industrial democracies, President Bush and other leaders called nuclear proliferation ''the pre-eminent threat to international security,'' urging North Korea and Iran to curb their programs. A1 Bush Visits Middle East George W. Bush arrived in the Middle East for the first time in his presidency, preparing to answer Arab leaders who are deeply wary of America's intentions in Iraq and to step in as the face-to-face intermediary between Israel and the Palestinians, a role he has long avoided. A1

headline: Police Arrest Mugabe Rival Amid Protests In Zimbabwe
snippet: Authorities arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader, beat protesters and fired tear gas and warning shots today to quell demonstrations aimed at presenting the most significant challenge yet to President Robert Mugabe.    Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of...
lead_paragraph: Authorities arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader, beat protesters and fired tear gas and warning shots today to quell demonstrations aimed at presenting the most significant challenge yet to President Robert Mugabe. Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, was arrested at his home today and charged with contempt of court for planning an illegal demonstration, said his lawyer, Innocent Chagonda.

keywords: MUGABE, ROBERT; ZIMBABWE; LABOR; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Strike Idles Zimbabwe as Opposition Tries to Oust the President
snippet: A general strike shut down much of Zimbabwe's battered economy today, but security forces prevented efforts to organize large street protests against President Robert Mugabe.    Most banks, shops and other businesses remained closed across Zimbabwe...
lead_paragraph: A general strike shut down much of Zimbabwe's battered economy today, but security forces prevented efforts to organize large street protests against President Robert Mugabe. Most banks, shops and other businesses remained closed across Zimbabwe on the second day of a weeklong show of antigovernment sentiment by an increasingly defiant opposition.

keywords: MUGABE, ROBERT; TSVANGIRAI, MORGAN; HARARE (ZIMBABWE); ZIMBABWE; TREASON; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Zimbabwe Arrests Opposition Leader and Fends Off Protests
snippet: Security forces arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader today, charged him with treason and clamped down on the capital to prevent mass protests demanding that President Robert Mugabe resign.    Military helicopters swooped over this capital city,...
lead_paragraph: Security forces arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader today, charged him with treason and clamped down on the capital to prevent mass protests demanding that President Robert Mugabe resign. Military helicopters swooped over this capital city, while army vehicles ferried troops around and police patrol cars cruised the streets. Hundreds of ruling party supporters, wearing white T-shirts reading ''No to Mass Action,'' occupied the capital's main square.

headline: Second Zimbabwe Opposition Figure Is Charged With Inciting Protests to Oust President
snippet: The police arrested a second senior Zimbabwe opposition figure today as the party's leader appeared in court after a weekend in jail to face charges of plotting to overthrow President Robert Mugabe.    A police spokesman, Andrew Phiri, said the...
lead_paragraph: The police arrested a second senior Zimbabwe opposition figure today as the party's leader appeared in court after a weekend in jail to face charges of plotting to overthrow President Robert Mugabe. A police spokesman, Andrew Phiri, said the secretary general of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, Welshman Ncube, had been arrested on treason charges on suspicion of inciting five days of protests against Mr. Mugabe last week.

headline: French Strike Against Cuts In Pensions Jams Traffic
snippet: Striking government workers tied up traffic in Paris today for the third time in a month to protest a bill that would slash retirement benefits. Legislators may vote on it within a few weeks.    In the stately National Assembly building, Prime...
lead_paragraph: Striking government workers tied up traffic in Paris today for the third time in a month to protest a bill that would slash retirement benefits. Legislators may vote on it within a few weeks. In the stately National Assembly building, Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin urged the legislators to pass the bill, a pension revision that would force workers to stay on the job several more years before retirement and cut the benefits due them.

headline: Serbs Arrest A Top Suspect For War Crimes
snippet: Serbian police commandos stormed a Belgrade apartment early this morning and arrested a top war crimes suspect amid fierce clashes with his hard-line nationalist supporters.    A senior member of the Interior Ministry confirmed that the suspect,...
lead_paragraph: Serbian police commandos stormed a Belgrade apartment early this morning and arrested a top war crimes suspect amid fierce clashes with his hard-line nationalist supporters. A senior member of the Interior Ministry confirmed that the suspect, Veselin Sljivancanin, a former colonel in the Yugoslav National Army, had been taken into custody.

keywords: MEDINA, ENRIQUE; BUSH, GEORGE W; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; STATE DEPARTMENT; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; VISAS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Call to Overthrow Chávez Cost Venezuelan a U.S. Visa
snippet: A former Venezuelan general whose visa was revoked by the Bush administration had been advocating the overthrow of President Hugo Chávez, American officials said today. The United States has publicly opposed the president's overthrow, urging that...
lead_paragraph: A former Venezuelan general whose visa was revoked by the Bush administration had been advocating the overthrow of President Hugo Chávez, American officials said today. The United States has publicly opposed the president's overthrow, urging that his fate be settled by democratic means. The visa of the former general, Enrique Medina, was rescinded by the State Department in May on the recommendation of the American Embassy in Venezuela, a State Department official said by phone from Washington. Mr. Medina, a former attaché in the Venezuelan Embassy in Washington, led a group of dissident generals who have for months gathered in a Caracas neighborhood opposed to Mr. Chávez and loudly called for his ouster.

keywords: IRAQ; FALLUJA (IRAQ); HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH; ATOMIC WEAPONS; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Rights Group Says U.S. Soldiers Twice Used Excessive Force
snippet: A leading human rights group today accused United States troops of using excessive force in two April shootings that killed 20 Iraqis and wounded at least 86. Commanders said their soldiers were responding to hostile fire from a crowd of protesters...
lead_paragraph: A leading human rights group today accused United States troops of using excessive force in two April shootings that killed 20 Iraqis and wounded at least 86. Commanders said their soldiers were responding to hostile fire from a crowd of protesters in Falluja, a city of 300,000 about 35 miles west of Baghdad. The group, Human Rights Watch, said researchers found few bullet holes that would suggest that the crowd of protesters fired on the soldiers using a school as a base. But they found more than 100 bullet holes on seven buildings across the street. The evidence, the report said, was inconsistent with American statements that the soldiers responded with ''precision fire'' when they were allegedly attacked.

headline: World Forum Moves Venue From Davos To Dead Sea
snippet: For those used to the ramparts of the snowbound Alps, it does not get lower or much hotter than this.    The World Economic Forum, a global assembly of luminaries from boardrooms and governments, usually holds its councils in Davos, the Swiss ski...
lead_paragraph: For those used to the ramparts of the snowbound Alps, it does not get lower or much hotter than this. The World Economic Forum, a global assembly of luminaries from boardrooms and governments, usually holds its councils in Davos, the Swiss ski resort. This time the forum's managers and King Abdullah II of Jordan determined that it should be held on the shores of the Dead Sea, 1,369 feet below sea level, the lowest place on earth, where temperatures routinely exceed 100 degrees.

keywords: MALAWI; MANGOCHI (MALAWI); ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; AL QAEDA; SAVE THE CHILDREN FOUNDATION; EXTRADITION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; ARSON; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
headline: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Muslims Riot Over Reported Extraditions
snippet: The police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of Muslims protesting the arrest and reported extradition by the United States this week of five suspected members of Al Qaeda. Angry demonstrators in the resort district of Mangochi burned down offices...
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of Muslims protesting the arrest and reported extradition by the United States this week of five suspected members of Al Qaeda. Angry demonstrators in the resort district of Mangochi burned down offices of the global Save the Children charity and a Catholic church, while others attacked the offices of the Muslim Association of Malawi in Blantyre, which they accused of failing to protect fellow Muslims, the police said. The protesters said their government relinquished its sovereignty by succumbing to pressure from the United States. The American Embassy initially denied involvement but has not responded to inquiries since Tuesday.

keywords: SILVA, LUIZ INACIO LULA; BRAZIL; SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT; LABOR; PUBLIC WORKS; FINANCES; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES); HIRING AND PROMOTION; INTEREST RATES; CREDIT; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Inflation Eases, But Other Worries Build Up in Brazil
snippet: A clash this week between Rio de Janeiro riot police and some 15,000 desperate unemployed people jostling to sign up for jobs as street sweepers and garbage collectors was a stark sign that President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva needs to take swift...
lead_paragraph: A clash this week between Rio de Janeiro riot police and some 15,000 desperate unemployed people jostling to sign up for jobs as street sweepers and garbage collectors was a stark sign that President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva needs to take swift action to get Brazil's sputtering economy growing again. Since taking office nearly six months ago, Mr. da Silva, the left-leaning former metalworker, has been steering a tricky course between inflation and recession, raising interest rates to four-year highs to keep consumer prices under control but trying not to push them so high as to stop the economy dead in its tracks.

keywords: OBASANJO, OLUSEGUN; ABUJA (NIGERIA); LAGOS (NIGERIA); LABOR; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES); STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LOOTING; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: General Strike
snippet: The police fired warning shots and tear gas to break up demonstrators as a general strike over raised fuel prices took hold. Stores and offices in Lagos, the commercial capital, were barricaded shut for fear of looting. Airline flights ran hours...
lead_paragraph: The police fired warning shots and tear gas to break up demonstrators as a general strike over raised fuel prices took hold. Stores and offices in Lagos, the commercial capital, were barricaded shut for fear of looting. Airline flights ran hours late, or not at all. Government offices and businesses in the capital, Abuja, and other cities also closed. In pamphlets, the striking Nigeria Labor Congress urged the public to ransack businesses that opened during the strike. Labor officials held talks with President Olusegun Obasanjo at his presidential villa in Abuja.

keywords: COPENHAGEN (DENMARK); CHRISTIANA (COPENHAGEN); SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; HASHISH; GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; AREA PLANNING AND RENEWAL; COMMUNES; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC
headline: Copenhagen Journal; Free Spirits in Their Fortress, the Law at the Gate
snippet: Ever since a group of squatters took over an abandoned military fortress in the heart of this intimate, orderly city 32 years ago, their ''Free Town,'' Christiania, has caused the government untold heartburn.    What began as a social experiment in...
lead_paragraph: Ever since a group of squatters took over an abandoned military fortress in the heart of this intimate, orderly city 32 years ago, their ''Free Town,'' Christiania, has caused the government untold heartburn. What began as a social experiment in communal living now draws hundreds of thousands of tourists. Hashish is sold freely on Pusher Street and smoked openly, despite the Danish law forbidding both activities. Houses built mostly without official permission are not bought and sold, but loaned to kindred spirits selected by other residents. There are no roads, and thus no cars.

keywords: VELASCO, IGNACIO; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Caracas Protest Quelled
snippet: Police officers firing tear gas and shotgun pellets today dispersed supporters of President Hugo Chávez who threw stones and firecrackers at Caracas Cathedral where the body of Cardinal Ignacio Velasco, a critic of Mr. Chávez, was lying in state,...
lead_paragraph: Police officers firing tear gas and shotgun pellets today dispersed supporters of President Hugo Chávez who threw stones and firecrackers at Caracas Cathedral where the body of Cardinal Ignacio Velasco, a critic of Mr. Chávez, was lying in state, the police said. Mourners and passers-by scattered as detonations rocked the square outside the cathedral.

keywords: IRAN; TEHRAN (IRAN); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: 3 Student Leaders Seized by Vigilantes in Iran
snippet: Armed vigilantes arrested three student leaders this morning after a news conference at which they announced the cancellation of protests to mark the anniversary of the 1999 student protests.     The three students, Ali Moghtaderi, Arash Hashemi and...
lead_paragraph: Armed vigilantes arrested three student leaders this morning after a news conference at which they announced the cancellation of protests to mark the anniversary of the 1999 student protests. The three students, Ali Moghtaderi, Arash Hashemi and Reza Amerinassab, were thrown into three separate cars by about 15 armed men. Mr. Moghtaderi's face was covered with blood, after having been shoved to the ground by the men.

keywords: OSORIO, JUAN; CHAVEZ, HUGO; ANZOATEGUI (VENEZUELA); VENEZUELA; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; LABOR; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Protester Killed By Police
snippet: An unemployed Venezuelan oil worker was shot dead by a soldier when National Guard troops clashed with workers blocking a highway near a major oil complex, witnesses and the police said. A group of unemployed oil workers demanding jobs occupied the...
lead_paragraph: An unemployed Venezuelan oil worker was shot dead by a soldier when National Guard troops clashed with workers blocking a highway near a major oil complex, witnesses and the police said. A group of unemployed oil workers demanding jobs occupied the highway near an oil and petrochemical plant in Anzoátegui, in the east. Witnesses said National Guard troops first tried to disperse the demonstrators with tear gas, but one of the troopers opened fire, hitting a protester, Juan Osorio, in the knee and the chest. More than 18,000 employees of the state oil firm Petróleos de Venezuela were fired after taking part in a general strike against President Hugo Chávez in December and January.

keywords: MCINNIS, SCOTT; STARK, PETE; THOMAS, BILL; UNITED STATES; CONGRESS; HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES; PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT PLANS; LAW AND LEGISLATION
headline: Sound, Fury, Pension Rules: Nasty Party Clash in House
snippet: As protests go, it wasn't much. There were no nightsticks or tear gas, and nobody was arrested.    But the conduct was far from orderly in the House of Representatives this morning, when more than a dozen Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee --...
lead_paragraph: As protests go, it wasn't much. There were no nightsticks or tear gas, and nobody was arrested. But the conduct was far from orderly in the House of Representatives this morning, when more than a dozen Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee -- infuriated by last-minute changes to a pension bill -- stalked out of a hearing in the Longworth Office Building and holed up in an adjacent library, prompting Representative Bill Thomas, the committee's chairman, to summon the Capitol police.

keywords: SHARON, ARIEL; BUSH, GEORGE W; WEST BANK; KAFR KANNA (ISRAEL); ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
headline: Israelis Drive Back Protesters Cutting Into Border Fence
snippet: Israeli troops fired tear gas and rubber-coated bullets today to drive away several hundred Palestinians, Israelis and foreign activists who were cutting through part of Israel's security fence in the northern West Bank.    The fence, a sensitive...
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops fired tear gas and rubber-coated bullets today to drive away several hundred Palestinians, Israelis and foreign activists who were cutting through part of Israel's security fence in the northern West Bank. The fence, a sensitive subject between Israel and Palestinian authorities, is expected to be on the agenda on Tuesday when Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel meets President Bush at the White House. Israel says the fence is essential to prevent Palestinian attacks, while the president has been critical of the fence's route, which juts into the West Bank.

snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-8    France and Germany Weigh Their Postwar Roles in Iraq  The open-ended American military occupation of Iraq is forcing European powers that opposed the war, notably France and Germany, to contemplate whether and how to help...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 France and Germany Weigh Their Postwar Roles in Iraq The open-ended American military occupation of Iraq is forcing European powers that opposed the war, notably France and Germany, to contemplate whether and how to help with the aftereffects, as President Bush presses for a more international presence there. A10 Liberia Rebels Take Second City Rebels captured Buchanan, the second-biggest city in Liberia, defeating President Charles G. Taylor's embattled forces on a new front. Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, warned rebels that those who caused suffering to the Liberian people would be held accountable for war crimes. A8

lead_paragraph: AN HOUR TO KILL By Karin Yapalater William Morrow ($23.95, hardcover) THURSDAY, MARCH 26 By Thursday morning, the Central Park precinct was humming. The burned corpse found on Sunday was Charlene Leone. Same back molars, and the hair in her brush matched the DNA. NYPD had a publicity problem. Leone had been kicked off the force nine months back.

snippet: After five weeks of relative calm, violence flared today on two fronts of the Middle East conflict.    Three Palestinians, two of them suspected gunmen from the Islamic militant group Hamas, and an Israeli soldier were killed in a firefight and...
lead_paragraph: After five weeks of relative calm, violence flared today on two fronts of the Middle East conflict. Three Palestinians, two of them suspected gunmen from the Islamic militant group Hamas, and an Israeli soldier were killed in a firefight and ensuing protest that erupted during what the Israeli Army called a hunt for bomb makers in the West Bank city of Nablus.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Police Buy Riot Gear
snippet: The police placed an order for 13,000 rounds of tear gas ammunition after 500,000 people marched peacefully on July 1 to protest the government's plan for stringent internal security laws. The police have also ordered 9,400 riot-control helmets, and...
lead_paragraph: The police placed an order for 13,000 rounds of tear gas ammunition after 500,000 people marched peacefully on July 1 to protest the government's plan for stringent internal security laws. The police have also ordered 9,400 riot-control helmets, and said the helmets were to replace gear dating as far back as 1967 while the unusually large order for gas ammunition was to replace rounds that had reached their expiration date. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

headline: Swaziland Quells Protests Over Commonwealth Summit Meeting
snippet: The police cracked down on protests in this African kingdom today as a Commonwealth summit meeting began and as demonstrators angrily criticized what they described as the king's increasingly autocratic rule.    The police fired tear gas to break up...
lead_paragraph: The police cracked down on protests in this African kingdom today as a Commonwealth summit meeting began and as demonstrators angrily criticized what they described as the king's increasingly autocratic rule. The police fired tear gas to break up hundreds of protesters in Mbabane, the capital, and soldiers swung rifle butts to disperse lingering groups of demonstrators, injuring several, witnesses said.

keywords: CHILE; CENTRAL WORKERS UNION; HEALTH INSURANCE AND MANAGED CARE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; MEDICINE AND HEALTH; GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: General Strike
snippet: The first general strike since the restoration of democratic rule more than a decade ago has been carried out by the country's leading labor federation, with the police arresting some demonstrators and using tear gas to disperse others. The work...
lead_paragraph: The first general strike since the restoration of democratic rule more than a decade ago has been carried out by the country's leading labor federation, with the police arresting some demonstrators and using tear gas to disperse others. The work stoppage, which failed to paralyze activity as leaders had hoped, was called by the 640,000-member Central Workers Union to protest what it describes as poor working conditions and inadequate health-care coverage in what has been South America's fastest-growing economy. Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: Dominican Police Disperse Crowd
snippet: The police in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, sprayed a chemical substance last night to disperse thousands of fans waiting outside the already-packed volleyball arena before the Pan American Games gold medal game between Cuba and the Dominican...
lead_paragraph: The police in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, sprayed a chemical substance last night to disperse thousands of fans waiting outside the already-packed volleyball arena before the Pan American Games gold medal game between Cuba and the Dominican Republic. The Dominican women won the match in five sets, 15-13 in the fifth, after blowing a two-set lead. The arena, which holds about 8,000 people, was nearly full two hours earlier as the United States women beat Brazil for the bronze medal. When that match ended, fans were sitting in aisles and on the floor, and armed police officers and militia members were walking through the building with guard dogs.

keywords: IMAM, MAZURUL; BANGLADESH; KHULNA (BANGLADESH); ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Protests After Assassination
snippet: The police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of protesters who attacked government buildings in the southwestern city of Khulna after the killing of an opposition politician. The protesters took to the streets after gunmen killed Manzurul Imam,...
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of protesters who attacked government buildings in the southwestern city of Khulna after the killing of an opposition politician. The protesters took to the streets after gunmen killed Manzurul Imam, 65, a leader of the country's main opposition party, the Awami League, the police and witnesses said. He was riding in a rickshaw when he was attacked outside his house. The rickshaw driver was also killed.

keywords: REYNA, CLAUDIO; MANCHESTER CITY; FULHAM; SOCCER
headline: Reyna Reverses His Field
snippet: The lure of playing in the UEFA Cup and in the new 48,000-seat City of Manchester Stadium, not to mention a more lucrative contract, was enough for CLAUDIO REYNA to turn his back on Fulham and jump to Manchester City.      The decision by Reyna and...
lead_paragraph: The lure of playing in the UEFA Cup and in the new 48,000-seat City of Manchester Stadium, not to mention a more lucrative contract, was enough for CLAUDIO REYNA to turn his back on Fulham and jump to Manchester City. The decision by Reyna and his former club, Sunderland, which was relegated from the English Premier League after last season, left officials at Fulham in London fuming.

keywords: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; OLMERT, EHUD; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEPORTATION
headline: Sharon Aide Says Israel Is Considering Killing Arafat
snippet: Israel's vice prime minister said today that killing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was one of several options now under government consideration. His remarks came as a beaming Mr. Arafat soaked up the cheers of supporters who descended on his...
lead_paragraph: Israel's vice prime minister said today that killing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was one of several options now under government consideration. His remarks came as a beaming Mr. Arafat soaked up the cheers of supporters who descended on his compound for a fourth consecutive day. ''Arafat can no longer be a factor in what happens here,'' the vice prime minister, Ehud Olmert, told the Israel radio. ''The question is: How are we going to do it? Expulsion is certainly one of the options, and killing is also one of the options.''

keywords: FLORIDA; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; PEPPER SPRAY; SUITS AND LITIGATION; GUARDS; TORTURE; TEAR GAS
headline: National Briefing | South: Florida: Inmates' Suit Claims Abuse
snippet: Twenty-two inmates have sued the state, saying it allowed prison guards to torture them in their cells by spraying them with pepper spray and tear gas. In a federal lawsuit filed on Friday in Fort Myers, the inmates said the use of chemical agents by...
lead_paragraph: Twenty-two inmates have sued the state, saying it allowed prison guards to torture them in their cells by spraying them with pepper spray and tear gas. In a federal lawsuit filed on Friday in Fort Myers, the inmates said the use of chemical agents by prison guards had greatly increased. They say the practice violates the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment. Lisa White Shirley, a lawyer for Florida Institutional Legal Services, which is representing the inmates, said that because the inmates sprayed were in their cells they generally did not pose a danger and that the spraying was done as retaliation, punishment or intimidation.

keywords: PANAMA CITY (PANAMA); PANAMA; COLON (PANAMA); LABOR; FINANCES; STRIKES; PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT PLANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ORGANIZED LABOR; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Panama: Thousands Strike
snippet: Workers participating in a 24-hour national strike protesting what they say is mismanagement of the social security fund clashed with riot police officers on the paralyzed streets of the country's two largest cities. According to reports from Panama...
lead_paragraph: Workers participating in a 24-hour national strike protesting what they say is mismanagement of the social security fund clashed with riot police officers on the paralyzed streets of the country's two largest cities. According to reports from Panama City and the port of Colón, protesters numbering in the tens of thousands threw rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who returned fire with rubber bullets and tear gas. The strike was the first nationwide work stoppage in six years. Union leaders called it after the government dismissed the head of the heavily indebted fund, which covers health care and retirement. They accuse the government of mismanaging the fund to the point of bankruptcy. David Gonzalez (NYT)

keywords: MESA, CARLOS; SANCHEZ DE LOZADA, GONZALO; LA PAZ (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Bolivian President Remains Defiant as Protests Intensify
snippet: Thousands of demonstrators marched in Bolivia's capital and other nearby cities on Monday, calling for the president's resignation. But they were dispersed by military units firing tear gas canisters, and at a midafternoon news conference President...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators marched in Bolivia's capital and other nearby cities on Monday, calling for the president's resignation. But they were dispersed by military units firing tear gas canisters, and at a midafternoon news conference President Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada was defiant and pugnacious. ''I'm not going anywhere,'' he said, citing his determination to remain in office and vowing that ''order will be restored.'' He added, ''It is not possible that democracy be replaced by a dictatorship of the unions'' that will ''pit region against region, class against class and ethnic group against ethnic group.''

keywords: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT (BOOK); MARANISS, DAVID; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
headline: Some Rough Days in October, in Microscopic Detail
snippet: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT  War and Peace  Vietnam and America  October 1967  By David Maraniss  Illustrated. 572 pages. Simon & Schuster. $29.95.      Tomorrow is the 36th anniversary of a riot at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The police...
lead_paragraph: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT War and Peace Vietnam and America October 1967 By David Maraniss Illustrated. 572 pages. Simon & Schuster. $29.95. Tomorrow is the 36th anniversary of a riot at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The police use of tear gas to subdue rebellious college students made it memorable, but at the heart of the event was a different chemical: napalm. The Dow Chemical Company (''Our position on the manufacture of napalm is that we are a supplier of goods to the Defense Department and not a policy maker'') had sent a recruiter to the campus. His very presence was enough to set off a violent uproar. His name was William L. Hendershot, known as Curly. He had brought a ham sandwich for lunch.

keywords: ERNEST, UNIK; PM; VOODOO; NIGHTCLUBS AND CABARETS
headline: The Voodoo That He Does, So Well, Into the Night
snippet: UNIK ERNEST, dreadlocks grazing the collar of his Yves St. Laurent blazer, slips into a leather banquette of his new PM lounge in the meatpacking district of the West Village. He nods a quick greeting here and there in the ultratrendy club, designed...
lead_paragraph: UNIK ERNEST, dreadlocks grazing the collar of his Yves St. Laurent blazer, slips into a leather banquette of his new PM lounge in the meatpacking district of the West Village. He nods a quick greeting here and there in the ultratrendy club, designed to evoke a forsaken gentlemen's club in Haiti circa the 1940's, or something like that. Mr. Ernest, who is 32 and Haitian born, is being interviewed late this night, an insane endeavor because the music is throbbing and the nightspot is starting to jump, with the impossibly tall and thin waitresses in Diane Von Furstenberg wiggling their hips.

keywords: ESTRADA, JOSEPH; DAVIDE, HILARIO; ARROYO, GLORIA MACAPAGAL; MANILA (PHILIPPINES); PHILIPPINES; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; COURTS; IMPEACHMENT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Thousands Protest
snippet: The police used tear gas and water cannons to break up a demonstration by as many as 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Joseph Estrada, in Manila's business district calling for the resignation of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. The crowd...
lead_paragraph: The police used tear gas and water cannons to break up a demonstration by as many as 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Joseph Estrada, in Manila's business district calling for the resignation of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. The crowd also protested the failure of efforts to impeach Chief Justice Hilario Davide, a case that has divided the country. A constitutional crisis was averted Tuesday when lawmakers backed a Supreme Court ruling that the impeachment was unlawful.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Police Act as Protest Becomes Riot in Haiti
snippet: Riot police officers fired tear gas at thousands of rock-throwing protesters on Friday as a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was overpowered by throngs of Aristide supporters.    Demonstrators scattered as tear gas canisters...
lead_paragraph: Riot police officers fired tear gas at thousands of rock-throwing protesters on Friday as a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was overpowered by throngs of Aristide supporters. Demonstrators scattered as tear gas canisters fell and shots rang out. There were reports of at least two people injured and 30 arrests.

keywords: FITHIAN, LISA; LATIN AMERICA; MIAMI (FLA); CANADA; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; FREE PORTS AND TRADING ZONES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Them Against the World, Part 2
snippet: On a rain-soaked October night in Miami, the police have commandeered downtown. It is midnight, and patrol cars cordon off the streets of run-down delis and dollar stores. Dozens of black-clad officers maneuver and bullhorn in the distance,...
lead_paragraph: On a rain-soaked October night in Miami, the police have commandeered downtown. It is midnight, and patrol cars cordon off the streets of run-down delis and dollar stores. Dozens of black-clad officers maneuver and bullhorn in the distance, practicing their tactics. ''We're expecting about 70,000 to 100,000 protesters to come down here in November,'' says a beat cop, guarding a corner from his squad car. ''Our guys are doing exercises all around.'' A few blocks over, at a red light, Lisa Fithian pulls her compact rental car behind a squadron of city police cruisers. Hers is one of the few civilian cars in this area, certainly the only one carrying an advance guard of that human wave heading for Miami. While most people have been ushered out of the downtown area, the 42-year-old Fithian wants to go into it, to do reconnaissance with three fellow activists. Weeks from now, she will be marching in these streets, and the police will no longer be practicing. Since it is difficult to find our way about, Fithian decides, boldly, to follow the cruisers. ''You know,'' she says, ''it's kind of nice to tail the cops for once.''

keywords: IRAQ; SAN FRANCISCO (CALIF); WASHINGTON (DC); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; SURVEILLANCE OF CITIZENS BY GOVERNMENT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; GAS MASKS; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; TEAR GAS
headline: F.B.I. SCRUTINIZES ANTIWAR RALLIES
snippet: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected extensive information on the tactics, training and organization of antiwar demonstrators and has advised local law enforcement officials to report any suspicious activity at protests to its...
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected extensive information on the tactics, training and organization of antiwar demonstrators and has advised local law enforcement officials to report any suspicious activity at protests to its counterterrorism squads, according to interviews and a confidential bureau memorandum. The memorandum, which the bureau sent to local law enforcement agencies last month in advance of antiwar demonstrations in Washington and San Francisco, detailed how protesters have sometimes used ''training camps'' to rehearse for demonstrations, the Internet to raise money and gas masks to defend against tear gas. The memorandum analyzed lawful activities like recruiting demonstrators, as well as illegal activities like using fake documentation to get into a secured site.

keywords: ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; FRANCE; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; MILITARY BASES AND INSTALLATIONS; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Protesters Attack French Base
snippet: Up to 500 protesters, some with machetes, besieged the French military base in Abidjan. French troops fired tear gas and stun grenades at the protesters, but a French Army spokesman said the youths had not been dispersed. The protest followed a call...
lead_paragraph: Up to 500 protesters, some with machetes, besieged the French military base in Abidjan. French troops fired tear gas and stun grenades at the protesters, but a French Army spokesman said the youths had not been dispersed. The protest followed a call by Ivoirian Army soldiers on Sunday for the French to let government troops fight rebels holding the northern half of the country.

keywords: VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Venezuelan Protesters Clash With Police
snippet: The Venezuelan police and national guard troops firing tear gas clashed with rioting street vendors in downtown Caracas on Wednesday and at least one policeman was hurt by stones thrown by the protesters, officials said.    The clashes began after...
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan police and national guard troops firing tear gas clashed with rioting street vendors in downtown Caracas on Wednesday and at least one policeman was hurt by stones thrown by the protesters, officials said. The clashes began after the police seized illegal fireworks, raising tensions as electoral authorities prepared to evaluate an opposition request for a referendum on the rule of President Hugo Chávez. The police said the demonstrators, some shouting slogans in support of Mr. Chávez, fired guns at officers and threw firecrackers.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Police And Students Clash
snippet: The police fired tear gas and warning shots at thousands of university students who spilled into the streets of Port-au-Prince in the latest protest aimed at ousting President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. One bystander was killed, and two students were...
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas and warning shots at thousands of university students who spilled into the streets of Port-au-Prince in the latest protest aimed at ousting President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. One bystander was killed, and two students were shot and wounded. It was not clear who shot the students. Three others were hurt as Aristide supporters reportedly pelted students with rocks. More than 24 people were hurt last Friday at the University of Haiti when dozens of government supporters attacked about 100 protesting students.

keywords: DEMPSEY, MARTIN E; RUMSFELD, DONALD H; HUSSEIN, SADDAM; HATTAM, QAIS; IRAQ; SAMARRA (IRAQ); BAGHDAD (IRAQ); ABU SAFA (IRAQ); CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY; FINANCES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; TERRORISM
headline: G.I.'s Fight Off Convoy Attack; Raid Iraqi Cell
snippet: American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis in ambushes and violent rallies on Monday and Tuesday, the military reported, as repercussions of the capture of Saddam Hussein continued to be felt from Washington to the seething Sunni Muslim heartland of...
lead_paragraph: American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis in ambushes and violent rallies on Monday and Tuesday, the military reported, as repercussions of the capture of Saddam Hussein continued to be felt from Washington to the seething Sunni Muslim heartland of Iraq. New details emerged Tuesday about documents found when Mr. Hussein was captured, contributing to a clearer picture of those organizing guerrilla attacks. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said in Washington that the Central Intelligence Agency would oversee Mr. Hussein's interrogation.

keywords: KELLER, GERTA; PRINCETON UNIVERSITY; PALEONTOLOGY; SPACE; ENDANGERED AND EXTINCT SPECIES; DINOSAURS; METEORS AND METEORITES
headline: Where Dinosaurs Roamed, She Throws Stones
snippet: REMEMBER the riddle about the extinction of the dinosaurs? It bedeviled many of us as children. It seemed to have been solved two decades ago with the theory that a single meteor plowed into the Earth 65 million years ago. Poof, we thought, the...
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the riddle about the extinction of the dinosaurs? It bedeviled many of us as children. It seemed to have been solved two decades ago with the theory that a single meteor plowed into the Earth 65 million years ago. Poof, we thought, the dinosaurs were gone. But Gerta Keller, 58, a professor in Princeton University's department of geosciences, is part of a small group that is rattling the foundations. And the theory she supports, which argues that the demise of the dinosaurs was more complicated, has unleashed a small tempest of its own among die-hard believers in the meteor theory, who are known as ''impacters.''

snippet: Israeli troops arrested a total of 16 wanted Palestinians in a series of overnight raids in the West Bank that ended early Saturday, an Israeli military source said.    The raids took place in five villages north of the city of Ramallah, the military...
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops arrested a total of 16 wanted Palestinians in a series of overnight raids in the West Bank that ended early Saturday, an Israeli military source said. The raids took place in five villages north of the city of Ramallah, the military said.

keywords: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Soldiers Shoot Israeli Protester At Barrier, and Furor Follows
snippet: At first glance, the confrontation on Friday along Israel's separation barrier seemed unremarkable.    About 20 protesters shook the chain-link fence, and some then took out pliers to cut it. After calling out warnings and firing shots into the air,...
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the confrontation on Friday along Israel's separation barrier seemed unremarkable. About 20 protesters shook the chain-link fence, and some then took out pliers to cut it. After calling out warnings and firing shots into the air, Israeli troops shot at the legs of the protesters with live ammunition, the military admits.

keywords: KATZ, YISRAEL; ASSAD, BASHAR AL-; GOLAN HEIGHTS; SYRIA; ISRAEL; FINANCES
headline: Israel Plans 25% Expansion Of Its Settlements on Golan
snippet: Israel plans a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the Golan Heights, the government confirmed Wednesday. The announcement angered Syria, from which Israel seized the territory in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.    The plan, approved two weeks ago,...
lead_paragraph: Israel plans a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the Golan Heights, the government confirmed Wednesday. The announcement angered Syria, from which Israel seized the territory in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. The plan, approved two weeks ago, comes just two months after the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, called for renewed peace talks between his country and Israel.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; FOREIGN AID
headline: 200 Years After Napoleon, Haiti Finds Little to Celebrate
snippet: Two hundred years ago, an army of African slaves defeated French forces on this tropical island, ending Napoleon's ambition to dominate the Americas and paving the way for the first black republic.     On Thursday, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide...
lead_paragraph: Two hundred years ago, an army of African slaves defeated French forces on this tropical island, ending Napoleon's ambition to dominate the Americas and paving the way for the first black republic. On Thursday, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide led a tense and chaotic observance of that bicentennial, though many found little to celebrate in Mr. Aristide's governance over what, after 200 years of independence, remains an impoverished and troubled nation.

keywords: MUBARAK, HOSNI; ARAFAT, YASIR; BAZ, OSAMA EL-; EGYPT; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; TERRORISM
headline: Egyptian Urges Arafat to Subdue Factions
snippet: Hoping to revive the stalled Middle East peace effort, an Egyptian government envoy met the embattled Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, here on Thursday and urged him to work with rival Palestinian factions to end attacks against Israel.    ''It is...
lead_paragraph: Hoping to revive the stalled Middle East peace effort, an Egyptian government envoy met the embattled Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, here on Thursday and urged him to work with rival Palestinian factions to end attacks against Israel. ''It is the duty of the people of the region and first of all us and you and the Arab people to take the decisions and measures from our side that will pave the road toward a better future,'' said the envoy, Osama el-Baz, speaking briefly to reporters outside the sandbagged entrance to Mr. Arafat's blasted West Bank headquarters. ''We hope that Israel will do the same because the issue depends on the will of both sides.''

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Clash At Protester's Funeral March
snippet: Firing warning shots and tear gas, the police stopped mourners who left a church funeral in Port-au-Prince to march on the presidential palace with the coffin of a protester killed this month in a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand...
lead_paragraph: Firing warning shots and tear gas, the police stopped mourners who left a church funeral in Port-au-Prince to march on the presidential palace with the coffin of a protester killed this month in a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. At least six people were injured in violence that followed, most of them hurt by hurled rocks or shots fired by Aristide supporters, witnesses said.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: 20,000 March For President
snippet: In one of the largest demonstrations in months in Port-au-Prince, the capital, more than 20,000 people marched in support of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the face of calls for his ouster. For the second time in three days, the police prevented...
lead_paragraph: In one of the largest demonstrations in months in Port-au-Prince, the capital, more than 20,000 people marched in support of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the face of calls for his ouster. For the second time in three days, the police prevented anti-Aristide demonstrators from marching by firing tear gas.

keywords: CHUR (SWITZERLAND); LANDQUART (SWITZERLAND); DAVOS (SWITZERLAND); WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Forum Protest Staged From a Distance
snippet: Armed with spray cans and paint bombs, about 500 antiglobalization protesters clashed with the police in the eastern Swiss town of Landquart on Saturday, as the officers tried to stop them from heading into nearby Davos to protest illegally at the...
lead_paragraph: Armed with spray cans and paint bombs, about 500 antiglobalization protesters clashed with the police in the eastern Swiss town of Landquart on Saturday, as the officers tried to stop them from heading into nearby Davos to protest illegally at the World Economic Forum. The police said they fired tear gas and pepper spray at the protesters at the Landquart railway station. Four protesters were injured, the police reported; two were given first aid, and two were taken to the hospital.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: One Dead In Clash Near U.S. Consulate
snippet: One person was killed and several others injured in a clash between the police, supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and antigovernment marchers near the American Consulate in Port-au-Prince. Demonstrators had gathered outside the...
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and several others injured in a clash between the police, supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and antigovernment marchers near the American Consulate in Port-au-Prince. Demonstrators had gathered outside the consulate, where they burned a coffin and called for the ouster of Mr. Aristide. As the demonstrators were leaving, rock-throwing Aristide supporters confronted them. The police fired warning shots and tear gas to disperse the crowd. Hospital officials said the man who was killed died when he was struck in the chest by a tear-gas canister. A spokeswoman for the consulate said the office closed because of the unrest but that officials hoped to re-open it today. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; CARIBBEAN COMMUNITY; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Haiti's Neighbors Are Pressing Aristide for Reforms
snippet: At 24, David Jonathas is barely old enough to remember the political revolution that eventually placed a Catholic priest named Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the presidential palace. And yet, Mr. Jonathas hopes to be part of another movement, equal in...
lead_paragraph: At 24, David Jonathas is barely old enough to remember the political revolution that eventually placed a Catholic priest named Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the presidential palace. And yet, Mr. Jonathas hopes to be part of another movement, equal in determination to that earlier campaign waged in the late 1980's but with opposite results. ''As long as Aristide is in power, there will be no democracy,'' said Mr. Jonathas, a student at the University of Haiti, wiping his brow moments after he and a few hundred other students finished a march through the winding, pockmarked streets of the capital here calling for Mr. Aristide's ouster. ''He must go. We need a new system.''

keywords: SIMMONS, RAMEL; NEW YORK CITY; ALBANY (NY); GALAXY DINER; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Suspect In Shootings Found Dead
snippet: A suspect in a shooting spree that wounded nine people at a Brooklyn diner last month was found dead, apparently a suicide, in an Albany apartment Wednesday afternoon after being surrounded by the police, the authorities said yesterday. After the...
lead_paragraph: A suspect in a shooting spree that wounded nine people at a Brooklyn diner last month was found dead, apparently a suicide, in an Albany apartment Wednesday afternoon after being surrounded by the police, the authorities said yesterday. After the suspect, Ramel Simmons, 23, had been tracked to the apartment, New York City and Albany police officers arrived to arrest him, the police said. After no response to police calls for two hours, tear gas was fired inside, and a fiber-optic camera showed Mr. Simmons dead on the floor with a 9-millimeter handgun, the police said. It is unclear whether Mr. Simmons shot himself before the police arrived or after the tear gas was used, the police said. The police had identified Mr. Simmons as one of two men who opened fire in the Galaxy Diner in East New York on Jan. 17, sending customers diving under tables for cover before taking jewelry and money and fleeing. Another suspect, Mark Blount of East New York, was arrested the following week. The police are seeking a third suspect, possibly a driver, an investigator said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

keywords: SOUTH KOREA; CHILE; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Clash in Seoul As Farmers Rally to Protest Chile Trade Bill
snippet: Rock-throwing South Korean farmers clashed with riot-equipped police officers outside Parliament on Monday in a battle against passage of a free trade agreement with Chile that the growers fear will flood their markets with cheap produce.    While...
lead_paragraph: Rock-throwing South Korean farmers clashed with riot-equipped police officers outside Parliament on Monday in a battle against passage of a free trade agreement with Chile that the growers fear will flood their markets with cheap produce. While the violent demonstration raged outside, legislators were unable to bring the measure to a vote. It was the third time Parliament had balked at ratifying the pact.

snippet: Militant supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide blocked a demonstration planned by civic opposition groups in the capital on Thursday, erecting barricades of flaming tires and throwing rocks at anyone who tried to breach their blockade.   ...
lead_paragraph: Militant supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide blocked a demonstration planned by civic opposition groups in the capital on Thursday, erecting barricades of flaming tires and throwing rocks at anyone who tried to breach their blockade. Militants loyal to Mr. Aristide and his Lavalas party started gathering in the square late Wednesday night, and Thursday morning hundreds of them threw rocks, taunted and shouted at opposition protesters.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; KERRY, JOHN; IRAQ; VIETNAM WAR; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; ELECTION ISSUES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2004; NATIONAL GUARD (US); UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: You Can't Skip Vietnam Twice
snippet: WHEN George W. Bush's handlers had him dress up as the 1986 Tom Cruise of ''Top Gun'' to dance a victory jig on an aircraft carrier, they didn't stop to think that he might soon face an opponent who could be type-cast more persuasively in his own Tom...
lead_paragraph: WHEN George W. Bush's handlers had him dress up as the 1986 Tom Cruise of ''Top Gun'' to dance a victory jig on an aircraft carrier, they didn't stop to think that he might soon face an opponent who could be type-cast more persuasively in his own Tom Cruise role. John F. Kerry was in real life a comrade of Ron Kovic, whom Mr. Cruise played to great acclaim in the 1989 ''Born on the Fourth of July.'' Mr. Kerry, like the movie's hero, was a decorated Vietnam soldier who became a star activist for Vietnam Veterans Against the War upon returning home. In a pivotal scene in the film, delegates at the 1972 Republican National Convention in Miami Beach eject Kovic and his fellow protesting vets from the hall, call him a traitor and spit on him. If that incident has a certain angry passion, it may be because the director was Oliver Stone. Like both Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry, Mr. Stone was a son of privilege who attended Yale in the mid-1960's. Like Mr. Kerry but unlike Mr. Bush, he went on to combat in Vietnam, won a bronze star and then turned against America's most disastrous foreign war.

keywords: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; INTERNATIONAL COURT OF JUSTICE; PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; FENCES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
headline: Hearing on West Bank Wall Draws Demonstrators
snippet: An international court opened a hearing on Monday about the Israeli barrier being built in and around the West Bank, as pro-Palestinian demonstrators here voiced encouragement in front of worried supporters of Israel.    In a three-hour presentation...
lead_paragraph: An international court opened a hearing on Monday about the Israeli barrier being built in and around the West Bank, as pro-Palestinian demonstrators here voiced encouragement in front of worried supporters of Israel. In a three-hour presentation to the International Court of Justice, the Palestinian Authority argued that the partly built barrier of ditches, watchposts and concrete walls was a violation of international law and an attempt to annex Palestinian land.

keywords: TRAVERS, MARY; STOKEY, NOEL PAUL; YARROW, PETER; NEW YORK CITY; PETER, PAUL AND MARY; MUSIC; PARTIES (SOCIAL)
headline: BOLDFACE NAMES
snippet: Now That's What We Call a Fan      PETER, PAUL and MARY had a party at Peter's -- that is to say PETER YARROW's -- apartment the other day. It's a duplex, off Central Park West. There are some hippie vestiges; the high ceiling is peeling badly, the...
lead_paragraph: Now That's What We Call a Fan PETER, PAUL and MARY had a party at Peter's -- that is to say PETER YARROW's -- apartment the other day. It's a duplex, off Central Park West. There are some hippie vestiges; the high ceiling is peeling badly, the coffee tables are wooden crates, but it's still an impressive address. So despite the group's iconic status, there is one important question to be dealt with, before Mr. Yarrow, who bought the apartment in 1978, drags us single-mindedly into a one-way conversation on issues.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: In Haiti, All the Bridges Are Burned
snippet: The world is now watching what is going on in Haiti. Everyone has seen how the population of Cap Haitien, Haiti's second-largest city, welcomed as liberators a motley group of rebels who now vow to march here to the capital. But that's only the most...
lead_paragraph: The world is now watching what is going on in Haiti. Everyone has seen how the population of Cap Haitien, Haiti's second-largest city, welcomed as liberators a motley group of rebels who now vow to march here to the capital. But that's only the most obvious sign of a resentment against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide that has been growing for years. The most popular song of the Carnival that just ended, for example, was an attack on a government official, ''Madan Gougou,'' and by extension, on Mr. Aristide's Lavalas party. Schoolchildren pass around unflattering caricatures of the president, and anti-Aristide graffiti have proliferated in the streets. That's why Haitians weren't surprised when the democratic opposition, with no ties to the rebels, this week rejected an American-drafted proposal that would give it more power but also let President Aristide complete his term in office. The only solution, the opposition said, was for Mr. Aristide to go.

keywords: QUREI, AHMED; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; BIDDU (WEST BANK); BEIT SURIK (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; INTERNATIONAL COURT OF JUSTICE; PALESTINIANS; FENCES; BANKS AND BANKING
headline: 2 Palestinians Are Killed and Dozens Wounded in Clashes With Israeli Troops Over Barrier
snippet: Israeli security forces shot dead two Palestinians and wounded dozens, according to Palestinian doctors, in daylong clashes on Thursday with stone-throwing protesters in two West Bank villages. It was the deadliest confrontation yet linked to...
lead_paragraph: Israeli security forces shot dead two Palestinians and wounded dozens, according to Palestinian doctors, in daylong clashes on Thursday with stone-throwing protesters in two West Bank villages. It was the deadliest confrontation yet linked to Israel's separation barrier. Also, two Palestinian gunmen killed an Israeli soldier at an industrial zone in the northern Gaza Strip, where thousands of Palestinians work in Israeli-run factories. Both attackers were fatally shot by other soldiers.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); RECALL (ELECTIONS); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; REFERENDUMS
headline: 2 Killed as Troops Fight Protesters in Venezuela
snippet: Venezuelan troops and antigovernment demonstrators clashed Friday in the streets of the capital, Caracas, leaving at least two people dead and several wounded as President Hugo Chávez convened a summit meeting of developing nations.    The...
lead_paragraph: Venezuelan troops and antigovernment demonstrators clashed Friday in the streets of the capital, Caracas, leaving at least two people dead and several wounded as President Hugo Chávez convened a summit meeting of developing nations. The confrontation, in which National Guard troops repeatedly fired tear gas at protesters and gunfire broke out, came two days before a government electoral board was to rule on the validity of signatures government opponents had collected to force a referendum on recalling Mr. Chávez from office.

keywords: SHAKAH, GHASSAN W; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; GAZA STRIP; NABLUS (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES
headline: A Day of Israeli-Palestinian Violence; Civil Disorder in Nablus
snippet: At least one Palestinian gunman shot and killed two Israelis as they drove near the southern edge of Israel's boundary with the West Bank on Friday night, the Israeli Army said.    The attack came on a day of chaotic violence, as a suicide bomber...
lead_paragraph: At least one Palestinian gunman shot and killed two Israelis as they drove near the southern edge of Israel's boundary with the West Bank on Friday night, the Israeli Army said. The attack came on a day of chaotic violence, as a suicide bomber riding a bicycle blew himself up near a Gaza Strip settlement, hurting no one else, and stone-throwing Palestinians clashed with riot-equipped police officers at a Jerusalem site sacred to Muslims and Jews.

keywords: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; FENCES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Ideas & Trends: Tactical Shift; On the West Bank, a Hint of Resistance Without Blood
snippet: THE barrier Israel is building against West Bank Palestinians has had a striking, if unintended, effect: It has stirred a sustained, bloodless protest movement among Palestinians for the first time in more than three years of conflict.    As the...
lead_paragraph: THE barrier Israel is building against West Bank Palestinians has had a striking, if unintended, effect: It has stirred a sustained, bloodless protest movement among Palestinians for the first time in more than three years of conflict. As the bulldozers have swept south toward Jerusalem and cut deeper into West Bank land, villagers who have mostly stayed on the sidelines of the uprising have joined with Israeli leftists to demonstrate. In places, as in this hamlet, they have blocked the machines with their bodies.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; RECALL (ELECTIONS); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Venezuelans' Plan to Recall Chávez Is Near Defeat
snippet: A campaign by opposition groups for a recall referendum to try to oust President Hugo Chávez appeared on the brink of collapse on Monday.    Opposition leaders, expecting election officials to disqualify enough of the 3.4 million signatures they...
lead_paragraph: A campaign by opposition groups for a recall referendum to try to oust President Hugo Chávez appeared on the brink of collapse on Monday. Opposition leaders, expecting election officials to disqualify enough of the 3.4 million signatures they have collected for a recall to keep the measure off the ballot, accused Mr. Chávez of influencing the process.

headline: Anger Rises In Pakistan After Attack On Shiites
snippet: Troops enforced a curfew in Quetta on Wednesday as Shiite Muslims reacted angrily to an attack on a religious procession the day before that killed 44 people.    Shiite leaders delayed the funerals of 32 of those killed in the attack by guns and...
lead_paragraph: Troops enforced a curfew in Quetta on Wednesday as Shiite Muslims reacted angrily to an attack on a religious procession the day before that killed 44 people. Shiite leaders delayed the funerals of 32 of those killed in the attack by guns and grenades, and they demanded the resignations of the provincial local police chief and others for failing to prevent the attack despite heavy nationwide security.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; LATORTUE, GERARD; JAMAICA; HAITI; UNITED NATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; FOREIGN AID
headline: Haiti's New Leader Sees a Long Transition
snippet: The newly appointed prime minister, Gérard Latortue, said Thursday that it might take as long as two years to prepare for elections. That would put a new elected government beyond the 2005 timeline envisioned in the United States-backed transition...
lead_paragraph: The newly appointed prime minister, Gérard Latortue, said Thursday that it might take as long as two years to prepare for elections. That would put a new elected government beyond the 2005 timeline envisioned in the United States-backed transition plan to help Haiti recover after the departure of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. ''We really want to give an equal chance to all political parties, to all candidates,'' said Mr. Latortue, in his first interview since returning to Haiti on Wednesday after decades of living in United States and elsewhere. ''We want not to go fast, but to take time.''

keywords: KOSOVO (SERBIA); SERBIA AND MONTENEGRO; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED NATIONS
headline: NATO Expanding Kosovo Forces to Combat Violence
snippet: NATO ordered reinforcements to Kosovo on Thursday as peacekeepers struggled to stem a wave of ethnic violence across the province, in southern Serbia.     The additional 1,000 troops, which will bring the overall NATO force to 19,000, began arriving...
lead_paragraph: NATO ordered reinforcements to Kosovo on Thursday as peacekeepers struggled to stem a wave of ethnic violence across the province, in southern Serbia. The additional 1,000 troops, which will bring the overall NATO force to 19,000, began arriving Thursday evening, at the end of a second day of violence between ethnic Albanians and Serbs in which at least 31 people have been killed and hundreds injured, according to United Nations officials. Most of the dead were Serbs.

keywords: HELLING, RICK; MINNESOTA TWINS; BASEBALL
