snippet: BASEBALL    Broken Leg Sidelines Twins Pitcher Helling      Rick Helling, who was expected to be the Minnesota Twins' No. 5 starter, will miss at least a month with a broken right leg after being hit by a line drive on Saturday. He will wear a...
lead_paragraph: BASEBALL Broken Leg Sidelines Twins Pitcher Helling Rick Helling, who was expected to be the Minnesota Twins' No. 5 starter, will miss at least a month with a broken right leg after being hit by a line drive on Saturday. He will wear a walking boot for about four weeks, said Sean Harlin, a team spokesman. (AP)

keywords: SISTANI, ALI AL-; IRAQ; UNITED NATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Shiite Ayatollah Is Warning U.N. Against Endorsing Charter Sponsored by U.S.
snippet: Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, has warned of ''dangerous consequences'' if the United Nations endorses the American-sponsored interim constitution for an independent Iraq that was adopted over Shiite protests...
lead_paragraph: Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, has warned of ''dangerous consequences'' if the United Nations endorses the American-sponsored interim constitution for an independent Iraq that was adopted over Shiite protests two weeks ago. The warning came in a letter released by Ayatollah Sistani's office on Monday, four days after it was delivered in New York to Lakhtar Brahimi, the chief United Nations envoy to Iraq. It amounted to a warning that the ayatollah's followers, by far the most powerful political bloc in Iraq, could move to paralyze American plans for a smooth transfer of sovereignty on June 30 unless Shiite terms for changing the interim constitution were met.

keywords: ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; FRANCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: 25 Killed in Antigovernment Protest in Ivory Coast
snippet: Violent clashes erupted on the streets of Abidjan, the commercial capital of Ivory Coast, on Thursday, killing 25 people, prompting rebels to withdraw from a power-sharing government and raising new doubts about the prospects for disarmament.   ...
lead_paragraph: Violent clashes erupted on the streets of Abidjan, the commercial capital of Ivory Coast, on Thursday, killing 25 people, prompting rebels to withdraw from a power-sharing government and raising new doubts about the prospects for disarmament. Ivory Coast was once an oasis of stability in West Africa, but the outbreak of war in September 2002 left the country partitioned between government and rebel-held territories. Under a French-brokered peace accord, rebels and opposition parties joined a government of national reconciliation, French troops monitored a cease-fire between the warring parties, and plans were under way to deploy a United Nations peacekeeping force. The first of 6,000 peacekeepers were to arrive next month.

keywords: GYANENDRA; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; ROYAL FAMILY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Dozens Injured In Anti-King Protests
snippet: The police fired tear gas and used batons to break up a rally by political parties against King Gyanendra, officials said. They said more than 100 protesters were injured in clashes with the police that began after the demonstrators tried to defy a...
lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas and used batons to break up a rally by political parties against King Gyanendra, officials said. They said more than 100 protesters were injured in clashes with the police that began after the demonstrators tried to defy a government order banning rallies on main streets leading to the king's palace and government buildings in Katmandu, the capital. It was the second day of protests demanding the restoration of democratic politics. Organizers of the protests called for a general strike today.

keywords: GYANENDRA; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; ROYAL FAMILY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Nepal Police Seize 1,000 Marchers At Antimonarchy Rally in Capital
snippet: With opposition to Nepal's monarchist government growing in intensity, more than 1,000 people were detained Friday in Katmandu, the capital, for violating a ban on public gatherings that was imposed this week.     As many as 25,000 demonstrators...
lead_paragraph: With opposition to Nepal's monarchist government growing in intensity, more than 1,000 people were detained Friday in Katmandu, the capital, for violating a ban on public gatherings that was imposed this week. As many as 25,000 demonstrators defied the ban, according to news agency reports, capping a week of pro-democracy, antimonarchy protests.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE; TEAR GAS
headline: Venezuela Abused Protesters, Human Rights Groups Charge
snippet: Once seen as deferential to civil liberties despite his increasing hold on power, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela is now coming under sharp criticism from human rights groups that say that torture and excessive force were used to tame recent...
lead_paragraph: Once seen as deferential to civil liberties despite his increasing hold on power, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela is now coming under sharp criticism from human rights groups that say that torture and excessive force were used to tame recent anti-Chávez protests. In the latest report, released on Friday in a six-page letter to Mr. Chávez, Human Rights Watch, which is based in New York, accused National Guard troops of using tear gas and electric batons to torture protesters after their arrests.

keywords: ADAM, SULIEMAN ABDALLAH; SUDAN; GENEINA (SUDAN); DARFUR (SUDAN); IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
headline: Uprooted Sudanese Balk at Invitation to Return Home
snippet: The governor of this rugged stretch of earth, where the climate and the outlaws are equally harsh, declared Thursday that Darfur was safe again. Speaking in his office in the regional capital of West Darfur, the governor, Sulieman Abdallah Adam, said...
lead_paragraph: The governor of this rugged stretch of earth, where the climate and the outlaws are equally harsh, declared Thursday that Darfur was safe again. Speaking in his office in the regional capital of West Darfur, the governor, Sulieman Abdallah Adam, said it was time for the million or so people amassed in makeshift camps across western Sudan, including 23,000 on the edge of this town, to head back to their villages again. The only problem with his decree is that the displaced villagers know better. They have the wounds to prove that Darfur remains deadly, no matter what the government says. Some of their wounds are fresh, so fresh that they plan to flout the governor's order.

keywords: RHODE, DAVID; BANGLADESH; DHAKA (BANGLADESH); LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Member Of Parliament Killed
snippet: Gunmen opened fire at a political rally held by Bangladesh's main opposition party in the capitol of Dhaka, killing a senior opposition member of Parliament and at least one other person, Reuters reported. The gunmen escaped. Hundreds of members of...
lead_paragraph: Gunmen opened fire at a political rally held by Bangladesh's main opposition party in the capitol of Dhaka, killing a senior opposition member of Parliament and at least one other person, Reuters reported. The gunmen escaped. Hundreds of members of the opposition Awami league gathered to protest the killing, and were dispersed by police officers wielding batons and tear gas. David Rohde (NYT)

keywords: OBASANJO, OLUSEGUN; KANO (NIGERIA); NIGERIA; YELWA (NIGERIA); CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Muslim Mobs, Seeking Vengence, Attack Christians in Nigeria
snippet: Muslim mobs brandishing machetes and clubs attacked Christians in the streets of Kano on Wednesday as security forces struggled to quell a two-day rampage to avenge a massacre of hundreds of Nigerian Muslims.    The police confirmed that at least 30...
lead_paragraph: Muslim mobs brandishing machetes and clubs attacked Christians in the streets of Kano on Wednesday as security forces struggled to quell a two-day rampage to avenge a massacre of hundreds of Nigerian Muslims. The police confirmed that at least 30 had been killed in strife engulfing Kano in northern Nigeria. Thousands of people, most of them belonging to the city's minority Christian population, cowered in army barracks and police stations as mobs attacked people outside. Witnesses said dozens more had been killed.

lead_paragraph: The police fired tear gas and beat people who were preparing to hold a meeting on constitutional reform in the central Zimbabwe city of Gweru on Saturday, the coalition organizing the event said. About 80 people were arrested, including the coalition's chairman, Lovemore Madhuku, said Ernest Mudzengi, spokesman for the group, the National Constitutional Assembly.

headline: In a New Nigeria, a Once-Exiled Nobelist Still Finds Trouble
snippet: For the first time since the return of civilian democracy in his home country, Wole Soyinka, the once-exiled Nigerian writer and Nobel laureate, took part in a political protest in the capital, Lagos.     He received a mixed welcome. A crowd of...
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the return of civilian democracy in his home country, Wole Soyinka, the once-exiled Nigerian writer and Nobel laureate, took part in a political protest in the capital, Lagos. He received a mixed welcome. A crowd of hundreds turned up with banners and trumpets Saturday morning. Then, according to demonstrators, the police lobbed tear gas and whisked Mr. Soyinka away to a police station, only to release him less than an hour later and offer apologies for the trouble.

keywords: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Police Break Up Pro-Aristide Rally
snippet: The police used tear gas and fired assault rifles in the air to break up a march by 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Thousands of people poured out of the slums to demand his return, making it one of the largest...
lead_paragraph: The police used tear gas and fired assault rifles in the air to break up a march by 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Thousands of people poured out of the slums to demand his return, making it one of the largest demonstrations of lingering support for Mr. Aristide since he left the country for exile in February.

headline: Sports of The Times; Olympic Doomsayers as Cyclical as Cicadas
snippet: LIKE 17-year cicadas, journalists emit their own cyclical loud buzzing noises before every set of Summer Games. Listen. You can hear us now, fretting about construction, security and ambience in Athens in August.    The other day, the Greek prime...
lead_paragraph: LIKE 17-year cicadas, journalists emit their own cyclical loud buzzing noises before every set of Summer Games. Listen. You can hear us now, fretting about construction, security and ambience in Athens in August. The other day, the Greek prime minister, Costas Caramanlis, visited the offices of The New York Times. We peppered him -- politely, of course -- about the progress of these Games.

keywords: SAAKASHVILI, MIKHAIL; GEORGIA (GEORGIAN REPUBLIC); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS
headline: The Not-So-Velvet Revolution
snippet: Georgia's president, Mikhail Saakashvili -- called Misha by just about everyone in the country -- took power on Nov. 22, 2003, by storming Parliament on live national television. Yelling from the back benches, he ordered Eduard Shevardnadze, who was...
lead_paragraph: Georgia's president, Mikhail Saakashvili -- called Misha by just about everyone in the country -- took power on Nov. 22, 2003, by storming Parliament on live national television. Yelling from the back benches, he ordered Eduard Shevardnadze, who was widely seen as having stolen the recent parliamentary elections, to step aside. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet foreign minister and custodian of Georgia's descent into poverty and lawlessness, seemed frozen, then shaken by Saakashvili's rhetorical fire. As Shevardnadze was shuttled out the backdoor, Saakashvili, who had served a contentious term as justice minister under Shevardnadze, marched to the lectern, scanned the riotous scene, found the cameras and drank Shevardnadze's tall glass of tea. Out in the streets, protesters stuck flowers in the barrels of soldiers' assault rifles, and the Rose Revolution, as it was called, was over. Saakashvili, a charismatic 36-year-old graduate of Columbia Law School, was elected president two months later, winning 97 percent of the vote. Georgia -- a nation cracked open by three breakaway regions, racked by corruption and a tsunami of crime, reeling from two civil wars, pocked by constant electricity and water shortages and unable to collect taxes from its citizens -- was his to govern.

keywords: SHAMZAI, NIZAMMUDIN; KARACHI (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; AFGHANISTAN; TALIBAN; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; SUNNI MUSLIMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Gunmen Kill a Leading Pro-Taliban Sunni Cleric in Pakistan
snippet: Unidentified gunmen killed a leading pro-Taliban Sunni cleric on Sunday morning in the southern port city of Karachi. Enraged protesters then took to the streets and clashed with the police, according to police officials and news reports.     The...
lead_paragraph: Unidentified gunmen killed a leading pro-Taliban Sunni cleric on Sunday morning in the southern port city of Karachi. Enraged protesters then took to the streets and clashed with the police, according to police officials and news reports. The cleric, Mufti Nizammudin Shamzai, had worked to bring together Pakistan's warring Islamic sects and was considered one of the country's most powerful Sunni voices.

keywords: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; KARACHI (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
headline: 14 Die in Bombing of Shiite Mosque in Karachi
snippet: At least 14 people were killed and 38 wounded Monday night when a powerful bomb exploded in a Shiite mosque here, police officials said. The attack set off a wave of violent protest, and angry demonstrators clashed with riot police officers across...
lead_paragraph: At least 14 people were killed and 38 wounded Monday night when a powerful bomb exploded in a Shiite mosque here, police officials said. The attack set off a wave of violent protest, and angry demonstrators clashed with riot police officers across the city. At least two people were killed in the rioting, local news media reported. The bombing was the fourth terrorist incident in a single month in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city and a center of sectarian attacks in recent years.

keywords: REUTHER, VICTOR; REUTHER, ROY; REUTHER, WALTER; UNITED AUTOMOBILE WORKERS; AUTOMOBILES; LABOR; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ORGANIZED LABOR; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Victor Reuther, Influential Labor Leader, Dies at 92
snippet: Victor Reuther, the last of three brothers who helped unionize Detroit amid the labor strife of the 1930's and remained central to the growth of industrial unionism for the next third of the century, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 92.    His...
lead_paragraph: Victor Reuther, the last of three brothers who helped unionize Detroit amid the labor strife of the 1930's and remained central to the growth of industrial unionism for the next third of the century, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 92. His death was announced by his family and Ron Gettelfinger, president of what is now the United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America in Detroit, which says it has 710,000 active members in the United States and Canada.

keywords: MPALA, DAVID; MUGABE, ROBERT; ZIMBABWE; LUPANE (ZIMBABWE); FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: New Wave of Repression Seen in Zimbabwe By-Election
snippet: Like scores of opposition politicians in Zimbabwe, David Mpala knew violence firsthand. As he campaigned for this region's seat in Parliament in 2000, 40 government supporters clubbed him so soundly that he was permanently scarred. In 2002, 18 thugs...
lead_paragraph: Like scores of opposition politicians in Zimbabwe, David Mpala knew violence firsthand. As he campaigned for this region's seat in Parliament in 2000, 40 government supporters clubbed him so soundly that he was permanently scarred. In 2002, 18 thugs dragged him into the bush, beat him and stabbed him in the back. Mr. Mpala, 48, died in February, and the government held an election last month to fill his seat. This time, government critics say, it was democracy that got mugged.

keywords: NEW YORK CITY; HSBC BANK USA; SUBWAYS; DYES AND DYESTUFFS; BANK ROBBERIES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TRANSIT SYSTEMS; TEAR GAS
headline: Dye Paints Subway, And a Robber Flees (Yes) Red-Handed
snippet: Ideally, the pack of dye that a bank teller slips into a robber's money bag explodes while the robber is in midflight, sending up an eye-catching puff of red smoke. This is exactly what happened to a robber in a subway station yesterday -- but with...
lead_paragraph: Ideally, the pack of dye that a bank teller slips into a robber's money bag explodes while the robber is in midflight, sending up an eye-catching puff of red smoke. This is exactly what happened to a robber in a subway station yesterday -- but with less than ideal results. According to the police, a man walked into the HSBC branch at the Avenue of the Americas and 14th Street just before 9:30 a.m. and passed a note demanding money. The robber then ran out of the bank with an undisclosed amount of cash and into the 14th Street subway station, a busy spot at the crossroads of the F, V, L, 1, 2, 3 and 9 lines, as well as two PATH lines.

keywords: ISRAEL; HEBRON (WEST BANK); RECORDINGS (VIDEO); PALESTINIANS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Former Israeli Soldiers Tell of Harassment of Palestinians
snippet: When Israeli soldiers opened an exhibit this month documenting some of their own misdeeds while serving in the tense West Bank city of Hebron, they caused a brief stir.    At a photographic institute in Tel Aviv, the soldiers, all recently...
lead_paragraph: When Israeli soldiers opened an exhibit this month documenting some of their own misdeeds while serving in the tense West Bank city of Hebron, they caused a brief stir. At a photographic institute in Tel Aviv, the soldiers, all recently discharged, offer video testimony of gratuitous harassment and abuse of Palestinians, like firing tear gas just to get a reaction. Hanging on the wall are dozens of car keys confiscated from Hebron residents, a punishment both common and unauthorized, soldiers say. And a photo taken by a soldier shows graffiti, presumably written by civilians, which reads, ''Arabs to the gas chambers.''

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; RUMSFELD, DONALD H; GERMANY; IRAQ; FRANCE; AFGHANISTAN; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: NATO Agrees to Help Train Iraqi Forces
snippet: NATO leaders agreed Monday to help rebuild Iraq's security forces just hours after the American-led occupation forces transferred formal sovereignty to Iraq. But for NATO, many crucial details remain unresolved.     Bush administration officials...
lead_paragraph: NATO leaders agreed Monday to help rebuild Iraq's security forces just hours after the American-led occupation forces transferred formal sovereignty to Iraq. But for NATO, many crucial details remain unresolved. Bush administration officials heralded the training accord and an agreement to increase NATO troops in Afghanistan to bolster security for elections there in September as proof the alliance could overcome divisions to reach consensus on contentious issues far beyond its members' national borders.

lead_paragraph: President Bush called on Muslim nations on Tuesday to embrace democracy and warned Middle East autocrats, including those who are American allies, that they ''must recognize the direction of events of the day.'' Speaking at the end of a five-day trip to Europe and Turkey, Mr. Bush acknowledged that Western nations have helped nourish extremism by supporting repressive Middle Eastern leaders for the sake of regional stability.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters overran the southern city of Ayacucho after the police used tear gas to break up a demonstration by striking teachers. The government ruled out calling a state of emergency, but Interior Minister Javier Reategui said he was sending more police officers.

headline: Threat of Police Pickets Adds to Boston's Worries
snippet: Besides the threat of a terrorist attack at the Democratic National Convention here later this month, the police will have to deal with at least 70 sets of demonstrators, including opponents of abortion, particularly passionate in this heavily Roman...
lead_paragraph: Besides the threat of a terrorist attack at the Democratic National Convention here later this month, the police will have to deal with at least 70 sets of demonstrators, including opponents of abortion, particularly passionate in this heavily Roman Catholic area; Quakers who want to protest the war in Iraq with 800 pairs of empty combat boots and a plowshare forged from 10,000 spent bullet casings; anarchists; Buddhists -- and even themselves. That's right. Boston police officers, along with the city's firefighters, are locked in a long-running contract dispute and plan to picket several convention events, beginning with the 32 welcoming parties for various state delegations given by Mayor Thomas M. Menino.

keywords: STRUGA (MACEDONIA); MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Ethnic Macedonians Riot Over New Laws That Aid Albanians
snippet: Police officers used tear gas and rubber bullets early Friday morning to help quell rioting in Struga, a lakeside town in southwestern Macedonia. It was the first major outbreak of civil unrest since the end of an interethnic conflict in the country...
lead_paragraph: Police officers used tear gas and rubber bullets early Friday morning to help quell rioting in Struga, a lakeside town in southwestern Macedonia. It was the first major outbreak of civil unrest since the end of an interethnic conflict in the country three years ago. Government officials said at least 17 people were injured in clashes as ethnic Macedonians, protesting plans that would give the country's Albanian minority greater rights and powers, ran through the town. Mobs attacked Albanian-owned shops and property as well as government cars and vehicles belonging to a European Union police monitoring mission.

keywords: UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: The Quest for the Nonkiller App.
snippet: I recently was invited to the Pentagon to watch a film depicting field tests of a new weapons program called the Active Denial System, which, it occurred to me, could have been named by an unhinged cognitive therapist. The live-action video opened on...
lead_paragraph: I recently was invited to the Pentagon to watch a film depicting field tests of a new weapons program called the Active Denial System, which, it occurred to me, could have been named by an unhinged cognitive therapist. The live-action video opened on a vista reminiscent of Iraq or Afghanistan. Scattered amid the scrub of a desert plain, angry demonstrators howl unintelligible slogans and advance menacingly on a handful of soldiers who nervously pivot their rifles back and forth trying to deter the mob. For safety's sake during this test run, the ''crowd'' -- played for the most part by off-duty soldiers -- flings bright green tennis balls at the uniformed servicemen instead of rocks. As one member of the crowd hurls a ball, a soldier operating the Active Denial System (it looks like a squat satellite dish) targets an unruly protester in the weapon's viewfinder, squeezes a trigger that releases a beam of energy and, in a split second, one ''civilian'' howls and scampers away, fanning his rear end. Other demonstrators suffer similar fates, yelping and fleeing in panic, as if they have encountered a wall of invisible fire. After tumbling backward, the horde spins around, pointing and hollering like a Stone Age tribe encountering modern weaponry for the first time. What they were feeling was a blast of electromagnetic energy that causes a great deal of pain but does no lasting harm. That, in essence, is the point of a new generation of nonlethal weapons being developed by the military: to enforce and do battle without killing, or in the words of the Defense Department, ''to incapacitate personnel or matériel, while minimizing fatalities, permanent injury to personnel and undesired damage to property and the environment.'' Along with the Active Denial System, the military is testing bullets that disintegrate in mid-air, propelling their nonlethal payload to their targets, slimy goo that stops people in their tracks and, eventually, guns that shoot pulses of plasma energy that stun and disorient.

keywords: VERAVAL (INDIA); INDIA; GUJARAT STATE (INDIA); RAJKOT (INDIA); ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: 2 Killed In Religious Riots
snippet: Muslims and Hindus burned buildings and clashed with the police in a third day of religious riots in Veraval, in western Gujarat State, throwing acid at officers who shot at the crowd. The unrest spread to Rajkot, another town in Gujarat and left 2...
lead_paragraph: Muslims and Hindus burned buildings and clashed with the police in a third day of religious riots in Veraval, in western Gujarat State, throwing acid at officers who shot at the crowd. The unrest spread to Rajkot, another town in Gujarat and left 2 dead and at least 10 wounded. The police fired tear gas and used bamboo sticks to break up the rioters. Thousands of officers were on patrol, fearing the religious violence could increase. More than 1,000 people were killed in three months of Hindu-Muslim rioting two years ago in Gujarat State.

keywords: MASKS; OLYMPIC GAMES; SUMMER GAMES (OLYMPICS); SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TERRORISM; OLYMPIC GAMES (2004)
headline: For Athens, U.S. Team Packs Emergency Masks
snippet: Security precautions in Athens for the 531 United States athletes will include emergency masks in the event of tear gas, pepper spray or pollutants, a United States Olympic official said Friday.    Team trainers will carry the masks, in flat bags, in...
lead_paragraph: Security precautions in Athens for the 531 United States athletes will include emergency masks in the event of tear gas, pepper spray or pollutants, a United States Olympic official said Friday. Team trainers will carry the masks, in flat bags, in their equipment, and more than 1,000 will be available for the 800-person delegation, which includes officials.

keywords: STANDER (MOVIE); FLETCHER, DEXTER; JANE, TOM; O'HARA, DAVID PATRICK; HUGHES, BRONWEN; MOTION PICTURES; REVIEWS
headline: A Policeman Turns Against Apartheid and Becomes a Bank-Robbing Folk Hero
snippet: After the Holocaust, racial apartheid in South Africa may be the 20th-century curse most people would identify as unequivocally evil. And the first half hour of ''Stander,'' which tells the true story of Andre Stander (Tom Jane), the notorious...
lead_paragraph: After the Holocaust, racial apartheid in South Africa may be the 20th-century curse most people would identify as unequivocally evil. And the first half hour of ''Stander,'' which tells the true story of Andre Stander (Tom Jane), the notorious Johannesburg police captain who turned against a system he found repugnant, plays like a smoothly executed if predictable drama of one man's heroic rebellion. But just when you begin to relax and wait for the usual buttons to be pushed, ''Stander'' swerves in a more uncertain direction. The issue of apartheid recedes, and the film, which opens today in New York, becomes an unsettling character study camouflaged as a heist movie. The further the volatile title character evolves into a swaggering self-styled Robin Hood, the more his nobility begins to tarnish. By the end of the film, his demons have taken over, and he has become a compulsively self-destructive outlaw addicted to flouting authority.

keywords: HINDI, ABU ISSA AL-; GREAT BRITAIN; AL QAEDA; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; TERRORISM
headline: Officials Investigate a Qaeda Suspect's Shadowy Life
snippet: Abu Issa al-Hindi, the operative of Al Qaeda who American officials say is one of 13 men arrested in raids last week in England, has lived a life of subterfuge and survival.      As an Islamic fighter in the 1990's he took part in a guerrilla...
lead_paragraph: Abu Issa al-Hindi, the operative of Al Qaeda who American officials say is one of 13 men arrested in raids last week in England, has lived a life of subterfuge and survival. As an Islamic fighter in the 1990's he took part in a guerrilla campaign against the Indian Army in the rugged and perilous terrain of Kashmir. As an instructor in the Qaeda terrorist indoctrination camps of Afghanistan, he passed on his martial skills to the next generation of volunteers. And as a reconnaissance agent who slipped in and out of the United States in 2000 and 2001, he helped build an archive on the vulnerability of American financial centers on behalf of the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks.

keywords: WALLING, JEFF; BEDS AND BEDDING; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES)
headline: For the Sleeper Who Counts Monsters
snippet: WHAT your mother said is true: orange alerts, fire drills and early warnings of impending tornadoes do not mean much without a good night's sleep. Jeff Walling, a 46-year-old boiler inspector from Virginia Beach, hopes he has come up with the latest...
lead_paragraph: WHAT your mother said is true: orange alerts, fire drills and early warnings of impending tornadoes do not mean much without a good night's sleep. Jeff Walling, a 46-year-old boiler inspector from Virginia Beach, hopes he has come up with the latest tool in home safety. Behold, the Quantum Sleeper -- where a Martha Stewart thread count meets a 007 bulletproof protective canopy. ''You don't have to run to a 'safe room,' '' Mr. Walling said. ''You're already in it.''

keywords: BANGLADESH; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Violence in Bangladesh
snippet: An angry mob set fire to a passenger train, and protesters clashed with the police across Bangladesh on Sunday, leaving dozens of people injured, as violence spread a day after a grenade attack on an opposition rally killed 19 people and wounded...
lead_paragraph: An angry mob set fire to a passenger train, and protesters clashed with the police across Bangladesh on Sunday, leaving dozens of people injured, as violence spread a day after a grenade attack on an opposition rally killed 19 people and wounded hundreds. The train, the Subarna Express, was attacked as it was entering a station in the town of Bhairab, 50 miles east of its destination of Dhaka, the capital, said Mostafa-e-Jamail, a spokesman for state-run Bangladesh Railways. About 20 people were injured, most of them passengers trying to flee while protesters angry about the attack on Saturday doused at least 15 of about 25 train cars with gas and ignited them, the police said. Police officers fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

keywords: NAIROBI (KENYA); KENYA; RIFT VALLEY (KENYA); MASAI (TRIBE); RENTING AND LEASING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LAND USE POLICIES; TEAR GAS
headline: Tribe, Claiming Whites' Land, Confronts Kenya's Government
snippet: In scenes reminiscent of Zimbabwe's land seizures, angry Masai tribesmen have begun marching onto sprawling ranches held by white settlers in Kenya's lush Rift Valley and claiming the tracts as their own.    But while President Robert Mugabe backed...
lead_paragraph: In scenes reminiscent of Zimbabwe's land seizures, angry Masai tribesmen have begun marching onto sprawling ranches held by white settlers in Kenya's lush Rift Valley and claiming the tracts as their own. But while President Robert Mugabe backed -- and even encouraged -- the forced redistribution of land in Zimbabwe as a way of righting colonial wrongs, the Kenyan authorities are rebuffing the recent trespasses by the Masai.

Powell. The anti-American protest was the first disturbance to mar the Summer Olympics in Athens, where Greek authorities and NATO have mobilized sea, air and land forces to guard against terrorist attacks.

lead_paragraph: DON'T strut on the Greeks' last nerve or preen over anti-American tripwires, they were warned. Don't ridicule their Olympic hosts' red-white-and-blue conspiracy theories; don't scowl at the kind of Schadenfreude-induced mocking the American men's basketball team faced; don't taunt the type of catcallers who teased the American volleyball players or spit at the brand of hostile chants that drowned out the starter's pistol at track.

keywords: POWELL, COLIN L; GREECE; ATHENS (GREECE); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; OLYMPIC GAMES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; OLYMPIC GAMES (2004)
headline: Powell Cancels a Visit to Athens to Attend Closing of Olympics
snippet: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, citing urgent business at home, has canceled his visit to Athens to attend the closing ceremony of the Olympic Games, the State Department announced Saturday. An aide to the secretary said Mr. Powell did not want...
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, citing urgent business at home, has canceled his visit to Athens to attend the closing ceremony of the Olympic Games, the State Department announced Saturday. An aide to the secretary said Mr. Powell did not want to encourage anti-American protests that would distract from the ceremony. The announcement came after a demonstration in Athens on Friday involving 2,000 people protesting the planned visit disintegrated into a rock-throwing melee. At least three people were injured, and the police fired tear gas to break up the crowds.

keywords: STRUGA (MACEDONIA); MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Boundary Changes Put Ethnic Peace to the Test in Macedonia
snippet: Angered by the national government's plans to change local boundaries, this rundown resort of 36,000 people on the shores of Lake Ohrid is preparing to declare independence.      The town's crusade, however quixotic, to become a city-state has struck...
lead_paragraph: Angered by the national government's plans to change local boundaries, this rundown resort of 36,000 people on the shores of Lake Ohrid is preparing to declare independence. The town's crusade, however quixotic, to become a city-state has struck a chord across Macedonia. That is because the boundary changes are part of a delicate peace arrangement that ended fighting between Albanian guerrillas and government security forces three years ago, when the country was on the brink of a civil war.

keywords: CHENEY, DICK; NEW YORK CITY; ACT UP; POLICE DEPARTMENT; REPUBLICAN PARTY; MADISON SQUARE GARDEN; CONVENTIONS, NATIONAL (US); SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2004; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Police Tactics Mute Protesters And Messages
snippet: New York police have developed a pre-emptive strike policy, cutting off demonstrations before they grow large.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican National Convention approached its final evening tonight, nearly 1,800 protesters had been arrested on the streets, two-thirds of them on Tuesday night alone. But for all the anger of the demonstrations, they have barely interrupted the convention narrative, and have drawn relatively little national news coverage. Using large orange nets to divide and conquer, and a near-zero tolerance policy for activities that even suggest the prospect of disorder, the New York Police Department has developed what amounts to a pre-emptive strike policy, cutting off demonstrations before they grow large enough, loud enough, or unruly enough to affect the convention.

keywords: CARLUCCI, DAVID E; NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC; BETHEL WOODS CENTER FOR THE ARTS; MUSIC; APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CULTURE
headline: Arts Briefing
snippet: HIGHLIGHTS    INTO THE WOODS -- The Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in Sullivan County, N.Y., rising on the site of the 1969 Woodstock Festival, has a president and executive director. He is David E. Carlucci, currently general manager of House of...
lead_paragraph: HIGHLIGHTS INTO THE WOODS -- The Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in Sullivan County, N.Y., rising on the site of the 1969 Woodstock Festival, has a president and executive director. He is David E. Carlucci, currently general manager of House of Blues Concerts Midwest, operator of the Blossom Music Center in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio; the Scene Pavilion in Cleveland and the Timberwolf Amphitheater at Kings Island in Cincinnati. Mr. Carlucci's background in arts management includes 17 years at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in New York. The Bethel Woods Center, where ground was broken in July, is to open on July 1, 2006, with an inaugural concert by the New York Philharmonic. It is to have a 4,800-seat pavilion with lawn seating for 12,000. FILM PROTEST -- The new Pedro Almodóvar film, ''Bad Education,'' which deals with the sexual molestation of a young boy by a Roman Catholic priest, has come under attack in Poland, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. In Warsaw, where the movie opened on Friday, posters were defaced with graffiti, and in the town of Poznan, tear gas was lobbed into a theater, according to Malgorzata Kostro-Olechowska, a spokeswoman for Gutek Film, the distributor. She said that despite the attacks, the film would not be withdrawn, ''as we don't consider that it is against the church.'' ''Bad Education'' is to be shown at the New York Film Festival on Oct. 9 and 10.

keywords: PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); GONAIVES (HAITI); HAITI; UNITED NATIONS; CARE INTERNATIONAL; CHOLERA; JEANNE (STORM); MEDICINE AND HEALTH; HOSPITALS; FOREIGN AID; LOOTING; TYPHOID; FLOODS; HURRICANES AND TROPICAL STORMS
headline: Floodwaters Recede From Haitian City, but Hunger Does Not
snippet: Chaos and looting in Haiti has hamstrung efforts to distribute food in the flood ravaged nation, United Nations officials said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Floodwaters receded Friday in this city where flooding from a tropical storm took more than 1,000 lives, leaving behind thousands of tired and hungry people who labored to clear the mud and debris from what was left of their homes. United Nations officials managed to distribute more than 40 tons of corn, flour and water in two of the hardest-hit neighborhoods of the city, Raboteau and Bienac, avoiding the mob scenes that have hampered aid efforts in recent days. But the United Nations soldiers at Raboteau used tear gas and fire shots in the air to control the crowd in the afternoon, witnesses said.

keywords: PEARL, DANIEL; FAROOQI, AMJED HUSSAIN; MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; PAKISTAN; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; TERRORISM; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Suspect in Attacks on Pakistan President Is Killed
snippet: Amjad Hussain Farooqi, who is accused of twice attempting to assassinate Gen. Pervez Musharraf was killed by law enforcement authorities on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Amjad Hussain Farooqi, who is accused of being the mastermind of the two assassination attempts on Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, was killed by law enforcement authorities on Sunday, Pakistani officials said. Mr. Farooqi, who was also suspected in the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, had been pursued in a nationwide hunt. The interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, confirmed Sunday evening that Mr. Farooqi had been killed.

headline: Zimbabwe Court Clears Opposition Leader of Treason
snippet: Surprising many critics of Zimbabwe's government, the nation's highest court on Friday acquitted the leading political opposition figure, Morgan Tsvangirai, on treason charges after a yearlong trial left the prosecution's case in shambles.    ...
lead_paragraph: Surprising many critics of Zimbabwe's government, the nation's highest court on Friday acquitted the leading political opposition figure, Morgan Tsvangirai, on treason charges after a yearlong trial left the prosecution's case in shambles. Hundreds of supporters of Mr. Tsvangirai's opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, cheered and danced outside the colonial-style courthouse in the capital, Harare, after Judge Paddington Garwe announced the verdict. Mr. Tsvangirai said at a news conference that he hoped his acquittal would set the stage for ''national reconciliation'' of Zimbabwe's political crisis.

keywords: THAILAND; NARATHIWAT PROVINCE (THAILAND); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ASPHYXIATION AND SUFFOCATION
headline: 78 Arrested in Thai Protests Suffocate in Crowded Trucks
snippet: At least 78 people died from suffocation while being transported in overcrowded military trucks after a violent demonstration in south Thailand.
lead_paragraph: At least 78 people died from suffocation while being transported in overcrowded military trucks after a violent demonstration in Thailand's largely Muslim south, officials said Tuesday. Six others were shot to death and about 20 were wounded during the demonstration on Monday when the police fired live rounds as well as water cannons and tear gas into wild, rock-throwing crowds, witnesses and officials said.

keywords: LIBERIA; UNITED NATIONS; VIOLENCE; CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY
headline: Violence Erupts in Liberia
snippet: Violence between Muslims and Christians engulfed Liberia's war-battered capital, with United Nations peacekeepers firing warning shots and tear gas to restore order.
lead_paragraph: Violence between Muslims and Christians engulfed Liberia's war-battered capital on Friday, with machete-wielding crowds rampaging through the streets and United Nations peacekeepers firing warning shots and tear gas to restore order. At least three people were killed, crushed under the wheels of a United Nations armored vehicle that was moving in to disperse a crowd, a policeman said. The number of dead and wounded elsewhere was unclear, with some residents reporting up to five dead.

keywords: SNELGROVE, VICTORIA; WEXLER, CHUCK; BOSTON (MASS); BOSTON RED SOX; NEW YORK YANKEES; POLICE EXECUTIVE RESEARCH FORUM; VIOLENCE; PLAYOFF GAMES; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FENWAY PARK (BOSTON); POLICE; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Student's Death Returns Crowd Control to the Fore
snippet: The death of a student outside Fenway Park is only the latest reminder that crowd control has re-emerged as one of the toughest challenges for the police nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The death of a 21-year-old college student outside Fenway Park on Oct. 21, the night the Red Sox beat the Yankees for the American League pennant, is only the latest reminder that crowd control has re-emerged as one of the toughest challenges for the police nationwide. ''I've known some police chiefs who now hope their hometown team doesn't win because controlling a big crowd can be so difficult,'' said Chuck Wexler, the executive director of the Police Executive Research Forum, an organization of police chiefs meant to promote smarter law enforcement.

keywords: PRONK, JAN; ANNAN, KOFI; SUDAN; DARFUR (SUDAN); UNITED NATIONS
headline: New Violence Hinders Relief Efforts in Western Sudan
snippet: Even as peace talks continued in an effort to stanch the suffering in western Sudan, kidnappings, land mines and, most recently, a government crackdown on a camp for displaced people, have created new pockets of no-go areas on the ground and made it...
lead_paragraph: Even as peace talks continued in an effort to stanch the suffering in western Sudan, kidnappings, land mines and, most recently, a government crackdown on a camp for displaced people, have created new pockets of no-go areas on the ground and made it impossible to deliver relief to tens of thousands of Sudanese, aid groups said. The latest trouble came early Tuesday when, officials with the World Food Program said, the Sudanese military and police surrounded two camps in the state of Southern Darfur, used tear gas to disperse crowds and began forcibly moving some people from the camps.

keywords: ABBAS, MAHMOUD; QUREI, AHMED; ARAFAT, YASIR; ISRAEL; PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANIZATION; PALESTINIANS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
headline: Odd Question on West Bank: Who Is Arafat, Really?
snippet: Like so much else they consider beyond their control, Palestinians in Nablus are adjusting to the prospect of Yasir Arafat's death.
lead_paragraph: The only overarching Palestinian leader he has ever known lay near death in Paris, but for the moment Khaled Khalaf had a more pressing concern. He wanted to go shutter his pharmacy here on Monday night, but it was down the hill, right beside the boys throwing stones at Israeli soldiers, who were raiding Nablus in armored personnel carriers and armored jeeps.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; IRAQ; CHILE; SANTIAGO (CHILE); ASIA-PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
headline: Thousands Demonstrate Against Bush in Santiago
snippet: Police dispersed hundreds of protesters who gathered to demonstrate against the presence of President Bush at a summit meeting in Chile.
lead_paragraph: Using tear gas and water cannons, riot police officers dispersed hundreds of rock-throwing protesters on Friday after thousands of people had gathered peacefully to demonstrate against the presence of President Bush at a weekend summit meeting here. Mr. Bush, in his first trip abroad since his re-election, is one of 21 world leaders scheduled to attend the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, being held here for the first time. The group, known as APEC, aims to encourage economic growth and trade among member nations, who account for more than half of the world's economy. The Chilean government has trumpeted the decision to hold the meeting here as an indication that this country of 15 million has achieved elite status.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; CHILE; SANTIAGO (CHILE); ASIA-PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION FORUM; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTELLIGENCE SERVICES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Security Dispute Dulls Luster of Bush's Trip to Chile
snippet: The Chilean government disinvited more than 200 guests to a dinner with President Bush rather than let them be screened for weapons.
lead_paragraph: President Bush's visit to Chile ended on a bizarre note here this evening when the Chilean government disinvited more than 200 guests to a dinner with the president rather than let the Secret Service screen them for weapons on their way into the presidential palace. Mr. Bush and President Ricardo Lagos of Chile did not mention the dispute when they gave a news conference at the palace this evening, with Mr. Lagos hailing the ''modern and mature'' relationship between Chile and the United States. ''Most of the time we will be in agreement,'' he said. ''Sometimes we won't.''

keywords: TRANSPORTATION DEPARTMENT; FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION; TRANSPORTATION SECURITY ADMINISTRATION; ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY; FINES (PENALTIES); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC SUBSTANCES; AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL; TERRORISM
headline: Report Faults F.A.A. Action On Handling Risky Cargoes
snippet: A recent report criticizes the Federal Aviation Administration's actions in the campaign to keep hazardous materials off airplanes.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration's campaign to keep hazardous materials off airplanes, begun after an improper shipment caused a crash in the Florida Everglades that killed 110 people eight years ago, has generated thousands of enforcement cases and tens of millions of dollars in civil penalties. But the punishment is sometimes too little, too late, the inspector general of the Transportation Department said Friday in a report that called for major improvements.

keywords: JIANG ZEMIN; SANCHAWAN (CHINA); SHAANXI PROVINCE (CHINA); CHINA; YULIN (CHINA); AGRICULTURE; FARMERS; SURVEYS AND SERIES; REAL ESTATE; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; RURAL AREAS; URBAN AREAS; LAND USE POLICIES
headline: Farmers Being Moved Aside By China's Real Estate Boom
snippet: A two-tiered property system favors city dwellers while handicapping the farmers once at the core of Chinese society.
lead_paragraph: For five months, Gao Lading and other angry farmers had occupied the walled compound of the Communist Party's village office. They had pitched tents, eaten rice and sweet potatoes, and waited. It was a sit-in born of desperation. Officials from the nearby city of Yulin had seized land that had been part of the village since imperial times. The farmers had protested for nearly two years before finally seizing the village government's seat of power.

keywords: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; ZARDARI, ASIF ALI; BHUTTO, BENAZIR; PAKISTAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: A Leading Opponent Of Pakistani President Is Under Arrest Again
snippet: The husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was arrested Tuesday, barely a month after being released on bail.
lead_paragraph: Asif Ali Zardari, the husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, was arrested Tuesday, barely a month after being released on bail, government and opposition officials said. He was taken into custody after landing in Islamabad, where he had been scheduled to address a political rally. At the same time, hundreds of armed police officers set up barricades to prevent members of Ms. Bhutto's political party from going to the airport or attending the rally. After word of Mr. Zardari's arrest spread, supporters clashed with the police at the airport, smashing windows as the police fired tear gas and carried out baton charges.

keywords: LAVERY, PETER; CONNECTICUT; NEWINGTON (CONN); POLICE DEPARTMENT; ATTACKS ON POLICE; HOSTAGES; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; DOMESTIC VIOLENCE; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS; POLICE
headline: Officer Is Dead After Standoff In Connecticut
snippet: A standoff between law enforcement officials and a gunman who shot a local police officer ended Friday when the gunman killed himself, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An overnight standoff between dozens of law enforcement officials and a gunman who shot a local police officer and then took him hostage ended on Friday when the gunman cut off communication with negotiators and killed himself, the authorities said. The police finally stormed the house where the standoff took place, where they found the bodies of the gunman and the officer, who appeared to have died from his wounds, the police said.

keywords: YUSCHENKO, VIKTOR A; POPKOV, SERGEI; YUSHCHENKO, VIKTOR; KUCHMA, LEONID D; YANUKOVICH, VIKTOR F; SKIBINETSKY, OLEKSANDER; GALAKA, OLEKSANDER; SMESHKO, IHOR P; SKIPALSKY, OKEKSANDER; UKRAINE; KIEV (UKRAINE); ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; INTELLIGENCE SERVICES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: How Top Spies in Ukraine Changed the Nation's Path
snippet: As protests against a rigged election grew, Kiev seemed headed for a Soviet-style crackdown. Then, inside Ukraine's security apparatus, strange events began to unfold.
lead_paragraph: As protests here against a rigged presidential election overwhelmed the capital last fall, an alarm sounded at Interior Ministry bases outside the city. It was just after 10 p.m. on Nov. 28. More than 10,000 troops scrambled toward trucks. Most had helmets, shields and clubs. Three thousand carried guns. Many wore black masks. Within 45 minutes, according to their commander, Lt. Gen. Sergei Popkov, they had distributed ammunition and tear gas and were rushing out the gates.

keywords: CASTRO, FIDEL; GONZALEZ, ELIAN; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE; ILLEGAL ALIENS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; SUITS AND LITIGATION; CUBAN-AMERICANS
headline: 5 Years Later, a Miami Trial Over the Seizing of Elián
snippet: Neighbors who claim they were traumatized by the three-minute raid have filed lawsuits and are seeking up to $250,000 each in damages.
lead_paragraph: The moment 5:14 a.m. on April 22, 2000 -- remains as vivid to them as yesterday. Armanda Santos was fixing her daughter a drink in the predawn quiet of their kitchen. Carmen Valdes was praying the rosary. Leslie Alvarez was eating a slice of pizza, and Madeleine Peraza was holding vigil with friends in her living room. The calm -- and for years to come, they said, their well-being -- was shattered when federal agents with long guns descended on NW Second Street in Little Havana, swarming a small white house and snatching a boy named Elián González. Now, almost five years after the government seized Elián from his great-uncle's home and returned him to his father in Cuba, neighbors and others who witnessed the three-minute raid are getting their day in court.

keywords: GNASSINGBE, FAURE; EYADEMA, GNASSINGBE; MALI; TOGO; BENIN; NIGER; NIGERIA; GHANA; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: West African Leaders Spar With Togo's Army-Backed President
snippet: West African leaders summoned Togo's new president to talks in Niger, threatening immediate sanctions if he did not attend.
lead_paragraph: West African leaders on Friday summoned Togo's new president to talks in Niger on Saturday, threatening immediate sanctions if the Togolese leader did not attend. Faure Gnassingbé was installed as president by the army just hours after his father, Gnassingbé Eyadéma, died a week ago. West African leaders denounced his appointment, which violated the Constitution, as a military coup. The Constitution was hastily amended to allow Mr. Gnassingbé to succeed his father and to run the country until 2008.

keywords: BONUS ARMY, THE: AN AMERICAN EPIC (BOOK); ALLEN, THOMAS B; DICKSON, PAUL; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; VETERANS
headline: Home From the War, Yet the Battle Is Just Beginning
snippet: Paul Dickson and Thomas B. Allen's bleakly fascinating book tells the story of a veterans' crusade for compensation during World War I.
lead_paragraph: The Bonus Army' 'An American Epic' By Paul Dickson and Thomas B. Allen. Illustrated. 370 pages. Walker & Company. $27. Paul Dickson and Thomas B. Allen began their prodigious research project on the Bonus Army of 1930's America with a nagging question: ''How could this all be forgotten?'' Certainly the events the authors sought to describe were well known in their day. These were the repeated marches on Washington by aging World War I veterans who had been promised federal funds in recognition of their wartime sacrifice. These veterans came home as heroes only to discover, in the words of one historian, that ''the Keys to the City had turned out only to be a pass to the flophouse.'' In 1924, the returning soldiers had been promised government recompense for the time they had spent overseas. By the early 1930's, with the nation in the throes of the Great Depression, this issue took on added urgency. There were veterans who had given up their main sources of income in order to enlist. They came back jobless, unable to pay their taxes and in danger of losing their homes.

keywords: SUMMERS, LAWRENCE H; HARVARD UNIVERSITY; MEN; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; WOMEN; SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY; ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERS
headline: Ideas & Trends; The Battle Behind the Battle at Harvard
section: Technology; Science; Education; Week in Review
snippet: The crisis at Harvard was more than a matter of an impolitic president. At stake is the university's very identity: Is Harvard liberal or conservative?
lead_paragraph: WHEN Lawrence Summers, president of Harvard, theorized last month at a conference on ''Diversifying the Science and Engineering Work Force'' that men might have an innate advantage over women in scientific aptitude, he could scarcely have anticipated the protests that unfolded last week on the university's campus. While the Coalition for an Anti-Sexist Harvard rallied outside the science center, a hastily formed group with the laid-back name Students for Larry was milling about Lowell Lecture Hall. But the crisis wasn't just about Larry Summers. Gendergate -- to give the scandal its obligatory suffix -- was more than a matter of an impolitic president. At stake is the university's very identity: Is Harvard liberal or conservative?

keywords: ABBAS, BONFOH; TOGO; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Crowds Protest in Togo
snippet: Demonstrators said the march was prompted by anger at the selection of Bonfoh Abbas as interim president of Togo.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators protested Sunday against Togo's new president, lighting flaming barricades in the capital's streets and throwing rocks at riot police officers who fired tear gas to keep crowds from moving toward government buildings. Demonstrators said the unannounced march was prompted by anger at the selection on Friday of Bonfoh Abbas as interim president of Togo until nationwide elections can be held in the coming months. Mr. Abbas, the deputy speaker of Parliament, was named interim president in a special session of Congress after Faure Gnassingbé stepped down. He had been installed as president after the death of his father, Gnassingbé Eyadéma, who ruled as strongman for nearly four decades.

keywords: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; GANGS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
headline: Gang Fight and Fire in Overcrowded Prison In Dominican Republic Kill 133 Inmates
snippet: Rival gangs armed with guns and knives and battling for dominance in a prison set a fire that swept through a crowded cellblock.
lead_paragraph: Rival gangs armed with guns, knives and machetes and battling for dominance in a prison in the Dominican Republic set a fire early Monday that swept through a crowded cellblock, killing at least 133 inmates and injuring 26, the authorities said. The fight in the prison in Higüey, 90 miles east of Santo Domingo, began late Sunday night and was briefly quelled by guards firing tear gas. But it flared anew about 2:30 a.m. when several members of one of the gangs set pillows and bedding on fire in the cellblock, known as Vietnam.

keywords: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC; RED CROSS; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; GANGS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
headline: After Prison Horror, Dominican Republic Plans a Study
snippet: The Dominican government has appointed a commission to investigate a deadly fire that killed 136 prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Zacaria Martínez is not sure how he survived the fire that swept through his prison cell, packed almost to the roof with inmates, killing nearly everyone inside. The only explanation he has is that it was ''at the hands of God.'' Inside the overcrowded prison here early Monday, a battle broke out in a cell known as Vietnam, the authorities said. Shots were fired and punches flew. Mattresses, machetes and other objects sailed through the air before a burst of flame came, then torrents of black, choking smoke.

keywords: BERGER, OSCAR; SANTA CRUZ DEL QUICHE (GUATEMALA); GUATEMALA; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Protesters and Police Clash
snippet: Protesters clashed with riot police who fired tear gas in the highland town of Santa Cruz del Quiché, in the eighth day of protests around the country over a free-trade deal with the United States. President Óscar Berger signed the accord into law...
lead_paragraph: Protesters clashed with riot police who fired tear gas in the highland town of Santa Cruz del Quiché, in the eighth day of protests around the country over a free-trade deal with the United States. President Óscar Berger signed the accord into law on Tuesday, as a teacher was killed and several people seriously injured when hundreds of police officers and soldiers tried to disperse a protest in the Huehuetenango region, near Mexico. Witnesses said the security forces used live ammunition.

keywords: EISDORFER, SIMON; NEW YORK CITY; POLICE DEPARTMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Simon Eisdorfer Dies at 87; Began Police Hostage Team
snippet: Former New York City police chief Simon Eisdorfer first conceived of his negotiating team in 1972, after 11 Israeli athletes were taken hostage at the Olympic Games in Munich.
lead_paragraph: Simon Eisdorfer, a retired New York City police chief who developed the department's widely emulated hostage negotiation team, died on Wednesday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Cedarhurst, N.Y. The cause was heart failure, his granddaughter Jennifer Waitman said.

keywords: GUTIERREZ, LUCIO; ECUADOR; ANDEAN COMMUNITY; JUDGES; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ATTORNEYS GENERAL
headline: Ecuador's Chief Seeks Help in Court Dispute
snippet: President Lucio Gutiérrez asked for international help to end a dispute over the dismissal of the country's Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: President Lucio Gutiérrez asked Wednesday for international help to end a dispute over the dismissal of the country's Supreme Court. Congress dismissed the judges in December at the president's behest.

keywords: WOODROW, DAVID; SOLLAND, JAMES; DAYTON (OHIO); SCHENECTADY (NY); MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS
headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Fugitive In 1999 Murder Arrested In Ohio
snippet: A man wanted in a 1999 murder in Schenectady was captured in Dayton, Ohio, after the police and federal marshals forced him out of a house with tear gas, the authorities said. Marshals had received a tip that the suspect, David Woodrow, 31, was...
lead_paragraph: A man wanted in a 1999 murder in Schenectady was captured in Dayton, Ohio, after the police and federal marshals forced him out of a house with tear gas, the authorities said. Marshals had received a tip that the suspect, David Woodrow, 31, was living in the area, and that trail led to the house. Mr. Woodrow, who is accused of fatally shooting James Holland, barricaded himself in the house when the authorities arrived, but surrendered after resisting the tear gas for about half an hour. Deputy Marshal Craig Martin said Mr. Woodrow was being held without bond at the Montgomery County jail. He is scheduled for a court appearance today.

keywords: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER; STEROIDS; LABOR; SOCCER; TESTS AND TESTING; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC; ORGANIZED LABOR
headline: Contract Has Strict Drug Policy
snippet: M.L.S. has adopted the list of banned substances issued by the World Anti-Doping Agency.
lead_paragraph: Under the terms of the first collective-bargaining agreement between Major League Soccer and the union representing its players, Commissioner Don Garber has the authority to nullify a player's contract for testing positive for a performance-enhancing drug. In the context of the steroids controversy that has engulfed baseball and has affected other professional sports in North America and some Olympic sports, M.L.S. asserts that its policy, while strict, is not new and has only been codified in the new union contract. The policy includes random testing for illegal steroids and recreational drugs.

keywords: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA; MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY; NCAA BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT; BASKETBALL
headline: Michigan St. Fans Turn Rowdy
snippet: Police officers in riot gear dispersed rowdy Michigan State fans who poured into the streets after their team's loss in the men's Final Four on Saturday night, resulting in more than 60 arrests.    Most of the arrests were for disorderly conduct, the...
lead_paragraph: Police officers in riot gear dispersed rowdy Michigan State fans who poured into the streets after their team's loss in the men's Final Four on Saturday night, resulting in more than 60 arrests. Most of the arrests were for disorderly conduct, the police said Sunday.

keywords: LOME (TOGO); TOGO; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: In Togo, Youths Fight Police Over Vote Plan
snippet: Youths burned tires and hurled rocks at riot police officers in Togo's capital after security forces broke up a march that demanded that presidential elections be delayed.
lead_paragraph: Youths burned tires and hurled rocks at riot police officers in Togo's capital on Friday after security forces broke up a march that demanded that presidential elections scheduled for this month be delayed. There were unconfirmed reports of protests in other parts of Togo. A leading opposition party said one protester was shot dead and five injured in Yoto, northeast of here.

keywords: GUELLEH, ISMAIL OMAR; DJIBOUTI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Djibouti's Leader Wins Uncontested Vote
snippet: The incumbent, Ismail Omar Guelleh, won Djibouti's presidential election in an uncontested race.
lead_paragraph: The incumbent, Ismail Omar Guelleh, won Djibouti's presidential election in an uncontested race on Friday, election officials said, after hundreds of people protesting against the voting clashed with police. Officials said early results showed that 73 percent to 86 percent of the electorate had voted for Mr. Guelleh, with ballots from 149 of the more than 200 voting booths counted.

keywords: GUTIERREZ, LUCIO; QUITO (ECUADOR); ECUADOR; ATTACKS ON POLICE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Police And Protesters Clash In Capital
snippet: The police in the capital, Quito, clashed with protesters who blocked streets with burning tires after the government and Congress failed to reach a truce in a struggle for control of the country's courts. Yelling slogans against President Lucio...
lead_paragraph: The police in the capital, Quito, clashed with protesters who blocked streets with burning tires after the government and Congress failed to reach a truce in a struggle for control of the country's courts. Yelling slogans against President Lucio Gutíerrez, several thousand demonstrators brought parts of the city to a halt and paralyzed transport. Schools and municipal offices remained closed and commercial activity was disrupted. Riot police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters, and soldiers guarded the presidential palace.

keywords: GUTIERREZ, LUCIO; PALACIO, ALFREDO; QUITO (ECUADOR); BRAZIL; ECUADOR; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; ASYLUM (POLITICAL); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; FOREIGN SERVICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Ecuador's Leader Flees and Vice President Replaces Him
snippet: President Lucio Gutiérrez of Ecuador fled after the Congress, meeting in special session, voted to remove him.
lead_paragraph: President Lucio Gutiérrez of Ecuador fled his presidential palace on Wednesday after the Congress, meeting in special session, voted to remove him. The Congress then swore in Vice President Alfredo Palacio, a 66-year-old cardiologist, to replace Mr. Gutiérrez, 48, a former army colonel who had faced mounting street protests against what critics called an illegal overhaul of the Supreme Court. Mr. Gutiérrez, who took office in January 2003, became the third president since 1997 to be ousted from power in the small but oil-rich Andean country, which has close economic ties to the United States. In 1997, Abdalá Bucaram was declared mentally unfit to govern and fled into exile. In 2000, President Jamil Mahuad was ousted in a coup supported by Mr. Gutiérrez, then an army colonel.

keywords: TOGO; PRESIDENTS AND PRESIDENCY (US); ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Word of Togo Leader's Victory Ignites Clashes
snippet: After the announcement that the son of longtime leader Gnassingbé Eyadéma had won Sunday's presidential election, police and opposition supporters clashed.
lead_paragraph: Togo's electoral commission on Tuesday declared Faure Gnassingbé, the son of the longtime leader Gnassingbé Eyadéma, the winner in Sunday's presidential election. Within minutes of the announcement, police officers and opposition supporters were clashing on the streets, and the skies grew dark with smoke from burning barricades. Clashes continued throughout the day, with the police firing tear gas and bullets at protesters who threw rocks, cut down trees to block thoroughfares and stockpiled Molotov cocktails. At least four people were reported wounded by gunfire, and many homes and stores were looted. By the end of the day, the country's borders remained closed and all phone service had been cut off.

keywords: EYADEMA, GNASSINGBE; GNASSINGBE, FAURE; TOGO; ANEHO (TOGO); VIOLENCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Togo Troops Kill 9 After Attack on Police Station
snippet: After residents attacked and burned a police station, Togolese soldiers rampaged through the town on Tuesday and Wednesday, killing nine people and wounding 61.
lead_paragraph: After residents attacked and burned a police station here, Togolese soldiers rampaged through the town on Tuesday and Wednesday, killing nine people and wounding 61, a Red Cross official reported Thursday. The violence indicated that the government and armed forces are taking a hard line against the violent protests that followed a presidential election on Sunday in which Faure Gnassingbé, the son of the country's longtime dictator, Eyadéma Gnassingbé, was declared the winner, with 60 percent of the vote. The opposition contends that the election was unfair.

keywords: BOLTON, JOHN R; WASHINGTON (DC); UNITED NATIONS
headline: Never Shy, Bolton Brings a Zeal to the Table
snippet: John Bolton, the U.N. nominee, is a conservative among conservatives who has long embraced the role of contrarian.
lead_paragraph: In the tumultuous days before John R. Bolton graduated from Yale University in 1970, he and his roommates leaned mattresses against the windows to keep out stray tear gas shells. The trial of a top Black Panther in New Haven had ignited riots and set off a national uproar. The National Guard patrolled the campus in tanks. A bomb went off at the hockey rink.

keywords: PEARL, DANIEL; LIBBI, ABU FARAJ AL-; BUSH, GEORGE W; ZAWAHIRI, AYMAN AL-; MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; FAROOQ, AMJAD HUSSAIN; BIN LADEN, OSAMA; PAKISTAN; PESHAWAR (PAKISTAN); AL QAEDA; WALL STREET JOURNAL; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; TERRORISM
headline: Pakistan Reports Arrest of a Senior Qaeda Leader
snippet: President Bush called Abu Faraj al-Libbi's arrest a "critical victory in the war on terror," but counterterrorism experts were skeptical.
lead_paragraph: Pakistani authorities announced yesterday the arrest of a senior operative for Al Qaeda who is suspected of directing two failed assassination attempts against the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. Both Pakistani and American officials described the man, a Libyan named Abu Faraj al-Libbi, as the third most senior leader in Al Qaeda's terrorist network, and President Bush called the arrest a ''critical victory in the war on terror.'' But counterterrorism experts in Europe immediately raised questions about Mr. Libbi's importance.

keywords: KENNEDY, EDWARD M; DOYLE, JIM; UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN; PEACE CORPS
headline: Heart From the Heartland: Peace Corps Is Special Tradition at Wisconsin
snippet: For each of the last 10 years, the University of Wisconsin has supplied the most entrants to the Peace Corps of any college or university.
lead_paragraph: FOUR hundred miles deep into the North African desert, Jim Doyle gathered the bundle of aerograms and month-old magazines that were his link to a former world, the one he had left behind to join the Peace Corps. This particular day in November 1967, the mail carried news about his college campus and hometown, the University of Wisconsin in Madison. There had been a protest against the Vietnam War, specifically a blockade against recruiters for the company that made napalm, and it had ended with tear gas, billy clubs, arrests and demonstrators taunting cops with cries of ''Sieg heil!'' Even at such a distance, Mr. Doyle could not call himself entirely surprised. In his senior year, he had seen the university's radicals shout down Senator Edward M. Kennedy. This was the brother of the president who had created the Peace Corps, and who before that was the presidential candidate a 14-year-old Jim had met on a campaign stop in Madison. ''I understand you play shortstop,'' John F. Kennedy had said, having been well-briefed about the son of a prominent local politician.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Clashes Outside Congress
snippet: The police in La Paz lobbed tear gas to repel dynamite-throwing protesters and protect Congress as thousands of people converged on the capital demanding nationalization of the energy sector while cutting off airport access and paralyzing public...
lead_paragraph: The police in La Paz lobbed tear gas to repel dynamite-throwing protesters and protect Congress as thousands of people converged on the capital demanding nationalization of the energy sector while cutting off airport access and paralyzing public transportation. Despite a guarantee of safety from President Carlos Mesa, who has struggled to stay in office, just a quarter of the country's lawmakers ventured into the city's narrow colonial streets and past heavily guarded police barriers for first congressional session in weeks.

keywords: ETHIOPIA; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Ethiopian Students and Police Clash Over Disputed Election Results
snippet: The violence killed one person, injured seven and led to hundreds of arrests.
lead_paragraph: Student demonstrators clashed with the police on Monday over disputed Ethiopian election results, a police statement said. The violence killed one person, injured seven and led to hundreds of arrests. Students at Addis Ababa University campuses had defied a government ban against demonstrations, holding the first public protest against how legislative elections on May 15 were conducted. The police charged into crowds to grab protesters, beating some with riot sticks.

keywords: MESA, CARLOS; SILES, JOSE IGNACIO; LA PAZ (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; INDIANS, AMERICAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Bolivia's Capital Reels From Surging Protests
snippet: Thousands streamed into the Bolivian capital as Indian protests against the ruling elite gained force even after President Carlos Mesa offered his resignation.
lead_paragraph: Thousands streamed into the Bolivian capital, La Paz, on Tuesday as Indian protests against the ruling elite gained force even after President Carlos Mesa offered his resignation. The critical highway to the highlands, where the international airport is situated, remained cut off by roadblocks, and the city of one million people was hit by food shortages and a transport strike.

keywords: CALIFORNIA; ROADS AND TRAFFIC; KIDNAPPING
headline: National Briefing | West: California: Man Captured After Freeway Standoff
snippet: A man suspected of attempted kidnapping was captured after a freeway chase and standoff in Southern California that lasted six and a half hours. The man, whose identity was not immediately released, tried to kidnap a woman in the wealthy Lake...
lead_paragraph: A man suspected of attempted kidnapping was captured after a freeway chase and standoff in Southern California that lasted six and a half hours. The man, whose identity was not immediately released, tried to kidnap a woman in the wealthy Lake Sherwood area, the police said. The woman escaped, and the man drove off in a van, the police said. He was chased for three hours until crashing in Alhambra, the police said. The driver, who the police said was armed, remained in the van for three hours before Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies shoved a tear gas grenade into the van, shot and wounded the man and sent a dog to drag him out. Traffic on Interstate 10 was backed up for miles while a negotiator talked to the man.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-7    U.S. Trained Uzbek Forces Tied to Recent Crackdown  Uzbek law enforcement and security ministries implicated by witnesses in the deadly crackdown in the city of Andijon last month have for years received training and...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 U.S. Trained Uzbek Forces Tied to Recent Crackdown Uzbek law enforcement and security ministries implicated by witnesses in the deadly crackdown in the city of Andijon last month have for years received training and equipment from counterterrorism programs run by the United States, according to American officials and Congressional records. A1 Brazil Official Resigns Brazil's deepening corruption scandal has claimed its first prominent victim, with the man who is President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's chief of staff and closest adviser stepping down after allegations that he knew of and encouraged a multimillion-dollar scheme to buy votes in Congress. A3 North Korea Demands Respect North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, said that the nation was ready to resume negotiations over its nuclear arms program as early as next month, provided the United States treated the country with respect, according to the South Korean government. A5 House Votes Cut in U.N. Dues Defying the Bush administration, the House passed a bill that would cut by half the dues paid by the United States to the United Nations unless the international organization drastically overhauled its operations. A5 Kyrgyzstan Political Protesters Several hundred protesters stormed the main government building in Bishkek in support of a minor presidential candidate, but riot police officers using tear gas and batons retook the building hours later. A6 Iran to Hold Runoff Election For the first time since the Islamic revolution in 1979, Iran will have a runoff election to chose a president after voters failed to give any one of the seven candidates in the race the 50 percent of the vote needed to win, an Interior Ministry spokesman announced. A7 NATIONAL A8-10 Governor Asks for Inquiry Into Schiavo's Collapse Gov.
