keywords: EUROPE; VENEZUELA; INDIA; WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; EUROPEAN UNION; AGRICULTURE; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CROP CONTROLS AND SUBSIDIES; CUSTOMS (TARIFF); THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; TELEPHONES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS; BANKS AND BANKING
headline: Orthodoxies On Trade Worn Down In Marathon
snippet: What made the World Trade Organization's agreement possible was the weaving of a series of deals - all night, in marathon talks.
lead_paragraph: The low point of the World Trade Organization conference here came on Saturday evening, as ministers were despairing of progress, while outside, protesters' steel pipes rained down on the shields of police officers and tear gas grenades spewed choking clouds. But 30 hours later, Pascal Lamy, the W.T.O.'s director general, jubilantly handed John Tsang, the conference chairman, a ceremonial gavel. Mr. Tsang tapped the gavel once, closing the conference and approving the Hong Kong Declaration, calling for changes in trade barriers including subsidies for European farm exports and industrial nations' tariffs on imports from countries like Bangladesh and Zambia.

keywords: MUBARAK, HOSNI; EGYPT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
headline: Testing Egypt, Mubarak Rival Is Sent to Jail
snippet: The case is seen as a political prosecution aimed at silencing a challenge to President Hosni Mubarak's monopoly on power.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian court sentenced Ayman Nour, a leading opposition figure, to five years at hard labor on Saturday after convicting him in a forgery case widely seen as a political prosecution aimed at silencing a challenge to President Hosni Mubarak's monopoly on power. With diplomats from the United States, France, Norway and the European Union seated in a courtroom otherwise packed with uniformed police and state security men, a judge read out the verdict and sentence in a nearly inaudible whisper. Mr. Nour, 41, locked in a foul-smelling, filthy cage in the courtroom, began to chant, ''Down with Mubarak.''

keywords: IRELAND; LABOR
headline: Ferry Dispute Tests Ireland's Tolerance for Globalization
snippet: The thousands who took to the streets of Ireland to protest the hiring of cheap East European labor for Irish Ferries gave voice to old familiar fears about job security.
lead_paragraph: When nearly 100,000 people took to the streets of Ireland earlier this month to protest the hiring of cheap East European labor for Irish Ferries, they gave voice to old familiar fears about job security that many thought had been forgotten. The last time similar crowds demonstrated here over industrial issues was in 1979, when young people were leaving the country in droves to find work and Ireland's unemployment rate was hovering around 20 percent.

keywords: MUBARAK, HOSNI; EGYPT
headline: Hosni Mubarak's Democracy
snippet: The sentencing of a prominent liberal opposition leader in Egypt shows that President Hosni Mubarak doesn't have the stomach for competitive elections.
lead_paragraph: So much for holding Egypt up as a beacon of burgeoning democracy in the Middle East. Last Saturday an Egyptian court, in a move worthy of Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe, sentenced Ayman Nour, the prominent liberal opposition leader, to five years at hard labor for supposedly forging signatures on petitions used to create his political party. Calling this a kangaroo court case would be an understatement. President Hosni Mubarak's security troops packed the courtroom in a show of force before Mr. Nour was brought in and locked in a foul-smelling, filthy cage to hear his fate. The charges on which the panel has convicted him are ridiculous: why would Mr. Nour forge the signatures of his own wife and father on his nomination form? Mr. Nour's second-place showing in the presidential election, collecting 7 percent of the vote, gives lie to any claim that he couldn't muster up the 50 signatures needed on the nomination papers.

keywords: SHARON, ARIEL; ROBERTSON, PAT; ISRAEL
headline: Israelis' Anger at Evangelist May Delay Christian Center
snippet: Israel broke off talks on a tourism project after Pat Robertson suggested Ariel Sharon's stroke was divine retribution.
lead_paragraph: Israel said Wednesday that it was breaking off negotiations on a tourism project with the evangelical leader Pat Robertson in response to his remarks suggesting that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's stroke was divine retribution. ''We cannot accept these statements, and we will not sign any contracts with Mr. Robertson,'' said Ido Hartuv, a spokesman for the Tourism Ministry.

keywords: AT CANAAN'S EDGE: AMERICA IN THE KING YEARS 1965-68 (BOOK); AT CANAAN'S EDGE: AMERICA IN THE KING YEARS, 1965-68 (BOOK); BRANCH, TAYLOR; KING, MARTIN LUTHER JR; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CIVIL RIGHTS; HISTORY
headline: King, Weary After Scaling His Great Mountain
snippet: The final volume of Taylor Branch's monumental life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. chronicles the fragmentation of the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: At Canaan's Edge America in the King Years 1965-68 By Taylor Branch 1,039 pages. Simon & Schuster. $35. Four decades ago, on March 7, 1965, Alabama state troopers and sheriff's deputies brutally attacked a group of civil rights demonstrators who were attempting to cross the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., setting upon them with clubs, bullwhips, cattle prods and tear gas. The violent clash, broadcast nationally on television, rocked the country, setting in motion a series of events that would change the political and social landscape of America and send out cultural shock waves that reverberate to this day.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Second Day Of Protests
snippet: Violent protests continued in Abidjan for a second day as a dispute over Parliament's mandate threatened the transitional government seeking to reunite the country, divided since civil war broke out in 2002. Protesters loyal to the president, Laurent...
lead_paragraph: Violent protests continued in Abidjan for a second day as a dispute over Parliament's mandate threatened the transitional government seeking to reunite the country, divided since civil war broke out in 2002. Protesters loyal to the president, Laurent Gbagbo, battered at the gates of the United Nations headquarters in Abidjan, throwing gasoline-filled bottles at the building, and United Nations peacekeepers fired bullets in the air and used tear gas. Mediators said Sunday that Parliament should be dissolved. Last October, elections to replace the Parliament and president were postponed under a peace agreement. LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

keywords: INDIA; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Fatal Clash at Mill Site Shows Perils of India's Rise
snippet: A challenge for India: Balancing industrial growth against citizens' demands.
lead_paragraph: On the first Monday morning of the year, four bulldozers, accompanied by nearly 300 police officers, arrived on a rocky patch of farmland on the edge of a wooded village and began leveling the earth. It was meant to be the first step in the construction of India's third-largest steel mill. Soon, from the bowels of the wooded village came an army of resistance. Armed with scythes and swords, stones and sticks -- and according to the police, bows and arrows -- the indigenous people who live on these lands in eastern India advanced toward the police line by the hundreds. Exactly what happened next is a matter of contention, except that by the day's end, the land was littered with the gore of more than a dozen dead and a fury that lingers.

keywords: IVORY COAST; VIOLENCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Ivorian Leader Urges Youths to End Anti-U.N. Protests
snippet: Youth leaders urged their supporters to abandon protests after thousands of young people defied a request from the president.
lead_paragraph: Youth leaders urged their supporters on Thursday to abandon their deadly protests after thousands of young people defied a request from the president of Ivory Coast to end days of rioting and violence. Militant youths once again took to the streets of Abidjan, tossing gasoline bombs at the United Nations headquarters and battering its walls with sledgehammers in an attempt to force the peacekeepers to leave the country they seek to reunite.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Police Break Up Democracy Rally
snippet: The police used batons, tear gas and water cannons to disperse pro-democracy demonstrators in Katmandu, the capital. It was the fourth consecutive day of street clashes in the city.   SOMINI SENGUPTA (NYT)
lead_paragraph: The police used batons, tear gas and water cannons to disperse pro-democracy demonstrators in Katmandu, the capital. It was the fourth consecutive day of street clashes in the city. SOMINI SENGUPTA (NYT)

keywords: LEBANON; DENMARK; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Beirut Mob Burns Danish Mission Building Over Cartoons
snippet: Protesters angry over Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad clashed with Lebanese security forces, attacking a church.
lead_paragraph: Protesters angry over Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad clashed with Lebanese security forces on Sunday, setting a building housing the Danish Mission on fire and attacking a nearby church. The sectarian tone of the violence in the predominantly Christian Achrafieh section of East Beirut on Sunday raised fears of deepening divisions in Lebanon a year after a former prime minister, Rafik Hariri, was assassinated, setting off political crises in Syria and Lebanon.

keywords: AFGHANISTAN; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Muslim Protests Against Cartoons Spread
snippet: At least five protesters died in Afghanistan during Muslim protests over Danish cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: Muslim anger over Danish cartoons that satirized the Prophet Muhammad continued to swell across the Middle East and elsewhere in the world on Monday, turning violent in Afghanistan, where at least five protesters died and more than a dozen police officers and protesters were wounded. As the unrest gained momentum, European diplomats worked the telephones and fanned out across the Muslim world, urging their counterparts to issue statements that might help calm the unrest that had destroyed the Danish Consulate in Lebanon and the Danish and Norwegian Embassies in Syria on Saturday.

keywords: EGYPT; FERRIES
headline: Ferry Victims' Kin Storm Owner's Offices
snippet: Relatives of passengers aboard an Egyptian ferry that sank in the Red Sea looted the office of the ship's owners and demanded more information.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated relatives of passengers aboard an Egyptian ferry that sank Friday in the Red Sea stormed into the office of the ship's owners here early Monday, looting it and demanding that the company and the government provide information about those lost. By Monday evening, only 388 survivors and 245 bodies had been found, officials said. That left the fate of almost 800 people unknown. Officials have sporadically released lists of survivors and photographs of the dead. But those in the crowd contended that the company was ignoring requests for more information.

keywords: MUHAMMAD; GREAT BRITAIN; EUROPE; MAIMANA (AFGHANISTAN); AFGHANISTAN; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED NATIONS; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; VIOLENCE; FREEDOM OF THE PRESS; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: 3 Afghan Demonstrators Die in Clash With NATO Troops
snippet: It was the first time NATO troops in Afghanistan, there under a U. N. mandate to establish security, had been attacked at their base by an angry crowd.
lead_paragraph: NATO troops fired on demonstrators in northern Afghanistan on Tuesday in a second day of deadly protests here against the publication of satirical cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in European newspapers. Also on Tuesday, a suicide bomber killed 13 people outside police headquarters in Kandahar, where civilians and police officers had gathered to get passports.

keywords: MOUSSAOUI, ZACARIAS; LONDON (ENG); ISLAM; TERRORISM; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
headline: CLERIC CONVICTED OF STIRRING HATE
snippet: Abu Hamza al-Masri was sentenced to 7 years for using his sermons to encourage his followers to murder non-Muslims.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Tuesday convicted Britain's most prominent radical Muslim cleric of 11 charges of soliciting murder and racial hatred for using his sermons to encourage his followers to kill non-Muslims. The cleric, Abu Hamza al-Masri, 47, is the best-known Islamic leader to face charges in a courtroom since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. He was the imam of the Finsbury Park mosque in North London, which became a magnet for militants, including Richard Reid, the so-called shoe bomber, and Zacarias Moussaoui, now on trial in the United States in connection with the attacks.

keywords: HAITI; UNITED NATIONS; VIOLENCE; ELECTIONS
headline: Haitians Flock to Vote, on a Day of Anger and Hope
snippet: At least four died on a chaotic presidential election day as determined voters stormed the polls, some waiting late into the night to vote.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of planning, the long-awaited presidential elections began here on Tuesday with signs of the same tensions and disorder that have kept this poor, troubled nation at the brink of chaos for the last two years. At least four people died in a day of anger and confusion, as many polling stations opened hours late. Two people died after collapsing from exhaustion in the shoving to cast ballots, while a man in the northwestern town of Gros Morne was shot to death by a police officer. Later, the same officer was killed by a vengeful crowd that hacked him to death with machetes and burned his body, a Haitian radio station reported.

keywords: LOS ANGELES COUNTY (CALIF); LOS ANGELES (CALIF); VIOLENCE; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; BLACKS; RACE; GANGS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; CRIME AND CRIMINALS; HISPANIC-AMERICANS
headline: More Injuries As Race Riots Disrupt Jails In Los Angeles
snippet: Blacks and Latinos have taken their conflicts from the streets behind bars, officials said, causing one death in five days of violence.
lead_paragraph: Five days of racial rioting have left one inmate dead and dozens injured at Los Angeles County jails as blacks and Latinos have taken their conflicts from the streets behind bars, the authorities said. The latest occurred on Thursday when 200 inmates at the Pitchess Detention Center, a collection of jails in the northern fringes of the county where most of the violence has occurred, clashed briefly until deputies used tear gas to bring them under control. There were no reported injuries.

keywords: MUHAMMAD; ROSE, FLEMMING; DENMARK; JYLLANDS-POSTEN; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; VIOLENCE; FREEDOM OF THE PRESS; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; BOYCOTTS; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Danish Cartoon Editor on Indefinite Leave
snippet: Flemming Rose defended publishing the caricatures and refused to apologize, but said he was unprepared for the reaction that followed and needed a break.
lead_paragraph: Flemming Rose, the Danish editor whose decision to publish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad helped provoke weeks of fury in the Muslim world, said in an interview on Friday that he was leaving his newspaper on indefinite vacation. Mr. Rose, 47, stood by the decision of the newspaper, Jyllands-Posten, to publish the caricatures, citing freedom of the press. And he refused to apologize for the drawings, which were seen by many Muslims as sacrilegious and have prompted widespread protests, boycotts of Danish goods and the burning of Danish diplomatic missions in the Middle East.

keywords: WAR OF NERVES: CHEMICAL WARFARE FROM WORLD WAR I TO AL-QAEDA (BOOK); WAR OF NERVES (BOOK); TUCKER, JONATHAN B; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Chemical Wars
snippet: Jonathan B. Tucker's book is a history of the race between the advance of a taboo technology and the political efforts to abolish it.
lead_paragraph: WAR OF NERVES Chemical Warfare from World War I to Al-Qaeda. By Jonathan B. Tucker. Illustrated. 479 pp. Pantheon Books. $30.

keywords: MUNCH, EDVARD; NORWAY; ROBBERIES AND THEFTS; ART
headline: The Case Of the Missing Munchs
snippet: Six men are about to stand trial for one of art's most shocking thefts. So where is "The Scream"?
lead_paragraph: THE thieves struck on the morning of Aug. 22, 2004, not long after the Munch Museum had opened. Many of the 80 or so visitors there were clustered in the ground-floor gallery, where the collection's most precious paintings were on display. The late-summer Sunday doziness was broken by the sudden shouting presence of two men in balaclavas who burst in through the main entrance. They came so unexpectedly, so brazenly, that at first it was hard to know what was happening. Using a gun to force the museum guards to the ground -- neither security guards nor police officers are routinely armed in Norway -- the intruders wrenched two paintings from the main gallery wall. They treated them with so little care, banging one repeatedly against the ground to dislodge it from its frame, that witnesses spoke afterward of their shock at the brutality of the assault as much as of the theft itself.

keywords: DENMARK; PAKISTAN; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; VIOLENCE; ISLAM; VANDALISM
headline: 2 Die as Pakistan Cartoon Rage Turns Violent
snippet: Violence flared in two cities Tuesday as demonstrators rampaged through Islamabad, the capital, and Lahore in the east.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and dozens injured on Tuesday in the nation's worst day of protests against the cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad, officials said. Violence flared in two cities as demonstrators rampaged through Islamabad, the capital, and Lahore in the east, vandalizing property, burning government buildings and attacking Western businesses. In Lahore, guards at a bank shot dead two people and the police struggled to control thousands of demonstrators.

keywords: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; PAKISTAN; AFGHANISTAN; TALIBAN; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Pakistan's Violent Protests Over Cartoons Taking Political Turn
snippet: Groups opposed to the Pakistani president are working to direct anger at Muhammad cartoons into denunciation of Pakistan's alliance with the West.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of protesters, incensed at cartoons satirizing the Prophet Muhammad, took to the streets in Pakistani cities for a third straight day on Wednesday, clashing with the police and setting Western businesses on fire, news media reports and officials said. Three people died in the day's violence, bringing the week's total to five.

keywords: BESIGYE, KIZZA; MUSEVENI, YOWERI; UGANDA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: President of Uganda Wins a Third Term
snippet: The results were immediately challenged by his main opponent, and fighting broke out between supporters of the two camps.
lead_paragraph: Yoweri Museveni extended his 20-year tenure as president of Uganda on Saturday in the country's first multiparty elections in a quarter century. The results were immediately challenged by his main opponent, and clashes broke out between supporters of the two camps on the streets of the capital. Mr. Museveni, the clear front-runner all along, won by a wide margin with 59 percent of the vote, compared with 37 percent for his main challenger, Kizza Besigye, according to final results released Saturday afternoon by the Electoral Commission.

headline: Bangladesh Holds Militant
snippet: Bangladesh security forces captured the country's top Islamic militant leader on Thursday, a senior security official said.     Sheik Abdur Rahman, whose movement was blamed for a wave of deadly bomb attacks across the country since August, gave...
lead_paragraph: Bangladesh security forces captured the country's top Islamic militant leader on Thursday, a senior security official said. Sheik Abdur Rahman, whose movement was blamed for a wave of deadly bomb attacks across the country since August, gave himself up in the northeastern city of Sylhet, said Lt. Col. Nurul Momen of the elite force Rapid Action Battalion. Security forces fired tear gas shells and pumped water into a building in Sylhet where Mr. Rahman, the supreme leader of the outlawed Jamaat-ul-Mujahedeen, was located. They had it surrounded since Tuesday night.

keywords: WAR OF NERVES (BOOK); TUCKER, JOHN B; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
headline: Correction
snippet: A review on Feb. 12 about ''War of Nerves: Chemical Warfare From World War I to Al-Qaeda,'' by Jonathan B. Tucker, referred imprecisely to the United States' use of tear gas and the defoliant Agent Orange in the Vietnam War. Unlike most of the other...
lead_paragraph: A review on Feb. 12 about ''War of Nerves: Chemical Warfare From World War I to Al-Qaeda,'' by Jonathan B. Tucker, referred imprecisely to the United States' use of tear gas and the defoliant Agent Orange in the Vietnam War. Unlike most of the other substances discussed in the review, neither was designed to cause direct casualties. However, the use of tear gas to flush enemy soldiers from hiding and Agent Orange to destroy overhead cover provoked debate about whether they should be counted as true chemical weapons under international law.

keywords: TRANSAMERICA (MOVIE); CAPOTE (MOVIE); BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN (MOVIE); HOFFMAN, PHILIP SEYMOUR; HUFFMAN, FELICITY; LEE, ANG; MOTION PICTURES; INDEPENDENT SPIRIT AWARDS; AWARDS, DECORATIONS AND HONORS
headline: Arts, Briefly
snippet: 'Twas the Night Before the Oscars       One sure way to get attention for your alternative-to-the-Oscars awards: schedule them a day ahead of the big show. At the Independent Spirit Awards in Los Angeles on Saturday afternoon, the big winner was...
lead_paragraph: Twas the Night Before the Oscars One sure way to get attention for your alternative-to-the-Oscars awards: schedule them a day ahead of the big show. At the Independent Spirit Awards in Los Angeles on Saturday afternoon, the big winner was ''Brokeback Mountain,'' which took best feature and best director (Ang Lee). ''Capote'' won best actor (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and best screenplay (Dan Futterman), and ''Transamerica'' won best actress (Felicity Huffman, right) and first screenplay (Duncan Tucker). The prizes are given by Film Independent, a nonprofit group that nurtures indie filmmakers. At the less reverent Razzies, the annual salute to the worst of Hollywood, Tom Cruise and his fiancée, Katie Holmes -- combined, they are the entity known in gossip columns simply as TomKat -- were named the ''most tiresome tabloid targets,'' a new prize meant to recognize the most overexposed celebrities. But the biggest winner at the awards, bestowed by the Golden Raspberry Award Foundation, was ''Dirty Love,'' written by and starring the former Playboy Playmate Jenny McCarthy. It won four prizes, including worst picture, worst actress and screenplay (both for Ms. McCarthy), and worst director (John Mallory Asher). Grandma-in-Drag Tops Box Office In a slow weekend at the box office, Tyler Perry's comedy ''Madea's Family Reunion'' (Lions Gate) held off new films starring Bruce Willis and Milla Jovovich to remain No. 1 for a second week. ''Madea,'' in which Mr. Perry, left, dresses up in dowdy drag as a Southern grandma working to organize a family gathering, took in an estimated $13 million. That was a drop of some 57 percent from its ticket sales last week, but still enough to top ''16 Blocks'' (Warner Brothers), a thriller starring Mr. Willis and Mos Def, which landed at No. 2 with $11.6 million. Two other new films had slow openings: ''Ultraviolet'' (Sony/Screen Gems), a sci-fi action picture starring Ms. Jovovich, took in $9 million, reaching No. 4, and ''Aquamarine'' (Fox), about a mermaid who appears at a seaside swimming pool, was No. 5 with $7.5 million. ''Eight Below'' (Buena Vista), about the survival of a pack of abandoned ice-sled dogs in the Antarctic, dropped one spot to No. 3 with $10.2 million in its third week of release, bring its total ticket sales to $58.7 million. Overall, the box office was down 16.5 percent from the weekend before, and 23.2 percent from the same weekend last year. Welcome Back, Edna Divine. Harvey Fierstein. Now John Travolta? The onetime ''Saturday Night Fever'' heartthrob, below, now 52, will play the role of Edna Turnblad in the film version of ''Hairspray,'' the hit Broadway musical based on John Waters's 1988 movie. Divine played the character, the mother of an aspiring teenage dancer, in the original film, and Mr. Fierstein won a Tony Award for the role in the Broadway version. Queen Latifah, 35, the rapper, singer and actress, is to play Motormouth Maybelle in the film, which is being made by New Line. Production is to begin this fall for a potential summer 2007 release, Reuters reported. Book Critics' Awards E. L. Doctorow's fictionalized tale of Sherman's march, an autobiography by Francine du Plessix Gray and a history of Chernobyl are among the winners of this year's National Book Critics Circle Awards. For fiction, Mr. Doctorow's ''March'' (Random House) beat books by William T. Vollmann, Mary Gaitskill, Andrea Levy and Kazuo Ishiguro. Svetlana Alexievich took the nonfiction prize for ''Voices From Chernobyl: The Oral History of a Nuclear Disaster'' (Dalkey Archive Press). In autobiography, a new category, Ms. Gray's ''Them: A Memoir of Parents'' (Penguin Press) won over books by Joan Didion, Judith Moore, Orhan Pamuk and Vikram Seth. In biography, Kai Bird and Martin J. Sherwin won for ''American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer'' (Knopf). William Logan took the criticism award for ''The Undiscovered Country: Poetry in the Age of Tin'' (Columbia University Press), and Jack Gilbert's ''Refusing Heaven'' (Knopf) won for poetry. Riot at Punk Concert Rioting broke out at a concert east of Los Angeles on Saturday night, injuring several people and destroying two police cars, The Associated Press reported. Two dozen mostly British punk bands, including GBH and the Adicts, were playing at ''British Invasion 2K6'' at the National Orange Show Events Center in San Bernardino. The rioting began when the police responded to a report of a stabbing. The crowd of 1,500 became agitated and several fights broke out, the police said. The officers extracted the stabbing victim and another person who had been beaten, but the violent crowd forced the police to withdraw. After calling for backup, officers lined up in phalanx formation to clear the area, firing pepper balls and tear gas to move the crowd. As the audience dispersed, rioters destroyed two police cars, set a trash bin on fire and smashed storefront windows, the police said. Footnotes The Folies-Bergère in Paris will be transformed into Berlin's Kit Kat Club when the Sam Mendes staging of the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical ''Cabaret'' opens there on Oct. 14. Beginning on June 20, main stage productions at this year's Berkshire Theater Festival will include Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus,'' Tina Howe's ''Coastal Disturbances,'' Tennessee Williams's ''Night of the Iguana'' and Wendy Wasserstein's ''Heidi Chronicles.''

keywords: News
headline: Protests in Manama
snippet: Traffic was thick last night on the way back to the hotel from the circuit after police blocked roads around Manama. Before the race weekend, news reports said there might be protests from a local group trying to use the massive media coverage of the...
lead_paragraph: Traffic was thick last night on the way back to the hotel from the circuit after police blocked roads around Manama. Before the race weekend, news reports said there might be protests from a local group trying to use the massive media coverage of the race to draw attention to their plight. The protest not only happened, it turned violent.

keywords: PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; SORBONNE; UNIVERSITY OF PARIS; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; LABOR; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Police in Paris Storm Sorbonne To Halt Protest
snippet: Riot police officers fired tear gas into the historic building early Saturday to disperse students who had occupied part of the building since Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: French riot police officers fired tear gas into the historic Sorbonne building at the University of Paris early Saturday to disperse students who had occupied part of the 19th-century stone edifice since Wednesday. The students were part of nationwide protests against new employment regulations that will allow employers to hire and fire young workers more easily. Hundreds of thousands of people have joined demonstrations to protest new rules for a ''first employment contract,'' which gives companies the right to hire people under the age of 26 for a two-year trial period, during which they can be fired without cause.

keywords: FRANCE; UNEMPLOYMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: French Students Step Up Protests Against New Job Law
snippet: Tens of thousands of students marched in opposition to a law that makes it easier to hire  and fire  young workers.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of students marched through Paris and other French cities on Tuesday, stepping up their opposition to a new law that makes it easier to hire -- and fire -- young workers. In Paris, university and high school students, joined by teachers, workers, union members and Communist Party members, marched across town, stopping traffic as they chanted slogans like ''We're not cannon fodder'' and ''We're not young flesh for the boss.'' At one location near the Sorbonne in the heart of the Latin Quarter, the police clashed with small groups of protesters, dispersing them with tear gas.

keywords: CHIRAC, JACQUES; FRANCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Not '68, but French Youths Hear Similar Cry to Rise Up
snippet: Once again, there is high anxiety in France. Not revolution. Not 1968 revisited. But a great deal of political drama.
lead_paragraph: Once again, students are on the barricades in France, evoking comparisons to the uprising of May 1968. But this is not a revolt. It is not 1968 revisited. Certainly, students are taking to the streets and shutting down universities, and tear gas penetrated the heart of Paris.

keywords: PAPUA PROVINCE (INDONESIA); JAYAPURA (INDONESIA); INDONESIA; FREEPORT-MCMORAN COPPER AND GOLD INC; COPPER, BRASS AND BRONZE; GOLD; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Top Indonesian Generals Take Control of Restive City
snippet: Nearly 60 people, many of them students, have been arrested after a violent demonstrationthat left three policemen and an air force officer dead.
lead_paragraph: Indonesia's top military and police generals took control of the provincial capital of Jayapura in Papua on Friday, ordering the arrest of university students and directing the riot police to fire into the air as they patrolled the streets. Nearly 60 people, many of them students, have been arrested after a violent demonstration on Thursday that left three policemen and an air force officer dead, said a police spokesman, Gen. Anton Bachrul.

keywords: DE VILLEPIN, DOMINIQUE; FRANCE; LABOR; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; LAW AND LEGISLATION; UNEMPLOYMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LAYOFFS AND JOB REDUCTIONS
headline: French Protests Over Youth Labor Law Spread to 150 Cities and Towns
snippet: The protesters want the abolition of a new law that allows employees under the age of 26 to be fired without cause until they have held their job for two years.
lead_paragraph: Students joined forces with teachers, workers, retirees, opposition politicians and labor union leaders in more than 150 cities and towns throughout France on Saturday in the largest nationwide protest against the government's new youth labor law. A number of public figures joined in, including the mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delanoe; the Socialist party leader, François Hollande; a former culture minister, Jack Lang; and the Communist Party leader, Marie-George Buffet.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Government Clamps Down On Protests
snippet: President Alfredo Palacio declared a state of emergency late Tuesday, the ninth day of protests by thousands of Indians against free trade talks with the United States that have closed off highways and led to millions of dollars in lost commerce....
lead_paragraph: President Alfredo Palacio declared a state of emergency late Tuesday, the ninth day of protests by thousands of Indians against free trade talks with the United States that have closed off highways and led to millions of dollars in lost commerce. Troops deployed to rural highland communities outside of Quito, the capital, cleared tree trunks and burning tires, while firing tear gas at demonstrators. Protest leaders vowed to press on, while Mr. Palacio vowed to continue the trade talks. A final round of negotiations with the Americans is set for today. JUAN FORERO (NYT)

keywords: CHIRAC, JACQUES; LABOR; SUBURBS; UNEMPLOYMENT
headline: France's Misguided Protesters
snippet: French students should stop focusing on their privileges and heed President Jacques Chirac's call for creative dialogue.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in four months, French streets are filled with riot police, tear gas and rampaging youths. But the similarity is deceptive. Back in November, it was the sons of North African immigrants in their dreary suburbs exploding in frustration at the lack of jobs, prospects or programs. It was hard not to feel sympathy with their cause, along with outrage at their response. This time, privileged university students have been protesting what they see as an assault on the job security that they consider their birthright. But the labor reform to which they are so opposed is much needed and was proposed by Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin as a partial answer to those who rioted in the suburbs.

keywords: FRANCE; LABOR; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: French Youth at Barricades, but It's No Revolution
snippet: Protests against a new labor law use the revolutionary methods of the streets in defense of the status quo.
lead_paragraph: Adrien Reynaud is a revolutionary, but only part time. A 20-year-old history major at the University of Avignon, in the south of France, he had been waging a round-the-clock protest against the new youth labor law, camping out with fellow protesters in two dozen tents pitched across the campus lawn.

keywords: VILLEPIN, DOMINIQUE DE; PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; LABOR; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; HIRING AND PROMOTION; STRIKES; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ORGANIZED LABOR
headline: Protests in France Over Youth Labor Law Turn Violent
snippet: The strikes were the latest act in a political and social drama aimed at forcing the government to rescind the new law.
lead_paragraph: France was racked by strikes and demonstrations that turned violent on Tuesday, the latest act in a nationwide political and social drama aimed at forcing the government to rescind a new youth labor law. A 36-hour strike, which began Monday night, set the stage for demonstrations in more than 250 towns and cities across the country that brought more than a million people into the streets, according to the police. Some of the labor unions put the figure much higher -- at close to three million.

keywords: INSIDE THE WALLS OF ALCATRAZ (BOOK); HEANEY, FRANK; SAN FRANCISCO BAY; SAN FRANCISCO (CALIF); ALCATRAZ (SAN FRANCISCO); DISCOVERY CHANNEL; NATIONAL PARK SERVICE; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; HISTORIC BUILDINGS AND SITES; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; GUARDS; MUSEUMS; TRAVEL AND VACATIONS
headline: Flocking To See Alcatraz
snippet: Frank Heaney, who worked as the youngest correctional officer in the history of Alcatraz, is one of the few people still living who can differentiate reality from myth.
lead_paragraph: THIS much Frank Heaney knows is true: the gangster George (Machine Gun) Kelly was easy to get along with and did not try to con the guards like other inmates on Alcatraz. Bonnie and Clyde's driver, Floyd Hamilton, was nice enough. Robert (the Birdman) Stroud was psychotic, but he never kept birds here and did not look anything like Burt Lancaster, who played him in ''Birdman of Alcatraz.'' Mr. Heaney ought to know. From 1948 to 1951, between serving in World War II and the Korean War, he worked as the youngest correctional officer in the history of Alcatraz, the former federal prison that was infamous as the end of the line for the nation's most incorrigible and violent criminals.

keywords: FRANCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Violent Youths Threaten to Hijack Demonstrations in Paris
snippet: Scenes of mayhem at protests over a new jobs law give the impression of a Paris under siege.
lead_paragraph: The images are unnerving: hooded, swift-footed youths infiltrating protest rallies in the heart of tourist Paris, smashing shop windows, setting cars on fire, beating and robbing passers-by and throwing all sorts of objects at the riot police. They are called the casseurs -- the smashers. With more huge marches planned for next week as part of a continuing protest over a new jobs law, the casseurs are the volatile chemical that could ignite an even bigger crisis for the government than the impasse over the law itself.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Turkey: 3 Dead As The Police Battle Kurdish Protesters
snippet: Three people died, hundreds of others were injured and more than 200 were arrested in two days of clashes between the police and Kurdish protestors in Diyarbakir, in the mainly Kurdish southeast, officials said. The fighting began after funerals for...
lead_paragraph: Three people died, hundreds of others were injured and more than 200 were arrested in two days of clashes between the police and Kurdish protestors in Diyarbakir, in the mainly Kurdish southeast, officials said. The fighting began after funerals for four Kurdish rebels killed by Turkish troops last week. Television news reports showed groups of mostly young people hurling stones and Molotov cocktails at armored police vehicles, as the police used tear gas to disperse the crowds. At least 130 police officers were injured, and the local headquarters of the country's governing Justice and Development Party was ransacked, the Anatolian News Agency reported. SEBNEM ARSU (NYT)

keywords: CHIRAC, JACQUES; PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; LABOR; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ORGANIZED LABOR
headline: Chirac Offers Labor Law Compromise; Protesters Reject It
snippet: The French president's offer to soften a new labor law was swiftly rejected, with thousands joining in spontaneous protest.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to defuse a growing revolt that has paralyzed his government, President Jacques Chirac offered a compromise on Friday, saying in a nationwide address that he would soften a divisive new labor law and calling on student and trade union leaders to begin constructive talks. His offer was swiftly rejected, and after the speech several thousand young people spilled into the streets in a spontaneous march that wound its way through central Paris. The protesters, who first tried to approach Élysée Palace, eventually made their way to the Sorbonne, in the Latin Quarter, where they were dispersed by police officers firing tear gas.

keywords: CHIRAC, JACQUES; DE VILLEPIN, DOMINIQUE GALOUZEAU; FRANCE; VIOLENCE; LABOR; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; UNEMPLOYMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: French Premier Refuses to Bow To Protests by Angry Youths
snippet: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, weakened but defiant, refused to bend to the demand that the government scrap a disputed youth labor law.
lead_paragraph: Waves of demonstrations, strikes and violence hit France again on Tuesday as Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, weakened but defiant, refused to bend to the demand that the government scrap a disputed youth labor law. It was the fifth nationwide protest since February against a modest initiative that was aimed at encouraging the hiring of young people but that has provoked an improvised, open-ended campaign against the French government itself.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Protests Follow A String Of Killings
snippet: Journalists, students and others blocked roads in Caracas, the capital, protesting the killing of three Canadian-Venezuelan brothers, ages 12 to 17, who were found dead late Tuesday. They were kidnapped Feb. 23 by men dressed as police officers. The...
lead_paragraph: Journalists, students and others blocked roads in Caracas, the capital, protesting the killing of three Canadian-Venezuelan brothers, ages 12 to 17, who were found dead late Tuesday. They were kidnapped Feb. 23 by men dressed as police officers. The protesters called for the resignation of the interior minister, Jesse Chacón. Troops used tear gas as crowds burned trash bins and tires in Altamira, an affluent neighborhood. A news photographer was shot and killed on his way to cover the protests on Wednesday. JENS ERIK GOULD (NYT)

keywords: KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Democracy Protests Continue
snippet: Flouting a government ban on demonstrations, hundreds of Nepalis rallied in Katmandu to demand a restoration of democracy, throwing stones and burning tires on the second day of a four-day nationwide strike. The riot police used tear gas and rubber...
lead_paragraph: Flouting a government ban on demonstrations, hundreds of Nepalis rallied in Katmandu to demand a restoration of democracy, throwing stones and burning tires on the second day of a four-day nationwide strike. The riot police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowds, arresting dozens. Two protesters and a police officer were injured. The strike was called by a coalition of Nepal's seven largest political parties to force King Gyanendra, who seized absolute power last year, to restore parliamentary rule. TILAK P. POKHAREL (NYT)

keywords: PARK CHANWOOK; SOUTH KOREA; MOTION PICTURES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
headline: Mr. Vengeance
snippet: Park Chanwook does not look like a violent man. When he isn't wearing glasses, his soft, round face resembles that of a gentle Tang dynasty Buddha. He speaks quietly and smiles a lot, more like a hip college professor than the director of an...
lead_paragraph: Park Chanwook does not look like a violent man. When he isn't wearing glasses, his soft, round face resembles that of a gentle Tang dynasty Buddha. He speaks quietly and smiles a lot, more like a hip college professor than the director of an ultraviolent revenge trilogy. Pinned on the walls of his office in Seoul, among the movie posters and postcards, are photographs of his wife and 12-year-old daughter. His wife, whom he met at a university film club in the 1980's, reads all his scripts and is his most trusted adviser. Their daughter has seen most of his films. A nice, quiet, reflective family man, then, this 42-year-old director who also happens to be a master of imagery at times so brutal that it is almost unbearable to watch.

keywords: FRANCE; LABOR; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; HIRING AND PROMOTION; LAW AND LEGISLATION; UNEMPLOYMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: French Unrest Reflects Old Faith in Quasi-Socialist Ideals
snippet: Standing amid the chaos of the protests here this week, Omar Sylla, 22, tried to explain why the French are so angry about what seems to many people like such a small thing: the French government's attempt to loosen labor laws a bit by allowing...
lead_paragraph: Standing amid the chaos of the protests here this week, Omar Sylla, 22, tried to explain why the French are so angry about what seems to many people like such a small thing: the French government's attempt to loosen labor laws a bit by allowing employers the right to fire young workers without cause during a trial period on the job. Even after President Jacques Chirac promised to shorten the period to one year from two, the protests continued, and French students and unions have vowed to keep demonstrating until the law is repealed.

keywords: GYANENDRA; NEPAL; UNITED NATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: In Nepal, Death Toll Is 3 as Protests Continue
snippet: Demonstrators protested for the fourth day in a row, burning government buildings and defiantly calling for the ouster of the king.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in this weekend's increasingly violent pro-democracy protests climbed to three late Sunday as demonstrators defied a curfew and poured out onto the streets for the fourth day in a row, storming a government hospital, burning government buildings and defiantly calling for the ouster of the king. A coalition of seven political parties pledged to carry on with its agitation ''indefinitely.''

keywords: YEMEN; JORDAN; AL QAEDA; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; PRISON ESCAPES; TERRORISM
headline: Militant Uprising at Jordanian Prison Is Quelled
snippet: It was the second such riot in less than two months, adding to concerns that Al Qaeda is gaining a new avenue for control.
lead_paragraph: Jordanian security forces stormed a high security prison outside Amman on Thursday, quashing a daylong uprising by Islamist prisoners and leaving one inmate dead and more than 35 guards and inmates wounded, government officials said. It was the second such riot in Jordan in less than two months, adding to rising concerns that the growing Islamist population within prisons is organizing and giving Al Qaeda a new avenue for control.

keywords: GYANENDRA; THAPA, GAGAN; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Nepal Protests Draw 8,000 and Police Wrath
snippet: Nepalese police fired tear gas and beat democracy advocates with canes to break up the largest protest yet against King Gyanendra.
lead_paragraph: Nepalese police officers beat democracy advocates with rattan canes and fired tear gas on Saturday to break up the largest protest against King Gyanendra in the capital since a campaign began 10 days ago. The police charged when about 8,000 demonstrators marched into the city from a western suburb, chanting slogans against the king and demanding that democracy be restored.

keywords: GYANENDRA; INDIA; NEPAL; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Army Fires at Protesters as Nepal's Political Crisis Deepens
snippet: The coalition that organized the demonstrations demanded that the king restore Nepal's Parliament and relinquish control of the government.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Nepalese Army fired at pro-democracy protesters in an eastern town on Wednesday, as the death toll climbed to at least eight in two weeks of defiant demonstrations and the country appeared headed toward a dangerous brink. The brink of what remained unclear.

keywords: NEPAL; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Nepal Chaos Gets Worse, As India Tries To Strike Deal
snippet: Demonstrations, which the government tried to head off with a strict 18-hour curfew, grew to tens of thousands of people, with rallies big and small.
lead_paragraph: The royal government struggled to dam a tide of pro-democracy protest on Thursday. But it broke through anyway, carnival-like in some places and violent in others, as emissaries from Nepal's most vital ally, India, met with King Gyanendra in an effort to defuse a hardening political impasse. The demonstrations, which the government tried to head off with a strict 18-hour curfew, brought tens of thousands of people to rallies big and small on the edges of the heavily fortified city center in the largest turnout in two weeks of protests.

keywords: GYANENDRA, KING OF NEPAL; GYANENDRA; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; REFERENDUMS
headline: PROTESTS MOUNT AS NEPAL PARTIES REJECT KING'S BID
snippet: Neither a curfew and tear gas nor King Gyanendra's offer to give up control of the state stemmed the fury of his subjects on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Neither a curfew and tear gas nor King Gyanendra's offer to give up control of the state stemmed the fury of his subjects on Saturday, as protesters, for the first time in 17 days of demonstrations, broke through police lines to pierce the ancient heart of the city, reaching within a few blocks of Narayanhiti Palace. Police officers pushed the pro-democracy protesters back through the warren of narrow, sunless alleys, firing tear gas, whipping with cane batons and infuriating them even more. ''Dogs!'' they screamed, eyes red from the tear gas, as paramedics rushed in to pick up the injured.

keywords: GYANENDRA; NEPAL; FIRST AID; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; HOSPITALS
headline: A Hospital Is Overwhelmed by Victims of Chaos in Nepal
snippet: Inundated with injured protesters, the Katmandu Model Hospital is a portrait of the acute distress gripping Nepal.
lead_paragraph: True to its name, the Katmandu Model Hospital is a portrait of the acute distress gripping this country. Overwhelmed by emergency cases, its outpatient department is closed. Its emergency supplies -- dressing pads, syringes, and analgesics and other trauma drugs -- are running low. It has only two working ventilators, which is not nearly enough for the number of people who inhale tear gas in the daily pro-democracy protests.

keywords: IRAN; UNITED STATES; GREECE; TURKEY; SECURITY COUNCIL; ATOMIC WEAPONS; KURDS
headline: Rice, in Greece and Turkey, Holds Talks on Iraq and Iran
snippet: She said the U.S. would work to keep Iraqi Kurd insurgents from infiltrating Turkey, and cautioned that Turkish troops should not enter Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice assured Turkish leaders on Tuesday that the United States would step up efforts to stop Kurdish insurgents in Iraq from infiltrating into Turkey, but she cautioned the government not to send troops to Iraq to do the job. The Turkish foreign minister, Abdullah Gul, said there had been a surge in infiltration in recent weeks.

keywords: ECONOMIC SCENE (TIMES COLUMN); FRANCE; APPLE COMPUTER INC; MUSIC; COMPUTER SOFTWARE; CODES (CIPHERS); LAW AND LEGISLATION; RECORDINGS AND DOWNLOADS (AUDIO); COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET
headline: In iTunes War, France Has Met the Enemy. Perhaps It Is France.
snippet: French politicians have abandoned one of the guiding principles of antitrust economics: penalize companies that harm consumers, not the ones that are building better products.
lead_paragraph: THE French take pride in their revolutions, which are usually hard to miss -- mass uprisings, heads rolling and such. So, with the scent of tear gas in the air this past month from the giant protests against a youth labor law, it was easy to overlook the French National Assembly's approval of a bill that would require Apple Computer to crack open the software codes of its iTunes music store and let the files work on players other than the iPod. While seemingly minor, the move is actually rather startling and has left many experts wondering (as ever): What has possessed the French? More is at stake than just whether French teenagers can get Chimène Badi tracks at iTunes for 0.99 euro. The move may signify a willingness to question the patents, copyrights and trade secrets of other successful products as well, like electronics, pharmaceuticals, even fast food. Might we soon see a French legislator demanding to know if it is fair that customers of the French fast-food chain Quick cannot get its signature burger, Le Giant, with McDonald's special sauce?

keywords: NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE; MONTREAL CANADIENS; CAROLINA HURRICANES; HOCKEY, ICE; PLAYOFF GAMES
headline: Canadiens Are Trying to Recapture Their Past Glory
snippet: There is cautious optimism in Montreal that this year could be different, and much of it stems from the sudden emergence of the 30-year-old French-born goaltender Cristobal Huet.
lead_paragraph: If there is any place where hockey is still a religion, it is here along the banks of the St. Lawrence River, where the National Hockey League was founded and where the Montreal Canadiens have taken home at least one Stanley Cup every decade since they won their first in 1916, before the league was even conceived. Every decade, that is, except this one. Since the N.H.L. was born, the Canadiens have won a league-record 23 Stanley Cups, second among North American professional franchises to the Yankees' 26 World Series championships.

keywords: IRAQ; IRAN; GREECE; ATHENS (GREECE); UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Demonstrators Clash With Police in Athens
snippet: Thousands of antiglobalization demonstrators marched to protest Washington's policies in Iraq and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of antiglobalization demonstrators marched Saturday through central Athens and to the United States Embassy to protest Washington's policies in Iraq and Iran. In clashes that filled downtown streets for hours, a Citibank building was set on fire, and a McDonald's restaurant and a Hilton Hotel were attacked.

keywords: GYANENDRA; NEPAL; CONSTITUTIONS
headline: Nepal Recalls Ambassadors Appointed by King
snippet: The newly installed cabinet moved to dismantle King Gyandendra's government and agreed to a plan for rewriting the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Nepal is recalling its ambassadors to 12 countries, including the United States, as political appointments made during King Gyanendra's autocratic rule are invalidated, a top official said Sunday. The decision was made by the new cabinet installed last week after the king, in the face of mass protests, yielded power on April 24 and restored democratic rule. Envoys to India, Japan, Britain and France will also be brought home, said Home Minister Krishna Sitaula.

keywords: MEXICO; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
headline: Marcos Back In Public Eye In Mexico
snippet: Subcommander Marcos, the Zapatista rebel leader, is trying to remake himself as a kind of civil rights leader, though one with a Marxist vision for Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Subcommander Marcos, the Zapatista rebel leader, latched on to an ugly clash last week between the police and farmers outside the capital to revive his flagging campaign for a socialist movement that he hopes will someday topple the government without a shot. Marcos appeared on national television on Tuesday and let himself be interviewed at length for the first time in years. As always, he appeared in his black ski mask and military fatigues, a headset atop his frayed cap, a pipe in his mouth.

keywords: PREVAL, RENE; ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: René Préval Is Inaugurated As President In Uneasy Haiti
snippet: President Préval is Haiti's first democratically elected leader since Jean-Bertrand Aristide fled more than two years ago.
lead_paragraph: President René Préval took office and appealed for peace in Haiti on Sunday as his troubled Caribbean nation inaugurated its first democratically elected leader since Jean-Bertrand Aristide fled more than two years ago. Scores of people chanted for Mr. Aristide's return from exile in South Africa as Mr. Préval took the oath of office.

keywords: AHMADINEJAD, MAHMOUD; IRAN; TEHRAN UNIVERSITY; CARTOONS AND CARTOONISTS; NEWSPAPERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Iran Shuts Down Newspaper Over Cartoon
snippet: The cartoon, published by one of Iran's most popular newspapers, mocked the Azeri minority and led to riots in northwestern cities.
lead_paragraph: The government shut down one of its official newspapers on Tuesday for publishing a cartoon that mocked Iran's Azeri minority and led to riots in northwestern cities. The government Press Supervisory Board shut down the daily newspaper Iran because the cartoon was ''divisive and provocative,'' state television reported. The newspaper is published by the official IRNA news agency and is among the country's most popular and influential newspapers.

keywords: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; POLICE; TERRORISM
headline: Israeli Raid in West Bank Kills 4 Palestinians
snippet: An Israeli undercover operation turned into a chaotic gun battle Wednesday, leaving four Palestinians dead and about 50 injured.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli undercover arrest operation on Wednesday turned into a chaotic gun battle in the center of Ramallah, leaving 4 Palestinians dead and about 50 wounded. It was the second time in two days that the Israeli military had raided Ramallah, the Palestinian political headquarters in the West Bank, to seize a Palestinian high on its most-wanted list. However, unlike the operation on Tuesday, which had led to the arrest of Ibrahim Hamed, a long-sought Hamas leader, and caused no casualties, the action on Wednesday quickly degenerated into a shootout around the main traffic circle in the congested city.

keywords: KARZAI, HAMID; WASHINGTON (DC); AFGHANISTAN; TALIBAN; CARE; ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY; AUTOMOBILES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: After Riots End, Kabul's Residents Begin to Point Fingers
snippet: Afghans placed blame for Monday's rioting on young hoodlums and criminal gangs, but also criticized the U.S. military's arrogance.
lead_paragraph: As they swept up broken glass and boarded up windows and doors on Tuesday, Kabul residents placed blame for Monday's rioting on young hoodlums and criminal gangs who seized on a fatal accident involving an American military convoy to spark a citywide conflagration. But they also criticized the American military for its arrogance, saying military vehicles frequently crush civilian cars, and they doubted that the government or the military would conduct an honest investigation of the incident.

keywords: FRANCE; ROCK AND STONE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: In Paris Suburbs, Worrying Attack by Youths
snippet: The youths threw rocks at police and set a dozen cars ablaze in a second night of violence reminiscent of last fall's unrest.
lead_paragraph: Youths in two Paris suburbs threw rocks at police officers and set a dozen cars ablaze overnight Tuesday, in the second night of violence reminiscent of the unrest that swept France in October and November. The police in the two towns northeast of Paris, Montfermeil and Clichy-sous-Bois, arrested 13 people, including Muhittin Altun, 18, the only survivor of the electrocution accident that set off the wave of violence last year. Two youths died in that incident.

keywords: STEWART, JAMES; TURNER, DESMOND; INDIANAPOLIS (IND); ROBBERIES AND THEFTS; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS
headline: Man Suspected In Killings of 7 Turns Self In
snippet: The suspect, Desmond Turner, surrendered to authorities at a downtown Indianapolis fast-food restaurant.
lead_paragraph: A man suspected of gunning down seven family members in their home here surrendered to the authorities on Saturday, a deputy police chief said. More than 100 officers had searched for the suspect, Desmond Turner, since the killings on Thursday, including unsuccessful raids at two Eastside houses.

keywords: BACHELET, MICHELLE; CHILE; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION; FINANCES; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BUILDING (CONSTRUCTION); TEACHERS AND SCHOOL EMPLOYEES; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Chilean Promised a New Deal; Now Striking Youth Demand It
snippet: More than 700,000 teenagers have walked out of classes at public high schools to demand an overhaul of the education system.
lead_paragraph: Less than three months after she took office promising to lead a government that welcomed greater citizen participation, President Michelle Bachelet is facing her first domestic crisis. To the surprise of many here, the challenge comes not from the right but from a group expected to be sympathetic to her center-left coalition: high school students. In protests that began in mid-May, more than 700,000 teenagers have walked out of classes at public high schools, demanding the overhaul of an education system they say is inferior and discriminatory. They have occupied several hundred schools, sleeping there overnight with sympathetic parents bringing them meals, and last week thousands marched in the streets of the capital here and in other cities in this nation of 16 million.

keywords: AFGHANISTAN; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: 33 Afghans U.S. Had Held Are Released
snippet: The detainees were given some clothing and money by the Afghan authorities and freed as part of the country's reconciliation program.
lead_paragraph: The United States military on Thursday released 33 Afghans from detention at Bagram Air Base and handed them over to the Afghan authorities. The detainees were given some clothing and money by the Afghan authorities and freed as part of the country's reconciliation program.

keywords: CALIFORNIA; BERKELEY (CALIF); CODY'S; UNITED STATES ECONOMY; SHUTDOWNS (INSTITUTIONAL); BOOKS AND LITERATURE; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; BOOK TRADE
headline: In Berkeley, a Store's End Clouds a Street's Future
snippet: Concern over deteriorating conditions on Telegraph Avenue in Berkeley, Calif., is turning into panic after longtime resident Cody's Books said it will close.
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, the reason Cody's Books is going out of business is either because of the City of Berkeley, the homeless, the University of California, the war in Iraq, Ronald Reagan, the Internet or the lack of short-term parking. Or, of course, all of the above.

keywords: Uzbekistan; Demonstrations and Riots; Freedom and Human Rights; News and News Media
headline: Video of Ill-Fated Uzbek Rising Offers Haunting, Complex View
snippet: The video provides an extensive account of the deadly crackdown on an anti-government uprising last spring.
lead_paragraph: The video provides an extensive account of the deadly crackdown on an anti-government uprising last spring.

headline: Video of Ill-Fated Uzbek Rising Offers Haunting, Complex View
snippet: The young man with an assault rifle, a convicted killer, stood beneath a statue in the central square of the Uzbek city of Andijon. He had been freed from prison in an armed raid the night before.     It was May 13, 2005. The man, Daniyor Akbarov,...
lead_paragraph: The young man with an assault rifle, a convicted killer, stood beneath a statue in the central square of the Uzbek city of Andijon. He had been freed from prison in an armed raid the night before. It was May 13, 2005. The man, Daniyor Akbarov, addressed a growing crowd of unarmed civilians, telling them he was part of a group of 100 to 150 armed men that had already lost 20 or 30 members in a night of fighting. He said that they were trying to change Uzbekistan, one of the world's most repressive nations.

keywords: LOPEZ OBRADOR, ANDRES MANUEL; FOX, VICENTE; MEXICO; INSTITUTIONAL REVOLUTIONARY PARTY; PARTY OF THE DEMOCRATIC REVOLUTION; INTERIOR DEPARTMENT; LABOR; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; TEACHERS AND SCHOOL EMPLOYEES
headline: Teacher Strike May Influence Mexican Vote
snippet: What started as a teachers' strike five weeks ago has grown into a major movement to oust the governor of Oaxaca State.
lead_paragraph: What started as a teachers' strike here five weeks ago has grown into a major movement to oust the governor of Oaxaca State that could affect the presidential election on July 2. Last week began with strikers battling the police and ended with failed talks with a federal mediator. Tens of thousands of teachers still occupy the central square and the surrounding streets of this colonial town of 265,000, a cultural center and tourist attraction known for its artists and haunting pre-Columbian ruins.

keywords: News
headline: Saving the "Music" of the Amazon
snippet: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 28 column, "The Cry of the Wild" Dan Swanson, Bolwing Green, Ky. : Central and South Americans might say, "Sure, you clear-cut all of North America, and reaped profit without regard for ecological...
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 28 column, "The Cry of the Wild"

keywords: PARIS (FRANCE); SWIMMING; WOMEN; APPAREL
headline: French Beach Requires Full Coverage, From Top to Bottom
snippet: The news last weekend that Pariss man-made beach was enforcing a ban on thongs and bare breasts came as a bit of a shock.
lead_paragraph: Paris is proud of its spirit of exhibitionism, so the front-page newspaper headline last weekend that the city's man-made beach was enforcing a ban on thongs and bare breasts came as a bit of a shock. Not only that, the article in the tabloid Le Parisien reported, but the police might go so far as to hand out a $48 fine for anyone who refused to cover up.

keywords: LOPEZ OBRADOR, ANDRES MANUEL; CALDERON, FELIPE; FOX, VICENTE; MEXICO; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Mexico's President Defends Vote Tally Electing His Ally
snippet: President Vicente Fox for the first time defended the vote that narrowly favored Felipe Calderón as clean and fair.
lead_paragraph: With the country locked in a battle over the results of last month's elections, President Vicente Fox for the first time defended the vote that narrowly favored his party's candidate as clean and fair, rejecting allegations of widespread irregularities. ''The process has been transparent in the eyes of the world,'' the president said Sunday evening in an interview at his residence inside Los Pinos, the presidential compound. ''It was watched by the media. There were observers. The entire world was watching the electoral process. There is nothing hidden.''

keywords: RUIZ, ULISES; FOX QUESADA, VICENTE; OAXACA (MEX); MEXICO; VIOLENCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Violent Civil Unrest Tightens Hold on a Mexican City
snippet: The original cause of strife in Oaxaca  a teachers’ strike for better pay  has become lost in escalating violence that has left two people dead.
lead_paragraph: For three months, civil unrest has gripped this lovely colonial city like a hound with a rabbit, leaving two people dead, crippling the tourist industry and shuttering schools. The original cause of the strife -- a teachers' strike for better pay -- has become lost in the escalating violence and the revolutionary demands of the protesters, who now demand that Gov. Ulises Ruiz step down.

keywords: RANGEL, JOSE VICENTE; CHAVEZ, HUGO; BARRETO, JUAN; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); HOUSING; COUNTRY CLUBS; GOLF
headline: Caracas Mayor Lays Claim to Golf Links to House Poor
snippet: In the latest uproar over property rights, the mayor of Caracas, Venezuela, ordered the “forced acquisition” of an exclusive golf course to make way for homes for poor families.
lead_paragraph: No place in this country symbolizes the resilience of Venezuela's moneyed elite more than the Caracas Country Club, a bastion of tropical luxury from the 1920's, conceived in part for foreign oilmen and designed by American landscape architects who invoked the feeling of a vast coffee plantation. So imagine the reactions in Caracas, a city choked by shantytowns and traffic congestion, when the mayor ordered the ''forced acquisition'' this week of the club's 18-hole golf course, and another exclusive course near the United States Embassy, to make way for homes for as many as 11,500 poor families.

keywords: GYURCSANY, FERENC; HUNGARY; RECORDINGS (AUDIO); ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Protests Turn Violent
snippet: The police and protesters clashed in Budapest after thousands of Hungarians marched to demand that Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany, left, resign after admitting that he had told colleagues that his government had ''lied in the morning and in the...
lead_paragraph: The police and protesters clashed in Budapest after thousands of Hungarians marched to demand that Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany, left, resign after admitting that he had told colleagues that his government had ''lied in the morning and in the evening'' about the economy to win April's election. It was the first such street violence since the fall of Communism in the late 1980's. Protesters hurled bottles and stones at the police, who fired tear gas to stop them from forcing their way into the state television offices. The protest was set off by a leaked audio recording of a closed-door meeting by Mr. Gyurcsany appealing to his party after the election to change its ways. The Socialist Party rallied behind its prime minister, who took office in 2004.

keywords: BANGLADESH; DHAKA (BANGLADESH); BLACKOUTS AND BROWNOUTS (ELECTRICAL); ELECTRIC LIGHT AND POWER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: 200 Injured In Riots Over Power Blackouts
snippet: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at thousands of demonstrators violently protesting two days of near-constant power failures in Bangladesh's capital, Dhaka, witnesses said. About 200 protesters were injured, and government offices were...
lead_paragraph: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at thousands of demonstrators violently protesting two days of near-constant power failures in Bangladesh's capital, Dhaka, witnesses said. About 200 protesters were injured, and government offices were attacked and vehicles smashed.

keywords: BOROUJERDI, MOHAMMAD KAZEMENI; KHOMEINI, RUHOLLAH; IRAN; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; CHURCH-STATE RELATIONS
headline: Iran Arrests Outspoken Cleric Who Opposes Religious Rule
snippet: A senior cleric who opposes religious rule of Iran and a number of his followers were arrested Sunday after clashes with the riot police over the weekend, news agencies reported.      About 1,000 supporters of the cleric, Ayatollah Mohammad Kazemeni...
lead_paragraph: A senior cleric who opposes religious rule of Iran and a number of his followers were arrested Sunday after clashes with the riot police over the weekend, news agencies reported. About 1,000 supporters of the cleric, Ayatollah Mohammad Kazemeni Boroujerdi, gathered outside his home and on the streets leading to it on Saturday, the semiofficial ILNA news agency reported. They were there apparently to protect him from arrest and to protest the arrests over the past month of other supporters who had tried to protect him after a court had summoned him.

headline: News Summary
snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-9    North Korea Announces Test of Nuclear Weapon  North Korea said that it had set off its first nuclear test -- just two days after the country was warned by the United Nations Security Council that the action could lead to severe...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 North Korea Announces Test of Nuclear Weapon North Korea said that it had set off its first nuclear test -- just two days after the country was warned by the United Nations Security Council that the action could lead to severe consequences. American officials cautioned that they had not yet received any confirmation that the test had occurred. A1 The North Korea nuclear test amounted to a major failure for China, which mounted one of its most extensive diplomatic efforts in years to find a negotiated solution to the North Korean nuclear crisis. The Chinese expressed their anger in unusually strong terms, saying the test was ''flagrant and brazen.'' A6 Tsunami Project Stalled Construction of a road in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, meant as a good-will gesture from the American people to the survivors of the 2004 tsunami, has met with difficulty. Because of long negotiations to acquire right of way through residential and farm land, and through several hundred graves of religious significance, the project has not even started. A8 Hints at Need for Iraq Change James A. Baker III, the Republican co-chairman of a panel reassessing Iraq strategy for President Bush, said he expected that the panel would depart from Mr. Bush's repeated calls to ''stay the course,'' and he strongly suggested that the White House enter direct talks with countries it has so far kept at arms length, including Iran and Syria. A1 American and Iraqi troops fought a fierce battle with militants in the city of Diwaniya, a stronghold of militia members loyal to radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, the American military said. The skirmish was the third serious clash between American or Iraqi soldiers against members of the Mahdi Army in Diwaniya in less than two months. A8 Japan and China Mend Fences China and Japan said they had made progress addressing their historical animosities and territorial differences as Shinzo Abe, the new Japanese prime minister, made his first trip to mend ties with Asian neighbors. President Hu Jintao of China, left, called Mr. Abe's visit a turning point for two Asian powers whose relations had sharply declined. A1 Virginia Republicans Resolute In dozens of interviews in southeastern Virginia, a swing state in tight races for the House and Senate, many conservative Christians said that rather than discourage them from going to the polls, the scandal surrounding Representative Mark Foley only reinforced their reasons to vote for their Republican incumbents. A1 For all the contradictions and inconsistencies in the tale of Mark Foley, the investigation into how Republicans handled concerns about his conduct may hinge on what transpired in a private meeting that was convened in his office last year. A12 Races Hinge on Local Economy Michigan's political races for governor and the Senate are hinging nearly entirely on the struggling economy and the question of who is to blame for it. And in other Rust Belt states, including Ohio, Indiana and Pennsylvania, economic worries are playing a similar role, if a far more subtle one. A10 Lawyer's Book Causes Trouble Joyce Dudley, a deputy district attorney in Santa Barbara, published a crime novel. The novel concerns a rape case with echoes of a real one.
