keywords: ABBAS, MAHMOUD; HANIYA, ISMAIL; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; FATAH, AL; HAMAS; PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY; FATAH; PALESTINIANS
headline: 5 Die as Palestinians Clash With Israelis and Each Other
snippet: Four Palestinians, including three Hamas militants, were killed Friday in a second day of deadly clashes with Israeli forces in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Four Palestinians, including three Hamas militants, were killed Friday in a second day of deadly clashes with Israeli forces in the Gaza Strip. In a separate confrontation, Palestinian gunmen from the two main factions, Hamas and Fatah, battled each other overnight and during the day on Friday, leaving a teenager dead and nearly 50 people wounded in the northern Gaza town of Beit Lahiya, the Palestinians said.

keywords: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; RAMADAN; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; AL AKSA MOSQUE (JERUSALEM); ISLAM
headline: Muslims Flood Streets of Jerusalem for Ramadan Prayers
snippet: The prayers were marred by scuffles as Israeli forces clashed with Palestinians seeking to enter Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: With Israel imposing tight restrictions on Palestinian movements, the holy month of Ramadan marks a rare occasion when large numbers of Palestinians from the West Bank can enter Jerusalem to worship at the Aksa Mosque compound, one of the most sacred sites in Islam. On Friday, the last one before Ramadan ends, an estimated 180,000 Muslims from the West Bank and Israel filled the narrow stone streets of Jerusalem's Old City and prayed at the compound. But it was no consolation for the thousands of West Bank men who were turned back at the city's edge, some in scuffles with Israeli security forces.

keywords: PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; LABOR; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; BLACKS; ELECTION ISSUES; ATTACKS ON POLICE; SUBURBS; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; HOUSING; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ISLAM; UNEMPLOYMENT; CRIME AND CRIMINALS
headline: Anger Festering In French Areas Scarred in Riots
snippet: Spiking violent crime statistics across Paris suburbs suggest not only that things have not improved, but that they may well have worsened.
lead_paragraph: When the call went out about a car burglary in the raw suburb of Épinay-sur-Seine north of here last weekend, three officers in a patrol car rushed over and found themselves surrounded by 30 youths in hoods throwing rocks and swinging bats and metal bars. Neither tear gas nor stun guns stopped the assault. Only when reinforcements arrived did the siege end. One officer was left with broken teeth and in need of 30 stitches to his face.

keywords: GYURCSANY, FERENC; BUDAPEST (HUNGARY); RUSSIA; HUNGARY; RECORDINGS (AUDIO); SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; POLICE; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Clashes Disrupt Hungarians' Celebration of Anti-Soviet Revolt in '56
snippet: The rally was one of several held over the past month calling for the resignation of the Socialist prime minister, Ferenc Gyurcsany.
lead_paragraph: Violent clashes in Budapest on Monday as the police tried to contain a month-old antigovernment protest movement marred the 50th anniversary of Hungary's uprising against Soviet domination. The police used rubber bullets, tear gas and a water cannon to disperse thousands of protesters who had gathered for a rally after a group of them took control of a Soviet-era T-34 tank that was on display for the commemorations and drove it toward the police. About two dozen people were injured, none seriously.

headline: THE WEEK AHEAD: Oct. 29 - Nov. 4; FILM
snippet: Last week, the police and protesters in Budapest celebrated the 50th anniversary of Hungary's uprising against the Soviet Union the old-fashioned way: with tear gas, a purloined tank and calls for the ouster of the prime minister. The Film Society...
lead_paragraph: Last week, the police and protesters in Budapest celebrated the 50th anniversary of Hungary's uprising against the Soviet Union the old-fashioned way: with tear gas, a purloined tank and calls for the ouster of the prime minister. The Film Society of Lincoln Center has opted for a quieter remembrance of those tragic events with a three-week, three-part program dedicated to old, new and relatively unknown Hungarian cinema. The awkwardly titled RESISTANCE AND REBIRTH: HUNGARIAN CINEMA, 50 YEARS AFTER '56 actually encompasses separate but related points of interest: ''Remembering '56,'' which highlights work about the uprising and its aftermath, including Istvan Szabo's autobiographically informed 1966 film ''Father''; the self-explanatory ''Tribute to Miklos Jancso: The Currents of History''; and ''New Cinema From Hungary.'' In recent years, Hungary has pushed hard to become a European film hub, notably with financial incentives that have helped local and foreign production alike. The fruits of its newly revived cinema scene have been trickling into international film festivals and, on occasion, into American art houses. Lajos Koltai's extremely moving adaptation of the Nobel Prize-winner Imre Kertesz's personal novel about the Holocaust, ''Fateless,'' opened here in January to enthusiastic notices and scant public interest and is now, happily, available on DVD. Among the new works in the festival are the critical favorite ''Kontroll,'' which enjoyed a marginally better run last year, and the singularly enthralling opera ''Johanna,'' about an accident victim turned angel of mercy who prowls an atmospherically dilapidated hospital in which the sounds of music include the refrain ''Let's run to urology!'' Through Nov. 15, Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, (212) 496-3809 or filmlinc.com.

keywords: RUIZ, ULISES; FOX QUESADA, VICENTE; MEXICO; OAXACA (MEXICO); VIOLENCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; POLICE
headline: Mexican Federal Police and Army Move to Retake Oaxaca
snippet: Federal forces bashed through barricades and pushed back activists who had seized the downtown five months ago.
lead_paragraph: Federal forces moved to take back this picturesque tourist town one cobblestone street at a time on Sunday, bashing through barricades and pushing back activists who had seized the downtown five months ago in an increasingly ugly dispute with the state governor. Police officers wearing riot gear and carrying shields were backed by water cannons, police helicopters and heavily armed soldiers as they marched from all directions toward Oaxaca's main square, the Zócalo, which used to draw tourists but in recent months has been a giant encampment for an array of groups intent on toppling Ulises Ruiz, the governor of Oaxaca State.

keywords: RUIZ, ULISES; MEXICO; OAXACA (MEXICO); ATTACKS ON POLICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Protesters in Mexico Push Riot Police Back
snippet: Protesters hurling Molotov cocktails forced riot police officers to retreat, as clashes intensified in Oaxaca.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters hurling Molotov cocktails forced riot police officers with tear gas and water cannons to retreat on Thursday, as clashes intensified here in this popular tourist city. At least eight people were injured in the violence, including a newspaper photographer who was hit by fireworks launched from the grounds of Oaxaca State's university, a center of the protests. More than a dozen people have died in the conflict.

keywords: ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; HAMAS; PALESTINIANS; WOMEN; MOSQUES
headline: Israelis Fire on Marchers Aiding Gaza Gunmen, Killing 2
snippet: Israeli troops killed two Palestinian women who were seeking to serve as human shields for Hamas militants holed up in a Gaza mosque.
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops killed two Palestinian women and wounded some 10 others who were seeking to serve as human shields for Hamas militants holed up in a Gaza mosque on Friday after an overnight standoff. The troops fired on a crowd of women and at least a few men as they marched to the mosque. Hundreds of women, urged on by Palestinian radio, were flocking to the mosque to try to prevent an Israeli attack and to help an estimated 60 men escape. In the chaos that erupted when the shooting began, the gunmen inside the mosque escaped.

keywords: MARTINEZ, FRANCISCO; MEXICO; OAXACA (MEXICO); VIOLENCE; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ACADEMIC FREEDOM
headline: A Week Later, Protesters Still Hanging On at University in Oaxaca
snippet: The state university has become a stronghold for leftists trying to oust the Oaxaca state governor in a five-month conflict.
lead_paragraph: Masked men with bats and gasoline bombs patrol the gates, and barbed wire and booby traps defile the campus lawns. Since protesters took over the state university in Mexico's besieged Oaxaca City last weekend, there have been no classes, only talk of revolution. The university of 30,000 students has become a stronghold for leftists trying to oust the Oaxaca state governor in a five-month conflict that has left more than 12 people dead.

keywords: RUIZ, ULISES; MEXICO; OAXACA (MEXICO); ATTACKS ON POLICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
headline: Protesters Set Buildings on Fire in Embattled Oaxaca
snippet: Leftist protesters set fire to another building in running street battles with the police that injured at least 43 people.
lead_paragraph: Leftist protesters trying to force out the Oaxaca state governor set fire to another building Sunday after a night of burning government offices and vehicles in running street battles with the police that injured at least 43 people. The violence broke out late Saturday after masked youths broke away from a protest march by about 4,000 people and began attacking the police and buildings in Oaxaca city.

keywords: CAGRICI, MUSTAFA; BENEDICT XVI; EUROPE; ISTANBUL (TURKEY); TURKEY; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; FREEDOM OF RELIGION; BLUE MOSQUE (ISTANBUL); CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY; ISLAM
headline: Pope Prays in Turkey With Muslim and Orthodox Leaders
snippet: Pope Benedict showed that many of his basic concerns about the relationship between Christianity and Islam, as well as between West and East, had not vanished.
lead_paragraph: Pope Benedict XVI, who spurred waves of anger among Muslims just two months ago, stood Thursday in silent prayer, facing Mecca, beside a Muslim prelate in one of the world's most important mosques. The image of two men in white -- the 79-year-old pope and Mustafa Cagrici, the chief of religious affairs for Istanbul -- under the ornate domes of the Blue Mosque sealed a trip in which Pope Benedict repeatedly underscored his desire to reconcile Christians and Muslims.

keywords: PINOCHET, AUGUSTO; PINOCHET UGARTE, AUGUSTO; CHILE; SANTIAGO (CHILE); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Joy, and Violence, at Death of Pinochet
snippet: Chileans celebrated the death of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Santiago but violence marred the revelry.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in celebration here on Sunday almost immediately after news circulated of the death of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet. But within hours the revelry was marred by violence, with confrontations breaking out and the police using tear gas and water cannons against a large group marching toward the presidential palace. Gen. Jorge Acuna, of the capital police force, said that six police officers had been wounded in the scuffles and that seven demonstrators had been arrested in the capital, while dozens of others were detained in police vehicles and more arrests were expected.

keywords: BOYLE, PETER; MOTION PICTURES; TELEVISION; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Peter Boyle, 71, Is Dead; Roles Evoked Laughter and Anger
snippet: Peter Boyle, a successful character actor, ended his career with a long stint on “Everybody Loves Raymond.”
lead_paragraph: Peter Boyle, who left the life of a monk to study acting and went on to become one of the most successful character actors of his time in films like ''Joe,'' ''Young Frankenstein'' and ''Monster's Ball,'' then capped his career as the curmudgeonly father on the hit sitcom ''Everybody Loves Raymond,'' died on Tuesday evening in Manhattan. He was 71. His death was announced by his publicist, Jennifer Plante. She said Mr. Boyle, who lived in Manhattan, had suffered from multiple myeloma and heart disease.

keywords: DEAN, JAMES E; IRAQ; MARYLAND; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLICE
headline: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Police Kill Reservist In Standoff
snippet: An Army Reservist despondent about being sent to Iraq was killed by the police during a 14-hour standoff that began Monday night. The man, James E. Dean, 28, had barricaded himself inside his father’s house with several weapons, family members told...
lead_paragraph: An Army Reservist despondent about being sent to Iraq was killed by the police during a 14-hour standoff that began Monday night. The man, James E. Dean, 28, had barricaded himself inside his father's house with several weapons, family members told the police. Around noon Tuesday, while the police were preparing to use tear gas to force Mr. Dean out of the home, he came to the front door and pointed his weapon at an officer, said Sheriff Tim Cameron of St. Mary's County. Another deputy shot Mr. Dean once, killing him. Mr. Dean had already served 18 months in Afghanistan and was despondent after learning recently that he would be deployed to Iraq, relatives told the police. Sheriff Cameron said he did not know in what reserve unit Mr. Dean had served.

keywords: GHARIB, MUHAMMAD; HANIYA, ISMAIL; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; FATAH, AL; HAMAS; FATAH; PALESTINIANS; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
headline: Day After Killings, a Hamas Leader Calls for a Truce
snippet: The Palestinian prime minister called for an end to the internal violence, after his own Hamas militia killed a Fatah commander.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, called Friday for an end to the internal violence in the Gaza Strip, a day after members of his own Hamas militia surrounded the house of a Fatah commander, killed him and his bodyguards and seriously wounded his wife and brother. Before his death, the commander, Col. Muhammad Gharib, begged for help on a live telephone call to Palestinian television, saying his home near Jabaliya was being attacked by the Executive Force, a parallel security force under the command of the Hamas-run Interior Ministry, but that Fatah leaders and fighters did not respond.

keywords: REYES VILLA, MANFRED; MORALES, EVO; COCHABAMBA (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; REFERENDUMS
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: 2 Killed, 70 Wounded In Street Battles
snippet: Two people were killed and more than 70 wounded as supporters of President Evo Morales and seekers of regional autonomy battled one another with guns, sticks and rocks on the streets of Cochabamba, in central Bolivia. Fighting broke out when...
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and more than 70 wounded as supporters of President Evo Morales and seekers of regional autonomy battled one another with guns, sticks and rocks on the streets of Cochabamba, in central Bolivia. Fighting broke out when supporters of Manfredo Reyes Villa, governor of the state with the same name as the city, entered downtown Cochabamba, occupied since Monday by thousands of supporters of the leftist president demanding that the governor step down over his plans to call a referendum on regional autonomy. A television station said two people, one of them a coca-leaf farmer, had been killed, but it was not immediately clear how. Television showed hundreds of men running through the streets, some carrying sticks, as onlookers applauded and the police fired tear gas. The government sent in troops.

keywords: CONTE, LANSANA; GUINEA; CONAKRY (GUINEA); STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: World Briefing | Africa: Guinea: Protests Spread
snippet: Security forces fired tear gas at demonstrators in the capital, Conakry, as street protests spread to seven other towns and cities on the eighth day of a general strike intended to force the country's ailing president, Lansana Conté, to step down....
lead_paragraph: Security forces fired tear gas at demonstrators in the capital, Conakry, as street protests spread to seven other towns and cities on the eighth day of a general strike intended to force the country's ailing president, Lansana Conté, to step down. Mr. Conté, left, a 72-year-old diabetic chain-smoker with no obvious successor, grabbed power in a 1984 coup and has refused to relinquish control despite a heart ailment that has required him to travel to Switzerland for care several times in the past year. He is also said to be senile. The strike began after he halted the trial of two men accused of stealing millions of dollars from the state.

keywords: ARAMIN, BASSAM; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; ANATA (WEST BANK); COMBATANTS FOR PEACE; FATAH; PALESTINIANS
headline: Father of Dead West Bank Girl Seeks Peace With Israelis
snippet: In a long and bitter conflict, killings often prompt revenge rather than understanding, but the father of a slain girl says he wants to talk to Israelis about making peace.
lead_paragraph: Even as Bassam Aramin mourns his 10-year-old daughter, killed last week during a clash between stone-throwing Palestinian youths and the Israeli police, he says he wants to talk to Israelis about making peace. It has been a long journey for Mr. Aramin, 38, a former Palestinian fighter. He spent seven years in Israeli jails, from 1986 to 1993, for weapons possession and for belonging to the Fatah movement, which was banned at the time.

keywords: SINIORA, FOUAD; LEBANON; BEIRUT (LEBANON); BEIRUT ARAB UNIVERSITY; HEZBOLLAH; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; CURFEWS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Beirut University Dispute Escalates Into Rioting, Killing 4
snippet: The army declared a rare night curfew amid fears that Lebanon’s two-month political crisis had entered a violent phase.
lead_paragraph: Violence erupted in Beirut on Thursday for the second time in three days, as an altercation in a university cafeteria escalated into rioting and gunfire. The army declared a rare night curfew throughout the city amid fears that Lebanon's two-month political crisis had entered a violent phase.

keywords: RACITI, FILIPPO; ITALY; PALERMO; CATANIA; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Italian Games Postponed After Officer Dies in Riots
snippet: The Italian soccer federation threatened to suspend games indefinitely after the death of a police officer in riots at a Serie A match.
lead_paragraph: The Italian soccer federation threatened to suspend games indefinitely after the death of a police officer in riots at a Serie A match. The officer was killed and more than 70 people were injured Friday when fans rioted at a game between the Sicilian teams Catania and Palermo, prompting the federation to postpone all league matches this weekend and cancel a friendly between world champion Italy and Romania on Wednesday.

keywords: GENERATION ON FIRE (BOOK); KISSELOFF, JEFF; NATION; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; PARTIES (SOCIAL)
headline: Recalling Days of Rebellion, Tear Gas and Kinship
snippet: Former revolutionaries traded war stories from the good and bad old days at a book party Monday.
lead_paragraph: THE gay Yippie, the three-times-wounded Vietnam veteran, the militant mother who once led an armed resistance in rural Maryland. The rock guitarist turned public defender who brags of having played a benefit concert to raise money for an armored truck for the Black Panther Party. One-seventh of the Chicago Seven. In a different time and place, they might have met under clouds of tear gas or shouts from angry mobs. They might have met on picket lines, or the wrong end of a National Guardsman's bayonet.

keywords: SUMBAL (KASHMIR); INDIA; PAKISTAN; KASHMIR AND JAMMU; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: Indian Army and Police Implicated in Kashmir Killings
snippet: A string of recent deaths has unearthed a deep well of resentment among the people of Indian-administered Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: Amid a grove of poplar trees in a village just north of here, a grave was unearthed Thursday afternoon. Out came the body of a man, shot dead nearly two months ago, whom the Indian police described at the time as an anti-Indian militant from Pakistan. An elderly man, who had been searching for his missing son for nearly two months, was summoned for the exhumation. He stared at the horror dug out of the ground and told the police what he had refused to believe all this time. ''He is my son,'' he said. Then he sat on the bare ground and shook.

keywords: ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; TEMPLE MOUNT (JERUSALEM); PALESTINIANS; NOBLE SANCTUARY (JERUSALEM); ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Arab Protesters in Jerusalem Clash With Israeli Forces
snippet: Israeli troops fired tear gas and stun grenades at stone-throwing Palestinian protesters on the fourth straight day of clashes.
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops charged onto the grounds of Jerusalem's most contentious religious site on Friday and fired tear gas and stun grenades at stone-throwing Palestinians who were protesting Israeli excavation work taking place nearby. The confrontation, which began immediately after midday worship on the Muslim day of prayer, marked the fourth straight day of Palestinian protests against Israel's renovation of a 50-yard walkway leading up to the compound, known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount.

keywords: MORALES, EVO; BOLIVIA; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH
headline: Indian Ritual Fades Into Blur of Drinking and Fighting
snippet: Several political organizations in Bolivia are pushing to preserve endangered traditions like Tinku, an ancient ritual once widespread throughout the Andean world.
lead_paragraph: For hundreds of years, the Indians of Bolivia's high plains have trekked to this town in early February. They dance, drink chicha, the fermented beverage made here from rye, and then fight one another until blood stains the dirt alleyways. The ritual, called Tinku, a word that means ''encounter'' in both Aymara and Quechua, was once widespread throughout the Andean world, predating the arrival of the conquistadors. Anthropologists say it now tenuously exists just in this isolated pocket of Bolivia, seven hours southeast of La Paz by bus on a washboard dirt road.

keywords: FINE, GLENN A; FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; ROBBERIES AND THEFTS; COMPUTER SECURITY; FIREARMS; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; PRIVACY
headline: F.B.I. Lags in Securing Its Laptops and Weapons
snippet: A report says that 160 weapons and 160 laptops had been lost or stolen over a 44-month period.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is making progress safeguarding its weapons and laptop computers, though there are still shortcomings to address, the Justice Department's inspector general said in a report issued on Monday. The report by the inspector general, Glenn A. Fine, said that 160 weapons and 160 laptops had been lost or stolen over a 44-month period and that the bureau could not determine ''in many cases'' whether the missing computers had contained sensitive or classified information. Six of those computers were assigned to the bureau's counterintelligence division, and one was assigned to its counterterrorism division, the report said.

keywords: RONALD REAGAN: FATE, FREEDOM, AND THE MAKING OF HISTORY (BOOK); REAGAN, RONALD WILSON; DIGGINS, JOHN PATRICK; UNITED STATES POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; REVIEWS; PRESIDENTS AND PRESIDENCY (US); BOOKS AND LITERATURE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: The Liberal Reagan
snippet: The historian John Patrick Diggins views Reagan as a liberating figure.
lead_paragraph: RONALD REAGAN Fate, Freedom, and the Making of History. By John Patrick Diggins. Illustrated. 493 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

keywords: COPENHAGEN (DENMARK); DENMARK; SQUATTERS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Uneasy Copenhagen Braces For More Violent Protesting
snippet: The riots started Thursday after police evicted squatters from a building that for years had been a popular cultural center for anarchists, punk rockers and left-wing groups.
lead_paragraph: The police braced for more violence on Saturday after two nights of street clashes with leftist youths from several countries that have turned parts of this capital city into a battlefield strewn with burning cars and shattered glass. As the smoke and tear gas cleared Saturday morning, the police said 188 people were arrested overnight, while more than 200 were arrested the day before.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; CHAVEZ, HUGO; LATIN AMERICA; BRAZIL; SAO PAULO (BRAZIL); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
headline: Visit by Bush Fires Up Latins' Debate Over Socialism
snippet: President Bush’s tour seems in part geared to counter the influence of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: President Bush has portrayed his trip to Latin America this week as a ''We Care'' tour aimed at dispelling perceptions that he has neglected his southern neighbors. But fresh graffiti on streets here in São Paulo, where he landed Thursday night for his first stop, calls him a murderer. The smattering of protests and the placement of military vehicles around the city, South America's largest, also present an alternate interpretation of his visit: as a clash between the open capitalism that Mr. Bush espouses and the socialist approach pushed by leftist leaders who have grown in power and popularity.

keywords: SOUTH KOREA; NORTH KOREA; ESPIONAGE; POLITICAL PRISONERS; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE
headline: South Korea Reviews Its Dark Past, but the Pace Is Slow
snippet: Former political prisoners are coming forward with accounts of witch hunts and torture that can sound unreal to young South Koreans today.
lead_paragraph: In his final days, the Venerable Bogwang, a fisherman turned Buddhist monk, wrestled with his conscience. The scriptures he revered exhorted him to leave behind the entanglements of the material world. But he could not shake off the nightmarish memories of the interrogation room of South Korea's once-infamous Army Security Command, where, he said, he was held for 43 days and tortured in 1983.

headline: Reader Suggestions for Darfur
snippet: Six weeks ago I asked readers to send in their suggestions for ending the conflict in Darfur. There were about 300 responses, and here's a sampling. Please add your comments at the bottom to identify which you agree with or think are awful. Michelle...
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago I asked readers to send in their suggestions for ending the conflict in Darfur. There were about 300 responses, and here's a sampling. Please add your comments at the bottom to identify which you agree with or think are awful.

keywords: BUSH, GEORGE W; MASSACHUSETTS; GUATEMALA; DEPORTATION; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS
headline: Bush Meets Anger Over Immigration Issue as He Promotes Free Trade in Guatemala
snippet: During his visit to the struggling Central American nation, President Bush was confronted with an angry, outside-in perspective on the immigration debate raging at home.
lead_paragraph: President Bush came to this struggling Central American nation on Tuesday bearing a message that free trade with the United States would improve conditions for even the poorest Latin Americans. But he was also confronted with an angry, outside-in perspective on the immigration debate raging at home, with even his otherwise friendly host, President Óscar Berger, using a ceremonial welcome to criticize the arrest of several hundred illegal workers, many of them Guatemalans, in Massachusetts last week.

keywords: GYURCSANY, FERENC; BUDAPEST (HUNGARY); HUNGARY; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Riot Erupts at Opposition Rally in Hungary
snippet: Police officers and rioters clashed after about 100,000 people rallied to demand that the Socialist prime minister resign.
lead_paragraph: Police officers and rioters clashed Thursday on the streets of Budapest after about 100,000 people rallied to demand that the Socialist prime minister resign. The rally, held on the national holiday that celebrates the uprising in 1848 against Hapsburg rule, was the biggest since a campaign to oust the prime minister, Ferenc Gyurcsany, began late last year, when he admitted that he had lied about the budget to win the 2006 election.

keywords: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; CHAUDHRY, IFTIKHAR MUHAMMAD; LAHORE (PAKISTAN); ISLAMABAD (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; RAWALPINDI (PAKISTAN); JUDGES; COURTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
headline: Swelling Crowds Across Pakistan Denounce Musharraf's Suspension of Chief Justice
snippet: Riot police officers and protesters clashed and the political opposition joined forces with lawyers who have been rallying for days.
lead_paragraph: Protests over the suspension of the country's top judge continued Friday in several cities, with riot police officers and protesters clashing for the first time here in the capital and the political opposition joining forces with lawyers who have been rallying for days. About 200 protesters, including a former president, were arrested in Islamabad, Rawalpindi and Lahore. The protests pose a serious political challenge for the current president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who suspended the judge, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, last week for reasons that have not been made public. Supporters say the move against the judge is politically motivated.

keywords: Pakistan; Musharraf, Pervez; Kidnapping; Freedom and Human Rights; Police Brutality and Misconduct
headline: The General and the Housewife
snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan is facing the most serious crisis of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan is facing the most serious crisis of his presidency.

lead_paragraph: This first novel follows a group of exiles in a Washington neighborhood.

keywords: EGYPT; CAIRO (EGYPT); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS; CONSTITUTIONS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
headline: As Egypt Votes on Laws, Cynicism Rules the Street
snippet: Issues of politics were overshadowed by more basic concerns, like lack of jobs, inadequate housing and the price of food.
lead_paragraph: There was no time on Sunday for politics in Qalaat el-Kabash, a poor neighborhood in a poor city, a neighborhood that burned to the ground five days ago. There were hundreds of people, homeless, sleeping with children amid ashes, in the open air, desperate only for their government to help with housing.

keywords: SARKOZY, NICOLAS; BAYROU, FRANCOIS; LE PEN, JEAN-MARIE; ROYAL, SEGOLENE; AUXERRE (FRANCE); FRANCE; PUBLIC OPINION; GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; ELECTION ISSUES; ELECTIONS
headline: Typical French Town Is Split Over Election
snippet: With the first round of the presidential election looming, almost half the voters in France’s “average town” are undecided.
lead_paragraph: With its timbered houses, twisted streets and Gothic cathedral, this picture-perfect town in Burgundy looks much as it did 500 years ago. The main employers are the hospital and city hall; the jobless rate is below the national average of 9 percent; the politics are moderate.

keywords: SARKOZY, NICOLAS; BAYROU, FRANCOIS; ROYAL, SEGOLENE; PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; ELECTION ISSUES; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: Street Violence by Paris Youths Intrudes Again Into French Politics
snippet: The fights were a reminder of the tensions still simmering 18 months after rioting swept immigrant neighborhoods across France.
lead_paragraph: France's top presidential candidates seized on a new campaign issue on Wednesday after the police fought gangs of youths for seven hours at a railroad station here. Stores were destroyed, the pall of tear gas filled the station, Gare du Nord, and 13 people were arrested. The episode, described as ''urban guerrilla warfare'' by the new interior minister, François Baroin, was a reminder of the tensions still simmering 18 months after rioting swept immigrant neighborhoods across France. It foreshadowed the task ahead for the candidate who is elected president in May.

keywords: SARKOZY, NICOLAS; LE PEN, JEAN-MARIE; ROYAL, SEGOLENE; FRANCE; FLAGS, EMBLEMS AND INSIGNIA; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; ELECTIONS; ANTHEMS, NATIONAL
headline: Identity, Staple of Right, Moves To Center of French Campaigns
snippet: France’s presidential campaign has been seized by a subject dear to the extreme right: how best to be French.
lead_paragraph: France's presidential campaign has been seized by a subject long monopolized by the extreme right: how best to be French. The conservative candidate, Nicolas Sarkozy, wants to create a ministry of ''immigration and national identity'' that would require newcomers to embrace the secular values of the republican state.

keywords: PUBLIC COWBOY NO 1: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF GENE AUTRY (BOOK); PUBLIC COWBOY NO. 1: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF GENE AUTRY (BOOK); AUTRY, GENE; GEORGE-WARREN, HOLLY; MOTION PICTURES; REVIEWS; COUNTRY MUSIC; RADIO; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
headline: Back in the Saddle: A Cowboy Tycoon
snippet: Holly George-Warren has written the first full-length biography of Gene Autry, the singing cowboy and shrewd businessman.
lead_paragraph: Public Cowboy No. 1 The Life and Times of Gene Autry By Holly George-Warren Illustrated. 406 pages. Oxford University Press. $28. The first man I fell in love with was Gene Autry. I was only 4, but I wasn't alone in my ardor. Autry, the singing cowboy, was a true showbiz phenomenon, the only American performer to have five different stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame -- one each for films, recordings, television, radio and live performance. In 1941 alone, he did eight recording sessions, seven movies and a weekly radio show.

keywords: KORESH, DAVID; PACE, CHARLES J; TEXAS; WACO (TEX); BRANCH, THE, THE LORD OF OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, FIREARMS AND EXPLOSIVES; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); RELIGIOUS CULTS; RELIGION AND CHURCHES
headline: Near Waco, a New Fight Over an Old Compound
snippet: A new religious community is rising from the ashes of the Branch Davidian compound, prompting a conflict with those who once lived there.
lead_paragraph: A new religious community is rising from the ashes of the Branch Davidian compound here, 14 years after nearly 80 people died in a fire that ended an armed standoff with the federal authorities. About a dozen believers gather in a chapel each weekend for services led by Charles J. Pace, the leader of The Branch, The Lord Our Righteousness. Mr. Pace said he planned to build a museum, a tabernacle, an amphitheater and a wellness center as part of his reorganized sect of the Branch Davidians.

keywords: CORREA, RAFAEL; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; ECUADOR; PUBLIC OPINION; POLITICAL ADVERTISING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONS; ELECTIONS; REFERENDUMS
headline: Ecuador, Ever Unstable, Prepares for New Leader's Plans
snippet: A referendum on Sunday could allow the constitution to be rewritten to weaken congressional power and enhance state control of the economy.
lead_paragraph: The past few weeks have been unkind to Ecuador's Congress. A court fired 57 of the legislators. Mobs beat some of the expelled lawmakers in the street. When Congress finally convened this week, someone lobbed a tear gas canister near its chamber, forcing lawmakers to flee. The future looks dimmer still for Congress, one of the most reviled institutions in chronically unstable Ecuador. If President Rafael Correa gets his way in a referendum on Sunday, his supporters will soon start rewriting the constitution to weaken congressional power and enhance state control of the economy.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Police Beat Back Protesters
snippet: The police used tear gas and flares to disperse a crowd of rock- and bottle-throwing demonstrators. It was the most violent unrest in recent months. About 3,000 people had gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakiev's office in Bishkek, the capital, for...
lead_paragraph: The police used tear gas and flares to disperse a crowd of rock- and bottle-throwing demonstrators. It was the most violent unrest in recent months. About 3,000 people had gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakiev's office in Bishkek, the capital, for a ninth day of protests, many of them throwing rocks and other objects. An additional 4,000 protesters gathered in surrounding streets. The police hurled rocks back at the crowd, and some beat residents of a tent camp set up by the protesters last week. As the crowd was dispersed, street lighting was switched off in the center of this city of nearly a million people and gangs of young men carrying sticks roamed the streets. There were several reports of looting. The interior minister, Bolotbek Nogoibayev, said that the police had detained 100 demonstrators and that any new protests or crowds would be dispersed.

keywords: BRINKERHOFF, DAVID C; FELTON, PRESTON L; GOMBASI, MATTHEW; MATTSON, RICHARD G; TRIM, TRAVIS D; MARGARETVILLE (NY); ATTACKS ON POLICE; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; TEAR GAS
headline: TROOPER IS SLAIN AND 2ND IS HURT IN CATSKILL TOWN
section: Front Page; New York and Region
snippet: The Catskill farmhouse where the suspect was believed to be hiding erupted in flames as the police were besieging it.
lead_paragraph: One New York State trooper was killed and another was wounded near this tiny Catskill Mountains town on Wednesday morning as they tracked down a suspect who the authorities said had shot and wounded another trooper the day before. The suspect, Travis D. Trim, 23, is now thought to be dead, the authorities say, after the farmhouse where he was hiding caught fire later on Wednesday as the police were besieging it.

keywords: News
headline: Trooper's Death Was 'Friendly Fire'
snippet: Preston L. Felton, the acting New York State Police Superintendent, said during a news conference this afternoon that Trooper David C. Brinkerhoff was apparently killed by friendly fire during a gunfight on Wednesday between state troopers and a...
lead_paragraph: Preston L. Felton, the acting New York State Police Superintendent, said during a news conference this afternoon that Trooper David C. Brinkerhoff was apparently killed by friendly fire during a gunfight on Wednesday between state troopers and a suspect holed up in an unoccupied farmhouse.

keywords: News
headline: A Statue's Place Revives Post-Soviet Tensions
snippet: The aftermath of six-foot statue's removal in Estonia's capital.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a week of mourning for Boris Yeltsin, the man who tried to sweep away remnants of the Soviet Union, including its anthem, the former Soviet republic of Estonia took another step in that direction today.

headline: The News in Quotes: Hardball, Gadflies and Bus Bulbs
snippet: Spitzer and the Raises: "The governor's agenda is to hold up legislative raises in order to use that as a chip for something else." – Senator John A. DeFrancisco, the Republican judiciary committee chairman, on a judicial reform bill that would...
lead_paragraph: Spitzer and the Raises: "The governor's agenda is to hold up legislative raises in order to use that as a chip for something else." -- Senator John A. DeFrancisco, the Republican judiciary committee chairman, on a judicial reform bill that would give raises to state judges.

keywords: MOLINARI, KEVIN; BRINKERHOFF, DAVID C; GOMBASI, MATTHEW; TRIM, TRAVIS D; CATSKILLS (NYS AREA); MARGARETVILLE (NY); ATTACKS ON POLICE; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS; TEAR GAS
headline: After Fatal Clash, Questions About Police Tactics and a Suspect's Mental State
snippet: It was dusk Wednesday when the roaring fire ended an extraordinary day of tragedy and the massing of police manpower, armor and technology in a quiet corner of the Catskill Mountains.
lead_paragraph: It was dusk Wednesday when the roaring fire ended an extraordinary day of tragedy and the massing of police manpower, armor and technology in a quiet corner of the Catskill Mountains. Cameras stuck on poles, cameras embedded in thrown balls and even a camera mounted on a stair-climbing robot were used to track a suspect in the killing of a state trooper who may have already been shot dead.

keywords: CHAMBERLAIN, ROBERT A; BRINKERHOFF, DAVID C; GOMBASI, MATTHEW; MATTSON, RICHARD G; TRIM, TRAVIS D; NEW YORK STATE; CATSKILLS (NYS AREA); MARGARETVILLE (NY); ATTACKS ON POLICE; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; CRIME AND CRIMINALS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
headline: A Family's Beloved Home, Now a Page in a Crime Story
snippet: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., April 26  Robert A. Chamberlain stood in a cold drizzle some 200 yards from his family’s weekend house in the shadow of the Catskill Mountains as members of an elite state police unit were preparing to storm it.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Chamberlain stood in a cold drizzle some 200 yards from his family's weekend house in the shadow of the Catskill Mountains as members of an elite state police unit were preparing to storm it. They were looking Wednesday afternoon for Travis D. Trim, a fugitive and petty criminal who they believed had shot three state troopers over the previous 24 hours, killing one, and who they suspected was holed up inside. But moments before the siege was to begin, a final round of tear gas was hurled into the cream-colored farmhouse, which suddenly caught fire.

keywords: BRINKERHOFF, DAVID C; GOMBOSI, MATTHEW; TRIM, TRAVIS D; NEW YORK STATE; MARGARETVILLE (NY); ATTACKS ON POLICE; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
headline: Comrade's Shot Killed Trooper In the Catskills
section: Front Page; New York and Region
snippet: The state police had believed that David C. Brinkerhoff was killed by a suspect he and other officers had cornered.
lead_paragraph: The bullet that killed a New York state trooper during a shootout Wednesday morning in a farmhouse in the Catskill Mountains came from the gun of a fellow officer, not the suspect they had cornered, the state police said yesterday. The police said that the suspect, who was hiding in the house after shooting another trooper the day before, fired one bullet at the slain trooper, David C. Brinkerhoff, but that it hit his body armor. That bullet knocked Trooper Brinkerhoff onto one knee. He was then struck once in the back of the head, fatally, during the fusillade of bullets that followed from three other troopers.

keywords: ESTONIA; RUSSIA; MOSCOW (RUSSIA); TALLINN (ESTONIA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; MONUMENTS AND MEMORIALS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; WORLD WAR II (1939-45)
headline: After Violent Night, Estonia Removes a Soviet-Era Memorial
snippet: The removal of the monument prompted a renewed diplomatic fury in neighboring Russia.
lead_paragraph: Estonia's government removed a Soviet-era war memorial early on Friday morning after a night of protest and violence that killed one person, injured dozens and left a swath of shattered windows and overturned cars in the center of the capital, Tallinn, officials there said. The removal of the monument, which includes a six-and-a-half-foot sculpture known as the Bronze Soldier, prompted a renewed diplomatic fury in neighboring Russia, where officials have repeatedly declared that tampering with the monument amounted to blasphemy and even the glorification of Nazism.

keywords: SARKOZY, NICOLAS; ROYAL, SEGOLENE; FRANCE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; WOMEN; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: SARKOZY, ELECTED IN FRANCE, VOWS BREAK WITH PAST
snippet: Nicolas Sarkozy earned a decisive victory on Sunday over Ségolène Royal, keeping the right in power for another five years. Turnout was 84 percent of France’s registered voters.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Sarkozy, the passionate, pugnacious son of a Hungarian immigrant, was elected president of France on Sunday, promising a break with the past, a new style of leadership, and a renewal of relations with the United States and the rest of Europe. Mr. Sarkozy's triumph over Ségolène Royal, the Socialist candidate, was a huge blow to her party and dashed her dream of becoming the country's first female president. But Ms. Royal tried to rally her supporters, telling them French politics had forever changed with her candidacy.

keywords: SARKOZY, NICOLAS; FRANCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
headline: Hundreds Are Arrested in Post-Election Riots Across France
snippet: Many people fear more violence to come if Nicolas Sarkozy makes good on campaign promises to push through divisive legislation in his first 100 days in office.
lead_paragraph: Violent protests against the election of Nicolas Sarkozy as president of France ended early Monday after hundreds of people were arrested, hundreds of cars gutted, and hundreds of windows smashed in several cities across France. Many people fear that the violence is just a taste of what is to come if Mr. Sarkozy makes good on his campaign promises to push through divisive legislation during his first 100 days in office.

keywords: KIRCHNER, NESTOR; ARGENTINA; BUENOS AIRES (ARGENTINA); PRIVATIZATION; RAILROADS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; DELAYS (TRANSPORTATION); COMMUTING; STATIONS AND TERMINALS (PASSENGER)
headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Rail Commuters Riot Over Delays
snippet: President Néstor Kirchner threatened to crack down on private rail operators for failing to make upgrades after commuters frustrated by constant delays in train service to Buenos Aires's poor suburbs set fire to parts of the city's Constitución...
lead_paragraph: President Néstor Kirchner threatened to crack down on private rail operators for failing to make upgrades after commuters frustrated by constant delays in train service to Buenos Aires's poor suburbs set fire to parts of the city's Constitución station on Tuesday, looted nearby shops and clashed with the police, who responded with rubber bullets and tear gas. The passengers' anger came to a head in the evening rush hour when a train broke down on a track just outside the station, blocking other trains from leaving the station, which serves some 300,000 commuters daily. Buenos Aires area commuter rail lines were privatized in the 1990s, and passengers have complained for years about the failure of the new operators to provide timely service on often crowded routes.

keywords: INDIA; HYDERABAD (INDIA); HINDUISM; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; MECCA MASJID MOSQUE (HYDERABAD, INDIA); ISLAM; MOSQUES; TERRORISM
headline: Bombing and Clashes Kill 13 at India Mosque
snippet: The bombing and subsequent clashes raised fears of Hindu-Muslim violence in Hyderabad, which has long been plagued by communal tensions.
lead_paragraph: A bomb ripped through a historic mosque in this southern Indian city on Friday, killing 11 people. Two more died in clashes that followed between Muslim worshipers and security forces, the police said. Minutes after the blast at the Mecca Masjid, which was built in the 17th century, worshipers who were angered by what they said had been a lack of police protection began chanting ''God is great!'' and hurling stones at the police.

keywords: INDIA; HYDERABAD (INDIA); ATTACKS ON POLICE; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; ISLAM; MOSQUES
headline: Mob Stones India Police After Rites For Muslims Killed in Mosque Blast
snippet: At least two policemen were injured on Saturday when a mob pelted them with stones after the burial of victims of an explosion at a mosque.
lead_paragraph: At least two policemen were injured here on Saturday when a mob pelted them with stones after the burial of victims of an explosion at a mosque and of violent clashes that ensued. Eleven people died in the explosion during Friday Prayers at the sprawling 17th-century Mecca Masjid.

keywords: WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART; REVIEWS; MUSEUMS; ART
headline: Through Rose-Colored Granny Glasses
snippet: The Whitney Museum’s show remembers a lot, but forgets much more, about what was happening in 1967.
lead_paragraph: Tear gas, pot and patchouli were the scents of the 1960s. You can almost detect the last two, spicy and pungent, wafting through ''Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art. But tear gas, with its weird-sweet burn, is missing in a show that remembers a lot, but forgets much more, about what was happening 40 years ago, when America was losing its mind to save, some would say, its soul.

keywords: DEAN, JAMES; MARYLAND; HOLLYWOOD (MD); AFGHANISTAN; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POST-TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER; POLICE; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
headline: Asked to Serve Again, a Soldier Goes Down Fighting
snippet: Sgt. James Dean was shot at his childhood home by a sniper representing his government.
lead_paragraph: The sniper fired. It was a clean shot, if there is such a thing. And down for good fell another American soldier. His name was Sergeant James Dean, but everyone called him Jamie. He was the farm boy who fished, hunted and tossed a horseshoe like nobody else. He was the guy at the end of Toots Bar, nursing a Bud and talking Nascar. He was the driver of that blue Silverado at the red light, his hands on the wheel, his mind on combat horrors that made him moody, angry, withdrawn.

keywords: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); RADIO CARACAS TELEVISION; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; CENSORSHIP; TELEVISION; FREEDOM OF THE PRESS; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
headline: Venezuela Police Repel Protests Over TV Network's Closing
snippet: Thousands took to the streets to support or protest against President Hugo Chávez’s decision to not renew the broadcasting license of Venezuela’s oldest television network.
lead_paragraph: With little more than an hour to go late Sunday until this country's oldest television network was to be taken off the air after 53 years of broadcasting, the police dispersed thousands of protesters by firing tear gas into demonstrations against the measure. The police said that shots were fired in their direction and that protesters hurling rocks had injured 11 officers. Local television showed images of policemen with guns drawn patrolling a highway that had been closed near one demonstration. Protesters in other areas of the city burned tires, apparently eliciting the police reaction.

keywords: ZAGARELLA, PHILIP; WHITE, JOANNA; WEST ISLIP (NY); LONG ISLAND (NY); HOSTAGES; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; SEX CRIMES; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
headline: In Long Island Standoff, Ex-Convict Kills a Hostage and Then Himself
snippet: A drunken man killed a 59-year-old woman and sexually assaulted a child before killing himself in West Islip, according to police.
lead_paragraph: A drunken ex-convict killed a 59-year-old acquaintance by cutting her throat and sexually assaulted one of her grandchildren during a 14-hour standoff on Long Island that ended when he fatally shot himself yesterday afternoon, the police said. Residents in the town of West Islip woke up to the last day of a holiday weekend with plans for backyard barbecues and beach excursions and found a frenzied ordeal in progress on Kime Avenue.

headline: German Police and Protesters Battle Near Site of G-8 Meeting
snippet: German police clashed with hundreds of protesters in the port of Rostock on Saturday following a much larger peaceful demonstration against the Group of 8 summit meeting next week in a nearby Baltic resort.
lead_paragraph: German police clashed with hundreds of protesters in the port of Rostock on Saturday following a much larger peaceful demonstration against the Group of 8 summit meeting next week in a nearby Baltic resort. About 2,000 protesters, identified by the police as a hard core of violent activists, threw bottles, sticks and stones at riot police officers, on the fringes of a rally in the town's harbor area.

keywords: PUTIN, VLADIMIR V; RUSSIA; MOSCOW (RUSSIA); TERM LIMITS (POLITICAL OFFICE); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2008; CONSTITUTIONS
headline: Putin Supports Longer Term For Successor To Presidency
snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out remaining in office after the expiration of his second term.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out the possibility that he would remain in office after the expiration of his second term next year, according to remarks published Monday. The remarks, made in an interview with a group of invited journalists from Group of 8 countries at his residence outside Moscow on Friday, further clouded the situation around Mr. Putin's post-presidential plans and his possible successor. The Kremlin published the text of the interview at kremlin.ru/eng/.

keywords: BONO; BUSH, GEORGE W; MERKEL, ANGELA; GELDOF, BOB; GERMANY; HEILIGENDAMM (GER); GROUP OF EIGHT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CARBON DIOXIDE; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; WEATHER; ENVIRONMENT; GLOBAL WARMING; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
headline: As Group of 8 Starts Meeting, Bush Rebuffs Germany on Cutting Greenhouse Emissions
snippet: The White House said it would hold firm against concrete long-term targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: As leaders of wealthy nations converged Wednesday on a Baltic Sea resort for their annual meeting, the White House effectively derailed a climate change initiative backed by one of President Bush's strongest European allies, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany. The White House said it would hold firm against concrete long-term targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, a major priority for Mrs. Merkel, the host of the Group of 8 meeting.

keywords: CLARK, JIM; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CIVIL RIGHTS; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
headline: Jim Clark, Sheriff Who Enforced Segregation, Dies at 84
snippet: Jim Clark was the former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed to the success of the voting rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Jim Clark, the former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed, however inadvertently, to the success of the voting rights movement, died Monday in Elba, Ala. He was 84 and had been living in a nursing home there. The death was confirmed by the Hayes Funeral Home in Elba.

headline: Thousands of Protesters Foil Some German Security Measures and Clash With the Police
snippet: Several thousand protesters clashed with riot police officers on the first day of the Group of 8 meeting in northern Germany.
lead_paragraph: They lurked in the woods, 50 strong, wearing black hoods and bandannas, and wielding tree limbs. At a signal, they sprang forward and threw their debris across one of the bigger roads here, creating a barricade that brought traffic to a halt. That little insurgency, and dozens like it, kept tensions high on the first day of the Group of 8 meeting in northern Germany on Wednesday. Several thousand protesters clashed with riot police officers, who used tear gas and water cannons to disperse demonstrators blocking roads and railways leading to the site of the meeting.

headline: Dissident Challenges U.N. Role on Kosovo
snippet: The treatment of a former dissident has increased nervousness among Kosovo politicians and international officials as the status of the province remains up in the air.
lead_paragraph: Like countless ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Albin Kurti spent the weekend glued to his television set, watching President Bush's visit to Albania. He was eager to see what Mr. Bush would say from just across the border about Kosovo's efforts to gain its independence from Serbia. Mr. Bush did say that he supported independence for Kosovo as soon as possible, but Mr. Kurti, who opposes the United Nations' role in determining the status of Kosovo, was unimpressed.

headline: Might Drink Your Blood, but Otherwise Not Bad Guys
snippet: The mystery of the Mungiki, a secret society that is part Sicilian Mafia, part Chicago street gang, is sweeping across Kenya and taking a lot of lives with it.
lead_paragraph: These days Charity Bokindo, the district commissioner of Nairobi North, is taking no chances. Wherever she goes, she carries not one but two pistols, and she always travels with armed guards.

headline: Rioting In Buenos Aires
snippet: A 41-year-old man was killed and 14 people were injured as rival fans swinging metal pipes and throwing rocks clashed yesterday after a match between Argentine clubs in Buenos Aires.At least 78 arrests were reported in the fighting, which spilled...
lead_paragraph: A 41-year-old man was killed and 14 people were injured as rival fans swinging metal pipes and throwing rocks clashed yesterday after a match between Argentine clubs in Buenos Aires.At least 78 arrests were reported in the fighting, which spilled onto a busy rush-hour freeway after Tigre defeated Nueva Chicago, 2-1, which was relegated from Argentina's first division.The police, who appeared initially overwhelmed by the fighting, were backed up by reinforcements firing tear gas and rubber bullets as rock-throwing fans scattered from the stadium in the Mataderos section of the capital.

keywords: PAKISTAN; WEATHER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FLOODS
headline: Pakistan: Villagers Hit By Floods Riot After Little or No Help Arrives
snippet: Hungry victims of floods in southwestern Pakistan rioted, protesting slow, meager aid reaching their marooned villages. The police fired tear gas and shots into the air but failed to disperse a crowd of several thousand villagers in Turbat who had...
lead_paragraph: Hungry victims of floods in southwestern Pakistan rioted, protesting slow, meager aid reaching their marooned villages. The police fired tear gas and shots into the air but failed to disperse a crowd of several thousand villagers in Turbat who had broken into and ransacked the mayor's office. The widespread flooding struck after a cyclone dumped torrential rains on the area on Tuesday. Khubah Bakhsh, the relief commissioner for Baluchistan, estimated that 200,000 houses had been destroyed or damaged. Protesters said they had waded through chest-deep water from outlying areas to voice their anger about the dearth of relief aid. Many said the only aid they had received was packets of biscuits and bottles of water. Military helicopters continued to drop relief supplies, but many of the more than 800,000 people affected by the flooding, many of them homeless, appeared to have received little or nothing. In Turbat City and surrounding villages, the first relief supplies began arriving only on Thursday. From a helicopter, a reporter saw just the tops of palm trees protruding from vast sheets of water in some areas. People, cows and goats were stranded on rooftops without water or food, in 109-degree heat.

keywords: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; ISLAMABAD (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; PRIVATE AND SECTARIAN SCHOOLS; KIDNAPPING; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; MOSQUES; CHURCH-STATE RELATIONS; LAL MASJID (ISLAMABAD, PAKISTAN); TEAR GAS
headline: Pakistan's Battles Against Islamic Militants Reach the Capital
snippet: A months-long standoff, between Pakistani authorities and militant Islamic students, erupted in fierce clashes that left at least nine people dead and scores wounded.
lead_paragraph: A months-long standoff between the Pakistani government and Islamic militants holed up in a mosque in the heart of the capital erupted in violence on Tuesday. The fierce clashes between security forces and students left at least nine people dead and scores wounded. The fighting exposed the normally placid capital to the wider divisions between moderates and militants in Pakistan, shattering the notion that the seat of government was immune from extremism.

keywords: GHAZI, ABDUR RASHID; GHAZI, MAULANA ABDUL AZIZ; ISLAMABAD (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; ISLAM; MOSQUES
headline: Hints of Surrender at Rebellious Mosque in Pakistan's Capital
snippet: The death toll in the government’s three-day siege of a radical mosque in the center of Islamabad rose to 19, as reports emerged that the rebellion’s leader was offering to surrender.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in the government's three-day siege of a radical mosque in the center of Islamabad has risen to 19, the interior minister said Thursday. Reports also emerged Thursday evening that the hold-out cleric leading the rebellion was offering to surrender. The government kept up its pressure on the Lal Masjid, or Red Mosque, demanding the unconditional surrender of the estimated 400 to 500 people still inside, as many as half of them female students and teachers. Army and police commandos have surrounded the complex and barred access since heavy clashes with armed followers on Tuesday.

headline: A Part Made for Her, About Life With a Maid
snippet: Argentina’s movie queen Norma Aleandro took a chance on a novice director with a good script to make “Live-In Maid.”
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES AS the grande dame of Latin American actresses, Norma Aleandro is accustomed to having choice roles gravitate in her direction. Whether in the theater or on the screen, her participation is considered a near-guarantee of both artistic quality and box office success.

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | ASIA | Bangladesh Acts Against Leaders Of Main Parties
snippet: Bangladesh on Monday moved against the leaders of its two main political parties, both former prime ministers, as it intensified efforts to clean up the nation's corrupt politics.     Sheik Hasina Wazed, who led the government from  1996 to 2001, was...
lead_paragraph: Bangladesh on Monday moved against the leaders of its two main political parties, both former prime ministers, as it intensified efforts to clean up the nation's corrupt politics. Sheik Hasina Wazed, who led the government from 1996 to 2001, was arrested by hundreds of police officers and members of the special forces in a dawn raid on her home and jailed on charges of extortion, which she has repeatedly denied.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
snippet: Selective listings from art critics of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: ART 'GLENN LIGON: UNAUTHORIZED' Famous for conceptual work that relishes and parodies racial stereotypes and cultural insensitivity, the gay African-American artist Glenn Ligon, 47, has not had a solo show in New York for four years. He returns, to the Bill Hodges Gallery, with a blistering assembly of works in various mediums from the last couple of decades, among them a pair of closely observed black-and-white screen prints on canvas of the back of his shaved head, above. They resemble studies in phrenology, a pseudoscience sometimes used to justify racism. There is also a nice selection of black-and-white text paintings, including ''Untitled (Crowd/The Fire Next Time)'' (2000), a photographic image of an African-American crowd at a demonstration on the Mall in Washington in 1995 overlaid with a silkscreen in glistening coal dust of an excerpt from ''The Fire Next Time'' by James Baldwin. The text reads: ''Something in me wondered, 'What will happen to all the beauty?,' '' in this context suggesting a gentle satire of protest rallies and the civil rights cause. Mr. Ligon's appetite for traversing racial stereotypes finds vivid expression in his narratives, etchings on handmade paper purporting to be the title page of testimonials on his intrepid life and adventures among white people in the art world. They make you laugh, but like all good socially or politically engaged art, the pieces also have the underappreciated virtue of momentarily letting the viewer see the world through someone else's eyes. (Through Aug. 25, Bill Hodges Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, Manhattan, 212-333-2640, billhodgesgallery.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

keywords: ISLAMABAD (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; MOSQUES; TERRORISM
headline: Suicide Attack and Protests Over Red Mosque Reopening
snippet: A suicide bomber killed at least 13 people as protesters clashed with the police when the government tried to reopen the Red Mosque in Islamabad, Pakistan, for prayers.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber killed at least 13 people here in the capital on Friday as hundreds of angry protesters clashed with the police when the government tried to reopen for prayers a militant mosque that was the scene of a violent siege this month. The suicide attack took place in a crowded marketplace as protesters, many of them former students of the Red Mosque's religious schools, held up blood-stained rubble and shawls shredded with bullet holes from the eight-day siege. They demanded that Maulana Abdul Aziz, one of the clerics who led the standoff and was arrested trying to flee in a burqa, be brought back to lead Friday Prayer.

keywords: CALDERON, FELIPE; BUSH, GEORGE W; HARPER, STEPHEN; CANADA; MEXICO; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS
headline: Bush's Talks With Neighbors Are Overshadowed by Storm
snippet: Hurricane Dean’s expected landfall on the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico threw into doubt three-way talks that were scheduled for Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: President Bush met in a wooded resort east of here on Monday with his counterparts to the north and the south -- Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada and President Felipe Calderón of Mexico -- to discuss the drafting of emergency border provisions, the stalled international trade talks, and immigration. But Hurricane Dean's expected landfall on the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico threw into doubt three-way talks that were scheduled for Tuesday. Mr. Calderón said Monday that he would return home early Tuesday to be on hand to deal with any fallout from the storm, and organizers of the meeting were scrambling to accommodate him.

keywords: BANGLADESH; DHAKA UNIVERSITY; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Bangladesh: Dozens Hurt In University Rioting
snippet: Students at Dhaka University, fed up with having the army on campus, burned a military van and damaged at least 50 vehicles, witnesses said. At least 150 students were hurt after the police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the...
lead_paragraph: Students at Dhaka University, fed up with having the army on campus, burned a military van and damaged at least 50 vehicles, witnesses said. At least 150 students were hurt after the police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the stone-throwing and stick-wielding students. More than 100 students were wounded in similar clashes on Monday. As reports of the Dhaka University violence spread, unrest spread to at least four other universities. Late yesterday, the army-backed interim government said it had ordered all its troops to withdraw from the Dhaka campus. Protests and street assemblies have been banned since the interim government took power on Jan. 12, after months of political violence around the country. Troops have been camping in the university gymnasium since then. The campus unrest was the first major defiance of the government restrictions.

keywords: NAVARRO, ALEJANDRO; CHILE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
headline: Chile: Clashes In Workers' Protest
snippet: The police used tear gas, water cannons and clubs against demonstrators staging nationwide protests over government social and economic policies. The authorities said 372 people had been detained in the daylong protests, which spread in the capital,...
lead_paragraph: The police used tear gas, water cannons and clubs against demonstrators staging nationwide protests over government social and economic policies. The authorities said 372 people had been detained in the daylong protests, which spread in the capital, Santiago, from downtown to several working-class districts. The Santiago regional governor, Adriana Delpiano, said 50 demonstrators and 18 police officers were injured. Among the injured was Senator Alejandro Navarro, of President Michelle Bachelet's Socialist Party, who bled from the back of the head after being clubbed by a police officer. Mr. Navarro was supporting the protest called by the country's largest union federation to oppose free-market economics and the government's social policies. Protest organizers called for higher pensions and better education, health and housing services.

headline: Art Listings
snippet: ART.
lead_paragraph: ART '25 YEARS LATER: WELCOME TO ART IN GENERAL' To celebrate its 25th anniversary, the scruffy, downtown, nonprofit art space Art in General is presenting a dozen newly commissioned installations by artists who have participated in its recent programs at the well-heeled Midtown gallery of UBS, one of the world's leading financial firms. It is an unorthodox partnership, though there is something immensely appealing about the idea of experimental art invading this sterile corporate environment. A handful of the artworks even poke fun at corporate culture and greed, including Ana Prvacki's mock money-laundering service (complete with a promotional video); the Dutch collective Bik Van der Pol's installation inspired by an out-of-print guidebook, ''How to Disappear Completely and Never Be Found''; and Lee Walton's hiring of an actor to hang around the gallery's 51st Street entrance for an hour each day, pretending to be an office worker at lunch. Bleachers are provided nearby for viewers in the know.

keywords: CLINTON, HILLARY RODHAM; KING, MARTIN LUTHER JR; DEMOCRATIC PARTY; REPUBLICAN PARTY; WELLESLEY COLLEGE; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; VIETNAM WAR; SURVEYS AND SERIES; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2008; BLACKS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
headline: In Turmoil of '68, Clinton Found a New Voice
snippet: As the nation boiled over Vietnam and civil rights, Hillary Rodham was completing a sweeping political shift.
lead_paragraph: In September 1968, Hillary Diane Rodham, role model and student government president, was addressing Wellesley College freshmen girls -- back when they were still called ''girls'' -- about methods of protest. It was a hot topic in that overheated year of what she termed ''confrontation politics from Chicago to Czechoslovakia.'' ''Dynamism is a function of change,'' Ms. Rodham said in her speech. ''On some campuses, change is effected through nonviolent or even violent means. Although we too have had our demonstrations, change here is usually a product of discussion in the decision-making process.''

keywords: WEST BANK; BILIN (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
headline: Israel's Top Court Orders Separation Barrier Rerouted
snippet: The section of Israel’s separation barrier in dispute had cut a West Bank village off from much of its farmland.
lead_paragraph: In its latest decision overruling Israel's influential security establishment, the High Court of Justice here on Tuesday ordered the government to reroute a section of its separation barrier that had split a West Bank village from much of its farmland. Although this is not the first time that Israel's High Court has ruled in the Palestinians' favor in a case about the barrier, this case has taken on a special significance as a symbol of popular resistance to construction of the barrier. In the past two and a half years, residents of the village, Bilin, and a band of Israeli far-leftists and foreign supporters have held weekly demonstrations in the fields and groves along the barrier route, often ending in confrontations with Israeli forces.

keywords: STANEK, RICHARD; KREISS, KEVIN; NEW JERSEY; BRICK TOWNSHIP (NJ); MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS
headline: Brick: Man Surrenders After Standoff
snippet: A man accused of shooting his mother’s companion several times surrendered early yesterday after officers fired tear gas into the house where he had barricaded himself for eight hours, the police said. The man, Richard Stanek, 28, was arrested...
lead_paragraph: A man accused of shooting his mother's companion several times surrendered early yesterday after officers fired tear gas into the house where he had barricaded himself for eight hours, the police said. The man, Richard Stanek, 28, was arrested about 1:30 a.m., said Sgt. Vincent Coburn of the Brick Township Police Department. His mother's companion, Kevin Kreiss, 54, was shot several times at his house and was rescued by the police about 4:35 p.m. Monday, the police said. He was in critical condition yesterday at Jersey Shore University Medical Center in Neptune.

headline: Pakistan Edgy As Ex-Premier Is Exiled Again
snippet: Pakistan faced the prospect of fresh clashes after a former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, was deported as he tried to return from exile on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, faced the prospect of fresh clashes with a newly independent Supreme Court after deporting a former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, as he tried to return from exile on Monday. Pakistan's military government moved harshly against Mr. Sharif, deporting him within four hours of his arrival and arresting almost the entire leadership of his party as they tried to travel to the airport to greet him.

headline: Comstock: Another Inmate Brawl
snippet: Guards at the Great Meadow Correctional Facility used tear gas to break up a fight involving nearly two dozen inmates on Monday night, state corrections officials said yesterday. Officials said that it was the second time in a week that guards had to...
lead_paragraph: Guards at the Great Meadow Correctional Facility used tear gas to break up a fight involving nearly two dozen inmates on Monday night, state corrections officials said yesterday. Officials said that it was the second time in a week that guards had to use gas to stop a brawl at Great Meadow, a maximum-security state prison about 70 miles north of Albany. No guards were hurt in the melee, which took place about 8 p.m. in a recreation yard, said Scott Bishop, a spokesman for the New York State Correctional Officers and Police Benevolent Association, a union that represents prison guards. The brawl appeared to be part of a gang dispute and was similar to a fight on Sept. 3, he said.
